investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted a tele-visit follow-up complaint inspection at REFUGE III and spoke with Khea Gumbs Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations, LPA Rollins conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, social workers and conducted client file review. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories on if there was a lack of supervision resulting in clients engaging in inappropriate activities. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories on if facility staff are not adequately trained. Based on interviews and documentation there was not enough evidence to prove that there was a lack of supervision resulting in minors engaging in inappropriate activities and facility staff are not adequately trained. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that there was a lack of supervision resulting in clients engaging in inappropriate activities and facility staff are not adequately trained, therefore the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted with Adminstrator and report was e-mail to Administrator for signature UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On Monday February 28, 2022 at 11: AM Regional Manager, Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Managers (LPM) Carolyn Flynn, Helga Wong and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza conducted a Office meeting virtually via Microsoft Teams due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Community Care Licensing (CCL) met with Executive Director Jason Henderson, Consultant Jeff Rackmil, DHCS Representatives, Sandi Snelgrove and DSS Representative, David Gutierrez. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss the Mental Health Status Approval (MHSA) Update, and the required items for permanent licensure for R.E.F.U.G.E. The facility has not submitted their MHPA yet to DHCS and the facilities 24 month expires on April 10, 2022. DHCS provided the facility all required documents for submission. During this meeting the following options were discussed; withdrawal of STRTP application by the program, this would prevent CCL (Community Care Licensing) from taking legal action against the program. The facility was informed that if the program is not able to obtain their Mental Health approval by the date of April 10, 2022 the department will have to take legal action. The facility was also informed that they could withdraw their STRTP application and submit a plan of closure. At this time, the facility will be working on submission and agrees to have a follow-up meeting on 3/9/22 at AM. The meeting was concluded, and a copy of this report will be sent to Executive Director, Jason Henderson.

On Wednesday March 09, 2022 at 11: AM Regional Manager, Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Managers (LPM's) Carolyn Flynn, Helga Wong and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza conducted a follow-up office meeting virtually via Microsoft Teams due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Community Care Licensing (CCL) met with Executive Director Jason Henderson, Consultant Jeff Rackmil, Clinicial Director, Jacqueline Smith, California Alliance, Chris Stoner-Mertz, DHCS Representatives, Pat Coyle, Kelsie Martinez, and DSS Representative, David Gutierrez. The purpose of this meeting was to follow-up on 2/28/22 office meeting regarding the Mental Health Status Approval (MHSA) Update. At this time, the facility submitted there application to DHCS on 3/6/22, and the application is currently under review. Per DHCS current review, the facility did not submit all required documents. Multiple items will be needed and revisions will be required. DHCS will complete their full review by next week 3/15/22, and will send out a notice. Also, will be coordinate a meeting with the provider to discuss all necessary changes. The meeting was concluded and CCL will follow-up with the provider towards the end of the month regarding the MHPA review. In addition, CCL reminded the provider withdrawal of STRTP application by the program, will prevent CCL from taking legal action against the program. The facilities 24 month expires on 4/10/22. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to Executive Director, Jason Henderson for signature.

An unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Carolyn on 2/23/22 at 11:00AM. During the inspection, LPA Ng and LPM Flynn met with Geneva Morgan, Program Trainer and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 3 of child's records on site at the facility at 11: PM. LPA reviewed 2 of staff personnel files on site at the facility at 1: PM. LPA reviewed 3 of child's psychotropic medications and medication records at 12: PM. LPA interviewed 2 of staff on site at 1: PM. LPA interviewed 3 of children currently taking psychotropic medication at 2: PM. LPA conducted exit interview with Geneva Morgan, Program Trainer at 3: PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Geneva Morgan, Program Trainer upon completion. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, and Health & Safety Codes during the inspection. LPA conducted exit interview with Geneva Morgan, Program Trainer at 3: PM.

On May 2, 2022 at 2: PM, LPAs Belfield and Schlembach conducted an unannounced inspection at R.E.F.U.G.E. III. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct a file review on staff, clients, and medication records. During this inspection, LPAs were assisted by Administrator Khea Gumbs. LPAs Belfield and Schlembach conducted file reviews for 6 staff members and 3 clients. Some documents were scanned from these files. The medication log was also reviewed and scanned as well. Due to time restraints, this inspection was concluded prior to the file review being completed. There were no violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 or Interim Licensing Standards cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to Administrator Khea Gumbs.

Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA) Shikya Belfield and Lisa Schlembach made an unannounced inspection to the above facility on 4/22/2022 at 12: PM. The purpose for this inspection is to conduct a case management. LPA's Belfield and Schlembach met with Direct care staff Carmen Lee who assisted with the visit. A walk through of the facility was conducted with these LPA's and staff Lee. During the walk through, the facility was observed to be clean and in good repair. During this walk through, LPA Belfield took photographs of the bedrooms, and the common areas of the facility. LPA's observed bedroom 3 that has a bathroom connected to it. LPA asked staff Lee which bathroom does staff use. Staff Lee informed these LPA's that they staff uses the bathroom in bedroom 3. Facility cited for violation of section 87087(b)(5) Buildings and Grounds. Based on a review of the in the Licensing Information System, facility roster and facility staff schedule, it was discovered that 8 staff on the schedule and staff roster for the facility are not associated to the facility and 3 staff do not have criminal record clearance to work. Administrator Khea Gumbs called LPA's Schlembach's phone at 12: PM. LPA's discussed with administrator Gumbs and staff Lee and asked them if the program has a current waiver on file with the department regarding criminal record clearances. Both administrator and staff Lee stated they did not know and were not sure. Facility is being cited for violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4: 80019(e)(1): Criminal Record Clearance. (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (1) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department. During this inspection, LPA's Belfield and Schlembach experienced technical issues with their equipment. Facility staff Lee and administrator were informed that the documents and information regarding this inspection would be sent via email for their review and signature. Advisory Issued for association of 8 staff ( see LIC 811 dated 4.22.2022) and facility cited for violation of section 80019(e)(1) as S6, S7, and S8 have no criminal record clearance to work. Immediate civil penalties were assessed. Advisories Issued. Facility cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards, Section 80019(e)(1): Criminal Record and Section 87087(b)(5) Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted with staff Lee and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to staff Lee and administrator Gumbs via email.

Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA) Shikya Belfield and Lisa Schlembach made an unannounced inspection to the above facility on 5/31/2022 at 5: PM. The purpose for this inspection is to conduct a case management. LPA's Belfield and Schlembach met with Direct care Nai Saelee who assisted with the visit. Based on confidential interviews and a review of the licensing information system, it was confirmed that S1 ( see lic 811 dated 5/31/22) has continued to work in the facility with clients and has not been criminally record cleared to work in the facility with clients. Facility is being cited for violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4, Section 80019(e)(1): Criminal Record Clearance. (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (1) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department. Based on a confidential interview conducted, it was confirmed that the facility failed to meet the requirement of having a Facility manager on site. Facility is being cited for violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4, Section 87065(f) Personnel Requirements. The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at all times when one or more children are present. Facility is being cited for violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4, Sections 80019(e)(1): Criminal Record Clearance and Section 87065(f) Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to administrator Khea Gumbs.

A review incident reports show that from 3/20/2022 to 3/28/2022, a client had multiple self-harm incidents and reports and there were no calls made to law enforcement nor was the client taken to hospital for assessment. It was confirmed that staff speak inappropriately to clients by calling them names and yelling at them. narrative: provided conflict with other documents such as incident reports, showing that staff were working as part of the staffing ratio before initial training had been completed, and it was confirmed that at least two staff did not receive training although an initial training log had been filled out. On at least one occasion medication was signed for by a staff to show medication was administered to a client, during a time the client was not present in the facility to receive the medication. Based on a review of client files, the needs and services plan do not reflect current and updated information regarding the mental health, concerns, needs assessments, or progress of the clients in care. At least two clients have Needs and service plans that are exactly the same for at least a three month period with no changes to reflect the incidents or concerns displayed by the clients in care. It was confirmed that on at least two occasions staff were told to sign documentation that they did not write or did not perform the task being signed for. Multiple incident reports were reviewed by LPA's Belfield and Schlembach where clients were not receiving trauma informed care nor was there appropriate follow up to the incidents. It was confirmed that as a form of punishment, clients were not given their allowance. The preponderance of the evidence has been met. Therefore, the above allegations are Substantiated. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Sections 87065.1(a)(d)2 and 87065.1(d)(2) Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements, 87061(i)(4) Reporting Requirements, attached on the LIC 9099D. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Sections 87065.1(a)(d)2 and 87065.1(d)(2) Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements, 87061(i)(4) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to administrator Khea Gumbs. narrative: Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Angela King and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dung Mac conducted a case management inspection on December 20, 2022 at 11: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 1 youth file were reviewed. 1 out of Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 1 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, December 20, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement will be emailed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and Daily Residential Care form, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPM King and LPA Mac observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Khea Gumbs.

met_with: Sylvia Smith, Acting Administrator Ke Ana Elzie Facility Manager
narrative: On 1-20-23 11: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) George Karkazis and Mariah Hawkins conducted an unannounced Case Management /Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) inspection to REFUGE 3, and met with Sylvia Smith, Acting Administrator Ke Ana Elzie Facility Manager. On 07/07/ Community Care Licensing held a Non-compliance conference. The purpose of the inspection was to review the progress of the facility since the facility had their NCC. Immediately after the NCC the facility was not operating and re-opened on 11-30-22. The facility will be on NCC until 11-30-24. Inspections shall occur quarterly. The following conditions were stated and discussed during today's inspection and also during the NCC. 1. Reporting requirements: Facility agrees to create and maintain a written log of all incidents for each client and who the incident reports were sent to. This log will be available for review upon request by the department. Facility agrees to create a plan to conduct an internal review of all documents and will include a review of all incident reports to make sure that they are being completed properly and match up with the internal log of what was sent out. LPA Karkazis observed facility did not have a log established. There have been no incident reports written. An incident report log shall be submitted, an internal review documentation, Wednesday, 2/10/23, emailed to George.Karkazis@DSS.ca.gov 2. Food service: Facility agrees to maintain menu and food supply log to be checked weekly. Facility agrees to provide and alternative menu that allows clients to have food options when what is being served is not preferred or does not meet dietary needs. Fresh fruit and snacks shall be available for the client throughout the day without prior approval needed by staff. Facility agrees to maintain the food supply required by the regulations on a regular basis; 7 day supply of non-perishable food and a 2 day supply of perishable food. Facility agrees to maintain written log that will reflect the above expectations. These expectations are in addition to the regulations that are already established. LPA Karkazis observed 7 day supply of non-perishable food and a 2 day supply of perishable food. This will be available for review at all future NCC inspections. [continued LIC 809-C] continued from LIC 809 *3. Communication with community partners and outside agencies: Facility agrees to submit a plan on how they will have better oversight on communication with community partners and outside agencies. facility agrees to update the land line voicemail and make sure that the voicemail box stays clear regularly. Facility will update program statement to reflect that clients will have access to emails anytime throughout the day. At this time, CCL has not received the plan nor the addendum to the program statement. LPA Karkazis observed that the mailbox is still full. Staff indicated that they need the voicemail code and will obtain it from Administrator. Voicemail box will be checked at future NCC inspections. In addition, the facility agrees to develop a communication logbook (including communication from outside agencies) for the AM, PM, and overnight shifts, and each log will provide line(s) for staff to sign off that they debriefed with the prior shift staff and reviewed the communication log as well as lines at the bottom for the administrator to sign off daily that the communication log was reviewed. The logbook will be available for review at all future NCC inspections. Lastly, the facility agreed to update the program statement to include discussion of permitting residents access to their email when they request, program limitations permitting, and never denying a resident confidential access to their email. LPA Karkazis is requesting the facility to submit both the logbook and the program statement addendum no later than Wednesday, 2/10/23, emailed to George.Karkazis@DSS.ca.gov 4. Client education services / Mental Health services / Needs and Service: In addition to the regulations that have already been established, facility agrees to maintain written record of all progress or decline in clients needs and service. All service notes and mental health information conducted by social work staff shall be kept in the client file and available to for review upon request by the department. All staff will be educated on each client's individual needs and service plan and signature of understanding shall be signed by the staff. The facility agreed to have CFT notes and clinical recommendation maintained in resident files. Additionally, needs and services are updated every thirty days, all staff are trained every thirty days on the updated needs and service plans for each resident, documentation of which with staff signatures will be maintained in training staff file. These items will be reviewed at all NCC inspections. continued on LIC 809-C continued from LIC 809-C 5. Staff training: Facility agrees to have all training's for staff conducted by qualified outside agencies and staff will receive training monthly in order to fulfill the training requirement per regulations. A training log shall me kept at the facility and regularly updated for all staff. The information to be kept in the log shall meet all of the training requirements in the regulations. The training information shall include but not limit; trainer qualifications, training materials, length of training, and signature of attendance. In addition to the training topics listed, facility agrees to hold quarterly training's on personal rights, trauma informed care ( to include de escalation techniques), and medication. Facility states: New hires will receive 24 hours of training before they come on board. Training has occurred on suicidal identification and interventions, and it will continue to be offered regularly. Other training's will be forthcoming, such as positive enforcement and medications. This will take at least one year. The facility is planning on bringing in a Clinical Director to cover training that can't be handled in-house. Training binder was not available for review. LPAs advised that training records be available for the last three years and for each staff's full career with the facility. The facility has hired a Clinical Director, Alber Boles. Additionally, the facility agrees to hold monthly training to meet the 40 hour annual training requirement with trainings every quarter on personal rights, trauma-informed care, de-escalation techniques, and medications. A training log for all staff will be maintained in the training binder that logs all training received each year and training topics, hours, and trainer name, title, and qualifications. Staff signature or certificate as verification of attendance as well as trainer qualifications will be maintained in the training binder. Training binder will be available for review at all future NCC inspections. 6. Emergency Interventions: Facility agrees to submit their emergency intervention plan (EIP) every three months to the department (to their LPA). The facility agreed to conduct a review, every three months, of all intervention methods, their effectiveness, resident response and intended outcomes, and staff implementation and need for training. If the facility identifies any changes to the EIP that are needed, the EIP will be updated and submitted every three months with the EIP review. If no changes are needed and/or further review needed, the EIP will be submitted as is with the EIP review. The first review will be submitted to LPA Karkazis by 2/10/23. continued on LIC 809-C 7. Personal rights: LPAs observed grievance procedures posted and a poster of foster youth bill of rights posted. The poster includes the contact information for Community Care Licensing and the Foster Care Ombudsperson office. The facility agrees to post grievance forms in the facility and to submit a plan on how the facility will conduct weekly meetings with staff and weekly meetings with residents on personal rights, including residents' right to file grievances. The plan will be submitted to LPA Karkazis by Wednesday, 2/8/23, emailed to George.Karkazis@DSS.ca.gov. 8. TSP: Technical Support Program services were offered and facility agrees to submit a response on if they would like to receive this service to LPA Karkazis by 2/10/23. 9. Inspection authority: The facility agrees to have better communication with CCL and provide requested information when requested. The training binder was not available for review during today's inspection, as noted above, and LPAs are issuing an advisory of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Personnel Records, which requires that personnel records be available for review at the facility site. See LIC 9102. 10. Finger print clearance: The facility confirmed understanding that all staff must have a criminal background clearance associated to the facility and has an account set up with Guardian to process background clearance check applications. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report provided to the facility.

On 4/24/23 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA ) Alyssa Ng and Assistant Program Administrator (APA) Angela Carmack visited listed facility for the purpose of a Psychotropic Medication Inspection. LPA Ng and APA Carmack met with Administrator Khea Gumbs and Alanna Spencer who is the Administrator for a TAY Program. Safety precautions were done such as mask-wearing and temperature checks. Administrator Khea Gumbs stated that there were no clients since March 17, 2023. Facility is working on a contract with the county so no clients are being accepted at this time. Administrator will notify the assigned LPA when there are clients in care. At 10: AM, LPA Ng and APA Carmack did a facility tour inside and out. There are three client bedrooms that were double occupancy. One bathroom was in the front and the second bathroom was located in the client master bedroom in the back of the house. Sharps and staff/client files were located in a locked closet in the backroom. At 10:45, LPA and APA reviewed 1 client file. The file review included the admission agreement, Needs and Service Plan, progress notes, and medication binder. At 11: AM, LPA also went over the facility Inspection checklist, child file review checklist, staff file review checklist, and client and staff interviews. At 12: PM, APA Carmack conducted one staff interview with Administrator. At this time, no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Administrator Khea Gumbs.

On 4-26-23 9:47AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis and Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA's met with Khea Gumbs, Facility Administrator and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask wearing. The Short Term Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve six clients. Present during the inspection were one staff member. Currently there are no clients in care, no clients present. At 10:02AM LPA Karkazis and LPA Ng reviewed staff files. There are no clients in placement, no client files were reviewed. Staff 3 did not have a current health screening form. At 10:45AM, LPA Ng and Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed three bedrooms and two bathrooms. LPAs observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 118.9 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 70 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There was no perishable food and seven days non-perishable foods present. There are no clients in care. The medication was also stored and locked in a closet, in a locked cabinet.. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis and Ng interviewed one staff and no clients. At 11:03AM LPA Karkazis and Ng toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. continued on LIC 809-C continued from LIC At this time there was a Technical Advisory issued, California Code of Regulations 80066(a)(10) Health Screening form. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Khea Gumbs, Facility Administrator.

On 4-26-23 11: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) George Karkazis and Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced Case Management /Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) inspection to REFUGE 3, and met with Khea Gumbs, Facility Administrator. On 07/07/ Community Care Licensing held a Non-compliance conference. The purpose of the inspection was to review the progress of the facility since the facility had their NCC. Immediately after the NCC the facility was not operating and re-opened on 11-30-22. The facility will be on NCC until 11-30-24. Inspections shall occur quarterly. The following conditions were stated and discussed during today's inspection and also during the NCC. Currently there are no clients in placement as of 03-17-2023. 1. Reporting requirements: Facility agrees to create and maintain a written log of all incidents for each client and who the incident reports were sent to. This log will be available for review upon request by the department. Facility agrees to create a plan to conduct an internal review of all documents and will include a review of all incident reports to make sure that they are being completed properly and match up with the internal log of what was sent out. LPA Karkazis observed that a log book was created with tabs for clients. 2. Food service: Facility agrees to maintain menu and food supply log to be checked weekly. Facility agrees to provide and alternative menu that allows clients to have food options when what is being served is not preferred or does not meet dietary needs. Fresh fruit and snacks shall be available for the client throughout the day without prior approval needed by staff. Facility agrees to maintain the food supply required by the regulations on a regular basis; 7 day supply of non-perishable food and a 2 day supply of perishable food. Facility agrees to maintain written log that will reflect the above expectations. These expectations are in addition to the regulations that are already established. LPA Karkazis observed 7 day supply of non-perishable food. There was no fresh food or menus present, no clients are in placement or present. continued on LIC 809-C continued from LIC 809 *3. Communication with community partners and outside agencies: Facility agrees to submit a plan on how they will have better oversight on communication with community partners and outside agencies. Facility agrees to update the land line voicemail and make sure that the voicemail box stays clear regularly. Facility will update program statement to reflect that clients will have access to emails anytime throughout the day. In addition, the facility agrees to develop a communication logbook (including communication from outside agencies) for the AM, PM, and overnight shifts, and each log will provide line(s) for staff to sign off that they debriefed with the prior shift staff and reviewed the communication log as well as lines at the bottom for the administrator to sign off daily that the communication log was reviewed. The logbook will be available for review at all future NCC inspections. Lastly, the facility agreed to update the program statement to include discussion of permitting residents access to their email when they request, program limitations permitting, and never denying a resident confidential access to their email. LPA Karkazis observed log book and program statement addendum and are on file. Documents received 3-10-23. LPA was able to phone the facility and leave a message. 4. Client education services / Mental Health services / Needs and Service: In addition to the regulations that have already been established, facility agrees to maintain written record of all progress or decline in clients needs and service. All service notes and mental health information conducted by social work staff shall be kept in the client file and available to for review upon request by the department. All staff will be educated on each client's individual needs and service plan and signature of understanding shall be signed by the staff. The facility agreed to have CFT notes and clinical recommendation maintained in resident files. Additionally, needs and services are updated every thirty days, all staff are trained every thirty days on the updated needs and service plans for each resident, documentation of which with staff signatures will be maintained in training staff file. These items will be reviewed at all NCC inspections. Currently there are no clients in placement, no needs and service plans present. continued from LIC 809 5. Staff training: Facility agrees to have all training's for staff conducted by qualified outside agencies and staff will receive training monthly in order to fulfill the training requirement per regulations. A training log shall me kept at the facility and regularly updated for all staff. The information to be kept in the log shall meet all of the training requirements in the regulations. The training information shall include but not limit; trainer qualifications, training materials, length of training, and signature of attendance. In addition to the training topics listed, facility agrees to hold quarterly training's on personal rights, trauma informed care ( to include de escalation techniques), and medication. Facility states: New hires will receive 24 hours of training before they come on board. Training has occurred on suicidal identification and interventions, and it will continue to be offered regularly. Other training's will be forthcoming, such as positive enforcement and medications. This will take at least one year. The facility is planning on bringing in a Clinical Director to cover training that can't be handled in-house. LPAs advised that training records be available for the last three years and for each staff's full career with the facility. The facility has hired a Clinical Director, Abner Boles. Additionally, the facility agrees to hold monthly training to meet the 40 hour annual training requirement with trainings every quarter on personal rights, trauma-informed care, de-escalation techniques, and medications. A training log for all staff will be maintained in the training binder that logs all training received each year and training topics, hours, and trainer name, title, and qualifications. Staff signature or certificate as verification of attendance as well as trainer qualifications will be maintained in the training binder. Training binder will be available for review at all future NCC inspections. LPA observed that the above conditions have been met. 6. Emergency Interventions: Facility agrees to submit their emergency intervention plan (EIP) every three months to the department (to their LPA). The facility agreed to conduct a review, every three months, of all intervention methods, their effectiveness, resident response and intended outcomes, and staff implementation and need for training. If the facility identifies any changes to the EIP that are needed, the EIP will be updated and submitted every three months with the EIP review. If no changes are needed and/or further review needed, the EIP will be submitted as is with the EIP review. Facility has submitted an updated EIP and is on file, received 3-10-23. No changes have been made, there are no clients in care at this time. continued from LIC 809 7. Personal rights: LPAs observed grievance procedures posted and a poster of foster youth bill of rights posted. The poster includes the contact information for Community Care Licensing and the Foster Care Ombudsperson office. The facility agrees to post grievance forms in the facility and to submit a plan on how the facility will conduct weekly meetings with staff and weekly meetings with residents on personal rights, including residents' right to file grievances. The above conditions were fulfilled 3-10-23, and are on file. 8. TSP: Technical Support Program services were offered and facility agrees to submit a response on if they would like to receive this service. Khea Gumbs has declined services at this time. 9. Inspection authority: The facility agrees to have better communication with CCL and provide requested information when requested. Training binder was available on request and reviewed, and in good order. 10. Finger print clearance: The facility confirmed understanding that all staff must have a criminal background clearance associated to the facility and has an account set up with Guardian to process background clearance check applications. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report provided to the facility.

The allegations clients are being unreasonably searched, clients are not being called by preferred pronouns, and staff is not trauma informed. may or may not be true. The allegations have not met the preponderance of doubt and are therefore unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Administrator, Mr. White, at 1: PM.
investigation_findings: 13On 06/5/2023 at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood conducted a visit to the above agency to deliver the findings on the listed allegation. LPA met with Administrator, Mr. White. At the time of the visit, there were two staff, and two clients present in the facility. During the course the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with reporting party member, clients, social workers, and resource parents. According to confidential interviews, record review, and a walkthrough of the facility, LPA Singh-Sood concluded, the allegation had inconsistent support. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated, and no Title 22 deficiencies were observed. investigation_findings: 13On 2/21/2024 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) George Karkazis and Jasmine Cardeno conducted an unannounced inspection at REFUGE III, and met with Khea Gumbs, Administrator, who helped with the inspection. On November 8, 2023, the facility sent three incident reports to the San Bruno Incident Report Inbox. All three were marked "late" by the officer on duty. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. At this time there is no citation issued. narrative: On 4-19-24 9:15AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Case Management /Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) inspection to REFUGE 3, and met with Dwayne White, Administrator, Sara Haile, Facility Manager. On 07/07/ Community Care Licensing held a Non-compliance conference. The purpose of the inspection was to review the progress of the facility since the facility had their NCC. Immediately after the NCC the facility was not operating and re-opened on 11-30-22. The facility will be on NCC until 11-30-24. Inspections shall occur quarterly. The following conditions were stated and discussed during today's inspection and also during the NCC. At this time this facility is a 30 day overflow facility for Alameda County. Khea Gumbs is no longer the Administrator. The purpose today's inspection was to reintroduce the terms of this Non-Compliance Conference to the new administrator and facility manager, provide clarification, and check facility progress. 1. Reporting requirements: Facility agrees to create and maintain a written log of all incidents for each client and who the incident reports were sent to. This log will be available for review upon request by the department. Facility agrees to create a plan to conduct an internal review of all documents and will include a review of all incident reports to make sure that they are being completed properly and match up with the internal log of what was sent out. LPA Karkazis observed that a log book was created with tabs for clients. LPA Karkazis viewed incident reports and a log in front. 2. Food service: Facility agrees to maintain menu and food supply log to be checked weekly. Facility agrees to provide and alternative menu that allows clients to have food options when what is being served is not preferred or does not meet dietary needs. Fresh fruit and snacks shall be available for the client throughout the day without prior approval needed by staff. Facility agrees to maintain the food supply required by the regulations on a regular basis; 7 day supply of non-perishable food and a 2 day supply of perishable food. Facility agrees to maintain written log that will reflect the above expectations. These expectations are in addition to the regulations that are already established. There are 2 clients in care. LPA toured the kitchen and observed 7 day supply of non-perishable food and a 2 day supply of perishable food.. A menu was posted and the kitchen was clean and in good repair. continued from LIC 809 *3. Communication with community partners and outside agencies: Facility agrees to submit a plan on how they will have better oversight on communication with community partners and outside agencies. Facility agrees to update the land line voicemail and make sure that the voicemail box stays clear regularly. Facility will update program statement to reflect that clients will have access to emails anytime throughout the day. In addition, the facility agrees to develop a communication logbook (including communication from outside agencies) for the AM, PM, and overnight shifts, and each log will provide line(s) for staff to sign off that they debriefed with the prior shift staff and reviewed the communication log as well as lines at the bottom for the administrator to sign off daily that the communication log was reviewed. The logbook will be available for review at all future NCC inspections. Lastly, the facility agreed to update the program statement to include discussion of permitting residents access to their email when they request, program limitations permitting, and never denying a resident confidential access to their email. LPA Karkazis observed log book and program statement addendum and are on file. Documents received 3-10-23. LPA was able to phone the facility and leave a message. In addition, Administrator White has made shift notes more detailed, which include client behaviors and moods, and a calendar various appointments, and sign in logs, which all match. 4. Client education services / Mental Health services / Needs and Service: In addition to the regulations that have already been established, facility agrees to maintain written record of all progress or decline in clients needs and service. All service notes and mental health information conducted by social work staff shall be kept in the client file and available to for review upon request by the department. All staff will be educated on each client's individual needs and service plan and signature of understanding shall be signed by the staff. The facility agreed to have CFT notes and clinical recommendation maintained in resident files. Additionally, needs and services are updated every thirty days, all staff are trained every thirty days on the updated needs and service plans for each resident, documentation of which with staff signatures will be maintained in training staff file. These items will be reviewed at all NCC inspections. LPA Karkazis observed that clients have current signed needs and service plans. continued on LIC 809-C 5. Staff training: Facility agrees to have all training's for staff conducted by qualified outside agencies and staff will receive training monthly in order to fulfill the training requirement per regulations. A training log shall me kept at the facility and regularly updated for all staff. The information to be kept in the log shall meet all of the training requirements in the regulations. The training information shall include but not limit; trainer qualifications, training materials, length of training, and signature of attendance. In addition to the training topics listed, facility agrees to hold quarterly training's on personal rights, trauma informed care ( to include de escalation techniques), and medication. Facility states: New hires will receive 24 hours of training before they come on board. Training has occurred on suicidal identification and interventions, and it will continue to be offered regularly. Other training's will be forthcoming, such as positive enforcement and medications. This will take at least one year. The facility is planning on bringing in a Clinical Director to cover training that can't be handled in-house. LPAs advised that training records be available for the last three years and for each staff's full career with the facility. The facility has hired a Clinical Director, Jacklyn Smith. Additionally, the facility agrees to hold monthly training to meet the 40 hour annual training requirement with trainings every quarter on personal rights, trauma-informed care, de-escalation techniques, and medications. A training log for all staff will be maintained in the training binder that logs all training received each year and training topics, hours, and trainer name, title, and qualifications. Staff signature or certificate as verification of attendance as well as trainer qualifications will be maintained in the training binder. Training binder will be available for review at all future NCC inspections. Some trainings were conducted via Zoom. LPA observed that the above conditions have been met. Trainings observed : Client Centered and Trauma Focused Approach 4-1-24, Treatment Plans, Assessments, Discharge Summary 4-1-24, Monitoring and Documenting Response to Psychotropic Medications. The above conditions have been met, proof of training viewed via email/DocuSign. LPA advises to keep training sheet in binders, and to update training form dates. 6. Emergency Interventions: Facility agrees to submit their emergency intervention plan (EIP) every three months to the department (to their LPA). The facility agreed to conduct a review, every three months, of all intervention methods, their effectiveness, resident response and intended outcomes, and staff implementation and need for training. If the facility identifies any changes to the EIP that are needed, the EIP will be updated and submitted every three months with the EIP review. If no changes are needed and/or further review needed, the EIP will be submitted as is with the EIP review. Facility has submitted an updated EIP and is on file, received 3-10-23. There are no changes required with the current EIP. continued from LIC 809-C 7. Personal rights: LPA observed grievance procedures posted and a poster of foster youth bill of rights posted. The poster includes the contact information for Community Care Licensing and the Foster Care Ombudsperson office. The facility agrees to post grievance forms in the facility and to submit a plan on how the facility will conduct weekly meetings with staff and weekly meetings with residents on personal rights, including residents' right to file grievances. The above conditions were fulfilled 3-10-23 , 8-23-23 and are on file. 8. TSP: Technical Support Program services were offered and facility agrees to submit a response on if they would like to receive this service. LPA offered and explained TSP Services 9. Inspection authority: The facility agrees to have better communication with CCL and provide requested information when requested. 10. Finger print clearance: The facility confirmed understanding that all staff must have a criminal background clearance associated to the facility and has an account set up with Guardian to process background clearance check applications. All staff on duty had fingerprint clearance. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report provided to the facility.

On 4-22-24 9:39AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Dwayne White, Administrator, and toured the facility inside and out. The Short Term Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve 6 clients. Present during the inspection were 2 staff and 1 client. LPA Karkazis requested copies of LIC 500, 610, and 309. At 9:50AM LPA Karkazis reviewed 1 client and 5 staff files. All staff files were complete and in good order. In the client files, C1 was missing a consent form. At 11:35AM LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 116 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 69 which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in a locked file cabinet, in a locked closet. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed 1 staff and 1 client. At 12:05PM LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At this time there two deficiencies. A Technical Violation was issued Children's Records Interim Licensing Standards 87070(b)(12), and a citation for National Accreditation ILS 87089(a). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Dwayne White, Administrator.

On 5-30-24 12:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at REFUGE 3. The purpose of the visit was to ensure that S1, (see LIC Confidential Names List dated 5-30-24), is no longer the Administrator at REFUGE 3. Furthermore, S1 shall no longer be employed/volunteer/work at any Community Care Licensing (CCL) facility, including REFUGE 1 #015600412, REFUGE 2 #015600744, and REFUGE 3 #015650058. LPA met with Dwayne White, Acting Administrator, who helped with the inspection. LPA toured the facility which was clean and in good repair, S1 not present in the facility at the time of inspection. LPA conducted document research in Guardian rosters and found that S1 is still associated to REFUGE 1 #015600412, REFUGE 2 #015600744, and REFUGE 3 #015650058. LPA inspected the posted LIC 500 and found S1 not listed . Dwayne White, Acting Administrator stated that S1's last day of employment was March 21, 2024 . Dwayne White, Acting Administrator stated the reason S1 has not been disassociated from the Guardian rosters is because of a change in Human Resource Directors. HR1 is no longer the Human Resource Director, who was able to make changes in Guardian. The new HR Director HR2 is the only authorized to make changes, and may not know how. Dwayne White, Acting Administrator stated that the Licensee was unable to remove S1 from the Guardian Rosters, yesterday. LPA advises that S1 be disassociated from all REFUGE facilities on Guardian rosters immediately. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Dwayne White, Acting Administrator.

On 6-12-24 12:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at REFUGE 3, and met with Dwayne White, Administrator, who helped with the inspection. The facility was clean and in good repair, clients and staff interacting peacefully. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on complaint investigation for REFUGE 3, dated 3-29-24 #14CR-20240329140947. During the course of the investigation, three clients were on AWOL 3-28-24. LPA conducted document research in LPA email and the San Bruno Incident Report Inbox. As of 6-3-24, there is still no incident report for the AWOL incident dated 3-28-24. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of was given to Dwayne White Administrator.

The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegations. met_with: Administrator Brittany Flentroy, Facility Manager Sara Haile
narrative: On 9/17/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the faciilty in order to deliver notice of deficiencies observed during an investigation at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Brittany Flentroy and Facility Manager Sara Haile and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation at the facility, LPA observed that the facility submitted an incident report for a restraint that took place on 4/11/24. The report indicated staff "contained" a resident, and through this investigation, LPA learned that this "containment" was a restraint. The reporting requirements for restraints were not followed, due to the report not indicating the type of restraint used nor the length of the restraint. Further, the facility's plan of operation indicates that no restraints will be performed at any time. Additionally, LPA observed that staff statements reflect that the facility has blanket policies to conduct searches of residents at intake and to confiscate cell phones. LPA observed that the facility's plan of operation indicates that residents will be allowed to access their cellphones and that no specific search policies at intake are outlined in the plan of operation. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Reporting Requirements, Subsection (i)(7)(C) and ILS Section Plan of Operation, Subsection (f). LPA also verbally advised of ILS Personal Rights to provide technical support and ensure familiarity with relevant regulations for the plan of operation updates. An exit interview was conducted, plans of correction (POCs) were developed, and a copy of this report and of the licensee's appeal rights were left with Administrator Brittany Flentroy, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: Control #: 2036-FN, 2037-FN On August 7, 2025 at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Omar Sawyer and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Monica Pavia, made an unannounced visit to R.E.F.U.G.E. III facility for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection regarding an Incident Report Follow-Up dated 07/29/2025 involving Client 1 (C1) and Client 2 (C2). (see LIC Confidential Names List dated 08/07/25). LPA Sawyer and LPA Pavia met with Program Supervisor, Dwayne White (S3). There are two clients in care currently present. LPA Sawyer requested Staff Roster and Staff Schedule to cross reference staffing on the day of initial Incident Report. Based on a review of the incident report received by the department, the facility did not provide information on a plan moving forward for the clients. Clarification was needed regarding how this incident occurred as the description did not provide all pertinent information, as well as the plan for both clients moving forward, how will staff ensure that clients feel safe and prevent an event like from occurring again, and what was done with the pepper spray. During the conversation with Mr. White, follow up information was given regarding the aforementioned issues. Pepper spray was confiscated and meeting was held with youth in care. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Program Supervisor Dwayne White, whose signature confirms receipt.

An unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 10/28/20 at 10:30am. During the inspection, LPA Stidman met with Candy Hernandez, Health Services Coordinator and inspected the facility inside and out. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via Facetime. All files and medication documents were sent to LPA Stidman prior to the inspection. A medication count was also conducted by Facetime on this date. LPA reviewed two children's records at the facility at 10:30am. LPA reviewed four staff personnel files on site at the facility at 10:30am. LPA interviewed four staff on site at 10:30am. LPA interviewed one child currently taking psychotropic medication at 1:00pm. No deficiencies being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Candy Hernandez, Health Services Coordinator at 3:30pm LPA provided the Summary Report to Candy Hernandez, Health Services Coordinator upon completion by email with a request for signature and to scan this back to the LPA with their signature on this date.

Licensing Program Analyst LPA (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called Director Annette Jumper to deliver the closure of this case management inspection that was opened on 8/13/2020. LPA met with Director over FaceTime, a video conferencing application. On 7/30/ CCL received an incident report dated 7/26/2020 which described client C1 (see confidential names list dated 8/13/2020 - LIC811) going into other clients' rooms and trying to remove their belongings. Staff attempted to redirect C1 but he picked up some fruit, slamming it on the counter, and ripping bags of fruit open. C1 took some fruit to his room. Staff followed C1 and observed him. Client stated he can do whatever he wanted and called staff names. Staff asked C1 to keep it down and C1 stopped in front of the staff postured like he was going to hit staff in the face with the fruit. Staff claimed he did not have time to safely evade, so staff took hold of C1 in a restraint. Staff had another staff open the door and then assisted staff in restraining C1 outside. C1 was thrashing around and threatening violence via gang. Staff called Law Enforcement (LE) based on C1's threats. When LE arrived, staff released C1 and C1 talked with LE. They agreed for C1 to stay in his room for the rest of the night. No further incident. LPA investigated this restraint's validity and the escalation of the incident. LPA interviewed six clients and four staff on 7/31/2020, 8/13/2020, 11/3/2020, and 11/4/2020. The client involved stated that the staff spoke to him inappropriately, slapped the bananas out of his hand, pushed up against him, and put him in a headlock after he came back from an unauthorized absence late at night. According to interviews provided, only one other client observed this incident. During interviews with the other clients, the one client who observed stated the staff restrained the client when he ran at staff, called him a name, and pushed staff to get out. This client stated the staff didn't really know how to take hold properly, but didn't feel the staff did anything wrong. One client stated that he heard staff talking to the client before he fell asleep and stated the staff had an aggressive tone, but he didn't know what happened. This client also stated that he has no knowledge of this staff restraining clients inappropriately. Another client stated the staff's attitude is usually calm, not aggressive, not threatening, kind, and normal. This client also stated the staff had never done an inappropriate restraint before. During interviews with other staff LPA learned that the staff appeared to have jumped into the restraint too soon. During LPA's interviews with the involved staff and other staff, LPA asked about the staff's use of de-escalation techniques, which were found to be lacking. The involved staff explained that his methods for de-escalation was reminding the client of the rules. Staff explained that he did this multiple times. The staff stated the client came to the facility under the influence and was acting out of character earlier in the day, in an off-put mood and cursing out staff. LPA discussed with staff how his de-escalation techniques of repeating rules to the agitated client may have further escalated him. The staff understood and agreed. When the restraint/escort initially occurred the staff stated that when the client swung the bananas up to posture to hit him with them, he immediately took hold for his safety. LPA asked the staff about his consideration of evasion. Staff explained that he did not think of evading. Staff explained that he did have a conversation about this with the Manager that reviews incident reports. The statements that the client made against staff that he used inappropriate language, pushed him, and put him in a headlock were unsubstantiated based on other client and staff interviews. The staff involved denied that he did those things. While the restraint may have been unavoidable in the end, the use of proper de-escalation techniques and evasion or backing down may have also prevented the restraint. On this date, LPA is issuing an advisory note, which is not a citation, for the lack of de-escalation techniques, and lack of evading to prevent the restraint. At 9: AM an exit interview was conducted with Director, and a copy of this report was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.

Upon staff noticing cleaning supplies missing from the locked supply closet, staff conducted a search of the cottage and found what appeared to be cleaning supplies under R1's bed (see LIC 811 for confidential names list dated 02/19/2021). R1 stated the cleaning supplies were his personal belongings. LPA King was unable to determine if the cleaning supplies that were confiscated belonged to R1 or the facility. Based on LPA King's interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegations of the facility staff took resident's personal property and facility staff conducted unreasonable room search are UNSUBSTANTIATED - meaning although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility and a read receipt will serve as her signature. Appeal rights provided.

investigation_findings: 13On 03/01/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon delivered the findings of this complaint investigation. LPA was met by Annette Jumper, Director of Child & Family Programs, with whom the report was discussed. Prior to opening the investigation, LPA reviewed the facility's history of complaints, deficiencies, and relevant incident reports. The investigation was then formally opened at the facility on 11/04/2021. Interviews were conducted with four youth clients, two facility staff, and three case-carrying County Social Workers. The following records were obtained: the Needs & Services Plan for the referenced child, training records for the staffer in question, and documentation pertaining to supervised visits. No other youth client corroborated child C1 on staff S1 hitting or handling C1 in any rough manner; C1's depiction of the alleged action by S1 was within the context of staff having to apply a restraint on C1-this emergency intervention, according to at least one other youth who witnessed part of the incident, looked to be justified. None of the other residents reported instances-witnessed or directly experienced-of any facility staff making inappropriate comments to, or about, any minors in care. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: The minor had no previous incidences of self-harm since placement at the facility; the youth having ingested a detergent pod was new and unusual behavior-LPA found no reported occurrences of the client even attempting to do self-harm or expressing suicidal ideations. As such, there was no reasonable cause to restrict the client's access to cleaning supplies during chore time during which youths are encouraged and expected to complete assigned chores as part of the facility's daily program. Per the clients interviewed, the cabinet in which the cleaning chemicals are stored is otherwise always locked; this LPA, during an unannounced inspection, also found the storage of these chemicals to be secured. The minor, upon exhibiting GI symptoms, was taken to acute care to be treated for ingestion of a toxic substance. The case-carrying County Social Work Supervisor confirmed that this was uncharacteristic of the youth, that the client had no prior instances of self-harm at the facility, and expressed confidence in the facility's ability to provide care and supervision to the minor in question. Though the youth did gain access to a potentially hazardous cleaning agent, this was not due to neglect, a lack of supervision, or incompliance with the youth's care plan on the part of facility staff. Based on LPA's interviews and a records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED-although the allegation may have been valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove a violation did or did not occur. No Interim Licensing Standards or Title Regulations were cited during today's inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

narrative: It was reported that a youth was "slammed" to the ground by a staff member. Though this was corroborated by one other youth, there were inconsistent details between obtained statements surrounding the incident including who else was there to witness it. None of the purported witnesses corroborated seeing anything like what was described by the youth, and none of the other interviewed youths reported ever seeing the staffer in question do anything that they would describe as physical abuse to any of their peers. In the staffer's statement, he was responding to, or intervening in, a situation where a potential assault was being perpetrated by the youth on a female staff-person, and that the extent of his actions were to hold back that youth which then caused them both to fall to the floor. Though there was some sort of physical contact between the staff-person and the youth, the force with which the youth hit the ground cannot be determined, nor can it be ascertained if "slam" was an appropriate description of how the staffer and the youth fell to the floor. The youth did not sustain any injuries from the incident and did not report feeling unsafe with, or around, the staff member in question. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report, along with the Appeal Rights, is being provided to this facility.

narrative: Based on information obtained from witness interviews, the child is active, intelligent, plays in a rough manner, hits, kicks, bites, pulls hair, yet, over the last couple of months, the child has improved significantly both behaviorally and emotionally. Different information obtained indicates the child had multiple injuries due to staff handling the child roughly and that multiple scratches and bruises were observed. There is no evidence to indicate staff were subject to disciplinary actions. Witness interviews corroborate the child is not afraid, appropriate discipline is used for children, and positive reinforcement is applied to include "behavior bucks" for children. It is unclear if the child's injuries were due to rough play, accidents, or because of inappropriate staff interventions. Although the allegation that staff was rough with minor causing multiple bruises may have happened, or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did, nor did not occur, therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. LPA conducted exit interview, provided appeal rights, and delivered this report January 16, 2024.

narrative: Obtained documentation from the Sacramento Children's Home (SCH, or facility) as well as corroborating statements that support it, show that an assessment or evaluation, and medical treatment if needed, was offered to a youth after an incident took place wherein a youth's hand was caught on a door that was being shut by a facility therapist. LPA met with Residential Clinical Program Manager Amanda Drumheller who facilitated, over two inspection days, the review of records, interviews with staff and clients, and a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. The facility's fire alarm system was tested and found to be operational. The kitchen, food prep, and storage areas were observed to be clean and sanitary. The refrigerator and freezer temperatures were found to be within the required ranges. Stock of perishable and non-perishable food items were found to be sufficient. The children's bedrooms had the required bedding and the furniture were in good repair. A First Aid Kit/Box was fully stocked with the required items. Medication were found to be centrally stored and secured. No potentially hazardous areas or items such as household chemicals and/or cleaning solutions, knives and other sharp kitchenware, were found to be left accessible to clients. The required posting were observed to be present: facility license, Foster Youth Rights; Five total staff interviews were conducted; two facility clients were interviewed in total (no additional client interviews were done on this day as none were available at the time of the inspection). Five staff files and five client files were reviewed-all of which were found to contain the required records. No citations are being issued as a result of this inspection; the facility was found to be in substantial compliance with Title Regulations including the Interim Licensing Standards. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On May 25, 2021, and office conference was held with San Diego Center for Children (SDCC) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) via Microsoft Teams, due to COVID-19 pandemic. In attendance were: Community Care Licensing representatives Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela, LPM Stephanie Hudak, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez; SDCC representatives- Director Ervey Salinas LMFT, Assistant Director of Operations/Residential Meghan Dambacher, Clinical Manager Yasmin Williams, LMFT, Clark Clinical Program Manager Marissa Jones, Training Specialist Michelle Pechtl, Nurse Manager Jennifer Loya, QA Director Misty Howard; CDSS/Systems of Care Provider Development Manager Marjana Jackson. San Diego County Representatives included: Senior Probation Officer Jorge Aguilar, Institutions Evaluation Unit (IEU) Monitor Julie Martinez, IEU Manager Natasha Hood, IEU/Contracts Supervisor Lyn Worthington, and Contracting Officer Representative Gentiana Janina. The following issues were discussed:  Complaints  Emergency Intervention Plan  Training During the meeting, LPM Hudak addressed that this meeting is to support and discuss how CCL can assist the facility in avoiding health and safety issues associated with the use of restraints. LPM Hudak discussed the substantiated complaints due to inappropriate restraint holds within the last 2 years and requested information on what the facility has changed to decrease holds; how the facility is incorporating the emergency intervention plan and how staff is being trained. (see continuation form LIC809-C dated 05/25/21) In response, the facility representative discussed the quality council and data collection that the facility has in place. The facility reviews and disperses the information to train staff and changes actions to meet the needs of clients. The Quality control group for the facility looks at data monthly in an extensive and very detailed data that is compared going back two years. In report details, the facility looks at the durations of holds, times of holds, clients with increased holds, staff who are conducting the holds and any patterns. The facility also reviews injuries and what can be modified to prevent injuries caused during activities. The facility uses trends as support in CFT's to show volume, to see effects of medications and to update weekly meetings on any new trends that have been observed. The facility never looks at numbers by themselves and looks at the number of incidents per occupied bed. Also in response, it was stated the review of the data supports the facility when adding extra services; assessing levels of need; to discuss other services to meet the clients needs; providing incentive plans; changing the way things are done which can include providing a client more breaks, providing psychological testing for functional level, getting a local CASA representative to visit children; reviewing campus video footage for staff feedback on interventions or to review incidents and finding better placement for the staff if the staff is better with adolescents vs. young children. It was specified that multiple staff read incident reports and give staff ideas on what could have been improved or provide feedback for trainings. LPM Hudak asked if the facility is still utilizing SPA as part of their emergency intervention plan and the facility responded they have used SPA since 2007 and haven't found a need to change the program. The facility receives current and up to date trainings yearly from the Devereux Foundation. RM Cook inquired about what the facility is doing to support staff's wellbeing and self-care. The facility discussed the importance of staff self-care and the Wellness Programs offered to encourage staff to take 5 minutes of meditations, take time off or use mental health days, increase team building activities, and provide time for staff to talk about stress levels. The facility highlighted the importance of staff wellness and the encouragement for self-care. All recommendations/suggestions and requirements given during the meeting by CCL were acknowledged by STRTP representatives. County and CCR representatives had no recommendations to add. (see continuation form LIC809-C dated 05/25/21) In closing, all parties were satisfied with all information that was discussed during the meeting. CCL is requesting the following be submitted by 6/25/21: A copy of the Internal Biannual Review of the emergency interventions that was completed by SDCC for January 2021. Also, for future comparison, CCL is also requesting that SDCC submit the Biannual Review due by July 5, 2021. CCL will review both reports to see the trends, patterns, and data collected by the facility and what modifications were recommended by the administrative staff of SDCC. LPA met with SDCC Director Ervey Salinas via tele-inspection to answer any questions. A copy of this report was emailed to SDCC Director Ervey Salinas with "read receipt" notification to verify that the licensee received the report. A copy of the signed reports will be placed in facility file.

Confidential interviews stated C1 initially refused to be taken to the hospital however staff convinced C1 and C1 was taken to the hospital for evaluation. Confidential interviews stated that S1 administered a medication dose amount to C1 that was not authorized by a physician and stated it was accidental due to unintentional oversight. Confidential interviews stated that C1's dosage was changed from liquid form to pill form and the type of syringe being used had been changed to a more accurate syringe for liquids. Confidential interviews stated S1 was given a corrective action, and re-training. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation that S1 mismanaged child's medication is substantiated at this time. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care. The facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Interim Licensing Standards 87075(c):Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a signed copy of this report was provided to Program Administrator Ervey Salinas, along with the LIC 811. (See Continuation Form LIC9099-D dated 05/27/2021)

On February 9, 2022 at 12:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted a annual inspection. On February 9, 2022 at 12:20PM, LPA Carol Anderson conducted a physical plant inspection with Administrator Ervey Salinas. LPA observed the physical plant inspection which included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The facility has four outdoor basketball courts, a ropes challenge course, various sporting equipment, game room with computers, books, and television gaming equipment were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. The cafeteria kitchen was inspected and is clean. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policy in the lobby, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the nursing office. Licensee provides the right for contraceptives to be held individually by clients and locked in containers by clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Continued. Jack and Carol Clark facility, the hot water in the client's bathroom was measured to be 109 degrees. Seaside, Baja, Bedrock and Skyline units, the hot water in the client's bathroom was reading at 108 degrees all within regulation. Facility has cameras in common areas of all cottages. The facility has a waiver on file to use the cameras and are meeting the terms and conditions. Per Administrator Ervey Salinas, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Per. Administrator Ervey Salinas he will be sending the board of director meeting minutes to CCL. A review of the Licensing Information System on February 9, 2022 indicates that all individuals are associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Administrator, Ervey Salinas, is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedules. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs Social Workers, 12 facility managers and 96 direct care staff. Per Administrator, Licensee has obtained Mental Health Certification. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through the Joint Commission. The Accreditations extended due to COVID-19. Licensing fee payments have been paid. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator and Representative: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Based upon the inspection of facility records reviewed of staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements and working on requesting the meetings sooner to not fall close to the 30-day mark. Continued. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained on-site in a locked file cabinet in staff HR office. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. A review of Thirteen client records and ten staff personnel were also completed. Due to time constraints, staff and clients will be interviewed at another date and time. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews on this date, there are no deficiencies found at his time. Exit interview conducted with Ervey Salinas, Administrator.
