investigation_findings: 13On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian met with Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Administrator Yasmin Williams to discuss the investigative findings for the above allegation. LPA Carol Anderson conducted an inspection to the STRTP on March 24, 2022 at 2:03PM. No immediate hazards observed. LPA reviewed and requested facility and client records. On March 24, 2022, Community Care Licensing received information alleging that Staff #1 (see LIC811 dated 03/14/2023) pushed minor #2 (see LIC811 dated 03/14/2023) while in care. Confidential interviews with two staff revealed that the minor was pushed by the staff while multiple witnesses were present. Documentation was received of three written witness statements. Confidential interviews confirm that the staff member #S1 did push the minor in care. The minor was unable to be interviewed at this time although multiple attempts were made. LPA received consistent confidential information and documentation that the allegation occurred. Based on interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that the staff #1 pushed the minor #2 while in care is substantiated. This posed an immediate health and safety risk to the children placed in care. These actions are in violation of the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 4, Article 6, 87072(c) Personal Rights. See attached LIC 9099D for cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided. Due to technical difficulties with printing the report, the report was scanned and emailed to the licensee. facility_name: SAN FRANCISCO BOYS AND GIRLS HOME - EUCLID HOUSE
narrative: On Tuesday, October 05, 2021 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza conducted an annual/required inspection at the above facility. LPA Mendoza met with Administrator, Scheron Douglas, due to the current Administrator LaTasha Knighten being out on leave. The facility has not been operating since May of 2021 so the facility has been vacant. Therefore, LPA Mendoza did not use Inspection Tool during todays inspection. Please note, the facility has been in communication with CCL regards to their current status. LPA Mendoza toured the facility inside and out and found the facility to be safe, clean and in good repair. During LPA Mendoza's walk thru LPA observed the facility having all items packed in plastic bins. The refrigerator and freezer were empty, and were unplugged due to the facility closure. LPA toured the upstairs and there were a total of 5 bedrooms. All bed rooms were empty and three were storing plastic bins, mattresses, and bed frames. The Administrator confirmed that their maintenance person visits the facility every 2 months to ensure the facility remains in good standing. Per Administrator Scheron, the facility believes they will not be operating until sometime next year (2022). The facility is still in discussion if they will remain as an STRTP or may change to another facility type. At this time the facility wants to remain as an STRTP due to the agency still deciding. Once the facility make a decision they will notify LPA Mendoza immediately. LPA Mendoza also advised the facility to check in with LPA by January of 2022, so LPA can know what the facility current status is. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

facility_name: SAN FRANCISCO BOYS AND GIRLS HOME - EUCLID HOUSE
narrative: On 8/29/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required 2-year inspection at the facility. LPA met with Program Manager Dessoni Redmond at the facility and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA also discussed the purpose of the visit with Administrator Teyona Galloway over the phone. Administrator confirmed that the facility is currently non-operational as a short-term residential therapeautic program (STRTP) and is instead being utilized as office and conference space for the operations of the licensee's other STRTP in the area. Therapists' offices are housed at the site, and staff meetings and therapeutic activies for the residents are hosted at the site. As such, there are no residents in care nor staff employed at this facility site. The licensee has been advised that they would be permitted to forfeit the license and still utilize this building as currently used. LPA toured the facility site and observed no safety hazards. Hot water measured within permitted range, and the site was maintained at a comfortable temperature within permitted range. Bathrooms and kitchen are maintained in clean and sanitary condition. Since the site is not in operation as a care facility at this time, there are no residents in care nor care staff working, so no interviews were conducted and no files were reviewed. No deficiency citations are being issued. LPA observed a few areas where technical support may be beneficial. See LIC Advisory Notes attached. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Program Manager, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

facility_name: SAN FRANCISCO BOYS AND GIRLS/ SHELTER
narrative: On Tuesday, October 05, 2021 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Scheron Douglas and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the Inspection Tool to complete the annual inspection. LPA toured the facility site and observed the facility to be clean and sanitary. Commonly touched services are sanitized regularly. Per Administrator, there are no firearms on the premises. Sharps and medications are stored in the locked closet in the staff office. First aid kit is also stored in the staff office. Bedrooms are tidy, residents have individual beds, and beds have clean linens. The room temperature and hot water temperature measured within permitted ranges, at F and F. The kitchen was in sanitary condition with functioning equipment and dishware, cookware, and utensils to meet the needs of residents in care. Food storage was sanitary, food was fresh and in date, and there was food storage to meet the 7-day nonperishable, 2-day perishable mandate. LPA reviewed 1 client file, due to the other client being placed at the facility yesterday. (C1), please refer to LIC 811, dated 10/5/21 for confidential names) did not have Modifications to their Needs and Service Plan on file. The facility only had (C1's) initial Needs and Service plan, which was dated 08/24/21. LPA Mendoza requested and updated Needs and Service plan from the Administrator, and Administrator received confirmation from (S3) that the facility does not have one. LPA reviewed 5 staff files. Staff files were complete, and training record shows that the facility has been conducting training's from 2019 to current. [Please Refer to Lic 809-c for Cont.] LPA issued 1 citation per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, STRTP Interim Licensing Standards 87068.3(a) Modifications to Needs and Services Plan. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 2/17/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit to deliver findings. LPA met with Administrator Teyona Galloway and informed of the purpose of the visit. During investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed relevant facility records. Based on LPA investigation, the facility does have a qualified facility manager who has experience working in a leadership role within the facility. The facility does have a qualified Head of Service who holds a valid marriage and family therapist license. The facility had the facility manager as acting interim administrator pending an administrator change, and during this time, in August, LPA made a visit and there were no residents in care pending the designation of an administrator. As of November 2022, Teyona Galloway has been the administrator and is qualified. The designation has been confirmed and approved by CCL and the licensing records will be updated. Lastly, the facility has been following intake procedures but has a history of permitting the county to place youth without prior receipt of admission paperwork. The facility is now requesting the admission paperwork prior to placement, complying with licensing requirements. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

LPA met with Administrator Teyona Galloway, and informed on the purpose of this visit. Based on the report received by the licensing agency, it was reported that the facility is not providing mental health services, the facility does not have a Head of Service, and the facility is not following Needs and Services Plans. LPA reviewed pertinent documentation and conducted confidential interviews. LPA found that a Head of Service has not been available to provide mental health services at the facility since December 2023. Additionally, the Department was not notified of any changes in the mental health program. Based on LPA's observations, interviews, and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. narrative: On 6/25/24, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mariah Hawkins and Nicole del Calvo conducted a random annual inspection. LPAs met with Program Supervisor Dessoni Redmond and informed of the purpose of the visit. During visit, LPAs toured the facility site and grounds. LPAs observed the facility to be clean, organized, and maintained in safe condition. Kitchen and bathrooms were maintained in sanitary condition. Knives and chemicals were stored where inaccessible to residents in care. Bedrooms had individual beds and closet space. A supply of food was observed that would meet the needs of the two residents in care, including fresh fruit, snacks, and refrigerated items. A current LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan was obtained. LPAs requested that a current LIC 500 be generated to align with the facility schedule and to list all facility staff. LPAs also obtained a staff contact sheet. LPAs reviewed resident records for the two current residents. LPAs discussed the facility's transition to a new head of services and the licensee's hiring progress. A continuation visit will be conducted to complete the review of personnel records. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Program Supervisor Dessoni Redmond.

facility_name: SAN FRANCISCO BOYS AND GIRLS/ SHELTER
narrative: On 8/14/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to the facility to discuss needed revisions to the program statement. LPA met with Program Manager Dessoni Redmond and informed of the purpose of the visit. Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 5 was published 12/13/2023. LPA requested that the necessary revisions be made and submitted to LPA and that the administrator respond to LPA by 8/16/24 with an anticipated submission date. Additionally, LPA requested the following specific items be addressed in the revised plan of operation (POO) / program statement (PS). 1) Staff Ratios The current PS indicates the staff to child ratio is 1 staff to 4 children. LPA advised that ILS Section 87065.5 requires that facilities with a capacity of 7 or more follow specific ratios for on-site supervision. LPA read through the section and explained that this means the following ratios must be followed for this facility, as it has a licensed capacity of 8: From 7AM-10PM: When 1 child is present, there shall be 1 awake direct care staff; when 2 to 4 children are present, there shall be 2 awake staff; when 4 to 8 children are present, there shall be 2 awake staff. From 10PM-7AM: When 1 child is present, there shall be 1 awake direct care staff; when 2 to 6 children are present, there shall be 2 awake staff; when 7 to 8 children are present, there shall be 2 awake staff. See Page 2 2) Search Policies During an investigation at the facility, it was learned that the facility is conducting person searches of children. LPA advised that specific search policies be outlined in the revised PS for the licensing agency's review. LPA also advised that blanket policies will not be allowed, but policies for case-specific searches authorized by the authorized representative may be reviewed by the licensing agency. 3) Cell Phone Policies The current PS includes a cell phone contract that permits the facility to confiscate children's cell phones. LPA advised that ILS Section 87072 requires that children be accorded the right to possess their personal belongings, which would include their cell phones, unless prohibited by a discipline program. LPA requested that the revised PS remove the blanket policy to confiscate cell phones. LPA also advised that policies for case-specific confiscation of phones authorized by the authorized representative may be reviewed by the licensing agency. No deficiency citations were issued at this visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Program Manager, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

facility_name: SAN FRANCISCO BOYS AND GIRLS/ SHELTER
narrative: On 8/15/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Teyona Galloway and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation and inspection at the facility, it was found that four staff working at the facility do not have a background clearance associated to the facility. LPA searched through the background clearance system Guardian and observed that multiple staff listed on the facility's clearance roster did not have a valid background clearance and that one staff listed on facility records and confirmed to be working in the facility did not have a background clearance associated to the facility. Administrator confirmed that the staff without a valid clearance no longer work at the facility and confirmed that Administrator would request that HR remove them from the Guardian roster. Due to one staff (S1 - See LIC Confidential Names dated 8/15/24) working on site without a background clearance associatied to the facility and therefore without eligibility to be working on site, LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 3, Section Criminal Record Clearance, Subsection (e). See attached LIC 809-D. Additionally, as mandated in Section 80019(g), LPA is assessing an immediate civil penalty of $100 for a maximum of 5 days in violation in which S1 worked on site, for a total of $500. See attached LIC 421BG. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 7/18/25 at 9: AM, A meeting was conducted with the San Jose Regional office and Seneca. Present during this meeting were, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Carolyn Flynn, LPM Joel Segura, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield, LPA Omar Sawyer, Systems of Care (SOC) Ansar Muhammad, Seneca representative Alicia Hooton. During this meeting, clarification was requested regarding the direction of the facility applications of the program. Seneca representative Alicia Hooton confirmed that Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) application one and STRTP application two, will be STRTP's and not Children's Crisis Residential Program (CCRP). It was also confirmed that both facilities will not be converting to CCRP. Details of the program statement were also discussed and changes that need to be revised regarding requirements, regulations, and length of stay in the program. It was discussed that the language of the Monterey Compass application will better reflect the STRTP program regulations and requirements. Questions were asked regarding application process, facility types, and program requirements. The meeting was concluded. A copy of this report will be sent to Seneca representative Alicia Hooton.

facility_name: SAN GABRIEL CHILDREN'S CENTER, INC./ENID HOME
narrative: On 10/02/2020, the department received a complaint alleging personal right violations by staff towards a client. Staff workers that were interviewed provided a statement and denied the allegations that inappropriate discipline was given to a client for allegedly walking off the property after being upset. Staff workers stated that clients are never allowed to go take a walk off the property, except within the property and under staff supervision. Staff workers denied the allegation that a client is being bullied by other clients and staff are not intervening. Staff workers that were interviewed stated that clients are not allowed to bully other clients. Staff workers disclosed that the client who is allegedly being bullied by other clients is known to intimidate staff and bully other clients as well. Staff workers stated that they take immediate action and will intervene and give verbal redirects to any client who acts inappropriate. Staff workers stated that all clients are treated fair without any preferential treatment. In confidential interviews. LPA Vargas was provided with inconsistent statements. One client stated that allegations are true, however other clients were consistent and denied that clients are not allowed to bully another client without having consequences for their actions. All clients stated that staff will verbally redirect them for individuals who acts inappropriate. All but one client stated that staff treats them fair without being given any preferential treatment (favoritism) as it pertains to being discipline. Based on interviews and records reviewed there was no corroborating information to substantiate the allegations for personal right violations. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the above allegation did or did not happen. Therefore, this complaint is being closed Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time during this inspection and LPA informed the facility representative that LPA would e-mail a copy of this report for review and signature.

facility_name: SAN GABRIEL CHILDREN'S CENTER, INC./ENID HOME
narrative: On 04/07/2023, the Department received a complaint alleging allegation for physical plant concerns. It was reported that the bathroom/shower for the clients is dirty with grime and mildew. In confidential interviews, all clients that were interviewed provided consistent statements that the bathroom is dirty with grime and mildew present in the shower. The house manager (HM) provided a statement that the bathroom is cleaned up by clients followed by staff checking that bathroom/shower is clean. Furthermore, the Administrator disclosed that a weekly "Chore Sheet" is completed by staff. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vargas visited the facility and inspected the bathroom on 04/10/2023 and observed the bathroom areas, such as the floor, shower enclosure, and toilet area not clean. The bathroom was present with grime along the edges of the floor and baseboard, including mildew present in most areas within the shower. Photos of the bathroom area were taken as part of the complaint investigation and was shared with the Facility Administrator on 04/11/23 via email. Interviews and documentary evidence produce corroborating evidence to support the allegation that the bathroom is dirty with grime and mildew. Based on the interview information obtained and LPA's visit to the facility on 4/10/2023, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated per California Code of Regulations Title Division Six Chapter Five. Facility cited for violation California Code of Regulations Title Division Six, 80088(e)(3). The bathroom: toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities shall be maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition. LPA Vargas discussed with the Administrator in the event of repeated violations within a 12-month period {(refer to Heath and Safety Code §1548 for Civil penalties; regulations setting forth appeal procedures for deficiencies, sections (2)(A)(B)}

facility_name: SAN GABRIEL CHILDREN'S CENTER, INC./ENID HOME
narrative: On 07/05/23, the Department received a complaint alleging allegation that one staff spoke inappropriately to a client. The focused staff (FS) who was identified in the report denied the allegation. Other staff workers that were interviewed denied the allegation and corroborated the FS statement. Information gathered from staff interviews and some of the clients suggest that the focused client (FC) who reported the allegation suggests or appears the client has a physical attraction towards a female staff worker (FS). In confidential interviews, four clients provided consistent statements and denied the allegations. The four clients disclosed that they were aware of the allegation being reported by another client because the FC was overheard speaking about his actions after the report was filed. The one-focused client (FC) stated that he believes a staff spoke inappropriately toward him. The FC did not respond when asked if he is physically attracted to a female staff. The FC admitted speaking to the FS saying inappropriate sexual comments and was told that he is making the staff feel uncomfortable. Information provided by staff and other clients disclosed that the focused client has admitted that he "likes the FS". The Facility Administrator has placed a second member of staff to work with the FS during her regular night shift as a form of support. The Administrator continues to monitor the situation involving that one client and his actions involving a member of staff who works nights. Based on the available information obtained by staff and clients, the above allegation is determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is no preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. The resolution to this complaint was discussed with the facility staff representative and copies of all licensing reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and the Appeal rights were given and explained. No deficiencies were cited at this time.

facility_name: SAN GABRIEL CHILDREN'S CENTER, INC./ENID HOME
narrative: On 10/26/2023, the Department received a complaint alleging that a staff worker got into a physical altercation with a client. The focused staff (FS) who was identified in the report denied the allegation and stated that the one focused client threw water at him and then attacked him. The focused client reported that there was physical contact between him and the FS that involved the FS pushing and pulling the client from one room to another room. During the physical incident another client was a witness to the incident and had to intervene and separate both the FS and the other client identified in the report. A second staff worker who was present and witnessed the incident has corroborated the physical altercation that occurred on Sunday 09/24/2023. There were no other clients or staff at the facility at the time when the physical altercation occurred. In confidential interviews, one staff member denied the allegation, and other clients and facility staff workers provided consistent statements that corroborated the allegation. Based on interviews by the clients, facility staff workers, and other witnesses, including documentary evidence produce corroborating evidence to support the allegation that a staff worker was involved in a physical altercation with a client. The preponderance of evidence has been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be substantiated per California Code of Regulations Title STRTP INTERIM LICENSING STANDARDS Chapter 7.5 (Vs. 5), Articles 06, 87072(c)(16), Personal Rights. The resolution to this complaint was discussed with the facility staff representative and copies of all licensing reports were provided after the conclusion of the inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and the Appeal rights were given and explained.

met_with: Hector Gonzalez, Quality Assurance Coordinator Administrator
narrative: Staff identified taking privileges away like not allowing children to play video games, no wi-fi or no outings consequently when children got into trouble. Interviews with staff did not state a concern or identify complaints being made about staff mistreating children. Additionally, interviews conducted with C1, C2, C3 and C4 varied in that two of the four interviews were not able to establish a time where staff spoke inappropriately or demonstrated inappropriate forms of discipline. Interviews conducted with C1 and C2 state that S1 made inappropriate comments or statements towards them. C1 and C2 further stated that S1 would get angry and yell at them. However, interviews conducted with C1, C2, C3 and C4 did not establish a specific date, time or how often these incidents were occurring. S1 denied the allegations made by C1 and C2 stating that incidents involving children have been more volatile towards staff and that staff try to redirect. Interview conducted with house manager identify staff receiving on-going training and did not identify any specific incidents of concern regarding staff and children. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail. There were no deficiencies cited during this tele-inspection.

narrative: An unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Claudia Portillo and Gilbert Gutierrez, at San Gabriel Children's Center, Inc./Homerest Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on 8/6/21 at 9: AM. During the inspection, LPAs Portillo and Gutierrez met with Sylvia Quintana, House Manager. All clients at this facility are Probation placements. Therefore, no files were inspected. LPA Gutierrez conducted a tour of the facility at 9: AM. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. All medications are centrally stored, locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. There is adequate staffing in the facility to provide care and supervision for the clients per facility's Plan of Operation/Program Statement. A review of the program statement was conducted at 10: AM. LPA Portillo reviewed four (4) staff files on site at 11: AM. Employees received training on psychotropic medications as specified in Section 16501.4(d) of the Welfare and Institutions Code (WIC). LPA Gutierrez interviewed three (3) staff members administering psychotropic medication on site. A copy of this report, and LIC811 was provided to the STRTP representative upon completion. No deficiency was found. LPAs conducted exit interview with STRTP representative.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to San Gabriel Children's Center/Homerest Home on December 06, 2021 at 12:30pm for the purposes of conducting an unannounced Required Annual inspection. The facility is licensed to serve six male clients ages 12-17 years old. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents. LPA met with Sylvia Quintana, House Manager (HM), and together they toured the facility. The facility is a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and is located in a residential neighborhood. It is a single story home with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, living room, dining area, staff office, and a backyard. Presently, there are four residents in placement at the facility. The backyard was observed to be free of debris and hazards. Smoke alarms were operable in each bedroom. LPA observed two bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. Sharp knives, cleaning supplies, and medications are kept locked in areas inaccessible to clients. There is adequate perishable and nonperishable food supply at the facility. LPA observed a fully stocked linen closet in the hallway. All three bedrooms contained two twin beds, two dressers, and closet space. There is adequate seating in the living room and dining area. The HM stated that there were no guns or weapons at the facility. There is no swimming pool or other bodies of water on the premises. All rules and regulations were posted at the facility. LPA observed several disaster kits, board games, and reference materials. LPA also observed a fully charged fire extinguisher in the dining area. The last fire drill was held on December 05, 2021 at 10:30am. The last earthquake drill was held on December 05, 2021 at 10:35am. LPA reviewed three staff files and all four client files and found the reviewed files to be in order. LPA also interviewed staff as well as clients during today's inspection. LPA obtained an updated LIC500 (Personnel Report) and a client roster. Licensee will scan/email LPA a copy of their most recent Board of Director's meeting minutes. LPA found no Title 22 deficiencies on this date. Exit interview conducted

There was a total of five clients residing in the facility. During investigation, all the clients were interviewed. During the incident, all five clients witnessed the physical altercation between C1 and C2. Based on the interview, on the day when the incident happened, an argument escalated, leading to C2 hitting C1. Both C1 and C2 engaged in a physical fight. Following the altercation, S3 called 911 for assistance. Three staff members were present during the incident, and all three were interviewed as part of the investigation. C1 sustained injuries during the altercation and was transported to the local hospital for medical attention. The interviews conducted with the youth placed in the facility revealed consistent statements. According to the accounts provided by C1(interviewed on 05/03/23), C2 (interviewed on 05/17/23), C3 and C4 (interviewed on 05/05/23), , and C5 (interviewed on 05/17/23), the staff members attempted to prevent the youth from engaging in a physical altercation during the incident. Statements from the youth also revealed that the staff members made efforts to intervene physically but also employed verbal redirection techniques to prevent the youth in care from engaging in a physical altercation. The client interviews indicated that the staff used communication strategies to redirect and de-escalate the situation. LPA Martinez also interviewed three staff during the investigation. S1 was interviewed on 04/28/23, S2 and S3 were interviewed on 07/06/23.The interviews revealed that the staff members were consistent in their presence during the altercation and made efforts to intervene. Staff members utilized both verbal de-escalation techniques and physical intervention to address the incident. Based on interviews conducted with five clients and three staff members, in addition to reviewing the needs and services plan obtained during the investigation, the allegation against license #197804961 is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. No deficiencies were identified during the inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the director.

On 09/13/2024, the Department received a complaint alleging that a staff worker (S1) applied a chokehold to a client (client to be identified only as C1 for this report), including making inappropriate comments about his overall status being placed in a facility, and that his family doesn't love him. S1 denied the allegations that he applied a chokehold to a client. S1 denied telling a client his family does not love him, which is why he is in a facility. S1 disclosed that on 09/01/24., a client got upset for impatiently waiting to be served more food, aside from just finished eating a large meal. S1 reported that C1 got upset, grabbed S1's food, and threw it at him, including smearing fries on his face. S1 reported that C1 became combative and was attempting to hit him. S1 only held his wrists or hands to prevent being injured by the client. S1 reported that other staff workers assisted and escorted the client to his bedroom without further incident. In confidential interviews, two staff workers who witnessed the incident denied the allegations, other staff workers provided statements to support S1 saying that he is not the type of person who would do and say things inappropriately to a client. In confidential interviews with five clients, they revealed inconsistent statements and could not corroborate the reported allegations against the staff identified in the report. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, and records reviewed, it cannot be determined whether the allegations occurred resulting in staff applying a chokehold to a client, and staff making inappropriate comments to a client. Therefore, the above allegations are determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. The resolution to this complaint was discussed with the agency representative and copies of all licensing reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection. An exit interview was conducted and the Appeal rights were given and explained. No deficiencies were cited at this time.

facility_name: SAN PASQUAL TREATMENT CENTER - FEMALE PROGRAM
narrative: On February 10, 2025, at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem conducted an announced visit to the above facility and met with San Pasqual Treatment Center Frank Simmons Program Manager, Keary Mason Head of Service, Dana Centanni Regional Director for the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection. Currently there are no clients placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve six ambulatory clients ages 12 to 17 and Non-Minor Dependents. LPA conducted component III of the orientation process and reviewed with the applicants Licensing requirements. The home is a one-story building with three client bedrooms and two client bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Client) has two twin beds and will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #2 (Client) has two twin beds and will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #3 (Client) has two twin bed and will sleep two client and attached bathroom · Kitchen, dining area, and family room area, locked storage and laundry room, hallway and storage closets, backyard/patio area, and attached two car garage for set up for visitation and mental health services. The Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, and complaint procedures are posted in the hallway of the home. The license will be posted as soon as it is issued. LPA and the applicants toured the facility inside and out and conducted a full inspection of the facilities physical plant, including building and grounds, food service, furniture fixtures and supplies, telephone service, health-related services, personal services, and activity space. The facility has demonstrated compliance with Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations and Interim Lincensing Standards. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Frank Simmons, Program Manager.

facility_name: SAN PASQUAL TREATMENT CENTER - FEMALE PROGRAM
narrative: On May 6, 2025 at 3: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a post-licensing inspection and met with Frank Simmons, Administrator. LPA conducted two staff interviews (S1 and S2) and one client interview (C1). LPA initiated an inspection the facility's physical plant. Due to time constraints, the annual is being extended to complete the physical inspection, as well as conduct files reviews and client interview. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report was provided to Frank Simmons, Administrator.

facility_name: SAN PASQUAL TREATMENT CENTER - FEMALE PROGRAM
narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent bullying among children resulting in an altercation; it was specifically reported that C2 and C3 were bullying C1 which ultimately led to an incident where C1 was chasing C2 and C3 with a large rock, and at one point, C2 tripped and fell sustaining a knee injury when trying to get away from C1. In addition, it was reported that C1 didn't make contact with either C2 or C3 with the rock, but law enforcement called in a violation of assault with a deadly weapon. During investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that C1 and C2 were involved in a verbal altercation that escalated to a physical altercation outside, although staff attempted to prevent C1 from going outside. However, C1 was able to get outside by escaping the house through the back door. In addition, multiple confidential interviews corroborated that staff attempted to de-escalate the altercation, however, C1 exited the area and pursued C2 and C3 with a rock. During the pursuit, C2 tripped and sustained a knee injury. LPAs received conflicting information. Based on interviews, the allegation that staff did not prevent bullying among children resulting in an altercation may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Regional Director, Dana Centanni.
investigation_findings: 13On 08/21/2025, at 1:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez met with Regional Director, Dana Centanni of San Pasqual Academy (SPA) to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation listed above involving staff and clients (C1-C3) as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC811). On 04/22/2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint that staff did not prevent bullying among children resulting in an altercation. On 05/01/2025, LPA J. Salem initiated the complaint at the facility and completed health and safety inspection. During the inspection, LPAs interviewed clients (C2 and C3), staff (S1, S3, and S4), and C1's County Social Worker (CSW). LPAs were unable to interview client 1 (C1) and staff (S2). Pertinent records were obtained and reviewed. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

facility_name: SAN PASQUAL TREATMENT CENTER - MALE PROGRAM
narrative: On February 10, 2025, at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem conducted an announced visit to the above facility and met with San Pasqual Treatment Center Frank Simmons Program Manager, Keary Mason Head of Service, Dana Centanni Regional Director for the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection. Currently there are no clients placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve six ambulatory clients ages 12 to 17 and Non-Minor Dependents. LPA conducted component III of the orientation process and reviewed with the applicants Licensing requirements. The home is a one-story building with three client bedrooms and two client bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Client) has two twin beds and will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #2 (Client) has two twin beds and will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #3 (Client) has two twin bed and will sleep two client and attached bathroom. · Kitchen, dining area, and family room area, locked storage and laundry room, hallway and storage closets, backyard/patio area, and attached two car garage which is set up for visitation and mental health services. The Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, and complaint procedures are posted in the hallway of the home. The license will be posted as soon as it is issued. LPA and the applicants toured the facility inside and out and conducted a full inspection of the facilities physical plant, including building and grounds, food service, furniture fixtures and supplies, telephone service, health-related services, personal services, and activity space. The facility has demonstrated compliance with Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations and Interim Lincensing Standards. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Frank Simmons, Program Manager.

Please include the following in runaway plan: - Procedure for complying with Reporting Requirements specified in Section 87061(i). - Procedures for management review of incident reports, policies, and practices to determine the cause of, and to develop strategies to address, runaway children, both on an individual and facility-wide level. Procedures must include regular management reviews to be conducted at least once a year.*n - How staff respond to runaway child(ren) and child(ren) outside of the facility property without permission, but who are within view of the staff. Continued... ...CONTINUED 11 i. The section stated "If a client is outside the facility without permission in view of staff, they will be immediately informed they must ask to return to the facility," is this what was intended to have been said? When reporting incidents, please ensure all report requirements specified in Section 87061(I) are also maintained Incident Reports documenting a runaway situation must include the following: - (A) When, how, and by whom was the child's absence first noted. (B) The child's last known activities. (C) What were the circumstances surrounding the child's absence. (D) What action did the facility personnel take to discourage the child from leaving and what interventions were utilized. (E) What action was taken by facility personnel to locate the child. If a manual restraint was used, and if it is determined by the post incident review, as required in Section 87095.68, that facility personnel did not attempt to prevent the manual restraint, a description of what action should have been taken by facility personnel to prevent the manual restraint incident. (F) Describe what corrective action that will be taken or will not be taken against thefacility personnel and why. (G) If law enforcement was involved in the incident, a detailed description of the events involving the law enforcement contact, including a - police report number if available. (H) Documentation that the child's authorized representative has been notified of the incident. 2. Please specify whether the youth are being supervised during the 15 min cool down. 3. Please describe the procedures for determining and using age and size appropriate emergency intervention techniques. 4. Please include criteria for assessing when an emergency intervention plan needs to be modified or terminated, along with the procedures for terminating the plan or making any necessary modifications. 5. The section stated, "Manual restraints shall not be longer than 15 minutes." Please describe in-depth what the facilities' intervention process is after 15 minutes. If the youth is unable to remain calm, what are the facilities' policies? If the facility will use restraints longer than 15 mins, please describe the procedures. Recommend detailing these procedures if the facility plans to use restraints past 15 mins. 6. The following required detail in the descriptions of the monthly restraint log was left out: result of licensee review. Please include. 7. Please include if facility will use separation rooms. Continued... ...Continued 12 8. Please state that the admissions agreement will include a written statement regarding the types of emergency interventions the licensee has been approved to use and must be reviewed with the child/NMD and authorized representative at the time of admission, and that a copy of the interventions used will be provided to the authorized rep upon request. (87095.22(i)(1)(A)) 9. Please state that the facility will follow the reporting requirements for each use of manual restraints of a child/NMD (87061(i)(7), which are: - Date and time of other manual restraints involving the same child in the past 24 hours. - A description of the child's behavior that required the use of manual restraints, and description of the precipitating factors which led to the intervention. - Description of what manual restraints were used and how long the child was restrained. - Description of what non-physical interventions, trauma-informed practices, or de-escalation techniques were utilized prior to the restraint and an explanation of why more restrictive interventions were necessary. - Description of any injuries sustained by the child or facility personnel, including what type of medical treatment was sought and where the child was taken. Provide an explanation if medical treatment was not sought for injuries. - Name(s) of facility personnel who conducted the manual restraint. - Name(s) of facility personnel who witnessed the child's behavior and the restraint. - The child's verbal response and physical appearance, including a description of any injuries at the completion of the restraint. - If it is determined by the post incident review, as required in Section 87095.68, that facility personnel did not attempt to prevent the manual restraint, provide a description of what action should have been taken by facility personnel to prevent the manual restraint incident. Describe the corrective action that will be taken or will not be taken against the facility personnel and why. - If law enforcement was involved, a detailed description of the events involving the law enforcement contact, including a police report number if available. - Documentation that the child's authorized representative has been notified of the incident. The original signed copy will be maintained in the facility file in the San Diego Regional Office.

deficiencies.title: Visit Date

met_with: Lauri Burns, Anasheh Safarian & Morgan Salmans
narrative: On October 21, 2020 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Torres conducted a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) pre-licensing inspection. The LPA met with Lauri Burns, Executive Director, Anasheh Safarian, Director of Operations, and Morgan Salmans, Facility Manager. The facility is a one story residential building with five bedrooms, four bathrooms, living room, staff office, family room, dining room, kitchen, laundry room and a two car attached garage. A physical plant inspection was completed and the following was observed by the LPA: The facility stores personnel files, client files, client cash resources, and medications in the staff office. The door to the staff office has a keyed locked. The office is kept locked when not in use and is only accessible to the facility staff. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris, observable hazards, and insects. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. A television, board games, books, and puzzle were observed for client's recreation time. The family room will be used for clients to use for relaxation and visits with family and friends. The following required forms were posted in the facility: Weekly Menu, Personal Rights form, and Complaint Procedures. Each of the four client bedrooms has proper lighting, adequate drawer space, all six beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses in good repair. The facility has telephone service on premises. The hot water was tested and measured to be 113 degrees Fahrenheit which is in the required range of 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kits and a current first aid manual approved by the American Red Cross. Smoking is prohibited in the facility and on the grounds. *** *** Per Executive Director, no firearms or weapons are kept or allowed in the facility and smoking is prohibited. Licensee has previously been accredited through the Joint Commission, and once the facility is licensed the licensee will notify the commission to make them aware of the program change to update the certification. Current staff have caregiver background checks and have received criminal record and child abuse index clearance. LPA discussed the following: Reporting requirements, facility manager requirements, personnel rights and Assembly Bill 388 requirements. The LPA was provided Criminal Record Transfer documents for Lauri Burns, Anasheh Safarian and Morgan Salmans during this inspection. . The licensee will ensure that LIC 503s Health Screening Report-Facility Personnel are submitted for Lauri Burns and Anasheh Safarian. After final review of the application, the program will be submitted for licensure. The facility will be notified once they are provisionally licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). A copy of this report was provided to Lauri Burns.

On 04/26/22 at 1: PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Belinda Torres, met with Andrea Carmona, Administrator. The LPA was informed by Andrea that she started working as the administrator at the facility on 04/11/22 in preparation for the facility's first placement. Andrea worked for the corporation in their adult rehabilitation program facilities across the street from this facility. The LPA obtained a copy of the LIC Personnel Report, dated 04/15/22, which shows an employment date of 10/08/20 for Andrea and job title of Administrator. The Administrator on file with the Department is Anasheh Safarian. The LPA spoke by telephone with Lauri Burns, CEO, and received verbal authorization from Lauri for Andrea to sign for this licensing report. Lauri informed the LPA that the change of administrator notification was sent to the Department at the end of February of 2022. The LPA informed her that the notification was not received. Based upon a record review as of today's date, the licensee failed to notify the Department, in writing, within ten calendar (10) days of the hiring of a new administrator. The facility is cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards STRTP Article 6 87061(h) Reporting Requirements. A copy of this report, LIC Proof of Correction and appeal rights were provided to Andrea.

On December 1, 2022 at 10:14am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Adrian Mendez and Eduardo Barragan arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct an Required Annual inspection of the facility. LPA's met with Case Manager Lora Caldwell and Head of Service Mariam Mott. LPA Barragan inspected the facility inside and out with Head of Service Mariam Mott. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There are five bedrooms in the facility. Four bedrooms are single rooms, one bedroom is set up for two clients. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. Each bed room contained one desk as well. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathrooms were measured at 116 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible. The medications were stored and locked in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a locked closet in the hallway. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked staff office. The First Aid Kit is located in the staff office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Head of Service Mariam Mott. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Emergency Disaster Plan and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. LPA discussed and reviewed the following inspection components; Operational Requirements, Emergency Disaster Preparedness, and the Emergency Intervention Plan. Cont. on 809-C A sample of two client files were reviewed during the inspection. All client files had the required documents per Title Regulations. All client files are maintained on a secured internet database. All of the staff records are accessible and maintained at an off-site location. LPA's reviewed 5 staff files. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulation requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. LPA's conducted a Post-Licensing inspection as well. Mental Health Program Approval for the facility is still currently pending. Based on the facility inspection, and files reviewed there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained to Case Manager Lora Caldwell. Due to printer malfunction, this report will be emailed to Case Manager Lora Caldwell.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura conducted an announced virtual inspection with the facility and met with Administrator Victoria Shannon regarding a Special Incident Reports (SIR) that were submitted to Community Care Licensing. The first incident report dated 01/31/2021 indicated that on multiple occasions for the month of January M1 (Medication 1) the client was given half of the prescribed dosage in the evening. The second SIR, dated 02/02/2021, stated that in the course of conducting a medication audit the facility manager Leann Leon discovered that M2 for C1 (Client 1, See Confidential names list LIC 811, dated 03/01/2021) was also given incorrectly causing the client not to receive their evening dose. LPA interviewed the administrator Victoria Shannon during this inspection and discussed the medication errors. Victoria stated that upon finding these medication errors the facility took immediate action and conducted a staff training. Further they have increased their audits of the medication. Every Monday either the administrator or facility manager audit the medication, on Wednesday the medication staff member conducts and audit and the evening/overnight staff also conduct and audit every night as part of their regular duties. Continued on 809C LPA reviewed the submitted incident reports and determined the facility failed to administer medication as prescribed. Per Title Regulations, deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of the report was emailed to the administrator Victoria Shannon. A read receipt was requested to acknowledge this report was received.

come back under the influence at the facility. Two staff were interviewed on 01/08/2021. The facility manager Leann Leon was interviewed at around 10:45am. The interview revealed and confirmed client statements that the facility staff do supervise clients at all times and check on them every 15 minutes over night. An interview was also conducted with the facility head of services Carolina Cortez at around 11:45 am. Interviews with the Carolina and LeeAnn revealed that as soon as the facility became aware of the allegation of inappropriate contact with clients the facility staff separated the youth in question and for the duration of their stay at the facility. The incidents of inappropriate contact allegedly occurred overnight between roommates C1 and C2 (Clients 1 and 3, see confidential names list LIC 811, dated 05/26/2021) at an unknown date. Clients reported using marijuana when they leave the facility on an unauthorized basis and do come back under the influence; however, they report that staff not only discourage that behavior they are asked to empty their possessions to search for contraband. An interview was conducted with C1 on 04/20/2021 at around 3:30pm. The interview further confirmed the statements clients made on 01/08/2021. Client confirmed that upon learning of the allegations staff separated client from C2 and shared a room with a different roommate. The C1 reported that C2 did not share a room with anyone else. The client stated that they pretended to sleep when staff were checking on them only to get up for the 15 minutes between when staff would come and check on them. C1 stated they were quiet when the incident happened and they were using a vape pen; which they hid after using. C1 reported this incident took place in the span of 3 -4 minutes. Interview with C2 on 01/08/2021 did not result with any information, the client denied participating or knowing anything about the allegations. Note that C2 was accused of being the perpetrator of the inappropriate contact and one of the instigators of using marijuana at the facility. An interview was also conducted with direct care staff Karolina Redondo on 05/13/2021 at approximately 3:30pm. The interview confirmed the staff check on clients every 15 minutes over night. Karolina indicated she was supervising clients when one of the incidents of inappropriate conduct occurred. Karolina stated that she had supervised the clients the whole time while at a car wash. She had taken clients to assist with washing the facility van as and activity and chore. Karolina was also cleaning the van with clients. She stated that nothing was reported to her or observed during the activity. It was alleged C2 had used the vacuum at the car wash to place near the C3's buttocks. Karolina stated that yes, clients used the vacuum but did not observe or hear the clients using the vacuum in an inappropriate manner. Although the allegations may have occurred or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence that they occurred as a result of lack of supervision by staff; therefore, the allegations above are unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the administrator Victoria Shannon. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was emailed for a signature to Victoria Shannon.

On November 15, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging facility staff do not prevent clients from bringing drugs into the home, and staff does not provide a safe environment for clients and staff does not treat clients equally. Based on confidential interviews, clients would come back to the facility already on drugs, not necessarily bring drugs into the facility. Staff did not ask the police to leave during an incident with a client. The client refused to talk with police. Staff treat clients as equally as possible. Some clients open up more to staff than others and this may lead to feelings of inequality. Based on confidential interviews conducted, the above allegations may have happened or are valid, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff did not prevent clients bringing drugs into the facility, staff does not provide a safe environment and staff does not treat clients equally; therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated.

Licensing Program Analyst Britanee Windom conducted a case management inspection on 06/02/22 at 9: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 4 out of Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 5 youth were interviewed.(See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, June 2, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, monthly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma informed and evidence based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Windom observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Steve Duran.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a Case Management inspection. LPA discussed this with Nic Briseno, Administrator (ADM) at 10: AM on 1/31/24. This case management was opened to discuss an incident report the department received for an incident that occurred on 1/29/24. The incident report stated that a staff member was attacked by clients in care. LPA Simien and ADM discussed the incident (see LIC Case Management Details 2/2/24 for details). ADM agreed to send LPA a detailed summary of clients time at the facility, client files, and photo evidence of the incident. LPA Simien reviewed client files at the facility. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to ADM. This document was amend on 2/2/24. confront or engage in a power struggle with C1 due to the client being new. Staff are instructed to not confront clients and to make behavioral notes instead. ADM stated that S1 has been working at the facility for 14 years and would not escalate with a client over an iPad. LPA Simien inquired if the facility knew if C1 had a history of violence or attacking staff. ADM stated that before accepting C1 as a client her social worker didn't inform them of C1 currently having five charges against her. C1 is charged with extensive property damage, unlawful force and violence upon a person, and resisting/delay/obstruct of a public officer/peace officer. ADM stated they were only informed of the charges when the client arrived at the facility on 1/25/24. ADM speculated that those charges may have come from her last placement. ADM stated that the social worker submitted an incomplete intake packet for C1 and has made several request for competition. ADM stated that upon C1's arrival on 1/25/24 that it was discovered that her social worker forgot her medication and that there was no approved JV-220 paper work, just a JV-220 request. C1's social worker also didn't provide the facility with any identifying information so they were unable to sign C1 up for school. ADM stated while they were aware C1 could be aggressive, they didn't know that it would be to the degree of attack that happened on 1/29/24. C1's social worker has been unresponsive to emails and phone calls. LPA Simien inquired if the facility knew if C2 had a history of violence or attacking staff. ADM stated that although C2 has a history of violence, she hasn't had any behavioral issues outside one AWOL at the facility. ADM stated he was shocked to find out that C2 was involved with the attack and completely out of charcter. He stated that C2 had no problems being incompliance with turning in her electronics at night. ADM stated that he is not sure exactly what happened during the incident and has not been able to debrief with S1 due to S1's hospitalization. As of 1/31/24, law enforcement has not provided any information regarding the incident to the facility. ADM agreed to send LPA a detailed summary of C1's time at the facility, client files, and photo evidence of the incident. LPA Simien reviewed C1 and C2's client files at the facility. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to ADM.

narrative: On 11/05/2020, at 10:13 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela conducted a pre-arranged pre-licensing tele-inspection, as a result of COVID-19 related restrictions. On 01/11/2019, the facility listed above submitted an application to transition the currently licensed group home facility to a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The application, application documents, Plan of Operation and Program Statement have been reviewed by Community Care Licensing (CCL) LPA Lorena Valenzuela and Continuum of Care (CCR) Policy Analyst Patrice Coleman. The facility tele- inspection was conducted with the facility Administrator, Francine Haynes. The home is a one-story residence with three bedrooms, one staff office, one therapist office, and three bathrooms. The tele- inspection included an observation of the following: 1. Yard is clean and free of debris or observable hazards. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials. 3. Chemicals stored in a locked cabinet inside the laundry room. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed in the staff office in a locked closet inside a locked cabinet. 5. First aid kit complete, including manual was inside the staff office in a locked closet. 6. Adequate storage space was observed for linens. 7. Individual beds in good repair, equipped with clean mattresses and pillows observed. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens in good repair. 8. Facility has three client bedrooms, double occupancy. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings including closet space, drawer storage and a desk for each client. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable food items were observed. (continued on page 2) 10. Weekly menu posted and accessible to clients. 11. Dining room equipped with large table with benches and chairs accommodating all clients. 12. Facility has two full client restrooms in this home and one staff restroom, all are operable. 13. Hot water measured within required range. Administrator Francine Haynes measured the water temperature using a thermometer. 14. All smoke detectors tested and appear to be in proper working order. 15. Carbon monoxide detector was observed and tested. 16. Fire extinguishers properly charged. 17. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed. 18. Facility maintains a current fire clearance. 19. Knives are stored in the staff office in a locked closet inside a container with a lock. 20. Appropriate forms posted in view of facility clients. 21. Facility does not have any open bodies of water. 22. Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The following items were discussed with Administrator Francine Haynes, by LPA during the inspection: 1. LIC 500 reviewed to ensure appropriate staffing ratios, including Administrator, Facility Manager, Social Work personnel, and Direct Care staff. The facility does not utilize Peer Partners at this time. 2. Administrator Francine Haynes will be present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week. 3. Facility procedures for 30-day updates of Needs and Services Plans discussed. 4. Facility is to ensure all clients considered for future placement have been assessed and meet placement eligibility requirements. Facility has a process in place to contact authorized representatives to ensure assessment for clients' continued placement. 5. Facility is to update all client admission agreements to reflect the STRTP rate. 6. Facility is to obtain Mental Health Program Approval (MHPA) within 12 months of effective date of the provisional licensure, will keep the department updated as to MHPA status, and will provide appropriate documentation to the department upon approval. (continued on page 3) During the tele-inspection, LPA Lorena Valenzuela interviewed the facility Administrator and staff to ensure staff understanding of the STRTP program requirements. It was recommended by LPA that all line staff be trained on keeping confidentiality of a client's gender identity, expression and orientation; what the Emergency Intervention Plan is; purpose of Children and Family Team meetings; and Reasonable Prudent Parent standards, prior to the STRTP conversion. In addition, during the tele-inspection LPA Valenzuela discussed with Administrator Francine Haynes the following revisions needed to the facility's Plan of Operation (POO) and Program Statement (PS) submitted on 10/09/2020. Below the revisions requested is how the facility will meet the requirement, per a previous discussion held 11/04/2020, with Program Administrator Denise Samano. Program Statement (PS) Section 4 - Core Services and Supports CCR Question: Does EVC have written agreements or contracts with external agencies? Such as Career Pathways. If so, please attach the agreement(s) with the final version of your PO/PS. Per ILS § 87022.1(b)(6) and ILS § 87078.1(b)(1-2) PS *The facility has some written agreements with external agencies and will submit those to CCL. and CCR. The facility will obtain written agreements for the external agencies for which they don't have written agreements for. Section 11- Complaints and Grievances CCL Question: It is indicated if a complaint or grievance arises, there will be mediation between the involved staff and client. Will there be a neutral third party involved the mediation? (PS, page 38) *The facility will revise this section to reflect their complaint procedure which is to have client complaints or grievances reported directly to the administrator. Section 22 - Emergency Intervention Plan (Runaway Plan) CCL Review 10/19/20- Facility did not provide name and qualifications of Behavior Management Consultant who assisted in plan preparation (PS page 80, Article 10. ILS 87095.22, 87001(b)(1).) *The facility will revise the PS to include the name and qualifications of the above mentioned consultant. (continued on page Plan of Operation (POO) Section B - Administrative Organization CCL Review 10/14/20-Missing- Staff Therapist qualifications regarding experience requirements. Facility provides the education requirements for Social work personnel per ILS, however, facility is missing the work experience requirements (POO page 11-12, ILS 87065 (c) (1) (C-F)) *The facility will review this section to ensure the work requirements for the social work personnel are included. Section E - Policies Regarding Child Abuse/Neglect Reporting CCL Review 10/14/20-Facility does not provide specific procedures and practices on how it will ensure the administrator does not impede or prohibit mandated reporting duties. (POO: page 40-41, ILS 87022 (b) (7) (A-C)) *The facility will revisit this section to ensure the administrator or other staff do not impede mandated reporting duties. -End of Revisions Requested- LPA Valenzuela advised the facility of the following steps. The facility agreed to the PS/POO revisions due date of 11/18/2020. The facility was advised to contact LPA Valenzuela or CCR Policy Analyst Coleman with any questions regarding the revisions requested. The facility was informed that failure to complete the agreed upon actions may result in denying the application to convert the facility to a STRTP. The facility was advised that the STRTP provisional licensure request will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. A copy of this report was emailed to Francine Haynes for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.
