On November 9, 2021, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Val Wilson, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela, arrived at Santa Maria Home Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for STRTP annual inspection that was initiated on November 8, 2021. LPAs already completed the physical inspection of the facility on the first day of the annual inspection. The LPAs met with Facility Administrator, Francine Haynes, and Program Administrator, Denise Samano, and on the telephone Executive Director Larnel Jackson, PsychD. During this annual inspection continuation, LPAs reviewed ten personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Personnel Files are maintained at the main office. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Eight of ten personnel files did not meet the annual training requirement for 2020. LPAs observed the training records for 2021 may not meet the training requirements. LPAs discussed that the Administrator is to ensure that the annual training requirements are met for 2021, which state all direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 40 hours annual training. Additionally, it could not be determined that staff 2 (S2) meets the direct staff personnel requirements based on education records and job history on file. Furthermore, four out of ten personnel records did not have valid CPR and first aid cards. Lastly, based on interviews, staff 3 (S3) and staff 4 (S4) are the designated Facility Managers. Based on training records review of S3 and S4, LPAs observed they did not meet the regulation training requirements. Based on the records review and interview, LPAs observed of S3 and S4 did not have the required training documentation needed to assume the role of a facility manager. The facility will be cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87065(f)(2) Personnel Requirements. Refer to LIC 809C for the continuation of this report. Based on the records review and interview, LPAs observed one of ten staff did not meet the direct staff personnel requirements based on education records and job history on file. The facility will be cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87065(g)(1)(A) Personnel Requirements. Based on the records review and interview, LPAs observed four of ten staff did not have a current and valid CPR and/or first aid cards. The facility will be cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87065.1(c)(6)(A) Training Requirements. Based on the records review and interview, LPAs observed eight of ten staff did not complete a minimum of 40 hours of annual training. The facility will be cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87065.1(d)(1) Training Requirements. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report LIC809Ds and a copy of the appeal rights was provided to Administrator, Francine Haynes. Due to time constraints, LPAs will return at a later time to conduct a review of client records.

An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Val Wilson, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes, on 11/08/2021 at 9:00am, at Santa Maria Home Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). Prior to the visit the facility file was reviewed for annual fees due and no annual fees are past due. Upon arrival, LPAs and LPM met with Facility Administrator, Francine Haynes, who led a tour of the facility. The home is a one story residence with three bedrooms and three bathrooms. LPAs and LPM toured the inside and outside of the facility at 10:15am. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. Bedroom #1 has a wall puncture and an unfinished repair to the ceiling. Bedroom #3 had water damage to the ceiling. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were in good repair. The hot water in the client bathrooms was measured to be 106* F bathroom #1 and 105.5*F bathroom #2. Facility walls need an overall cleaning/painting due to LPA's and LPM observing paint chips and the walls being dirty with foreign matter smeared. The therapist office behind the garage has a broken window Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in laundry area and storage room in the garage. Chemicals were also found in the food pantry. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked box in a locked cabinet in the staff office. The facility's Smoke and Carbon Monoxide Detectors were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator. LPAs and LPM observed facility posted items in the kitchen area that included: Child's Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked file cabinet within a locked cabinet in the staff office. LPAs observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. However, snacks are locked in a cabinet inaccessible to clients. During the inspection, there was one client present. Refer to LIC 809C for the continuation of this report. The facility outside grounds was also inspected. LPAs observed boards missing in the backyard wooden fence. In addition, multiple wood boards and plywood were observed to be leaning at the side of the home near the backyard gate. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Facility Administrator was unable to provide signed Board Meeting Minutes for the past year. LPAs interviewed 2 staff on cite. Based on the facility inspection, observation, and interviews Chemicals were observed by the LPAs in the food pantry by the therapist office. The facility will be cited under Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06, Section 80076(a)(16) Food Service. Based on the facility inspection, observation, and interviews, snacks were not accessible to the children in care. The facility will be cited under Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06, Section 80076(a)(4) Food Service. Based on the facility inspection and observation, LPAs observed boards missing from the wooden backyard fence. The facility will be cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87087.2(a)(4)(A) Outdoor Activity Space. Based on the facility inspection, observation, and interviews, LPAs observed punctures in walls, water damage to the ceiling, and facility walls need an overall cleaning/painting. The facility will be cited under Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06, Section 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. Based on the facility inspection and observation, LPAs observed one window broken in the Therapists office. The facility is cited under Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06, Section 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. Refer to LIC 809C for the continuation of this report. Based on the facility inspection, observation, the LPAs observed paint chips and the walls dirty with foreign matter smeared. The facility is cited under Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06, Section 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. Based on the facility inspection, observation, documents, and interviews, LPAs obtained unsigned, incomplete, required Board Meeting Minutes. LPA observed that the minutes did not reflect there was a review and discussion of the documents required per the Health and Safety Code 1520.1(f). The facility will be cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87063(a)(9) Accountability. Based on the facility inspection and interviews, the facility did not ensure monthly logs of each manual restraint use was documented as required. The facility will be cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87095.61(f) Documentation and Reporting Requirements. Due to time constraints, LPAs will return to complete the staff and children's record review at a later time. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report LIC 809Ds and LIC9102TA was provided to Administrator, Francine Haynes. Appeal rights were provided.

On April 15, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela and Joon Choi arrived at Santa Maria Home and met with the Short-Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) Administrator Francine Haynes regarding an incident report received 03/05/2022 at Community Care Licensing (CCL). On 05/03/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi and Lorena Valenzuela met with Santa Maria Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Administrator Francine Haynes. The purpose of this case management is to discuss information received during a review of an incident that occurred at the facility. The incident involved Child #1 (C1). See Confidential Names List form (LIC 811) dated 05/03/2022. On 04/15/2022, LPA Valenzuela conducted a review of facility records and conducted interviews. Interviews conducted revealed that on 03/05/2022, Child #1, ingested a non-prescribed medication. Interviews revealed it is unknown how C1 obtained the non prescribed medication. Per interviews and records review, on 03/05/2022, at 6:20pm, C1 had "convulsion like actions" and "was unable to speak to staff". Interviews and records revealed Staff #1 (S1) called the facility Administrator at 6:22 pm to speak with administrator regarding C1's condition. Per records review, at 6:24 pm, facility staff called 911 for C1's medical emergency. Interviews and records review indicate staff have not received training on medical emergency response procedures or topics related to the effects of medications on children. Based on interviews and records, the Department has determined there is a preponderance of evidence the facility did not ensure that direct care staff have appropriate skills to protect the health and safety of Child #1. The facility is cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4, Section 87065.1 (a) (1) (C) Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements. An exit interview was conducted where the citation and plan of corrections were discussed. A copy of this report, LIC 809-D, LIC 811 and appeal rights was provided to Francine Haynes.

narrative: On May 6, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela and LPA Joon Choi arrived at Santa Maria Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to conduct a Plan of Correction (POC) follow up visit to determine compliance with a plan of correction (POC) plan for the deficiency cited on 05/03/2022. LPA's met with Administrator Francine Haynes. On 05/03/2022, the facility was cited for Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), Version 4, Section 87065.1 (a)(1) (c) Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements, due to the STRTP not ensuring staff have training in matters of emergency medical responses and recognizing the effects of drugs and/or medication on children. Based on observations and interviews, the POC plan where the facility was to have submitted a written plan to LPA Valenzuela on due date 5/4/2022 before 5pm, has not been completed. The facility is being assessed daily civil penalties, until the agreed POC is submitted to the Department, due to the correction not being completed by due date of 05/04/2022. A copy of this report, appeal rights and LIC 421FC was provided and discussed with Francine Haynes.

narrative: On May 19, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela and LPA Joon Choi arrived at Santa Maria Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to conduct a follow up visit to the Plan of Correction (POC) visit conducted on 05/06/2022. On December, 6 2022 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced Annual Continuation visit at Santa Maria Home Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was met at by Administrator Francine Haynes LPA Peete visited the facility on 12/05/2022 to complete inspection of the Physical Plant, Disaster Preparedness, Operational Requirements, and Emergency Interventions. At 9: AM, assisted by the Administrator, LPA began the review of five client files and (C1-C5). Based on record review the licensee did not comply with the Interim Licensing Standards(ILS) 87087(e) In every situation where children share a bedroom, the licensee shall document that the bedroom sharing arrangement ensures the health and safety of each child and that the children are compatible... This documentation shall be maintained in the child's record. The licensee did not have documented bedroom sharing arrangements for C1,C4 and C5. At 12: PM LPA began review of Core Therapeutic Services. All the documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. LPA conducted two staff interviews (S4, S5) and one client interview (C5). At the time of today's inspection, no other clients were on facility grounds. Based on observations made during the inspection, see LIC D, deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Administrator Francine Haynes.

met_with: Administrator Francine Haynes, Facility Manager Carson Brooks
narrative: On December,5st 2022 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Santa Maria Home Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was met at by Administrator Francine Haynes and Facility Manager Carson Brooks. LPA began a physical plant inspection at 9: AM assisted by the Facility Manager and Administrator. The physical plant inspection included the following checks: The facilities kitchen, dining area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, garage, living room, family room, staff office, therapy office, two client bathrooms and three client bedrooms (B1,B2,B3). Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there is one client per bed. Each client room has the appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses are in good repair. Extra linens are stored in the hall closet. Additionally, there is adequate drawer space for each client's belongings. Cleansers, chemicals, and cooking knives are inaccessible to clients. Cleaners and chemicals are locked in a cabinet in the laundry room and in bathroom two. The cooking knives are locked inside of the staff office. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of food and a variety of snacks for clients. LPA observed a minimum seven day non-perishable and a two day perishable supply of food. Additionally, LPA observed the following postings: facility license, grievance procedures, personal rights, Ombudsman poster, visitation policies, and current menu. Age appropriate toys, games and books were observed for client's recreation time. The facility's outside grounds (front yard, backyard) were also inspected and were found to be clean, well maintained, and free of observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space; all exits, and walkways were free from obstruction. Per Administrator there are no guns or weapons on facility grounds. The hot water in each client bathroom measured within 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. (Continued on LIC C) The facility has an operable carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway and smoke detectors are located throughout the facility. Fire extinguishers are properly charged, serviced, and located in the kitchen and staff office. The medications are centrally stored in the staff office inside of a locked cabinet. The First Aid Kit is complete and kept in the kitchen. The washer and dryer are located inside of the facility next to the kitchen and accessible to clients with staff assistance. Per Administrator's statement clients are supervised while they do their own laundry and LPA observed detergents are kept locked in a cabinet. At 9: AM LPA observed the licensee was not in compliance with California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80088(f)(1) ...All containers, including movable bins, used for storage of solid wastes shall have tight-fitting covers kept on the containers; shall be in good repair, shall be leakproof and rodent-proof. Trash cans were observed, without lids, in B1, B2 and B3. At 10: AM LPA began review of the Operational Requirements and Emergency Interventions, assisted by the Administrator and Facility Manager, all the documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. The facility has one vehicle used to transport clients to appointments and recreational activities. At 11: AM LPA observed multiple rips and tears in the vehicle's upholstery; placing the facility out of compliance with CCR 80074(c) Motor vehicles used to transport clients shall be maintained in a safe operating condition. At 11: AM , assisted by the Administrator and Facility Manager, LPA began review of the facilities Disaster Preparedness. The licensees Disaster Plan did not have procedures regarding the storage and perseveration of medication; placing the facility out of compliance with Health and Safety Code( HSC) 1565(a)(7)(E). A facility shall have an emergency and disaster plan that shall include, but not be limited to, all of the following: (7) Procedures that address, but are not limited to, all of the following: (E) Storage and preservation of medications, including the storage of medications that require refrigeration. At 11: AM LPA observed the Disaster Preparedness Plan did not have documentation of the annual training provided to staff regarding staff responsibilities during an emergency or disaster. The facility is not in compliance with HSC 1565(b) If a facility employs staff, the facility shall provide training on the plan to each staff member upon hire and annually thereafter. The training shall include staff responsibilities during an emergency or disaster. (Continued on LIC C) At 12: PM, assisted by the Administrator and Facility Manager , LPA began review of five staff files (S1-S5). At 1: PM LPA observed the licensee was not in compliance with Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87065.1(e)(1) ... all direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 40 hours of annual training... S1 had 21.5 of the required 40 hours of annual training. Based on observations made during the inspection, see LIC D, deficiencies are being cited. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager Carson Brooks.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Covarrubias on May 19, 2023 at 9: AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Covarrubias met with Administrator, Francine Haynes and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed five of child's records and two of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed five of child's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed two of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed zero of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication, as clients were not present. LPA will interview two children at their schools. During the inspection the LPA observed deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Administrator, Francine Haynes.

that some facility staff are aware that specific clients may be using and bringing vape pens into the facility when the contraband is found. Per confidential interviews, staff will make an effort to prevent clients from using vape pens and bringing vape pens into the facility by having regular small group meetings with the clients to address these issues. Confidential interviews reported that if staff were concerned about a specific client and their use of vape pens and bringing vape pens to the facility, then the in-house therapist would be advised to address these issues in therapy. Confidential interviews reported that if a client has shown a history of bringing in contraband or is suspected of bringing in contraband, then facility staff will conduct a search of their room. Confidential interviews reported that vape pens had been found during room searches. Per facility policy, when clients return from leaving without permission and they were recently caught with vape pens or have a history of bringing back vape pens, the staff will search their items such as shoes, dresser drawers, closets, bags, and ask the clients to empty their pockets. In addition, confidential interviews stated that staff would knock on bathroom doors if clients were taking too long in the bathrooms from what the client stated the purpose for them to be in the bathrooms. Confidential interviews also reported that these concerns were addressed in clients' updated needs and service plans. Other confidential interviews reported that when facility staff encounters a client using a vape pen, they address the behavior immediately and confiscate the contraband. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegation that staff do not prevent minors in care from using nicotine vapes in the facility is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Administrator Francine Haynes.

narrative: It was reported that staff do not adequately supervise clients at night. The Department was informed facility clients were walking around the community at all hours of the day, including the evening, up to three times during one week. Staff denied the allegation. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff revealed the facility uses an incentive-based program which affords clients the opportunity to leave the facility and return by a set curfew. Staff interviewed reported clients also leave the facility without authorization. In situations where clients leave without authorization, staff reported they follow protocol. Staff attempt to verbally redirect clients, try to obtain the location of where clients are going and shadow clients as they leave the facility until visual is lost. Upon clients return, staff reported they inquire if clients need medical attention, ask what occurred while they were away from the facility and offer clients a meal. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted indicated staff supervise clients diligently. Clients interviewed consistently reported staff follow protocol during unauthorized absences. Statements obtained from CSWs did not reveal concerns related to the reported allegation. One CSW reported her client was prone to leaving the facility without authorization. In an effort to deter the client from leaving the facility without authorization, staff reportedly reach out the clients relatives to schedule visits. The facility offered relatives traveling accommodations to be able to attend the visits. Based on information obtained through interviews conducted and records reviewed the allegation was Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative. No deficiencies were cited.

narrative: On 08/06/21 at 11:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Lofton made an announced visit to Glenwood Drive, Bakersfield, CA 93306 with the purpose of conducting a Pre-licensing inspection for the move of Scott's Youth Facility from Rancho Sierra, Bakersfield, CA 93306. LPA Lofton was greeted and allowed into the facility by Scotts CEO Robert Carter and together toured the facility. The facility will be licensed for a capacity of six (6) ambulatory female clients ages 12-17 years old and services will also be provided to non-minor dependents. The facility is a one-story home located in a residential neighborhood. It consists of three (3) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, living room, recreation room, library area, dining room and kitchen. There are other three (3) rooms that will be used as human resource office, staff/administrators' office and mental health therapy room. The facility also has a laundry room equipped with washer and dryer. Front yard and backyard are clean, maintained and free of debris. Garage is clean of any obstruction. There is a pool on the premises which has a 5 feet tall pool gate with two self-latching gate doors. Gate will always be locked, unless clients are in the pool with staff supervision. The ratio is one staff for two clients. All of the facility's staff have been certified for water safety procedures. During the inspection visit LPA Lofton observed the following: PHYSICAL PLANT 1st Floor Bedroom #1: vacant/ room and closet space Bedroom #2: vacant/room and closet space Bedroom #3: vacant/ room and closet space Room #4: Human Resource office Room #5: Staff/Administrators office Room #6: Mental Health Therapy room At the time of the inspection the house was empty pending licensing approval to move furniture from old address. All fire and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and were operational. All utilities were on available for use. Hot water temperature is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees (F). Medicine will be kept in a locked safe that will be located in the staff office and only accessible to employees supervising stored medications. There will be no firearms/weapons on the premises. Overall facility temperature in the home is maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are locked and kept in locked cabinets in the laundry room. There are three (3) fully charged fire extinguishers throughout the facility. There were no citations during this visit. Facility is ready and available for the clients to move in. This report was finalized on 8/13/2021 due technical issues with the system. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Mary Ramos.

On October 28, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zeyda Loera conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection at the facility. LPA met with Trina Smith Administrator Assistant. The facility currently has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license. The STRTP's Mental Health Program Application and National Accreditation are pending approval. The facility provides services to five (5) female children (ages 11-17) and one (1) non-minor dependents. LPA conducted a tour of the facility on October 28, 2021 at 09: AM. PHYSICAL PLANT Facility is a one (1) story home that has three bedrooms double occupancy. Bedroom are accommodating of all required furnishings. Individual beds in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Adequate supply of additional beddings and lines observed. Facility has all required posters. Adequate food observed upon inspection. In the kitchen one (1) drawer is missing and one (1) cabinet door is missing. In the master restroom, the tub has a leak. The hot water was measured at F, which was within required temperature range. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide were tested and in proper working order. Sharps items are in a locked box inside the staff office. First aid was inspected and found to be complete. All hallways and backyard were free of obstructions. The facility has a pool with a fence of five (5) feet tall. LPA observed a lock on the gate. Generally, the facility is clean, safe, and sanitary. Annual to be continue at a later date.

narrative: It revealed that another staff was in route to the facility, that the fire department was called and other staff were notified to come to the facility. The investigation revealed that on a second occasion, all the clients ran away from the facility and engaged in another physical altercation, resulting in Ref. #5 fighting Ref. #6 and the other clients jumping Ref. #5. The investigation revealed that the facility was in compliance with Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Section 87065.5(a)(2) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios, During the hours of 10 p.m. to 7 a.m., there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.

narrative: The investigation revealed statements that initials were carved into a tree in a neighbor's front yard and that clients pulled branches from a tree. It revealed that no staff interviewed were notified of complaints of vandalism. It revealed that a neighbor's son invited some clients to the neighbor's home and while at the home the clients smoked marijuana. It revealed that the facility received complaints about clients hanging in the neighbor's yard. It revealed that the staff counseled the clients not to hang out in the neighbor's yard, yet the client's would leave the facility without permission and hang in the neighbor's yard anyway. The investigation revealed that other children in the neighborhood also congregated in the neighbor's yard, not just the facility clients. All witnesses stated that the clients are supervised at the facility. It revealed that the clients have community passes. It revealed that staff re-direct clients when they leave the facility without permission and shadow them. It revealed that the staff call law enforcement if the clients do not return to the facility within three hours of leaving without permission. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.

Page The Department received a complaint alleging staff allow minors to have access to contraband while in care, alleging a staff is having an innapropriate relationship with a minor, alleging staff yell and hit minors, alleging staff are not preventing innapropriate sexual interactions between minors at the facility and alleging staff do not adequately supervise minors resulting in minors leaving the facility without permission. Staff denied the allegation that minors are allowed to have access to contraband while in care. The allegation was regarding an incident involving two residents fighting over contraband at the facility on 2/16/23 where law enforcement was contacted to stop the fight. It was alleged law enforcement did not confiscate the contraband and staff allowed the residents to have the contraband. Record review revealed law enforcement was contacted by a resident after the altercation to report assault. In addition, statements obtained confidential interviews conducted indicated that the fight was a result of a resident accusing another resident of stealing her marijuana earlier that day. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted and interviews with staff indicated that no contraband was observed or located during the incident. Staff denied the allegation that a staff is having an inappropriate relationship with a client in care. However, statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff revealed clients reported observing inappropriate interactions between a staff and client. When interviewed by the Department and another agency, all clients denied the allegation. Staff denied the allegation that they hit minors at the facility. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted revealed there are no witnesses who observed staff physically abuse clients. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff revealed staff may use a loud, stern, or raised tone of voice but, it is dependent on the behavior of the clients. Staff stated they use this tone of voice when clients are having a behavior such as arguing, fighting, or bullying another client. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted indicated staff yell at residents for insignificant incidents such as not cleaning their rooms, washing dishes, or being loud. Other clients reported staff yell when staff feel clients are provoking them or disrespectful, when clients are misbehaving, when clients are running and screaming inside the facility and when clients do not listen, act aggressively, or damage property. (Continued on page 3) Page Staff denied they are not preventing innapropriate sexual interactions between minors in the facility. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff revealed they became aware two clients were dating. Staff immediately adjusted the sleeping arrangements and actively supervised the clients if they were together in common areas. In addition, the facility did not allow the clients to visit each other's room. Staff statements were corroborated by statements obtained while conducting confidential interviews. Staff denied clients leave the facility on an unauthorized absence due to inadequate supervision. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff indicate staff verbally redirect clients when they suspect a client will leave the facility without an approved pass. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted corroborated staff statements. During the course of the investigation LPA Larios attempted to interview six placing agency social workers however, only two were interviewed. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with social workers indicated there were no concerns regarding the referral. Based on information gathered from interviews conducted and record review the allegations are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. A copy of this report and Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 6/15/23 were given to the above mentioned facility representative. Exit interview conducted. No deficiencies were cited.

narrative: It was confirmed by the HR Manager that Ref. #2 did not work at the Glenwood facility, but was hired for the Scott's Youth Facility II on Prism Way License #157806101. Ref. #3 worked at the facility without a criminal record clearance or exemption. The LPA observed that Ref. #3 had submitted to a criminal record review and initially obtained fingerprint clearances. The information was present in Ref. #3's personnel record and in the Licensing System. Guardian indicated that on May 23, 2022, Ref. #3 required a Criminal Record Exemption. Correspondence was generated and mailed to three addresses for Scott's Youth Facility, Rancho Sierra St, Bakersfield, 93306, H St., #25, Bakersfield 93301 and Glenwood Drive, Bakersfield, 93306. The correspondence indicated that Ref. #3 could not work or be present in an agency licensed by the Department. As mentioned above, the HR Manager indicated that the H St address is incorrect. The HR Manager denied receiving correspondence regarding Ref. #3 needing an exemption. Guardian indicated that on March 9, 2023, Ref. #3 was denied an exemption. The denial letter was sent to the three addresses mentioned above. The letter indicated the prohibition regarding Ref. #3 working in a licensed facility by the Department. The HR Manager provided the LPA with an Employee Status Change dated November 7, 2023 indicating that Ref. #3's employment was terminated. Based upon this information, there is evidence that Ref. #3 worked at the facility without a criminal record clearance or exemption for approximately 594 days. Based upon the previous information, it is determined that the complaint is substantiated. The complaint is valid because the standard of a preponderance of evidence has been met. It is determined that a citation be issued: The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, General Licensing Regulations, Personnel Requirements, Section 80065(i)(1). Prior to employment or initial presence in the facility, all employees and volunteers subject to a criminal record review shall: Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by law or Department regulations. - (see 809d) It is determined that a civil penalty be issued: The facility is being issued a civil penalty due to criminal background check violations prescribed by California Health and Safety Code section 1522, 1568.09, 1569.17, or 1596.871. As a result, a civil penalty of $100 per person per day for a maximum of 5 days is being assessed. A total of $500 is being assessed. The LPA conducted an Exit Interview. The licensee was provided a copy of their Appeal Rights (LIC 9058) and their signature on this form acknowledges receipt of these rights. A copy of this report was provided to the facility's authorized representative.

investigation_findings: 13On July 3, 2024, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Winston Moroney conducted a complaint inspection at the above Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with the Facility Unit Coordinator Jackie Aguilar. The inspection aimed to deliver the finding(s) regarding the complaint allegation(s). On January 18, 2024, the Community Care Licensing Division of the California Department of Social Services received a complaint from the Centralized Complaint and Information Bureau (CCIB) with the following allegation(s): The staff did not prevent inappropriate interaction between youth. This LPA conducted the investigation of the above allegation(s) and it consisted of but was not limited to a review of records, including the client's needs and services plans, medical records, and interviews with three staff members (S1, S2) on 1/30/24, S3 on 2/5/24, and 2 of 3 clients (C2, and C3) on 1/25/24. C1 declined to be interviewed, so no statement was obtained from them. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated July 3, 2024). The Following Allegation(s) were reported: 1. The staff did not prevent inappropriate interaction between youth. The team (S1, S2, and S3) have denied the accusation and highlighted their proficiency in trauma-informed care. They implement all necessary steps to guarantee a secure and healthy environment for all individuals. The team recognizes that each individual is unique and may need different approaches to de-escalate specific situations. In the incident that was reported, it began earlier in the day when C2 and C3 unexpectedly took a photo of C1, which greatly upset C1. Later, on their way back from an outing, C2 and C3 started teasing C1 about the photo taken earlier in the day. S1 stepped in by trying to redirect C2 and C3 verbally and changing the subject of conversation. Upon returning to the facility, C2 and C3 got out of the vehicle, but C1 refused to do so. After a few minutes of attempting to verbally redirect C1, S1 allowed C2 and C3 to enter the facility. However, shortly after, C2 and C3 came back out with a small mop and a hand duster, pretending to clean the vehicle and making noises to provoke C1. The team verbally redirected C2 and C3 back into the facility. Soon after, C1 got out of the vehicle and entered the facility with the team. C1 informed the team that she had called the police while in the car and falsely claimed to have been physically assaulted by C2 and C3. Later that evening, the police arrived at the facility, spoke to all the individuals involved, reviewed the driveway camera footage, and determined that no crime had taken place. The team stresses that, aside from occasional disagreements, the individuals have not had any issues with each other. Information provided by C2 and C3 further supported the above, indicating that they feel safe and satisfied living at the facility. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation(s) is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Foster Family Agency. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the STRTP Unit Coordinator. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: The investigation revealed that the facility reported incidents of Ref. #2's drug use to law enforcement and Community Care Licensing. The LPA toured the facility and observed it to be clean and sanitary. On February 2, 2024, the LPA observed the bathroom near the staff's office to be clean. On June 6, 2024, the LPA observed a staff cleaning the facility. An interview with the Administrator revealed that staff are required to clean nightly, including client bedrooms and submit pictures to management. The Administrator indicated that if staff are unable to clean at night due to supervision issues, then the morning staff are required to clean. There were statements made that there was mold in the bathrooms. The LPA did not observe mold. The staff informed the LPA that the facility maintenance repaired caulking in the bathroom and there was no mold. The LPA observed sufficient perishable and non-perishable food at the facility. The interviews revealed inconsistent statements regarding food. One client had no complaints regarding the food, another indicated they had sufficient food, but were not offered alternatives, another indicated that there was too much processed food, another client indicated that they were punished with processed foods. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. There was no preponderance of the evidence to substantiate the allegations. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.

narrative: On 9/5/ Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Dawn Mahecha and Christopher Williams made an unannounced visit to the Scotts Youth facility for the purpose of an annual required inspection. LPAs met with unit coordinator and together did a walk through of the facility. LPAs observed the following: This is a single-story residential facility located in a residential neighborhood. Facility has a human resource office, administrative office, mental health office, four (4) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, kitchen, and an attached garage. Facility has a pool that was observed to be empty. LPAs obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC Personnel and client roster · LIC C Emergency Disaster Plan · Board of Directors report, allowance log, disaster, and restraint logs. Annual compliance Review consisted of the all domains. LPAs reviewed 4 client files and 4 staff files. At the time of this inspection all smoke detectors tested audible, fire extinguishers were charged and lights/ appliances were in working order. Facility has cameras inside and outside of the facility that are monitored by human resource coordinator. Exit interview completed, LPAs observed and cited the following deficiencies. A copy of this report and deficiencies was provided to unit coordinator.

On January 26, 2024, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: four clients (see Confidential Names, LIC Ref. #2, 3, 4 and 6) at their placements on May 15, 2024, May 31, 2024, June 6, 2024 and July 12, 2024; and the Administrator Trina Smith on July 9, 2024. The LPA was unable to interview clients Ref. #1 and 5 after several attempts. The LPA toured the facility and observed the food supply on February 2, 2024. The LPA observed the restroom in the front hallway on June 6, 2024. The LPA reviewed incident reports. The investigation revealed that Ref. #2 admitted to using drugs and having them at the facility. Ref. #2 revealed that staff did not allow Ref. #2 to have the drugs, but that they hid the drugs in private areas on their person and the staff at the facility could not search them. There were statements that older clients gave drugs to younger client, who turned them into the staff. There was another statement made that older clients did not give drugs to the younger client, but that the younger client obtained drugs on their own. The investigation revealed that the facility reported incidents of Ref. #2's drug use to law enforcement and Community Care Licensing. The LPA toured the facility and observed it to be clean and sanitary. On February 2, 2024, the LPA observed the bathroom near the staff's office to be clean. On June 6, 2024, the LPA observed a staff cleaning the facility. An interview with the Administrator revealed that staff are required to clean nightly, including client bedrooms and submit pictures to management. The Administrator indicated that if staff are unable to clean at night due to supervision issues, then the morning staff are required to clean. There were statements made that there was mold in the bathrooms. The LPA did not observe mold. The staff informed the LPA that the facility maintenance repaired caulking in the bathroom and there was no mold. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. There was no preponderance of the evidence to substantiate the allegations. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: On August 8, 2024 at 5:30 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, arrived at the facility for the purpose of delivering the Complaint Investigation Report. The LPA met with Facility Manager, Kayla Taylor. This Complaint Investigation Report (LIC9099) was created to note a correction and add additional information to the report on July 16, 2024. The July 16, Complaint Investigation Report indicates that the type of inspection was a RO (Regional Office) Meeting which is incorrect. The correct inspection type was a Visit to the facility. The LPA observed sufficient perishable and non-perishable food at the facility. The interviews revealed inconsistent statements regarding food. One client had no complaints regarding the food, another indicated they had sufficient food, but were not offered alternatives, another indicated that there was too much processed food, another client indicated that they were punished with processed foods. The LPA observed the food menus. The investigation revealed that the meal menu is followed, but can be changed based upon client requests. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Page The Department received a complaint regarding alleged Neglect/Lack of Supervision by facility staff resulted in a client accessing the facility vehicle and a client sustaining injuries during a car accident. Information obtained during the course of the investigation corroborated the allegations. On 8/19/24 around 1: AM, a client was able to obtain the key to a facility vehicle and drove herself, and two other clients away from the facility. Law enforcement was contacted and the vehicle was located. The client refused to yield to law enforcement and a pursuit ensued. Ultimately, the pursuit concluded when the client drove past a red light, through an intersection and struck another vehicle. Responding deputies observed a client "pinned" inside the front passenger side of the vehicle, unresponsive and unconscious. Medical records obtained during the course of the investigation revealed the passenger sustained trauma to the head resulting in brain bleeding. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted revealed the client was able to enter the staff office through an unlocked door and obtain the key from a safe which was also unlocked. Although staff who were interviewed stated it is procedure to ensure the staff office and safe are secure, staff could not confirm that the procedure was followed on the date of the incident. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The facility staff failed to ensure the vehicle key was secure and inaccessible to clients, resulting a client stealing a facility vehicle and client sustaining injuries during the ensuing car ride. Per the new Civil Penalty laws, Health and Safety (H&S) Code section 1548(E), an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending due to the substantiated allegation. If an ECP is warranted, a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment. A copy of this report, LIC9099D and appeals rights were provided to the above mentioned staff. Exit interview conducted.

narrative: Page The Department received a complaint alleging a staff (S1) (See Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 11/20/24) threatened to hit a client (C1) with a curtain rod and punched C1. S1 denied the allegation. Confidential interviews conducted by LPA Larios did not corroborate the allegation. Although the alleged victim maintained she was punched on the face by S1, other clients did not report witnessing S1 hit C1 or reported they were aware of the allegation through hearsay. Record review revealed KCSD deputies arrived at the facility on the evening of 6/5/24 in response to an alleged battery incident and observed C1 with minor injuries to her nose and cheek. The KCSD report states no other clients or staff members witnessed the alleged incident. Based on information gathered from interviewed conducted and record review, the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the incident may have happened or is valid the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. A copy of this report and Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 11/20/24 were provided to the above mentioned facility representative. Exit interview conducted. No deficiencies were cited.

narrative: On November 5, 2024, at 10:30 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced collateral inspection to Scott's Youth Facility I Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of reviewing staff files pertaining to an annual inspection being conducted at Scott's Youth Facility II. LPA met with Mary Arriaga, HR Manager. LPA reviewed 5 facility staff files (See LIC Confidential Names list dated 10/18/24). No deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted.

An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 11/20/24 at 11: AM. During the inspection LPA Larios met with Unit Coordinator (UC) Jackilyn Aguilar. The purpose of the inspection was to issue a citation regarding a personal rights violation on a youth in placement which occurred at the facility on 6/05/24. Statements obtained from an interview conducted with staff (S1) (See Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 11/20/24) revealed that on 6/05/ S1 engaged a client (C1) in a struggle for possession of a curtain rod. S1 stated that during the struggle C1 tripped, fell backward on top of her bed, and S1 fell on top of C1 while both maintained a grip of the curtain rod. While on the bed C1 relinquished the curtain rod and S1 and C1 stood up. S1 stated she attempted to take the curtain rod away from S1 due to feeling she was going to be struck by C1. However, S1 did not state C1 swung the curtain rod in her direction. The facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) STRTP 87072(c)(1) Personal Rights. C1's personal rights were violated when S1 engaged her to take away a curtain rod in her possession which began a struggle and ultimately S1 falling on top of C1 on a bed. A copy of this report, LIC809D, LIC811 dated 11/20/24 and appeals rights were provided to the above-mentioned facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 12/10/24 at 8: AM. During the inspection LPA Larios met with Administrator, Trina Smith. The purpose of the inspection was to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) due to a client sustaining seriously bodily injury while in the care of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). On August 20, 2024, the Department received a complaint alleging a client residing at this STRTP sustained severe injuries due to staff neglect and, in addition, STRTP staff did not ensure clients did not have access to facility vehicle keys. The allegations were substantiated; the investigation concluded STRTP staff did not ensure the staff office was inaccessible to clients and did not secure a safe containing the facility vehicle key. On 8/19/24, at 1: AM, a client accessed the staff office through an unlocked door, obtained the facility vehicle key, stole the facility vehicle and was involved in a vehicle collision while driving. A passenger client suffered traumatic brain injury with multiple punctate hemorrhages, predominantly involving the anterior frontal and temporal lobes during the collision. The Department has concluded an analysis and determined that an ECP is warranted. Under Health and Safety Code section 1548 (f)(1)(C) a violation that the Department determines results in serious bodily injury as defined in Section 243 of the Penal Code, to a person receiving care at a short term residential therapeutic program, there shall be a civil penalty of $2,500.00. Under Section 243 of the Penal Code, "Serious bodily injury" means a serious impairment of physical condition, including, but not limited to, the following: loss of consciousness; concussion; bone fracture; protracted loss or impairment of function of any bodily member or organ; a wound requiring extensive suturing; and serious disfigurement. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report, Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 12/10/24, Appeal Rights and form LIC421-D(CRP) for a Civil Penalty Assessment - Death / Serious Bodily Injury / Physical Abuse were provided to the facility representative.

Interviews completed on 08/22/24 with S2 and FY2, 08/27/24-FY3,FY4, 10/14/24-S1, 03/10/25-FY1 (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated February 20, 2025). STRTP staff interviews revealed that they denied hitting or pushing the youth with a fan and stated they had no recollection of the allegation.STRTP staff explained that they have never used an object to move or physically harm a youth in their care. Four youths were interviewed as part of the investigation. Interviews with two foster youths revealed that neither witnessed the alleged incident involving S1 and a fan. One youth heard about a disagreement involving S1 but did not know the details while the other was asleep. Three out of four youths reported feeling safe in the facility and denied witnessing or experiencing physical harm from staff.One youth stated that she tried to retrieve a fan being used to cool off, and while holding the fan with S1, the back of the fan hit her stomach. Based on the statements provided by staff and other youth in the home, there is insufficient evidence to confirm that a staff member used a fan to push or hit minor in care. One staff member stated, "I do not recall the specific incident and have never used an object to harm a youth." The interviewed youth reported hearing about a disagreement but did not witness any physical altercation. Therefore, the allegation that a staff member used a fan to push or hit a youth is unsubstantiated. An unsubstantiated determination means the allegation lacks a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the violation occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and LPA Martinez provided a signed LIC 9099 to the representative.

narrative: Confidential interviews were completed on 09/20/24 with S2 and C6, 09/27/ C3 and C4, 10/14/24 with S1 (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated February 20, 2025). The investigation revealed the following: Three youth were interviewed as part of the investigation. Two youth claimed that S1 became aggressive and stated she was "going to call her friends," One youth also admitted that she became confrontational in response. Youth interviews could not recall specific details, such as who else was present, date and time of the alleged allegation. STRTP staff denied threatening or using inappropriate language, stating they could not recall the specific interaction. Staff denied any wrongdoing and stated that "youth make daily allegations towards the staff.Staff expressed facility's policies regarding respectful communication with youth placed in their care. LPA Martinez observed the video and confirmed that inappropriate language was heard. However, the recording was too dark to identify who was speaking, and LPA Martinez could not verify the date, time of the recording. At this time, LPA Martinez was unable to retrieve a copy of the recording. While the video supports that inappropriate language was used, it does not provide clear evidence regarding who was involved. Given the lack of corroborating details and the inability to verify key elements the allegations are unsubstantiated. An unsubstantiated determination means the allegation lacks a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the violation occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA Martinez conducted an exit interview and provided a signed LIC 9099 to the STRTP representative.

On June 10, 2025, at 10:30 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced Case Management - Incident inspection at Scott's Youth Facility, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on June 2, 2025. LPA met with Maria Vidales, Facility Manager. On June 2, 2025, the Department received an SIR stating that a client (C1) (See LIC Confidential Names list dated 06/10/25) had been allowed to go out after school, but was to be home by curfew at 10:00 p.m. Per the SIR, C1 called at 10:00 p.m. requesting a ride home from STRTP staff, who stated that they could not pick C1 up due to being the lone staff at the STRTP, and then proceeded to call Law Enforcement to report an unauthorized absence for C1. Based on document review, C1 called the STRTP to arrange for transportation to avoid an unauthorized absence, but was denied a ride home, instead having been reported to Law Enforcement. The STRTP was issued one deficiency under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) and one technical advisory during this inspection. Refer to LIC809D (deficiency page) and LIC9102TA (technical advisory page). Exit interview was conducted. Signed copies of Licensing Reports were provided to STRTP representative. Appeal rights explained.

On August 6, 2025, at 11:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Ashley Ruacho and John Bonilla arrived unannounced at Scott's Youth Facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPAs met with Trina Smith, Administrator. A tour of the facility was conducted, and LPAs reviewed the following domains in the Compliance And Regulation Enforcement (CARE) Tool: Physical Plant, Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention Plan, Staffing Records, Client Records, Clients with Special Health Care Needs and Core/Therapeutic Services. Physical Plant: The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions are locked in a closet and sharps are locked in the office. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked in office. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Facility has one or more carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at 72 degrees F. The hot water temperature was within the required range. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe sanitary and in good repair. ... Operational Requirements: Facility maintains a current, written plan of operation that meets licensing standards. Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. Facility maintains and implements written complaint procedures and the procedures are posted in a publicly accessible location in the facility. The board of directors regularly conducts meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. Cash resources are kept on the facility premises in a locked and secure location. Disaster Preparedness Plan: Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least every month for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, and portable register of clients. Emergency Intervention Plan: Facility maintains a monthly log of each use of manual restraints that contains all required information. The log is available for review by the Department upon request. LPAs observed documentation of Emergency Intervention Training and on-going training. Staffing Records: LPAs reviewed five (5) staff records. Staff records contain documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training. All staff subject to criminal records review are fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility at the time of the inspection. Client Records/Clients with Special Health Care Needs: LPAs reviewed three (3) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records reviewed include, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, appraisal/needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessments; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. Core/Therapeutic Services: Facility provides core services and supports to children as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and services to achieve permanency. During today's inspection, LPAs provided seven (7) Advisory Notes/Technical Violations (LIC9102TV). An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC9102TVs, LIC Confidential Names list and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative.

On 10/05/20 at 8:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Lofton made an announced video inspection to Scott's Youth Facility II located at Prism Way, Bakersfield, CA 93313 with the purpose of conducting a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Pre-licensing inspection. The inspection is being conducted via video call due to the Covid-19 pandemic. LPA Lofton got in contact with the Facility CEO Robert Carter who provided access via video into the home. There are currently no clients placed at the facility. The facility is a two-story home located in a residential neighborhood. It consists of four (4) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, living room, full kitchen, dining area, family room, garage, back and front yard and laundry room. The facility will be licensed for a capacity of six (6) ambulatory female clients ages 11 through 17 years old. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents. During the inspection visit LPA Lofton observed the following: PHYSICAL PLANT 1st Floor Bedroom #1: Administrator, Social Worker and Staff Office, client's files Living room: Study/TV/Recreation Room (desks, computers, TV, table and chairs) Kitchen: Equipped with refrigerator, stove, microwave and dishwasher. LPA observed the stove is in working order. Fire extinguisher is placed in the kitchen Family room furnished with sofas and TV Garage and Storage were medicine and cleaning supply storage. Storage has a lock. 2nd Floor Den: Staff desk/ Client homework desk. A second fire extinguisher in place. Bedroom #2: Master Bedroom- Two twin beds, drawer and closet space Bedroom #3: Two twin beds, drawer and closet space Bedroom #4: Two twin beds, drawer and closet space. Laundry Room: Washer, dryer and linen closet The facility is safe and in good repair. Passageways and porches are unobstructed. There are no bodies of water on the premises. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are locked. There are no firearms on the premises. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarm were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguishers are fully charged. Medications area will be locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. All utilities (water, gas, electricity) were on at the time of the inspection. Back and front yard was clean and free of debris. There were no citations during this visit. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Robert Carter via email for signature.

The LPA reviewed at least Law Enforcement Contact Reports (LIC624-LE) from January 2021 to May 2021 submitted to MPCRP involving Ref. #1 and #2. The LIC624-LEs indicate that staff followed procedure. One CSW revealed no concerns with supervision at the facility. It revealed that since May 2021, Ref. #1 has raised their level and no special incident reports have been received by Ref. #1's CSW. Ref. #2's CSW was recently assigned Ref. #2's case and was unable to provide a statement regarding the facility's supervision. The former CSW is no longer with their department. Based upon interviews, Ref. #1 no longer hangs out at the mailboxes. The facility put in place a plan for staff to pick-up trash left at the mailboxes. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegation. A copy of this complaint was emailed to CEO Robert Carter.
investigation_findings: On August 14, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings of a complaint investigation. The LPA met with Facility Manager, Celest Almengor. On April 22, 2021, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP) received a complaint with the above mentioned allegation. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of, but were not limited to: Administrator Assistant, Kenneth Calvin, at the facility on July 16, 2021; one client (see Confidential Names, LIC Ref. #1 dated August 14, 2021) and two county social workers (CSWs) via telephone on August 13, 2021. The LPA was unable to interview client Ref. #2, whose status is runaway since May 24, 2021. The LPA reviewed the client's Needs & Services Plan and Special Incident Reports. The investigation revealed that at least two clients, Ref. #1 and #2, were hanging out at mailboxes around the corner from the facility and leaving trash (i.e. - e-cigarettes, fast food wrappers, styrofoam cups and water bottles, etc.). It revealed that the clients at the facility are ages 12 to 17 years old and engage in teenage behavior. It revealed that other teenagers in the neighborhood hangout at the mailboxes, along with the clients at the facility. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: One CSW revealed no concerns with supervision at the facility. It revealed that since May 2021, Ref. #1 has raised their level and no special incident reports have been received by Ref. #1's CSW. Ref. #2's CSW was recently assigned Ref. #2's case and was unable to provide a statement regarding the facility's supervision. The former CSW is no longer with their department. The investigation revealed that there were statements made that when Ref. #1 and #2 ran away from the facility that they engaged in a sexual relationship with an adult male neighbor in the community who was supplying them drugs. It revealed that the individual who reported the information recanted the statements. It revealed that the neighbor's partner called Ref. #1 threatening Ref. #1 for having sexual contact with the adult male. The report revealed that Ref. #1 and #2 denied having a sexual relations with the neighbor and denied that the neighbor supplied them with drugs. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegation. A copy of this complaint was emailed to Ms. Ramos.

narrative: The allegations are that staff members engage in verbal and physical altercation with clients. All staff members and clients that were interviewed denied the allegations. No client and staff member ever witnessed any staff getting physical with a client nor have they witnessed any staff engaging in verbal altercation with a client. Interviews consistently revealed that when a client becomes physically or verbally aggressive, staff members would re-direct the client or would take the client out for a walk or drive to calm the client down. Clients that were interviewed feel safe in the facility and have no concerns regarding staff members. CSW has no concerns regarding the facility and its staff members. The allegation indicated that a staff member provoked and hit a client, giving the client a busted lip. Contrary to the allegation, a review of records revealed that the client headbutted the staff, busting the staff's lip. Based on the information gathered through interviews and record review, there is not enough evidence to corroborate the allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, the preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations were not met, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the agency representative. There were no deficiencies cited during today's inspection. (Page 2 of 2)

narrative: On October 26, 2021, Licensing Program Anakysts (LPA) Zeyda Loera and Pamela Silva conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection at the facility. LPAs met with Kenneth Calvin, Administrator Assistant. The facility currently has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license. The STRTP's Mental Health Program Application and National Accreditation are pending approval. The facility provides services to six (6) female children (ages 11-17) and non-minor dependents. LPAs conducted a tour of the facility on October 20, 2021 at 09: AM. PHYSICAL PLANT Facility is a two story home that has three bedrooms double occupancy. Bedroom are accommodating of all required furnishings. Individual beds in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Adequate supply of additional beddings and lines observed. Facility has all required posters. Adequate food observed upon inspection. The hot water was measured at F, which was within required temperature range. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide were tested and in proper working order. Sharps items are in a locked box inside the staff office. First aid was inspected and found to be complete. All hallways and backyard were free of obstructions. Generally, the facility is clean, safe, and sanitary. Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conducts meeting to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility administrator and manager are the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility should update their Emergency Disaster Plan per Provider Information Notice PIN 21-03. Facility conducts disaster drill at least quarterly for each shift. Facility maintains register of clients in their emergency plan. Staffing Records LPAs reviewed six (6) staff records. All individuals subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and signed a Criminal Record Statement. All staff completed 40 hours of annual training. Education, experience, job description, First Aid/CPR verification are on file. Client Records LPAs reviewed six (6) client records. One (1) client has no Pre-placement Appraisal on file. LPAs reviewed medication log vs. medication count and found that on one (1) client's record, the date initialled by staff did not match the current date. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff members. Two (2) clients who were present at the facility during the inspection refused to be interviewed. There were one (1) Type B deficiency ,one (1) Technical Violation (LIC9102TV) and one (1) Technical Assistance (LIC9102TA) issued during today's inspection. At the conclusion of the inspection, LPAs discussed the findings with the facility administrator. LPAs agreed to work with facility administrator to collaborate with guidance to get the facility in compliance with ILS and Title Regulations. The administrator was provided information on where to locate Provider Information Notices (PINs), guidance of the new CARES tools inspection process and Guardian. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC 809-D, LIC9102TV, LIC9102TA, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative.

narrative: On April 27, 2022 at 9: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Timika Martin and Jenny Mundo conducted an unannounced annual/required inspection at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility and met the Administrator Assistant, Kenneth Calvin. The STRTP's Mental Health Program Application is pending approval. The facility provides services to six (6) female children (ages 11-17) and non-minor dependents. There are currently 6 clients in placement. Physical Plant: At 9: AM, LPA's conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility with Administrator Assistant, Kenneth Calvin­­­­. The facility is a two-story home that has a total of (3) three bedrooms, (3) bathrooms, (1) staff office and a facility manager booth. There are three (3) bedrooms that have two (2) twin beds. There is adequate drawer, shelf and closet space for client's belongings. All beds are clean and in good repair. LPA's observed the following required posted items that are accessible to clients: Facility license, facility sketch, grievance procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman poster, Emergency Disaster Plan, daily schedule/activities, daily food menu and Covid-19 postings. The kitchen is sanitary and in good repair. LPA's observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Sharp knives and sharp utensils were locked inside of the staff office. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were tested and working. The first aid kit was checked and complete. All medications and medication logs are centrally stored and kept in a locked cabinet located upstairs in the facility manager booth located upstairs. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and other hazardous items are kept inaccessible to the clients in a locked closet. The washer and dryer are located upstairs and accessible to the clients. The facility vehicles' current insurance, registration and vehicle log were checked. The hot water temperature in the bathrooms were checked using a digital thermometer and registered at 117 degrees Fahrenheit. Each client is supplied with personal hygiene products. There were extra towels and linens for clients use in cabinets. Client Files: At 10: AM LPA Mundo reviewed four (4) client files. Documentation for each client is complete, signed and current. All medications are recorded and logged. Psychotropic medications prescribed have current JV223 court order, medical consent authorization is available for review and current in client's file. Facility is providing adequate services with the client's needs & services plan; it is current and updated. Staff Files: LPA's started to review staff and client files. LPA's obtained Personnel Summary report (LIC 500) from the facility. LPA Jenny Mundo reviewed four (4) staff files. All staff files contained the required documentation per Title Regulations. Both staff who required caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions and associations. Staff files contained the Mandated Reporter/acknowledgement form. At 11: AM LPA's conducted interviews. LPA Martin interviewed two (2) clients and two (2) staff. LPA Martin reviewed the current LIC 500, LIC 309 current Board Meeting minutes and an updated copy of the emergency disaster plan. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator. LPA provided a copy of the following reports: LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to Administrator Assistant, Kenneth Calvin.
