narrative: Staff denied the alleged allegation further indicating clients are always being supervised by three to four staff members and at times even more depending on the needs of the facility. Staff indicated that due to the facility not being a lockdown facility, clients are given the privilege of community passes upon being approved by their Social Worker or addressed on the clients' Needs and Service Plan. Furthermore, any client who is deemed AWOL from a community pass or for any other reason, staff will conduct a search and if not located will file a missing person report with local law enforcement as described in their program statement. Information obtained from clients indicated that they feel safe and that staff is always looking out for their best interests. Clients further indicated that when they AWOL staff will follow them and try to discourage them from leaving and informing them of the dangers they may face if they AWOL. Clients indicated that they are aware of what staff can and can't do and if they want to leave will leave. . Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. narrative: On 1/3/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Scotts Youth facility II for the purpose of a Case management other inspection. LPA met with Human Resource director (HR) and discussed the below identified information. Facility still utilizing a level system with STRTP: HR stated the following: Facility uses level system in identifying that children are following there programs and following rules in the home and barriers behaviors. LPA told HR that according to STRTP ILS having all children be subject to a facility's uniform rewards/punishment system isn't trauma-informed because it's not individualized care (as required by 87072.2) and it erroneously assumes all children respond to the system the same way. The facility has to make an individual assessment and take into account the child's history/trauma responses/triggers, as well as their strengths and what sort of discipline works best for them. 87001(t)(3) "Trauma-informed" means prevention services, that proactively provide program models, interventions, practices, services, and supports that acknowledge, seek to understand, recognize, and respond to the varying impacts and effects of all types of trauma on children, nonminor dependents, their families, and those who have contact with the child welfare system. In accordance with recognized principles of a trauma-informed approach and trauma-specific interventions, trauma-informed programs recognize the impact of trauma on a child's or nonminor dependent's development and implements individualized interventions to address trauma's consequences and facilitate healing, as specified in Section 87078.2. 87078. TRAUMA-INFORMED INTERVENTIONS AND TREATMENT PRACTICES (a) A program that is trauma-informed shall include curricula, training, interventions, policies, practices and procedures which include the following:(2) Prevention services, interventions, practices, services and supports that demonstrate the following:(E) How individualized strategies for trauma-specific interventions address trauma's consequences and facilitate healing, and can be implemented in components including, but not limited to, the needs and services plan and treatment plan and how these strategies are implemented by direct care staff pursuant to provisions set forth in Section 87022.1(a)(2)(D); and (F) Minimization of any potential for re-traumatization. Based on the information provided by the HR Director the Case management is Substantiated and the following information identified previously was cited. A exit interview was conducted and HR Director was provided the following appeal rights, citation and report.

narrative: The LPA was provided with copies of the videos and observed the following: In the first video The Facility Manager #5, who's back is to the camera initially, grabbed something out of Ref. #2's hand. Ref. #2 verbally responded and the Facility Manager stepped towards Ref. #2. Ref. #2 splashed what appeared to be water from a bottle onto the Facility Manager and the Facility Manager attempted to grab the bottle and Ref. #2's hands. Ref. #2 grabs the Facility Manager's hair and the Facility Manager grabs Ref. #2's hair and they began wrestling and fell onto the hardwood floor continuing to wrestle. The Facility Manager noticed and mentioned Ref. #1 video recording the incident. In the second video, the Facility Manager and Ref. #2 are still wrestling and had moved to the carpet and pulling each other's hair. The Facility Manager sat with her buttocks on Ref. #2's face. Ref. #2 asked the Facility Manager to get off of her and began to cry and stated that she could not breath. The LPA corroborated statements that Facility Manager Ref. #6 was transporting another client at the time the physical altercation. It is determined that there is at least one eye witness and video recordings of the physical altercation between the facility manager #5 and Client Ref. #2. At no time in the videos did the LPA observe the Facility Manager Ref. #5 try to avoid, walk away, call for assistance or verbally de-escalate Ref. #2. The Facility Manager #5 did not attempt to conduct a proper restraint as trained by the facility on Ref. #2. Based upon the above, it is determined that the complaint is substantiated. The complaint is valid because the standard of a preponderance of evidence has been met. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Section 87072(c)(11), Personal Rights . To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning.- (see 809d) The LPA conducted an Exit Interview and provided a copy of this report, along with a Appeal Rights and Proof of Correction to the agency representative via email. investigation_findings: On December 28, 2023 at 2:15 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings of a complaint investigation to the facility. The LPA met with Administrator, Kenneth Calvin. On August 30, 2023, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegation. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: four clients - Ref. #1 and 3 at the facility on September 21, 2023, Ref. #2 at school on October 6, 2023, Ref. #4 at their new placement on November 7, 2023; the Administrator via telephone on September 22, 2023 and December 19, 2023; Facility Manager Ref. #6 via telephone on December 28, 2023. On several occasions with no success, the LPA attempted to contact the Facility Manager, Ref. #5, who terminated their employment at the facility. The LPA reviewed two videos of the assault, a Termination Report, a Debriefing, and incident reports. The investigation revealed two videos of a physical altercation between Facility Manager Ref. #5 and Ref. #2, 11 years old, at the facility. It revealed that at least one client, Ref. #1 was a witness and recorded the video. The investigation revealed that Ref. #2 did not suffer injuries, marks or bruises due to the altercation. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Estimated Days of Completion: Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Confidential interviews reveal that the clients were observed smoking marijuana outside the facility. Clients refused redirection from staff then started verbally and physically assaulting two staff. Staff defended themselves by attempting containment and avoided further conflict by walking towards the staff office. There were no other staff or clients who witnessed the full incident, but one client recalled observing the client/victim physically assaulting a staff, and staff kicked the client to stop client's continued physical assault on staff. Clients continued with their physical assault of staff until staff was able to contact law enforcement. Paramedics responded to treat the client/victim who was bleeding from the nose and mouth when law enforcement arrived, but client refused medical care. There was no mark or injury observed on the client/victim's stomach. Additional information revealed that the client/victim was purposely hit in the face by the other client so they can put the blame on staff when law enforcement arrived. Although there is a five second video showing the client/victim with blood from the nose, it cannot be determined from the video if the client was spitting blood from the mouth or was spitting blood that dripped from the nose to the mouth. The video did not show how this injury was sustained by the client/victim. Records show that there was no indication of any physical abuse by staff to clients. Staff were protecting themselves from being repeatedly assaulted by the clients. Furthermore, there was evidence found that one of the clients also vandalized the vehicles of the staff. In regard to the alleged theft by staff, LPA was informed that the facility provides for the meals of staff who work at the facility. Staff either bring their own meals or partake from the meals they cook for the clients. Staff and clients eat together and none of the clients had any issues with this until one of the two clients involved came into placement. Interviews obtained did not provide any corroborating evidence of theft. Based on information obtained during the investigation, there was no preponderance of evidence found to support the allegations, so the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of the following reports were provided at the conclusion of today's inspection: LIC9099, LIC9099-C and LIC Confidential Names. Appeal rights were provided and explained. There was no deficiency citation issued.

narrative: Ref. #2 worked at the facility without a criminal record clearance or exemption. The LPA observed no history in the Licensing System indicating that Ref. #2's submitted fingerprints for a criminal record review. Guardian observed that Ref. #2's Live Scan was uploaded on February 8, 2023. Guardian indicated that Ref. #2 required a Criminal Record Exemption on April 28, 2023 via correspondence that was generated and mailed to Scott's Youth Facility at H St #25, Bakersfield 93301. The HR Manager indicated that all of the mail comes to the Glenwood address and that the corporate address was incorrect. Guardian indicated that Ref. #2 obtained an Exemption Approval October 23, 2023. The LPA obtained evidence that Ref. #2 worked at the facility, because the LPA conducted a telephone interview with Ref. #2 via telephone regarding a complaint against the facility dated June 30, 2023. Based upon this information, there is evidence that Ref. #2 worked at the facility without a criminal record clearance or exemption for approximately 178 days. Ref. #3 worked at the facility without a criminal record clearance or exemption. The LPA observed that Ref. #3 had submitted to a criminal record review and initially obtained fingerprint clearances. The information was present in Ref. #3's personnel record and in the Licensing System. Guardian indicated that on May 23, 2022, Ref. #3 required a Criminal Record Exemption. Correspondence was generated and mailed to three addresses for Scott's Youth Facility, Rancho Sierra St, Bakersfield, 93306, H St., #25, Bakersfield 93301 and Glenwood Drive, Bakersfield, 93306. The correspondence indicated that Ref. #3 could not work or be present in an agency licensed by the Department As mentioned above, the HR Manager indicated that the H St address is incorrect. The HR Manager denied receiving correspondence regarding Ref. #3 needing an exemption. Guardian indicated that on March 9, 2023, Ref. #3 was denied an exemption. The denial letter was sent to the three addresses mentioned above. The letter indicated the prohibition regarding Ref. #3 work in a licensed facility by the Department. The HR Manager provided the LPA with an Employee Status Change dated November 7, 2023 indicating that Ref. #3's employment was terminated. Based upon this information, there is evidence that Ref. #3 worked at the facility without a criminal record clearance or exemption for approximately 594 days. Based upon the previous information, it is determined that the complaint is substantiated. The complaint is valid because the standard of a preponderance of evidence has been met. It is determined that a citation be issued: The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, General Licensing Regulations, Personnel Requirements, Section 80065(i)(1). Prior to employment or initial presence in the facility, all employees and volunteers subject to a criminal record review shall: Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by law or Department regulations. - (see 809d) It is determined that a civil penalty be issued: The facility is being issued a civil penalty due to criminal background check violations prescribed by California Health and Safety Code section 1522, 1568.09, 1569.17, or 1596.871. As a result, a civil penalty of $100 per person per day for a maximum of 5 days is being assessed. A total of $1000 is being assessed. The LPA conducted an Exit Interview. The licensee was provided a copy of their Appeal Rights (LIC 9058) and their signature on this form acknowledges receipt of these rights. A copy of this report was provided to the facility's authorized representative.

narrative: Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged that staff caused injuries to a minor while in care. Staff denied the allegation. Staff stated that the child bruises easily due to medical condition and that child had blood drawn which caused discoloration to child's arm. Most children declined to meet with LPA, however, one child who was interviewed denied the allegation and stated that staff are always there to support children in care and denied that staff caused any injuries. It was also alleged staff were verbally abusive to a minor while in care. Staff denied the allegation and had similar statements that staff are not verbally abusive to children, but that one child has been verbally abusive towards staff and other children in the home. Staff stated they redirect children and provide support to other children but that staff continue to work with children in comments that they make to others in the home. Most children denied speaking with LPA, however, two children had similar statements of staff and stated that one child is verbally aggressive and causes problems in the home with staff and other children. Lastly, it was alleged staff are physically abusive to a minor while in care. Staff made similar statements and denied ever physically abusing a child. Staff stated that one child has been physically aggressive towards other children in the home, but that child is redirected to keep their hands to themselves. One child who was interviewed denied staff being physically abusive but had similar statements of staff that one child in the home has been physically aggressive and that staff try their best to redirect the behavior and provide support to remove the aggressive child from the situation or area. Based on information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: Staff stated that the staff in which incident occurred with child was injured and that staff was defending themselves from being attacked by children by grabbing one child's hair to stop child from hitting and stomping on them. Interviews conducted with children had similar statements and stated that a staff grabbed and pulled a child's hair and staff punching a child in the back after children threw water and condiments at staff. Additionally, children provided video documentation of staff pulling child's hair and child being on the ground. Interviews conducted with witnesses stated an ongoing problem with one staff and some children. Witnesses stated that staff communicated issues or concerns with children and that situation may have arisen from previous issues. It was also alleged facility staff physically restrained youth in care. Staff had similar statements and denied the allegation. Staff stated there was an incident that occurred where a child threw soap and water at a staff. Staff provided video footage of staff falling and staff getting up and grabbing a child from behind to prevent child from throwing another item. Staff were unable to provide a clear guideline or description of how to properly restrain a child and identified multiple ways in which children have been restrained. Interviews conducted with children had similar statements in that staff complete restraints that have ranged from pushing, wrist grabbing, floor restraints and various other restraints that are not apart of facilities plan of operation or program statement. LPA reviewed video and video did not depict a restraint being utilized in this incident however, based on interviews and information obtained staff did not properly restrain children in previous incident where staff handled child roughly. Based on the information gathered, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was met, therefore the allegation is substantiated per California Code of Regulations Title 22 - refer to LIC9099-D for deficiencies. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form, LIC 9099-D for deficiency and Appeal Rights were provided to the agency representative via electronic mail. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was provided to facility representative.

narrative: Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged staff hit client. Interviews conducted with staff had similar statements and denied the allegation. Staff stated that some children told them that one staff hit a child with a tablet during the time of an altercation. However, staff denied being present or observing staff hit any clients. Staff stated they try to talk with children and de-escalate the incidents before they have to do any sort of restraints. Interviews conducted with two of the four children had similar statements and denied witnessing staff hit child with a tablet. Children stated they were told about the incident occurring with staff but stated they did not witness incident. Interviews conducted with additional two children had similar statements and stated that one staff was trying to obtain a tablet from one child and that as staff was grabbing and pulling at tablet from child the tablet hit child in the face. Children further stated that the incident was caught on camera and clearly depicted staff hitting child. All children interviewed stated that one staff has been known to hit clients and drag clients by the hair, but children were not able to identify which client staff was hitting when or where. Interviews conducted with county social workers had similar statements and stated they were told by children in the home of an altercation between staff and a client and that staff hit client with a tablet. County social workers denied observing the altercation or observing any marks or bruises on children. LPA obtained a video from one child which showed child hitting staff and staff trying to take a tablet from child, however, video did not show staff hitting client or that staff hit client with the tablet. It was also alleged staff solicited client to assault another client. Staff had similar statements and denied the allegation. Staff stated that they do not solicit children to assault each other. Staff denied ever being told or seeing a staff give money to children to assault anyone. Interviews conducted with children varied in that one child recalled hearing or seeing a staff provide twenty dollars to a client to assault another child. Child was unable to recall which staff provided the money and what client received money or who was assaulted. Interviews conducted with additional three children denied knowing or observing interaction with staff or children. County social workers and witnesses denied knowing or receiving information regarding a staff soliciting money to children to assault anyone in or out of the home. Furthermore, it was alleged staff discloses personal information. Interviews conducted with four staff had similar statements and denied the allegation. Staff stated that they do not disclose personal or confidential information about anyone. Interviews conducted with two staff identified that one staff started a rumor about another staff not really being pregnant, however staff were unable to say who was provided the information and what information was directly disclosed. Interviews conducted with children were similar in that all children denied the allegation. Children stated they were not aware of any staff disclosing personal information or receiving any personal information from staff. Lastly, it was alleged facility is not reporting incidents. Staff had similar statements and denied the allegation. Staff stated that incidents are documented and submitted by Administrator or facility managers. Staff stated that incident reports go out with in the required time frames and that all agencies receive notification of incidents or complaints. Children had similar statements and did not know if facility staff are reporting incidents or not. Children stated that they do not disclose or report issues as they do not believe that anything will be resolved. County social workers had similar statements and stated that agency reports incidents regularly and on time and had no concerns with facility reporting. Documents reviewed identified that staff had reported incidents to required agencies and that an altercation had occurred between one identified staff and client. LPA observed no documents that identify staff being documented as being aggressive towards children or other staff. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: On October 18, 2024, at 09:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Christopher J. Williams and John Bonilla and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jean Herring arrived unannounced at Scott's Youth Facility II for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPAs and LPM met with Cecilia Ramos, A.M. Unit Coordinator. A tour of the facility was conducted, and LPAs and LPM reviewed the following domains in the Compliance And Regulation Enforcement (CARE) Tool: Physical Plant, Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Client Records, and Core/Therapeutic Services. Physical Plant: The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions are locked in a closet and sharps are locked in the office. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked upstairs. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Facility has one or more carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at 72 degrees F. The hot water temperature was within the required range. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe sanitary and in good repair. ... Client Records: LPAs and LPM reviewed five (5) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records reviewed include, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, appraisal/needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. Disaster Preparedness Plan: Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least every month for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Operations: Facility maintains a current, written plan of operation that meets licensing standards. Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. Facility maintains and implements written complaint procedures and the procedures are posted in a publicly accessible location in the facility. The board of directors regularly conducts meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. Cash resources are kept on the facility premises in a locked and secure location. Core/Therapeutic Services: Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. During today's inspection, one (1) Type B citation was issued, see LIC809D. LPAs and LPM also provided eight (8) Advisory Notes/Technical Violation (LIC9102TV). An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC809D, LIC9102TVs, LIC Confidential Names list and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative.

Allegation #1. There were statements made that the staff allow the clients to do whatever they want without consequences; that the former administrator covers for all the employees so they can't get in trouble; the clients are up all night causing ruckus and ringing the neighbors doorbells at 5:00 a.m.; a pregnant staff is constantly being punched in the stomach by a client with no repercussion to the client; and another staff member was hit in the face by a client. The former administrator is no longer at the facility and voluntarily terminated their employment due to finding another position. The investigation revealed that on one occasion, clients went to the next door neighbor to get a ball out of the yard. The CEO indicated that no one allowed the clients to hit others. There was no evidence provided that law enforcement was involved as it relates to the clients punching or hitting staff. The CEO indicated that there is a rule that law enforcement is not normally called, but they do utilize law enforcement action if necessary and MAB. Allegation #2. There was a statement that a client sleeps in the living room. The investigation revealed that Ref. #14 was sleeping in the living room on occasion, because Ref. #14 was accustomed to having their own bedroom after living in a resource home and Ref. #14 did not like their roommates cleanliness and hygiene. Allegation #3. There was a statement that the staff use facility funds inappropriately. The CEO indicated that all managers have credit cards and there are threads on each staff's telephone. The CEO indicated that all the logs go thru the CEO, Human Resources or the Administrator. Allegation #4. There was a statement that staff eat the clients food. The CEO indicated that there is a policy that the staff have to eat with the clients and if they eat out, then they are required to bring the clients the same food, unless the staff have a special dietary need. The CEO stated that there is a food budget of $700 per week. Allegation #5. There was a statement that staff discontinued a client's therapy. The investigation did not reveal any information on which client's therapy was discontinued. The CEO indicated the only reason a client's therapy would be discontinued is if the client's behavior was an issue. Allegation #6: There was a statement that staff is not qualified for position. The staff in question is the Human Resources (HR) Director. The Interim Licensing Standards has no requirements for the HR Director, who has submitted to a criminal record review and (cont'd) Allegation #7. There was a statement that the PM Unit Coordinator and the HR Director smelled like marijuana. The investigation revealed that all staff and clients denied the allegation. It revealed that the PM Unit Coordinator was pregnant at the time and denied the allegation. It revealed that the HR Director denied the allegation, does not work out of the facility and does not allow clients at their personal home. Allegation #8. There was a statement that staff are not performing their duties. The investigation revealed no evidence to support this allegation. Allegation #9. There was a statement that clients records are not safeguarded. The investigation revealed no evidence to support this allegation. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegations. There was no preponderance of the evidence to substantiate the allegations. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Moroney conducted an investigation into the previously mentioned allegations. This investigation encompassed a thorough examination of various records, including the children's needs and services plans, medical documentation, incident reports, restraint logs, and interviews with four staff members: S1 and S3 on November 26, 2024; S2 on January 29, 2025; and S4 on February 4, 2025. Additionally, two of the three clients, C2 and C3, were interviewed on January 23, 2025, along with two County Social Workers, CSW1 on January 22, 2025, and CSW2 on January 24, 2025. It is important to note that no statement was obtained from client C1 due to their absence without leave. (Refer to Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated February 7, 2025.) The Following Allegations were reported: 1. A staff member hit a minor while in care. The Staff (S1, S2, S3, and S4) refuted the claims, asserting that all personnel are trained in trauma-informed care and recognize the significance of fostering a safe and healthy atmosphere within the facility. They noted that there have been no observations of staff mistreating clients, nor have any clients reported instances of misconduct by staff members. Additionally, S1 emphasized that all staff have received training in the Management of Assaultive Behavior (MAB), which is utilized only as a final measure to avert self-harm by clients or serious injury to others. 2. Staff not adequately supervising minors resulting in minor engaging in physical altercation with another minor. The Staff (S1, S2, S3, and S4) refuted the claims made, asserting that there are consistently two or more staff members present to uphold the staff-to-client ratio of 1:4. By adhering to this standard, the staff is able to swiftly address any concerns that may emerge, thereby guaranteeing that all clients obtain the necessary assistance and support customized to their specific requirements. 3. Staff not adequately supervising resulting in minor AWOLing. The staff members, namely S1, S2, S3, and S4, denied the allegations, asserting that they do not operate as a locked facility and that clients are free to leave at their discretion. S1 elaborated that through interactions with clients, staff can deter AWOL behavior by providing verbal guidance and emphasizing the significance of fulfilling their personalized plans, as well as the potential risks associated with leaving the facility. Additionally, the staff offers a variety of activities and seeks to understand the underlying reasons driving a client's desire to be absent without leave (AWOL). All occurrences of AWOL are reported promptly to the relevant support agencies. Furthermore, the accounts given by C1 and C2 corroborated the above information, indicating that they are receiving adequate support from the staff and feel safe residing in the facility. The statements obtained from CSW1 and CSW2 affirmed that they have no concerns regarding the care and supervision provided to their clients, and their clients have not reported any incidents of misconduct by the facility staff. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation(s) are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation(s) occurred, therefore the allegation(s) are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the STRTP Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the STRTP Administrator.

The Following Allegation was reported: 1. A staff member hit a minor while in care. The Staff (S1, S2, S3, and S4) refuted the claims, asserting that all personnel are trained in trauma-informed care and recognize the significance of fostering a safe and healthy atmosphere within the facility. They noted that there have been no observations of staff mistreating clients, nor have any clients reported instances of misconduct by staff members. Additionally, S1 emphasized that all staff have received training in the Management of Assaultive Behavior (MAB), which is utilized only as a final measure to avert self-harm by clients or serious injury to others. 2. The staff members (S1, S2, S3, and S4) denied the allegation, asserting that they were unaware of any such incident occurring and that no client has ever reported such an event to them. S1 emphasized that her team maintains a strong rapport with clients and ensures a safe and healthy atmosphere. The staff noted that while they generally adopt a hands-off approach, they have previously intervened to physically separate clients and escort them to different areas of the facility. Clients C2 and C3 both stated that they had not observed or heard of any staff member mistreating any client. 3. Staff inappropriately restrained a minor. The staff members (S1, S2, S3, and S4) denied the allegations, asserting that all personnel have received training in the Management of Assaultive Behavior (MAB), which is employed solely as a last resort to avert self-injury or harm to others. They further explained that an incident involving C1 transpired after her return from AWOL while under the influence of an unidentified substance. During this incident, staff attempted to confiscate contraband, prompting C1 to bang her head against the door. In response, the staff positioned themselves in front of the door to prevent any potential head injury and subsequently arranged for C1 to receive a medical evaluation from Bakersfield Paramedics. S1 noted that the incident was reported to the relevant supporting agencies without delay. Furthermore, the accounts given by C2 and C3 corroborated the above information, indicating that they are receiving adequate support from the staff and feel safe residing in the facility. The statements obtained from CSW1 and CSW2 affirmed that they have no concerns regarding the care and supervision provided to their clients, and their clients have not reported any incidents of misconduct by the facility staff. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation(s) are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation(s) occurred, therefore the allegation(s) are found to be unsubstantiated. narrative: ...page Complainant was unable to be interviewed. CSW and five (5) staff were interviewed. Three (3) out of five (5) youth were interviewed (See confidential names list LIC 811 dated June 18, 2025). The investigation revealed the following: It was alleged that staff did not prevent a minor from being physically assaulted by another minor and that staff threatened a minor. It was revealed that during a birthday party or celebration event at the facility home, a youth made comments to other youth that were celebrating. These comments were taken as negative by some of the youth in the home. There was a fight that ensued between three (3) youth. After the fight occurred, there was a staff of the facility that threatened to have their child come up to the facility or a youth's school to fight them. LPA reviewed documents including incident reports and notes that revealed the altercation between youth. All three (3) youth interviewed confirmed the fight. One (1) out of three (3) youth interviewed confirmed that a youth was threatened by staff. LPA interviewed five (5) staff, and all five (5) staff were aware of the altercation between youth. Staff interviewed did not hear the threat made from staff to youth. Staff were interviewed and said that the fight was broken up when first made aware. Further, staff said that the allegation of staff threatening a youth was not known until a week after the fight, during a CFT meeting. Staff admitted that the statement made by the youth was not reported to CCL, and only reported to the County. Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were provided to A.M. Unit Coordinator No deficiencies cited. Exit interview was conducted.

narrative: Interviews completed on 02/06/25 with C1, R1,R2,R3. On 02/07/25 interviewed C3 and on 04/09/25 interviewed C2. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated August 26, 2025). The Department investigated allegations that staff at the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) failed to seek medical treatment for a minor, threatened to confiscate the minor's personal item, and did not administer prescribed medications. Three (3) staff members were interviewed for the investigation. 3 staff reported that the youth was offered over-the-counter medication and that an appointment for medical care was arranged the following day. Three (3) out of five (5) youth were interviewed. Interviews were consistent in reporting that staff intervene appropriately during peer altercations, provide over-the-counter medication when needed, and do not confiscate phones or threaten to remove them. Three youths described feeling safe in the home and being able to communicate their needs to staff. The principal youth of the investigation reported receiving over-the-counter medication and being transported to urgent care. Records review confirmed that no incident reports were generated by STRTP staff. Stakeholder reports revealed that the principal youth was being provided over-the-counter medication when she felt ill, and that staff transported her to urgent care. Based on the interviews and records reviewed, the allegations are unsubstantiated. The evidence demonstrates that staff responded to the youth's medical concerns by offering over-the-counter medication and arranging follow-up care through urgent care services. Neither interviews nor records supported claims that staff threatened to confiscate the youth's personal belongings or failed to administer prescribed medication. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA Martinez conducted an exit interview and provided a signed LIC 9099 to the facility representative.

narrative: On 02/02/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheraki Davis and Natasha Dunlap conducted an SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection and met with Facility Administrator Keyneica Jones. The inspection was conducted via tele-inspection using video conference due to COVID-19. A virtual health and safety inspection was completed and no immediate deficiencies were observed. narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore conducted an annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) on June 22, 2020. LPA and LPM met with the facility administrator Colette Miller and the executive director Keyneica Jones. The facility was toured inside and out with facility administrator, Colette Miller. The home is a two-story residence with three bedrooms, two and half bathrooms and facility staff office with additional storage. Two clients, the administrator and the executive director were present at the facility during the inspection. The home was approved for six non-ambulatory clients age 13-17. The bedrooms were arranged so that there was one client to a room, and there was one client per bed. Client 1 and 2 were in room #1, client # 3 was in room #2 and client #4 was in the room #3. There were two vacant beds. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. Clients had adequate hygiene supplies stocked in the closet in the staff office. Facility grounds were clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There were adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/games/ books were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were in appropriate working order, fire extinguishers were properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. The hot water was measured to be F degrees. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The kitchen had adequate cooking supplies and utensils. All required forms were posted including the Grievance Procedure, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are stored and locked and centrally stored in a lockbox located in the staff office. Licensee did not have provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Facility had cameras in common areas of the facility. Per facility administrator, there were no firearms or weapons in the facility. (...) ***This is an amended report from June, 23, 2021*** Administrator Colette Miller is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs four Social Workers, two facility managers and 11 direct care staff. Licensee is in the process of obtaining Mental Health Certification and has been in communication with San Bernardino County regarding the time frame. Licensee anticipates receiving the mental health certification by June 30, 2021. Licensee has not obtained National Accreditation through CARF. The CARF Accreditation survey has been scheduled from January 5, 2022 through January 7, 2022. LPA discussed the following with Administrator: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings including an overview of the required core services and supports. Based upon the facility records and interviews with staff and clients, Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and core services/supports requirements. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Personnel files were maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in staff office. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index checks clearances and exemptions. A review of client records was also completed on this date. Client and staff interviews were conducted and there were no health and safety concerns. The facility was issued a technical violation due to LPA and LPM observing that the facility did not provide locked containers for client's contraceptives. No deficiencies were noted in the areas during time of inspection. Facility appeared to be meeting the terms and conditions of the license.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz conducted an unannounced case management inspection on April 13, 2022, at 3: PM. LPA met with facility staff, Colette Miller, to address information obtained during a review of an incident that occurred on or around April 6, 2022, involving Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) as identified on the Confidential Name List (LIC 811) dated April 13, 2022. LPA reviewed the staff and client files on April 13, 2022, at 2: PM. During LPA's inspection of the staff files on April 13, 2022, LPA noted that the facility had not obtained a criminal record clearance for staff #1 (S1). Facility staff confirmed that S1 had not obtained a criminal record clearance to work at the facility prior to working. Based on records review, confidential interviews, and observations, S1 did not have a fingerprint clearance. Therefore, the facility is being issued a citation for fingerprint/criminal record clearance violation of Title Regulations 80019(e)(1) Criminal Record Clearance. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report along with LIC 811, LIC 421BG and appeal rights were provided to Colette Miller.

On April 28, 2022, at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz met with facility administrator, Colette Miller, to discuss an incident that occurred involving client #1 (C1) and staff #1 (S1) see LIC 811 confidential names list dated April 28, 2022. LPA obtained supplemental information regarding facility not reporting an incident that occurred on or around January 18, 2022. The incident involved an allegation of physical abuse of C1 by S1. This incident was not reported to the Department. During interviews with confidential witnesses, it was reported that S1 pushed C1 and C1 discloses this information to facility staff during a Child and Family Team Meeting. According to facility records, and confidential witness statement the serious incident report (SIR) was not reported to the Department. Based on facility records and confidential interviews, the facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the California Code of Regulations (CCR) section 80061(b)(1)(G) Reporting Requirements. Facility staff neglected to report an incident involving S1 possibly physically abusing C1. This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to children placed in care. An exit interview was conducted, and appeals rights explained to Colette Miller. A copy of this report and the LIC D was provided to Colette Miller.

Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that staff #1 (S1) pushed client #1 (C1) and S1 called C1 names may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. narrative: During the investigation, confidential witnesses stated that they had not witnessed staff at the facility hit any clients. In regard to the allegation that S1 and C1 engaged in a physical altercation, confidential witnesses stated that C1 attacked S1 and S1 attempted to evade C1. CSW added that C1 had a history of making allegations to be moved to a different facility. Other confidential witnesses stated S1 slapped C1 on the face after finding C1 engaging in inappropriate activity in the backyard. Furthermore, confidential witnesses revealed that C1 was antagonized by S1 which resulted into a physical altercation between C1 and S1. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that S1 hit C1, S1 antagonized C1 and S1 engaged in a physical altercation with C1 may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Kanayo Aikpaojie.

During LPA's visit to the facility LPA found that the facility did not have a facility manager on site when children were present. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7. On July 10, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside and out with facility administrator Keynecia Jones. The home is a residence with 4 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. 3 clients were present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the kitchen was measured to be 117 degrees. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in the closet in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the staff office in a closet.Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked in the staff office. The First Aid Kit is located in the staff office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector was operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Keyneica Jones. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and current menu. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the staff office closet in a locked cabinet. The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Two clients were interviewed and indicated that they feel safe in the home and accorded their personal rights. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The side gates were closed and had a latch on them. Client and staff files were reviewed during the inspection. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, are no deficiencies found at this time. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, conducted an unannounced case management inspection on December 1, 2023, at 9: AM. During the inspection, LPA met with facility manager Jeanette Hefner. The purpose of the inspection was to address deficiency observed on facility grounds during a review of an incident that occurred on or around September 6, 2023. LPA inspected the facility on September 14, 2023, at 9: AM. During LPA's inspection LPA observed trash on both sides of the facility and LPA found the garage unclean and unsafe. Facility will be cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7. Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Articles 1 through 10, Version 4 87087(a) Building and Grounds. Based on LPA's inspection the preponderance of evidence standard has been met that the facility was not clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times, for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report along with LIC 809D, and appeal rights were provided to Jeanette Hefner.

On April 3, 2024 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jason Dalton arrived unannounced at Search Light Center for Healing, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), and met with Administrator, Melissa Dalziel, Administrator . The purpose of this visit was to conduct a collateral inspection to interview client #1, C1 (see Confidential Names List Form 811), regarding an open investigation on the client's previous placement. LPA conducted a confidential interview with one client. A copy of this report was given to Administrator, Melissa Dalziel.

Additionally, during LPA inspection of the facility LPA observed a broken mini fridge and cardboard boxes on the side of the facility. Furthermore, confidential witnesses informed LPA that the mini fridge and cardboard boxes had been on the side of the facility for several weeks. Based on confidential interviews and inspection observations, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that the facility did not replace minor's bed frame in a timely manner and the facility was unkept. Therefore, the allegations are substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards version 5, 87088(c)(1) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies and Title 22. Division 6, 80087(c) Building and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 9099d was provided to Jeanette Hefner. During the investigation, there was no corroborating evidence to support the above allegations. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements. Confidential witnesses informed LPA that facility staff provided all the clients backpacks and all the necessary school supplies. Additionally, LPA was informed that two clients C1 and C3 sold the backpacks that they were provided online and when the facility offered to replace the backpack, C1 declined the offer. Other confidential witnesses stated that the facility provided the clients with some of the necessary school supplies but no all the school supplies. Regarding the allegation that the facility did not prevent mold from growing in the refrigerator confidential witnesses informed LPA that the facility kitchen and refrigerator were always clean, and mold had not been observed in the refrigerator. Additionally, LPA was informed that clients were asked to clean up after themselves but if they failed to do so staff would clean. Other confidential witnesses informed LPA that they had observed mold in the refrigerator. LPA observed the kitchen and refrigerator to be free from mold. In regard to the allegation that the facility was not providing mental health care to the clients, confidential witnesses informed LPA that the facility had mental health care staff available to the clients. Additionally, LPA was informed by confidential witnesses that mental health services were offered to the clients but many of the clients refused the services. Another confidential witness informed LPA that some clients were offered mental health care services and other clients were not. LPA received conflicting information regarding this allegation. In relation to the allegation that facility staff did not cook dinner for the clients. Confidential witnesses informed LPA that facility staff always cooked for the clients and staff attempted to follow the menu as closely as possible. Other confidential witnesses informed LPA that the facility staff would not always cook and would encourage clients to cook dinner but some of the clients did not like when their peers cooked the meals. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that the facility did not supply a client with school supplies (backpack), there was mold in the kitchen refrigerator, the facility was not providing mental health care to the clients, and facility staff did not cook dinner for the clients may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. (...) An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Jeanette Hefner.

narrative: On July 9, 2024 at 11: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jason Dalton arrived unannounced at Search Light Center for Healing, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), and met with Jeanette Hefner, Senior Facility Manager. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a collateral inspection to interview client #1, C1 (see Confidential Names List Form 811), regarding an open investigation on the client's previous placement. LPA conducted a confidential interview with one client. A copy of this report was given to Senior Facility Manager, Jeanette Hefner.

On July 17, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Maya Chavez and Joon Choi conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside and out with facility administrator Melissa Dalziel. The home is a residence with 4 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. 3 clients were present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the kitchen was measured to be 113.3 degrees. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in the closet in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the staff office in a closet. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked in the staff office. The First Aid Kit is located in the staff office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector was operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by the administrator Melissa Dalziel. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and current menu. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the staff office closet in a locked cabinet. The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Three staff and one client were interviewed. Client indicated that they feel safe in the home and accorded their personal rights. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. At 10:40AM administrator led LPA Chavez on a walk through inspection of the facility. At 11:20AM LPA and administrator reviewed the facility's operational requirements. At 11:10AM LPA and administrator reviewed the facility's disaster preparedness. At 11:20AM LPA and administrator reviewed the facility's emergency intervention plan. At 11:30AM LPA and administrator reviewed the facility's core therapeutic services At 11:40AM LPA and administrator reviewed the facility's special health care needs protocol. During inspection LPA Choi interviewed three staff and one client, two clients denied to be interviewed. Client and staff files will be reviewed during the follow up inspection. Based on the facility inspection and review of program statement, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report and a technical assistance was reviewed and given to facility representative, Melissa Dalziel.

On April 30, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero arrived at the facility to conduct an interview regarding an incident unrelated to this facility. LPA met with Facility Manager Jermaine Jordan who granted LPA access to the facility. A copy of this report was provided to Jermaine Jordan.

On 03/02/2023 at 10:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia made arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection on the Seneca Compass-Ventura: Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1) who granted access to the Conference Room and an inspection was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 03/02/23. The annual fees are current. The Seneca Compass Ventura program is licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) clients, ages 12-17, ambulatory only. The program provides intensive, individualized assessment and diagnostic treatment services for youth who do not meet the criteria for a psychiatric hospitalization but require treatment to stabilize their high-risk behaviors. Most youth placed into the Seneca Compass Program come directly from the 23-hour Crisis Stabilization Unit (CSU), where they have received immediate psychiatric assessment and stabilization services following an acute crisis. The residential program is one component of a larger continuum of care for youth in crisis, which include the 23-hour CSU, mobile crisis response services and community-based transition support services. There are currently 2 clients residing at the facility. Seneca Family of Agencies "The Seneca Compass Program", in partnership with Ventura County Behavioral Health Department (VCBHD), provide Short-term Assessment and Residential Treatment to six (6) children for thirty (30) days or less. This is a Commercial Building owned by the by the County of Ventura located in a residential area facing the main street. The National Accreditation through Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF) valid extended through November 20, 2024. The Mental Health Approval is affected date September 22, 2022 and expires September 22, 2023. There are no bodies on water on the premises. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. Report continues on LIC809-C, page 1 out of The facility was equipped as follow and the following was observed during the Inspection: Bedroom #1: Currently is not occupied. There are two (2) full size beds. The room has adequate drawer space, closet and lighting, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. Bedroom #2: Currently is occupied by client #1 (C1). There are two (2) full size beds. The bedroom has adequate drawer space, closet and lighting, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. Bedroom #3: Currently is occupied client #2 (C2). There is one (1) full-size bed and one (1) twin size bed; The room has an adequate drawer space, closet and lighting, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. Bathrooms/Showers: There is one bathroom with a toilet only and two bathrooms with showers only located in hallway outside of bedroom area. All bathrooms are clean, safe and operable. Storage Hallway Closets: There are four closets located in the hallways near the bedroom area and near the shower areas. Two closets were set to store linens, comforters, and pillow, two closets were set to store supplies. There are adequate linen supplies. Dining Area/Group Training-Meeting Room: There is adequate table and chairs for meals. Training-Meeting room is adjourned to the dining area. There is an accessible fireplace with a secured cover on in the dining area. Kitchen/Pantry Food/Storage: There is a commercial kitchen on the premise. There is a stove/oven with operable burners all working properly now. There is a microwave and commercials refrigerator/freezer. The food service in the facility is adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. Sharp knives are kept lock on combination safe. Nurse/Medication Office/Meds Storage Room: There is an area for medication storage and medication will be administered by staff. There are locked cabinets, and a refrigerator for medication. Facility maintains medication logs and first aid kit in this room. The first aid kit is checked and is complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and 1st Aid Manual. The door to this room always remains locked. Report continues on LIC809-C, page 2 out of Living Room/Lounge Activity Room: The living room, located in the corner of the hallway adjacent to Bedroom #3, is equipped with living room furniture and a powder room with toilet and sink only. The lounge activity room adjacent to the other side of Bedroom #3 is equipped with adequate living room furniture, desk/chair, books and activity games. Office: This is an office that is being used by the clerical staff. There are two (2) computers, health information and medical billing treatment information is kept in this office. Equipment Room: Only janitorial supplies will be stored in this room. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in this room and in the hallway as well. Staff Office: Is located by the alley main back entry and is equipped with four (4) computers, camera monitors, private bathroom with toilet and sink only. There is also a sitting lounge small area with a sofa and chair. Laundry Room: There is a washer and dryer located in the hallway near the showers. The doors were observed to be locked and made inaccessible to the youth unless supervised by staff. Cleaning solutions are observed to be locked in this room. Common Corridor: There are two sets of double doors, one set of double door lead to the Crisis Stabilization Unit and the other set of double doors lead to the Crisis Stabilization Unit area but both doors are locked always. The lobby area where the receptionist is located is used by Seneca as the main entrance. There is an entrance leading from the lobby area into the Dining Area/Training-Meeting Room that is used by the STRTP. There is no shared hallway area between the Community Treatment Team and the STRTP. Outside Patio Area: The patio is located out the exit doors from the Training/Meeting Room. There is sufficient space. There is no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. There are additional doors leading into the dining area. There are also two doors that lead to staff offices of the 23 hours Crisis Stabilization Unit; these doors will always remain locked and not used by the STRTP. The Backyard/Front yard is clean and free of all debris. Report continues on LIC809-C, page 3 out of Alarm/Carbon Monoxide/Fire Extinguishers: There are carbon monoxide alarms available on three different hallways (bedroom hallway, shower hallway and nurse medical hallway) and another alarm was also located in the dining/meeting room area. The facility is equipped with a pull-up alarm system throughout the facility. The system is checked by the County on monthly bases. LPA reviewed the monthly report which indicates that the alarm system is tested on June 30, 2022, and is in working order/PASS. There are four (4) operable Fire Extinguishers available in the facility. One is in the hallway near the bedrooms' area, two in the kitchen area, one in the reception area by the main entrance. Cameras and Delayed Egress Doors: There were a total of 11 cameras located in the entire facility. There were 10 cameras inside the facility (3 cameras by the bedroom hallway, 1 in the patio area, 2 in the dining/meeting room area, 1 in the tele-psych room, 1 in the reception area, 1 in the kitchen hallway, 1 in the hallway passing the kitchen area, 1 inside the back entrance and 1 outside the back entrance). The monitor is installed in the staff office, but staff has no access to view any videos. The Administrator, Program Director and the Head of Service are the only staff in charge who have access to the videos. The cameras are non-audio and LPA observed no monitors in the staff office during the inspection. Per the Administrator, the cameras record about two (2) weeks' worth of footage before rewriting over itself, onto a server, which is only accessible by password, by the Administrator, and the Executive Director. The back-up hard drive server is located in a locked IT room. There is a camera waiver on file. Clients in care are supervised and protected always. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passage ways, stairways, inclines ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants/poisons are inaccessible. Facility posts child's rights if licensed to provide foster care for six or more children. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. Clients can use the telephone unless restricted by court order and are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Clients can contact CCL or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment. Report continues on LIC809-C, page 4 out of LPA Rosas reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Rosas requested the following forms for review, Register of Youth (LIC 9020), Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC610C), Emergency Evacuation Plan and Emergency Disaster Plan including log that drills were conducted every six months. In addition, staff weekly schedule, Oxnard Fire Department Annual Licensed Care Inspection letter . Staff Records Review: LPA reviewed five (5) staff records stored in individual personnel file/binders provided by S1. LPA ensured to thoroughly review the records of the primary active staff (i.e Program Administrator, Facility Manager, and three (3) Mental Health Counselors). LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that Direct Care Staff Ratio present for the two (2) clients in placement. LPA confirmed that all staff have required criminal record clearance. DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response; which meet qualification. Administrator provided evidence of staff training transcripts that are store on Seneca Institute for Advanced Practice portal. Staff files are kept digitally and hard file are kept in Head Quarters Offices in Northern California. Clients Records Review: LPA reviewed two (2) clients records which meet qualification. Staff Interviews: LPA conducted a confidential interview with one (1) on duty staff. Client Interviews: LPA conducted confidential interviews with two (2) clients present during the inspection. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 02/27/2022 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. LPA Rosas by email send the following PINS to S1 by email: PIN 22-06-CCLD Guardian Background Check Best Practices, PIN 22-07-CCLD Guardian Webinar For Licensees and Providers, PIN 21-20-CRP Statewide Launch Of New Inspection Tools For Children's Residential Licensees. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility. Page 5 out of 5
