The door to this room always remains locked. Continue on 809-C (Page 2) Living Room/Lounge Activity Room: The living room, located in the corner of the hallway adjacent to Bedroom #3, is equipped with living room furniture and a powder room with toilet and sink only. The lounge activity room adjacent to the other side of Bedroom #3 is equipped with adequate living room furniture, desk/chair, books and activity games. Office: This is an office that is being used by the clerical staff. There are two (2) computers, health information and medical billing treatment information is kept in this office. Equipment Room: Only janitorial supplies will be stored in this room. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in this room and in the hallway as well. Staff Office: Is located by the alley main back entry and is equipped with four (4) computers, camera monitors, private bathroom with toilet and sink only. There is also a sitting lounge small area with a sofa and chair. Laundry Room: There is a washer and dryer located in the hallway near the showers. The doors were observed to be locked and made inaccessible to the youth unless supervised by staff. Cleaning solutions are observed to be locked in this room. Common Corridor: There are two sets of double doors, one set of double door lead to the Crisis Stabilization Unit and the other set of double doors lead to the Crisis Stabilization Unit area but both doors are locked always. The lobby area where the receptionist is located is used by Seneca as the main entrance. There is an entrance leading from the lobby area into the Dining Area/Training-Meeting Room that is used by the STRTP. There is no shared hallway area between the Community Treatment Team and the STRTP. Outside Patio Area: The patio is located out the exit doors from the Training/Meeting Room. There is sufficient space. There is no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. There are additional doors leading into the dining area. There are also two doors that lead to staff offices of the 23 hours Crisis Stabilization Unit; these doors will always remain locked and not used by the STRTP. The Backyard/Front yard is clean and free of all debris. Continue on 809-C (Page 3) Alarm/Carbon Monoxide/Fire Extinguishers: There are carbon monoxide alarms available on three different hallways (bedroom hallway, shower hallway and nurse medical hallway) and another alarm was also located in the dining/meeting room area. The facility is equipped with a pull-up alarm system throughout the facility. The system is checked by the County on monthly bases. LPA reviewed the monthly report which indicates that the alarm system is tested on February 7, 2025, and is in working order/PASS. There are four (4) operable Fire Extinguishers available in the facility. One is in the hallway near the bedrooms' area, two in the kitchen area, one in the reception area by the main entrance. Cameras and Delayed Egress Doors: There were a total of 10 cameras located in the entire facility inside and out. There were 8 cameras inside the facility (3 cameras by the bedroom hallway, 1 in the patio area, 2 in the dining/meeting room area, 1 in the reception area, 1 in the kitchen hallway, 1 in the hallway passing the kitchen area, 1 inside the front entrance and 1 in the lobby. The monitor is installed in the staff office, but staff has no access to view any videos. The Administrator, Program Director and the Head of Service are the only staff in charge who have access to the videos. The cameras are non-audio and LPA observed no monitors in the staff office during the inspection. Per the Administrator, the cameras record about two (2) weeks' worth of footage before rewriting over itself, onto a server, which is only accessible by password, by the Administrator, and the Executive Director. The back-up hard drive server is located in a locked IT room. There is a camera waiver on file. Clients in care are supervised and protected always. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passage ways, stairways, inclines ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants/poisons are inaccessible. Facility posts child's rights if licensed to provide foster care for six or more children. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. Clients can use the telephone unless restricted by court order and are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Clients can contact CCL or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment. Continue on 809-C (Page 4) LPA Gomez reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Gomez requested the following forms for review, Current Census, Register of Clients, Personnel Report (LIC 500), and Facility sketch. Staff Interviews: LPA conducted a confidential interview with two (2) on duty staff. A review of the Guardian Report on 02/18/2025 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. Client Interviews: LPA conducted confidential interviews with one (1) client present during the inspection. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with the Facility Administrator and a copy of this report was emailed to the Facility Administrator. End of Interview (Page 5)

On 8/24/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required visit. LPA Hiett met with Program Director Aowyn Soane and inspected the facility, inside and out. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Front and backyard are safe and free from hazards. All passageways are unobstructed. There are no bodies of water. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom. All bedrooms have adequate closet and drawer space. The home is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Sharps are kept locked in the kitchen cabinets and toxins are kept locked in cabinets in the kitchen. Medications are kept double locked in the staff office. There are carbon monoxide and smoke detectors throughout the facility. There were operable fire extinguishers in the facility. There are complete first-aid kits located in the facility. Applicant understands that the hot water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. There are no firearms on the property. Personal rights, license, Complaint Procedures, and Emergency disaster forms were posted in the facility. Menus and Activities are not currently posted as there are no clients, but facility will post as soon as that occurs. 5 staff files were reviewed. As there have been no clients present in 3 years, no client files were reviewed. The Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve three clients ages 12-17. There are currently no placements. Day 1 of Annual Inspection completed 8/24/2021 at 3:27pm. Day 2 of Annual Inspection resumed on 8/26/2021 at 11:50am and was completed at 4:30pm. 2 deficients were cited for Title CCR 87064(b) ADMINISTRATOR QUALIFICATIONS AND DUTIES and CCR 80066(c) PERSONNEL RECORDS (see 809-D). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

On April 18, 2022 at 9:45AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia, LPA Lisa Schlembach and LPA Lisette Valenzuela conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with Lauren Crutsinger, Executive Director, Greg Rideout, Chief Program Officer, and Delaney Messner, Lead Health Information Specialist, and Aowyn Soane, Administrator. This is a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program for a capacity of one. It is a an apartment on the second floor that consists of one bedroom, one bathroom, living room, lounge and kitchen. Seneca Family if Agencies (agency) will utilize a laundry cleaning service for client's laundry. Agency will utilize a food delivery service for groceries. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There are no bodies of water on the facility premises. Fire arms are not allowed on the facility premises. Medications will be centrally stored and locked in lounge closet. Disinfectants, sharps, and other toxic materials will be locked in the lounge closet. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguisher located in the kitchen and outside the front door. Smoke detectors are throughout the house and operational. Carbon monoxide detector is combined with the smoke detectors. The bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 118 degrees Fahrenheit. This site is ready for licensure, once the fire clearance is received. Agency will supply 2 days of perishable and 7 days of nonperishable food prior to any placement. LPA Pavia will mail a copy of the license to the site location, once licensed.

On 11/2/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Manager of Operations Delaney Messner and Assistant Director Miles Jordan and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool to complete this inspection. LPA interviewed one resident and five staff and toured the facility site. The facility is clean and organized, and the kitchen and bathroom are sanitary. The kitchen is stocked with food in good quality and in a quantity to meet the needs of resident in care. Medication is stored where inaccessible to resident in care, and medication administrator records are correct and up to date. Resident has their own room, with their own bed and personal storage space. The facility has the license, emergency plan, facility sketch, personal rights, and menu posted. A continuation visit will be required to complete this inspection. No deficiencies were found during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Manager of Operations Delaney Messner, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

This report was amended on October 18, 2023. On 4/21/23 at 12:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Miles Jordan Manager of Operations Delaney Messner and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE inspection tool was used to conduct this inspection. LPA conducted a tour of the facility site and reviewed the current LIC 500. A visit will be conducted at a later date to continue this inspection. LPA observed the facility to be clean and living spaces organized. Medications are stored safely and securely. The kitchen contained a variety of food in the quantity and quality to meet the needs of the resident in care. The following requires follow-up. LPA observed the hot water in the bathroom to reach a temperature above the permitted range of F to F. The hot water in the bathroom measured 123. F, and hot water in the kitchen measured 128. F. LPA is issuing a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 80088. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator and Manager of Operations Delaney Messner.

met_with: Cody Ward, Scott Seymour, Carrie Maddox
narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Lisa Slusher and travelled to the facility listed above to conduct an annual inspection. Met at the facility by Facility Manager Cody Ward and Social Worker Carrie Maddox. The facility listed above is accredited through the joint commission and is in the process of finalizing their current review, and has current Mental Health Program Approval through Mariposa County Mental Health . Arrived at the facility at 9:30 am. At the start of the inspection, LPA discussed procedures for psychotropic medication, current census and other administrative questions. The following were observed upon inspection of the physical plant inspection conducted at 10:30 am : 1. Facility Grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. 3. Chemicals appropriately locked. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications. 5. First aid kit complete with appropriate manual observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. 8. The house has 3 bedrooms, one single occupancy, one with a waiver for a maximum occupancy of 3. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. 10. Weekly menu posted and accessible to clients. 11.Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 12.Facility has two full restrooms in the house for client use. 13.Appropriate forms posted in view of facility clients. 14.No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The following items were discussed and reviewed by LPA during Inspection 1. LIC Reviewed to ensure appropriate staffing ratios, including Administrator, Social Work personnel, and Direct Care staff. 2. Administrator Jerry Lura is present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week. 3. Personnel files reviewed (11) at 1:00 pm during today's inspection to ensure staff meet regulatory requirements. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. All staff are verified to have appropriate emergency intervention training and training hours are within regulatory guidelines. 4. Client files reviewed on this date (4) from 10:45 am-11:45 am. The following are to be updated and submitted to CCL by 12/20/21- LIC 500 (Personnel Report), LIC 9020 (Client Roster), LIC 308, LIC 309, individual staff training records and board meeting minutes for 2021.. No deficiencies noted in areas observed. Client (2) and staff (3) interviews conducted. No deficiencies noted in areas observed.

narrative: On March 19, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd visited the Short Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and reviewed an incident with Jerome Johnson and Shadi Ahmad as it was reported to Licensing. Facility Name: SIERRA VISTA-HUNTER HOUSE IR File Name: LopezL.031424.R.FN.pdf Incident Type(s): Restraint; Other Link to Record: 0000367-FN Facility Name: SIERRA VISTA-HUNTER HOUSE IR File Name: Duran-SotoA.030424.R.O.FN Incident Type(s): Restraint Link to Record: 0000334-FN IR discussed forFacility Sierra Vista Hunter for client Preston Peternell -Brown (DOB 4/28/10) in which he stated another client visited his room after night shift started. Administrator Shadi stated that they have two night shift on staff and they have now set expectations that one staff will remain in the living room, which is in the middle of the home, and the alternate staff will take care of the cleaning and other duties that is expected of night staff. Shadi also stated that they are now going into rooms and required to see the flesh of the child in the bed, not just a lump under the blanket. Shade stated that they have added a motion camera in the living room facing the kitchen, so they can verify movements at night.Restraints and Discipline Policy was discussed with staff. Staff stated that restraint time was about 1 minute for 367-FN and Discipline Policy needs to be clear for clients per 334-FN. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: On the above mentioned date, Licensing Program Analyst,(LPA) Brinae Pointer traveled to Sierra Vista Hunter House, Short Term Residential Placement to conduct a case management. LPA was notified by the AD of their being an exchange between C1 and another youth throwing their plate at the wall, and C1 spilling their food onto the dinner table and escalating, which resulted in a hold. AD informed LPA of them having new hires that are learning how to document, as well as account for the entirety of all accounts leading to the event. Staff did indicate that a secondary food option was provided and informed LPA the youth are given a snack called "Last Call" that is either protein based or fruit. This information was written on the initial received Incident Report (IR). LPA was informed the Facility doctor and psychologist have advised the STRTP not to offer certain youth seconds of dinner due to weight gain and health concerns no later than August 27th, 2025 end of day. The facility will resubmit the IR with the missing information including the I-ESCAPE debrief. C1 was interviewed separately. AD was interviewed separately. LPA collected restraint logs, Needs and Services Plans,weight logs for youth of concern and Copies of all Incident Reports for C1 since arrival. narrative: An announced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 03/12/2021 at 9am and met with Case Manager Daisy Prasad. Direct Care Staff Chou Yang gave LPA a tour of the home both inside and out. Present during the inspection were Direct Care Staff Monica Martinez, Chou Yang and Daisy Prasad. LPA requested documents from the facility on 03/03/2021 by emailing the administrator Jennifer Duarte a document request checklist .The facility submitted plan of operation, program statement and medication training on the same date 03/03/2021. The facility began to submit client documents via email on 03/09/2021 due to technical difficulties according to Miriam Castellon who submitted client and staff documentation. LPA Segura reviewed client files on 03/10/2021, on that date LPA Segura identified that there were LPA Segura reviewed client files and found items missing for all three clients. The facility did not submit copies of the Assessment Needs and Services Plans, JV223/220s, Centrally Stored log, and Psychotropic Medication Administration log. LPA replied via email to Miriam on 03/10/2021 2:04pm with a word document indicating which pieces of information were still missing. On the same date Miriam submitted some of the requested documents. LPA Segura received the Assessment Needs and Services Plans on 03/10/2021; however, the documents were not signed or had a written authorization by the county social worker or probation officer. On todays date 03/12/ LPA received a copy of the centrally stored medication logs and JV223s; LPA Segura did not receive all of the Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMAR); however, Daisy Prasad was able to show LPA Segura via video feed that the facility is maintaining the PMARs. Continued on 812c During the medication count at 12:25pm, conducted with Daisy Prasad ; LPA Segura detected that the facility had not logged M3 for C1 (Medication 3, Child 1; see LIC 811 confidential names list LIC811 dated 03/12/2021) into the centrally stored log. LPA Segura advised daisy that although the medication is normally an over the counter PRN. In this case it is being prescribed as a psychotropic medication subject to court approval and should be treated as any other psychotropic medication. See Technical Violation LIC9102 dated 03/12/ LPA advised the facility on documenting court approved medication. LPA reviewed three file reviews of children who are taking psychotropic medication at the facility. LPA conduct two interviews with the clients C1 and C2 on 03/10/2021 at approximately at 4pm via Microsoft Teams and an interview of C3 on 03/12/2020 at approximately 3:45pm. LPA Reviewed three staff files and interviewed the same three staff via MS Teams on todays date beginning at 9am. One deficiency was observed and cited from the California Code of Regulations Title 22 during this inspection. LPA conducted exit interview with Tim Mathews director of Foster Family Division of Sierra Vista Child and Family Services at 3pm. Appeal rights and a copy sent along with this report. LPA provided the Summary Report to Tim Mathews and Daisy Prasad via email. A read receipt was requested as acknowledgement that the facility received the report.
LPA Daiquiri Boyd went to the main office of Sierra Vista and observed staff files and training records. No violations were found on this day.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd visited Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Sierra Vista Woodbridge House, for the purpose of discussing concerns with the safety of clients Mariah Nunez-Lara (DOB 3/30/11) and Heaven Charleston (DOB 8/12/10). Staff was able to confirm with LPA that clients are kept on opposite ends of the home for sleep, clients are supervised at all times while in the home. Night staff is doing bed checks for clients, to ensure they are safe an in their beds. Facility staff stated that the school is also aware of the concerns and has enacted a plan for safety as well. Staff Blanca stated that the CFT for Heaven was held recently and there is a plan for her to move up to a resource home and she has already made a few visits to get to know the family. Client Mariah has also had a CFT, but the plan going forward for her is not known at this time. Staff said that Kristine Rae at the main office, will be able to give further details on how the plan for Mariah is going. Staff Clarissa Ochoa stated that when there is an incident between the clients, it had come up between the clients at a team meeting with all the clients at the home. Staff Clarissa said that the girls are receptive and understanding when everyone talks together. Staff Clarissa stated that the girls have asked to be able to hang out once again, but staff told them that for now they need to continue to work the plan in place and see how things go. Staff assured LPA that they are continuing their efforts for the safety of these clients and the others in this home.

It was alleged that on 12/22/2020, C1 was "beat up badly" by another client in the group home whose name is unknown. narrative: On July 14, 2021 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Hamilton and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore conducted an annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on 08/19/2021. LPA was met at the facility by Facility Manager II Debra Kennedy and later joined by Facility Manager III Sherrae Smith. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked closet in the staff office. Licensee did not have provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client's bathroom was measured to be 113 degrees. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. The facility has an exception on file to use the cameras and are meeting the terms and conditions. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Based on observations the facility is being issued a technical violation of Title 22, Chapter 7.5, version 3.1, Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87075(b)(1)(A) Health Related Services. The licensee shall ensure that all prescribed medications, with the exception of contraceptives, are centrally stored, as provided in California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80075. (1) Licensees shall continue to ensure the health and safety of all children in the facility. (A) The licensee shall provide the child with a locked container in which to store their contraceptives. The facility is also being issued a technical violation of , STRTP ILS section 87075(b)(1)(A)(1) Health Related Services (1) There shall be more than one key to the container. One key shall be given to the child and the others shall be kept by short-term residential therapeutic program staff. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager III Sherrae Smith.

On July 15, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Hamilton and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore continued an annual inspection. The purpose of the continuance was to review the facility's staff and client files and conduct staff and client interviews. LPA and LPM was met at the facility by Administrator Gina Melendez. Administrator Gina Melendez is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one therapist and 10 facility managers. Licensee has obtained a Mental Health contract with San Bernardino County. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF). The Accreditation is valid through December 31, 2021. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0.00. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Based upon the inspection of facility records and interviews with staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained on-site in a locked closet in the front living area. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have not received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. A review of client records was also completed on this date. Client and staff interviews were conducted and revealed no health and safety concerns. Based on records review the facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Chapter 7.5, version 3.1, Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87075 (c ) Health Related Services and section 87065 (f)(2) Personnel Requirements. The facility is also being cited for violation of Title 22, Chapter 6 section 80019(d) Criminal Record Clearance. Also , the facility was issued a technical violation of Title 22, Chapter 7.5, version 3.1, Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87095.61(f) Documentation and Reporting requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights was explained and provided to Administrator Gina Melendez.

On August 12, 2021, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Cindy Hamilton returned to the facility to follow-up on a Plan of correction (POC) that has not been received by Community Care Licensing (CCL). LPA Hamilton met with Sojourners Haven Group Home II Administrator Gina Melendez. The Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) was cited on July 15, 2021 at 9:24 am for Personnel Requirements (f) The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when one or more children are present: (1) The facility manager shall meet one of the following requirements prior to employment: Prior to assuming the duties and responsibilities of the facility manager, the individual shall complete a minimum of one hour of training as specified in Section 87065.1(a), in addition to training required in Sections 87065.1(c) and (d). When the citation was issued at Sojourners Haven Group Home II, LPA Cindy Hamilton and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore met with Facility Manager III Sherrae Williams and Administrator Gina Melendez in person and discussed that the POC was to provide staff #3 and all facility managers with the necessary training for the facility manager position. The proof of training and training content was to be provided to CCL by August 2, 2021. CCL did not receive the POC. Based on the failure to correct the deficiency issued on July 15, 2021, a civil penalty of $100 per day beginning on August 3, 2021, and will continue to accrue at $100.00 per day, until deficiency is corrected. A copy of this report along with LIC Civil Penalty Assessment were provided to Administrator Gina Melendez.

A copy of this report was provided to Executive DIrector.

to hit C1. Confidential witness interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Additional conflicting information received via confidential witness interviews was that S1 was not witnessed "putting hands up" at C1 as though S1 was going to hit C1. narrative: On June 30, 2022 at 9:19AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Adaleyci Caballero and Rafael Enriquez conducted an unannounced required two year inspection and met with Administrator Elizabeth Meyer. LPA disclosed the purpose of the visit and was granted entry into the facility. Two clients and two staff were present in the facility during the inspection. The facility is a three-bedroom, three-bathroom house composed of an office, den, and living room area. One bathroom is for staff use. Administrator Elizabeth Meyer accompanied LPAs inside and out of the facility inspection. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following areas: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked closet in the staff office. First aid kit had all supplies. Licensee had contraceptives individually locked in containers by clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client's bathroom was measured to be 115 degrees Fahrenheit. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. The facility has a waiver on file to use the cameras and are meeting the terms and conditions. LPAs will continue the required two year inspection in another day due to time restraint.

Confidential witnesses stated that the air conditioning (AC) was not working since September 6, 2023, and the facility staff was not working to fix the issue. The confidential witnesses added that a company fixed the AC after September 6, 2023, but two days later the AC broke again, and the facility had not done anything to fix the issue. CSW3 stated that she had visited the facility recently and the facility temperature was comfortable. CSW4 stated that she visited the facility on September 19, 2023, and it was not uncomfortably hot. Other confidential witnesses stated that the facility was working to fix the AC and had several different companies attempt to fix the problem. Additionally, LPA was informed that portable AC units had been ordered for the clients' bedrooms. Regarding the allegation that the facility was purchasing spoiled fruit, confidential witnesses stated that the facility purchased fruit that was of low quality and would mold within a day of being purchased. Other confidential witnesses stated that the facility would purchase fruit that the clients did not eat and would eventually mold. Additionally, LPA was informed that all moldy and spoiled fruit was thrown out. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that the facility was 86 degrees Fahrenheit due to the air conditioning unit not working and the facility purchased fruit that was spoiled may have occurred, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Sherrae Smith.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, conducted an unannounced case management inspection on November 17, 2023, at 12: PM. During the inspection, LPA met with facility manager II Kieera Anderson. The purpose of the inspection was to address information obtained during a review of an incident that occurred on or around October 9, 2023. LPA reviewed facility and staff files on October 10, 2023, at 12: PM. During LPA's record review of staff files, it was noted that the facility never obtained a criminal record clearance for staff #1 (S1) (Refer to LIC Confidential Name List dated 11/17/23). Facility will be cited for violation of Title Regulations 80019(e)(2) Criminal Record Clearance. Based on LPA's record review the preponderance of evidence standard has been met that S1 did not obtain a criminal record clearance. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report along with LIC 809D, LIC 421B, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to Kieera Anderson.

On August 29, 2024, at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Velasquez conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection of facility. The walkway was easily accessible and there was a concrete sidewalk leading up to the front door. The home has a wooden fence around perimeter and is located on a corner lot. LPA was greeted by Sherrae Smith, Administrator, and shared information regarding annual inspection to be conducted. LPA was welcomed into the facility; LPA was led into an office for conducting review of staff and client files. Partial Staff and client files were reviewed. Additional time to review staff and client files is needed and will be performed on another day, as well as physical inspection of premises, operations, disaster preparedness, emergency intervention, and client and staff interviews. Due to time constraints, this annual inspection will be continued on a different day. A copy of LIC809, and LIC811 was given to Sherrae Smith, Administrator.

Regarding the allegation that staff did not allow C1 to participate in religious activities, it was specifically alleged that religious activities were not being followed and C1 requested to be in a new placement to practice Ramadan (fasting). A confidential interview stated that C1 was allowed to practice religious activities in the home. The confidential interview revealed C1 had the space in the home to practice religious activities. Another confidential interview did not feel comfortable practicing religious activities in the home. The confidential interview revealed that it was difficult to practice religious activities around those who were not from the same religion. A confidential witness believed C1 wanted to be in a home set up with same religious practices. Based on confidential interviews and observations, the allegations that staff did not allow C1 to participate in religious activities may have occurred, however, they were not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation. Therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to STRTP Administrator Sherrae.
investigation_findings: 13On November 4, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Sojourners Haven Group Home II, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with the facility administrator Sharrae Smith. to deliver investigative finding involving the STRTP. On May 29, 2024, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging staff did not allow minor to participate in religious activities. On June 5, 2024, (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at the STRTP to initiate the investigation and conducted interviews with facility manager 1 and Client 1 (C1). Additionally, LPA interviewed Administrator 1 (A1). LPA was unable to interview County Social Worker (CSW). UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Regarding the allegation that facility did not provide a safe environment for the resident, a confidential interview did not elaborate an environment deemed unsafe for the clients. Confidential interview disclosed that C1 did not want to be in the room with a roommate due to C1 engaging in inappropriate conducts. A confidential witness revealed C1 had contraband in the room, therefore C1 was avoiding being in the room with the roommate. The confidential witness believed the facility was a safe place for C In regard to the allegation that staff engaged in verbal altercation with the resident, it was not specified what was verbal altercations. A confidential interview stated that C1 repeatedly cursed staff whenever C1 was reminded by staff to complete a task. The confidential witness revealed C1 was did not respect staff when C1 was told to complete chores, and they did not observe staff engaging in a verbal altercation with C1. Regarding the allegation that staff made inappropriate comments to C1, a confidential interview stated staff always made positive and encouraging comments to C1. Another confidential interview did not receive any reports in the past regarding staff making inappropriate comment to C1. A confidential witness did not hear staff make inappropriate comments to C1. A confidential interview maintained that staff made inappropriate comments toward C1. LPA didn't receive additional information. The allegation that staff did not keep C1's information confidential, it was not specific what information was revealed. A confidential interview was not sure what information was revealed but believed staff kept all C1's information confidential. Another confidential interview was not sure what information was revealed and was unable to provide additional information. LPA wasn't able to gather additional information. Regarding the allegation that staff withheld mail from C1, it was specifically stated that staff withheld C1's mail from C1. A confidential interview explained that C1's mail was not delivered at the time C1 was asking staff for the mail. Confidential interview further explained that when the mail was delivered, it was handed to C1. Additional confidential interview stated that all C1's' mails were always delivered to C1 as soon it was received, however, a confidential interview believed that C1's mail was not handled appropriately. In regard to the allegation that staff yelled at C1, a confidential interview stated that staff did not yell at C1. The confidential interview added that staff used a firm tone to communicate. Another confidential interview was not sure staff yelled during communication with C1. Other confidential witnesses didn't provide relevant information. Regarding the allegation that facility did not provide C1 with nutritious foods, it was specifically alleged that the food was mostly junk food. A confidential interview stated there were variety of food in the home. The confidential interview added that C1 was allowed to select from many choices of food available in the home. Another confidential interview stated there was always adequate food in the home. Regarding the allegation that staff did not ensure that C1 had appropriate sleeping arrangements, it was specifically stated that C1 was in the living room; C1 was currently sleeping on the couch. A confidential interview stated that C1 shared room with a roommate but C1 refused to sleep in the room. The confidential interview stated that C1 did not want to sleep in the room due to C1 not feeling safe. Another confidential interview believed C1 did not want to have a roommate. Confidential interview believed C1 was safe in the room but did not want to sleep there due to personal reasons. LPA received a conflicting information. In regard to the allegation that staff harassed C1 while in care, a confidential interview stated that staff did not harass C1. Confidential interview stated C1 did not like to be told what to do. Another confidential interview believed staff did not harass C1. The confidential interview revealed C1 misinterpreted information regarding being reminded to complete chores. Based on confidential interviews and observations, the allegations that facility did not provide a safe environment for C1, staff engaged in verbal altercations with C1, staff made inappropriate comments to C1, staff did not keep C1's' information confidential, staff withheld mail from C1, staff yelled at C1, facility did not provide C1 with nutritious foods, staff did not ensure that C1 had appropriate sleeping arrangements, staff harassed C1 while in care may have occurred, however, there were not a preponderance evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to STRTP Sherrae Smith.

narrative: In regard to the allegation that facility staff do not provide minor with dignity and respect, it was specifically alleged that STRTP staff do not listen to client #1(C1) and laughs at C1. It was also reported that STRTP staff refer to C1 as a "spoiled brat" and C1 does not receive emotional support at the STRTP. A confidential interview stated that STRTP staff are not disrespectful to C1. The same interview reported that the staff that had called C1 a "spoiled brat" no longer works for the STRTP. One confidential interview reported hearing staff call C1 a "spoiled brat." Another confidential interview stated denied ever witnessing anyone talk to any client in that manner at the STRTP. Facility staff stated that there have not been any reports of staff being disrespectful to C1 or name calling. One last interview denied witnessing name calling in the STRTP. County social worker stated that C1 has not reported staff laughing at C1, but they know C1 has a history of hearing voices, having illusions, and seeing things. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that facility staff do not provide client #1(C1) with dignity and respect may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the alleged violation. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and Appeal Rights were provided to Sherrae Smith.

allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Regarding the allegation that A1 yelled at C1 in care. A confidential interview stated C1 was not yelled at. The confidential interview stated A1 was on the phone with C1 communicating and encouraging C1 to stay calm. Another confidential interview stated C1 was having behaviors. The confidential interview stated C1's behavior of yelling woke other clients up. Additional confidential interview stated C1 was yelled at while being talked to. The additional confidential interview added A1's voice was perceived as yelling. In regard to the allegation that staff don't treat C1 equally, a confidential interview stated C1 was treated like everyone else. The confidential interview stated facility staff treated everyone equally. Another confidential interview stated C1 did not feel treated equally. The confidential interview stated staff gave more attention to other clients than C1. Additional confidential interview stated staff always respected and treated C1 well. The additional confidential interview added C1 was never treated differently than others. The allegation that staff did not safeguard C1's personal belongings, a confidential interview stated C1's personal belongings were well guarded. The confidential interview added that C1 was not telling the truth. Another confidential interview stated C1's personal belongings were missing. The confidential interview stated C1 could not find C1'shirt. Additional confidential interview stated staff was always available. The additional confidential interview added that staff provided 24 hours of supervision in the home. LPA received a conflicting information. Regarding A1 threatened C1 in care, a confidential interview stated C1 was not threatened. The confidential interview stated A1 was talking over phone with C1, but A1 did not threaten C1. Another confidential interview stated C1 was threatened. The confidential interview added that A1 mentioned calling the police. Additional confidential interview did not hear staff threatening C1. The additional confidential interview stated staff were trained well and would not threaten C1. In regard to the allegation that staff were not meeting C1's dietary needs, it was specifically stated that A1 does not purchase foods that C1 can eat for C1's diabetic diet. A confidential interview stated there was adequate amount of food in the home. The confidential interview added that C1 was not on any prescribed dietary specific food and there was variety of food to pick from. Another confidential interview stated C1 was not provided the type of food C1 can eat. The confidential interview added C1 was pre-diabetic and C1 should not eat the same as others. Regarding the allegation that staff were not meeting C1's medical needs, it was specifically stated that C1 needed to get back on C1's medication as C1 could not focus on anything, and the staff were not taking C1 to get C1's medication. A confidential interview stated an appointment was made for C1 to see the doctor. The confidential interview added that C1 was taken to the doctor on appointment day. Another confidential interview stated C1 was not taken to the doctor on a timely basis. The confidential interview stated C1 wanted to be taken to the doctor before the appointment date. LPA received a conflicting information. Concerning the allegation that staff made an inappropriate comment towards C1 in care, a confidential interview stated all staff were trained to treat clients with respect. The confidential interview added that staff were always respectful when dealing with C1. Another confidential interview did not state or define what inappropriate comment was. The confidential interview stated C1 did not get spoken to the same way as other clients. The confidential interview added that other clients got better treatment than C1. Additional confidential interview stated C1 was always treated equally. The additional interview stated that staff may be firm with C1 during behavior episodes, but staff remained professional when talking to C1. Based on confidential interviews and observations, the allegations that A1 yelled at C1while in care; staff don't treat C1 equally; staff did not safeguard C1's personal belongings; staff threatened C1 in care; staff are not meeting C1's dietary needs; staff are not meeting C1's medical needs; and staff made an inappropriate comment towards C1 in care may have occurred, however, there were not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811 along with appeal rights were reviewed and provided to STRTP Administrator Sherrae Smith.
investigation_findings: 13On June 27, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Sojourners Haven Group Home II, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with the facility manager II Deborah Kennedy to deliver investigative finding involving the STRTP and clients as listed on the Confidential Name List (LIC 811). On May 23, 2025, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging that staff yelled at a minor in care; staff don't treat minors equally; staff did not safeguard minor's personal belongings; staff threatened a minor in care; staff are not meeting minor's dietary needs; staff are not meeting minor's medical needs; and staff made an inappropriate comment towards a minor in care. On May 30, 2025, (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at the STRTP to initiate the investigation and conducted interviews with Client 1, 2, 3 (C1, C2, C3). Additionally, LPA interviewed Staff 1 (S1), Administrator 1 (A1). LPA was unable to interview County Social Worker (CSW). UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: In regard to the allegation that stating staff does not assist C1 with intervention, behavioral goals or mental health plan, confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews revealed that staff is as helpful as staff can possibly be in assisting C1 or any client with their programs; whereas other confidential interview disclosed that staff are not helpful at all. Confidential interviews also indicated that specific details and examples were unable to be provided to LPA regarding the allegation. In regard to the allegation that staff does not treat C1 fairly, it was alleged that staff is rude and dismissive to C1 and that staff told C1 that C1 was "being sneaky" and "manipulative". Confidential interviews revealed that staff treat all clients fairly and with dignity and respect. In addition, confidential interviews revealed that they had not witnessed staff tell C1 that C1 was "being sneaky" or "manipulative"; whereas another confidential interview revealed that they were told that C1 was described as such but was not advised by whom C1 was called these things. OCI had no issues or concerns with the care, supervision or treatment being provided by the STRTP. Based on confidential interviews, allegations that staff does not assist C1 with intervention, behavioral goals or mental health plan and staff does not treat C1 fairly, may have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. This report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator Tabitha Murray for signature. The signed report will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On February 11, 2021 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Hamilton contacted Sojourners Haven Group Home III (STRTP) Administrator Tabitha Murray to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. Due to COVID-19 a tele-inspection was conducted via Facetime. On November 10, 2020, LPA conducted a health and safety tele-inspection and no hazards or concerns were observed. LPA also requested pertinent documentation from GH client and facility files. The investigation included interviews with two of six clients, three staff and the Facility Administrator. LPA Hamilton made multiple attempts to reach county social worker for Client #1 (C1), but the social worker did not respond to LPA's requests for a call back. LPA Hamilton also attempted to conduct tele-interviews with C1, Client #3 (C3), Client #4 (C4) and Client #5 (C5) but all the clients declined to interview with LPA. On November 4, 2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations stating staff does not assist C1 with intervention, behavioral goals or mental health plan and staff does not treat C1 fairly. narrative: residents and facility does not provide a safe environment for C1. In regard to the allegation that staff did not assist C2 with a health event in a timely manner, it is alleged that during the period January 10 - January 16, C2 had a seizure, C1 yelled for help two or three times and staff did not respond timely. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews revealed that none of the clients have ever been denied medical attention in a timely manner; whereas another confidential interview revealed staff did not respond timely when another client alerted staff that C2 was having a seizure. Confidential interviews also revealed that staff was not alerted by anyone of C2's seizure but it was discovered as staff did their rounds. In regard to the allegation that staff did not treat C1 with dignity and respect, it was alleged that Staff #1 (S1) treated C1 inappropriately by rolling S1's eyes at C1, mumbling things under S1's breath, nagging C1, shutting a door in C1's face and other things to irritate C1. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that all clients are treated with dignity and respect by all staff at the facility; whereas another confidential interview disclosed that staff always "mistreat, single-out and make it seem like C1 is a bad person". In regard to the allegation that C1 was bullied by C3, C4 and C5, it was alleged C3 was being bullied by C3, C4 and C5 and staff did not do anything about it. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that C1 was not bullied by any of the other clients; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed C1 had an issue with C4 and staff conducted a conflict resolution session with both clients. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed of an incident where C1 was threatened by C5 and C4 and staff de-escalated the situation and kept C1 safe in the staff office. In regard to the allegation staff did not adequately supervise residents, it was alleged that staff did not check on C1 after C2 had a seizure. Confidential interviews disclosed that the STRTP was utilizing correct direct care staff/child ratio as regulated in STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Confidential interviews also disclosed that staff adequately monitor clients and staff do routine checks throughout the STRTP. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed to LPA that after C2's seizure, the Administrator spoke with C1 regarding incident and to check on C1; whereas other information received stated that staff did not check on C1 and C1 stayed in room most of that day. CSW had no issues or concerns regarding STRTP. In regard to the allegation that the facility does not provide a safe environment for C1. It was alleged that C1 was threatened by another youth and felt unsafe in the STRTP. Document review disclosed that C1 spoke with social worker, advised social worker that C1 did not feel safe and requested a new placement. In addition, C1 was relocated to another STRTP within two hours. Confidential interviews disclosed to LPA that all the clients feel safe in STRTP and staff ensure the STRTP is safe for all staff and clients. Based on confidential interviews and document review, the allegation that staff did not assist C2 with a health event in a timely manner, staff did not treat C1 with dignity and respect, C1 was bullied by C3, C4 and C5, staff did not adequately supervise residents, and facility does not provide a safe environment for C1, may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator Tabitha Murray for signature. The signed report will be placed in facility file.

narrative: On 05/25/2021 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheraki Davis conducted an SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection and met with Administrator Gina Melendez. The inspection was conducted via tele-inspection using video conference due to COVID-19. A virtual health and safety inspection were completed and no immediate deficiencies were observed. All files and medication documents were sent to LPA Davis on dates prior to inspection. A medication count was also conducted via video conference on this date. LPA reviewed two facility staff records and two client records for this facility. LPA began two client interviews via video conference at 11: AM LPA began two staff interviews via video conference at 10: AM. LPA conducted an exit interview with Gina Melendez, Administrator. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA scanned and emailed this LIC 809 & LIC 811 to Gina Melendez, Administrator with a request for signature. On July 7, 2021 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cindy Hamilton, Jazmond Harris and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore conducted an annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on 08/20/2020. LPAs and LPM were met at the facility by child care worker Onelda Avila. A physical plant inspection was completed at 12: PM and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in locked cabinet in the upstairs staff office. Licensee did not have provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client's bathroom was measured to be 105 degrees. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. The facility has an exception on file to use the cameras and are meeting the terms and conditions. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrators Gina Melendez and Tabitha Murray were not present at the facility at the time of inspection. Staff schedule and staff interviews revealed that the Administrators are not at the facility for a minimum of 20 hours a week. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs eight direct care/facility managers. A review of client records was also completed on this date and deficiencies were observed. Client #1's (C1) (see Confidential Names List, LIC 811 dated July 7, 2021) file did not have a Needs and Services Plan which poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care. Client interviews were conducted and did not reveal any health or safety concerns. In addition, during the facility inspection the facility was unable to provide copies of the Board of Director's meeting minutes. Other deficiencies were observed: technical violations and deficiencies will be assessed. A case management inspection will be conducted at a later date to complete the annual inspection. Exit interview was conducted and deficiencies were advised.

narrative: On July 9, 2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cindy Hamilton, Jasmond Harris and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore continued an annual inspection. The purpose of the continuance was to review the facility's staff files. LPAs and LPM was met at the facility by case manager Erica Brown. At time of previous inspection Administrators Tabitha Murray and Gina Melendez were not present and upon further record review it was determined that Administrators are not present at the facility for the required time set fourth in the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to the clients in care and deficiencies will be cited. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF). The Accreditation is valid through December 31, 2021. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0.00. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in a locked downstairs closet. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Staff interviews were conducted and did not reveal any health and safety concerns. During the inspection deficiencies were observed regarding staff scheduling and files, staff training and client files. These deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and this report was explained and provided to Facility Manager Shanesha Lee.

On August 12, 2021, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Cindy Hamilton met with Administrator Gina Melendez at Sojourners Haven Group Home II to do follow-up on a Plan of correction (POC) regarding Sojourners Haven Group Home III that has not been received by Community Care Licensing (CCL). The Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) was cited on July 09, 2021 at 9:20 am for Training Requirements (d) Annual Training (1) Notwithstanding California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 80065(f)(1) through (6), all direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 40 hours of annual training, except as specified in (2) below. When the citation was issued Sojourners Haven Group Home III, LPAs Cindy Hamilton and Jazmond Harris, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore met with Case Manager (CM) Erica Brown in person and discussed that the POC was to provide CCL with copies of the completed annual training certificates and certificates be filed in individual staff files by POC due date August 9, 2021. CCL did not receive the POC. The STRTP ws cited on July 9, 2021 for Training Requirements (d) Annual Training (1) Notwithstanding California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 80065(f)(1) through (6), all direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 40 hours of annual training, except as specified in (2) below. (A) At least 20 of the 40 hours of annual training shall consist of course work from an entity other than the short-term residential therapeutic program such as an accredited educational institution, workshops, seminars, or other direct training provided by a qualified individual, who meets the requirements specified in Section 87065.1(c)(4)(A)1, who is not affiliated with the short-term residential therapeutic program licensee. When the citation was issued CM and LPAs and LPM discussed the POC was to provide CCL with copies of the completed training certificates and the certificates to be filed in individual staff files by the POC due date August 9, 2021. CCL did not receive the POC. Based on the failure to correct the deficiency issued on July 15, 2021, a civil penalty of $100 per day beginning on August 3, 2021, and will continue to accrue at $100.00 per day, until deficiency is corrected. A copy of this report along with LIC Civil Penalty Assessment were provided to Administrator Gina Melendez.

On September 17, 2021 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Hamilton met with Sojourners Haven Executive Director Latrese Armstrong. The purpose of this office visit was to have Executive DIrector Armstrong sign the Non-Compliance Conference Summary that occurred on August 30, 2021. A copy of this report was provided to Executive DIrector.

Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. A confidential interview disclosed that S1 would sleep on the night shift almost every time S1 worked the night shift; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed S1 had not been seen sleeping during S1's shift. ADM stated ADM reviewed camera footage from August 26, 2021 to two weeks after from inside the STRTP and S1 was not observed sleeping. Confidential interviews also disclosed that S1 did not advise clients that they could do whatever they want as long as they do not disturb S1; whereas a confidential interview disclosed that S1 told this to C2. Confidential interviews also disclosed to LPA that no one had witnessed C1 and C2 engaging in inappropriate sexual interactions. Confidential interviews and document review disclosed that on June 6, 2021 staff did entered the room of C1 and C2 and C1 was in C1's underwear. When staff opened the door, C1 grabbed a towel to cover C1's upper body and C2 was in the room and staff asked C2 to exit the room. Per document review and confidential interviews, on June 10, 2021, C2 was assigned to another room and C1 and C2 were no longer roommates. ADM and Executive Director advised STRTP was concerned with C1 and C2 having inappropriate boundaries but none of the staff had advised of witnessing any inappropriate sexual interactions between any of the clients. Confidential interviews disclosed that there are usually two to three staff per day shift and one to two staff on the night shift. A confidential interview disclosed that an unknown staff left clients alone in the STRTP approximately five to seven times; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed the clients have never been left alone in the facility. Confidential interviews also disclosed that staff conducts room checks every 15 to 20 minutes and these checks are documented in the communication log. CSW had no issues or concerns with the care and supervision provided by STRTP. Based on confidential interviews and document review, the allegation lack of supervision resulting C1 and C2 engaging in inappropriate sexual interactions while in care, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to Executive Director.

narrative: For the allegations regarding a minor sustained injuries while in care and staff do not prevent altercations between youth, it was alleged that client #1 (C1) was jumped by another client at the facility. Specifically, it was alleged that Client #3 (C3) walked into C1's room and started to hit (C1) in (C1)'s arms, grabbed (C1) by the hair, and was beating (C1) in (C1)'s back. Additionally, (C1) reports having bruises on (C1)'s body. Furthermore, it was indicated that another client in care put client's arms around (C1)'s neck with no further details. A confidential interview reported that (C1) was warned not to touch (C3)'s belongings and (C1) did so, (C3) hit (C1). Confidential interviews stated staff do not let the clients in care fight. Other confidential interviews stated (C1) was bullying (C2) and wanted to fight (C2). Other confidential interviews stated not witnessing (C1) get jumped. Administrator stated Law Enforcement came out to the STRTP during an altercation between clients and did not observe bruising or marks on (C1). Administrator stated staff prevent fights between clients and one staff was injured by preventing a fight between two clients. County Social Worker stated (C1) did not disclose getting "jumped" at the group home but did indicate (C1) was jumped at school or after school. LPA received inconsistent information regarding these allegations. Regarding the allegation that staff locked minor out of the STRTP, it was specified that (C1) was locked out of the STRTP because staff did not feel safe. Confidential interviews reported that (C1) was AWOL and staff took the rest of the clients to the movie theater when (C1) arrived. Other confidential interviews stated not witnessing (C1) being locked out of the STRTP. Administrator stated (C1) broke into the STRTP through a window because facility staff took clients to an outing during the time (C1) was AWOL. County social worker stated that (C1) mentioned during a Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting that she was locked out of the STRTP. County social worker added that according to what he understood staff indicated not feeling safe because (C1) wanted to fight another client in care and there was only one staff there. LPA was unable to interview C1 due to C1 currently AWOL. LPA received inconsistent information regarding this allegation. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that Client #1 (C1) sustained injuries while in care, staff do not prevent altercations between clients and staff locked client out of the STRTP may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Administrator Sherrae Smith.

narrative: On June 16, 2022, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging procedures for filing a complaint with licensing are not posted in an accessible location at facility Regarding the allegation that procedures for filing a complaint with licensing are not posted in an accessible location at the facility, a confidential interview stated that C1 was unable to locate the number for licensing while placed at the facility. Confidential interview continued stating that when C1 asked S1 for licensing's information S1 did not provide C1 with the information. Another confidential interview stated that when C1 asked for the number to file a complaint a staff member at the facility provided C1 with that information and further assisted C1 with locating the posting for future reference. Another confidential interview stated that the facility has multiple postings available, and the information is located in an accessible area for clients. Other confidential interviews stated being aware on how to file a complaint and further reported that there are postings found throughout the facility. Based on confidential interviews, observations, and file reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the allegation that procedures for filing a complaint with licensing was not posted in an accessible location at the facility is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards Section 87022.2(a)(3) COMPLAINT PROCEDURES Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and provided to Case Manager, Erica Brown. **Continued from LIC A page 1** and on January 20, 2023, LPA Urena interviewed a County Social Worker (CSW). On June 16, 2022, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging that C1 sustained injuries while in care, staff did not prevent the altercation between minors while in care,a minor was not accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and other persons, and facility air conditioning in disrepair. In regard to the allegations that minor sustained injuries while in care, and staff did not prevent the altercation between minors while in care, a confidential interview stated that C1 had visible scratches after a physical altercation with C2. Other confidential interviews stated not observing injuries on C1. Another confidential interview stated CSW was aware of the altercation between C1 and C2, however, CSW was not aware that C1 sustained injuries. Other confidential interviews stated S1 and S3 attempted to intervene and stop the altercation from occurring. Confidential interviews continued stating that S1 and S3 separated C1 and C2. Other confidential interviews stated that S1 instigated the fight between C1 and C2 by the comments S1 made against C1. Confidential interviews specified that S1 lied about an incident involving an extension cord which led to the altercation between C1 and C2. Regarding the allegation that C1 was not accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and other persons, a confidential interview stated after the incident involving the extension cord S1 was ignoring C1 resulting in C1 feeling left out and isolated. Confidential interview continued stating C1 was bonding with staff and S1 changed staff duties to prevent C1 from further forming bonds with staff. Other confidential interviews stated that S1 favors C2 and does more for C2 than other clients. Confidential interview stated that C2 does not receive consequences for behaviors like other clients. Other confidential interviews stated that favoritism is not allowed by staff and client treatment varies from client to client due to client needs and client history. Another confidential interview denied that S1 favors C2 more than other clients. Regarding the allegation facility air conditioning in disrepair, all confidential interviews stated the air conditioner (AC) was not operating and it was fixed weeks later. A confidential interview stated that there was a leak in the ceiling that was linked to the AC not working. **Continued from LIC A page 2** Confidential interviews stated that fans were being used to keep clients cool during the maintenance process. Confidential interviews reported no concerns about the facility's AC. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations C1 sustained injuries while in care, staff did not prevent the altercation between C1 and C2 while in care, C1 was not accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and other persons, and facility air conditioning in disrepair, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations were unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Sojourner's Heaven III Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Case Manager, Erica Brown.
