narrative: facility staff did not give minor medication as prescribed, facility staff did not monitor minor's online activities, facility staff did not ensure that minor attended therapy sessions, and facility staff did not ensure that minor attended school on a regular basis. In regard to the allegations that facility staff bullied and intimidated C4 while in care, and facility staff made other minors verbally attack C4 while in care, a confidential interview stated that S1 instigated a fight between C4 and C3 that involved an extension cord. Confidential interview further stated that S1 was calling C4 "sticky fingers" which resulted in other clients accusing C4 of stealing. Confidential interview further reported that S1 gave C3 permission to fight C4. Another confidential interview stated that bullying does occur among clients and witnessed C4 being bullied by other clients while in care due to "the extension cord incident". Another confidential interview denied bullying C4 and stated that C4 was taking C3's things without permission. Other confidential interviews stated that staff do not bully or intimidate clients and denied that S1 was bullying or intimidating C4 while in care. Regarding the allegation that facility staff did not ensure that minors were adequately fed while in care, during inspection LPA observed an ample amount of food in the pantry, in the fridge, and also witnessed staff putting away groceries that were recently purchased. A confidential interview stated that when S1 took C4 and other clients to their appointments S1 stopped to purchase food and a drink while clients observed S1 eating and drinking. Confidential interview further stated that C4 and other clients were hungry and thirsty and were not offered any food or drinks. Another confidential interview stated that staff are given permission to purchase fast food for clients during transportation to visits. Confidential interview further stated that clients eat fast food in front of staff and reported no issues with food at the facility. Another confidential interview denied that S1 was eating food and drinking in front of clients. Regarding the allegation facility was not maintained at a comfortable temperature, all confidential interview stated the air conditioner (AC) was not operating and it was fixed later on. A confidential interview stated that there was a leak in the ceiling that was linked to the AC not working. Confidential interviews stated that fans were being used to keep clients cool during the maintenance process. Regarding the allegation that facility staff refused to provide C4 with the number to licensing, a confidential interview stated that C4 was unable to locate the number for licensing while placed at the facility. Confidential interview continued stating that when C4 asked S1 for licensing's information S1 did not provide C4 with the information Another confidential interview stated that when C4 asked for the number to file a complaint a staff member at the facility provided C4 with that information and helped C4 with locating the posting. Another confidential interview stated that the facility has multiple postings available, and the information is located in an accessible area for clients. Other confidential interviews stated being aware on how to file a complaint and further reported that there are postings found throughout the facility. LPA was unable to verify if the posting was available when the complaint was initiated. Regarding the allegation that facility staff did not give minor medication as prescribed, confidential interviews stated that C1 is provided with medications as prescribed. Confidential interviews further stated that staff log all medication administered to C1 and log all of C1's refusals as well. A confidential interview stated that C1 is complaint with taking medication and reported no issues. A confidential interview denied providing information. Regarding facility staff did not monitor C1's online activities, confidential interviews stated that there was an incident when C1 was observed using inappropriate contents on C4's computer. Confidential interviews stated that since the incident C1 was not allowed to use a computer without staff supervision. Confidential interviews further stated that there have been no issues reported and C1's online usage was being monitored by staff. Other confidential interviews reported not knowing if staff were monitoring C1's online activities. Regarding the allegation that facility staff did not ensure that C1 attended therapy sessions, a confidential interview stated that C1 attends all therapy sessions. It is documented that C1 participates weekly in individual therapy. Other confidential interviews reported not knowing if C1 is attending therapy sessions. Other confidential interviews stated that clients decide whether to participate in therapy or not. Regarding the allegation facility staff did not ensure that C1 attended school on a regular basis, a confidential interview stated that C1 was refusing to go to school. Other confidential interviews stated that staff were not sure why C1 was refusing to go to school. Confidential interviews further stated that staff held a meeting with C1's County Social Worker to discuss C1's school refusals. Another confidential interview stated that C1 was transferred to another school and C1 has been attending school daily. Other confidential interviews stated that staff ensure that clients are taken to school each day. Confidential interviews continued stating not having concerns about attending school daily. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff bullied and intimidated C4 while in care, facility staff made other minors verbally attack C4 while in care, facility staff did not ensure that minors were adequately fed while in care, facility was not maintained at a comfortable temperature, facility staff refused to provide C4 with number to licensing, facility staff did not give C1 medication as prescribed, facility staff did not monitor C1's online activities, facility staff did not ensure that C1 attended therapy sessions, and facility staff did not ensure that C1 attended school on a regular basis, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Sojourner's Heaven III Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Administrator.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Covarrubias on August 3, 2023 at AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Covarrubias met with Administrator, Sharrae Smith and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed three of child's records and three of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed three of child's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed three of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed three of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Administrator, Sharrae Smith. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Administrator, Sharrae Smith.

On December 4, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero conducted an unannounced required 2-year inspection and met with Facility Manager III Precious Spence. LPA disclosed the purpose of the visit and was granted entry into the facility. One client and three staff were present during the inspection. The facility is a three-bedroom, three-bathroom two-story house composed of two offices, one living room, and a TV area. One out of the three bathrooms is for staff use. Facility Manager III Precious Spence accompanied LPA inside and out of the facility inspection. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following areas: facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/games were observed for clients' recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Sethany Yem, conducted a case management inspection on 5/26/2022 at 9:31AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated May 26th, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Sethany Yem observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to the Facility Administrator Omar Gomez. Present in the discussion was Program Director Staci Tornquist and Administrator for San Rafael Facility Joseph Hancock.

and specifically for the specialized population. Confidential interviews revealed that training is not provided for the specialized population of clients placed at the facility; the lack of staff training resulted in staff overstimulating the C1 and staff were not able to fully understand the needs of the C1. Review of the facility Program Statement indicated that staff are to be trained initially during the new hire process and annually regarding working with specialized populations. Facility could not provide documentation for staff training. Based on confidential interviews and record review of the facility's program statement, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met regarding the allegation that unqualified adults are caring for children is substantiated. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to C1 in care, the facility will be cited for violating Interim Licensing Standards, STRTP Article 6, 87065.1(a)(1)(C). narrative: On June 20, 2023 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Sarah Lo, arrived at South Coast Children's Society - Caladium Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by Administrator/Program Supervisor (PS), Ethan Alli. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were three staffs and two clients present at the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 10: AM, Administrator/Program Supervisor led the physical inspection of the facility. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the medication closet located next to the bathroom upstairs. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Two bedrooms contain one twin bed, and two bedroom contained two twin beds. The facility has three bathrooms but only two of the three bathrooms are for client use only. The water temperature in the client bathrooms with the sink was tested at 10: AM and registered at 118.7 and 119.2 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Continued on LIC 809-C Per Administrator/Program Supervisor, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator/Program Supervisor is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs four Clinical Support Staff, two facility managers and 3 full time direct care staffs and 5 regular part-time/on-call staffs that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA and the Accreditation is valid through September 30, 2025. The facility annual licensing fees are paid to current. Licensee has mental health approval and good until February 16, 2024. LPA reviewed four out of four client files and each file met the minimum requirement per the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). All client records reviewed had the required documents including admission agreements, personal rights, medical history, immunization records, medical consent form, and an initial or updated needs and services plan on file. LPA reviewed five staff files and each file met the minimum requirement per the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). All personnel records reviewed have the verification of Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigations, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. All staff have proof in file of acknowledging confidentiality and mandated child abuse reporting requirements. All personnel records reviewed met the required education and experience requirement. All personnel records reviewed had a completed physical exam on file. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Core Services, Specialty Mental Health Service, Trauma Informed Care, Client Personal Rights, and Administrative Duties. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to the facility to conduct a continuation of the annual inspection and interviewing of staff/client. No deficiencies were found. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator/Program Supervisor, Ethan Alli.

Per Administrator/Program Supervisor, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA and the Accreditation is valid through September 30, 2025. The facility annual licensing fees are paid to current. Licensee has current mental health approval. LPA reviewed six out of six client files and each file met the minimum requirement per the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). All client records reviewed had the required documents including admission agreements, personal rights, medical history, immunization records, medical consent form, and an initial or updated needs and services plan on file. LPA reviewed five staff files and each file met the minimum requirement per the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). All personnel records reviewed have the verification of Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigations, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. All staff have proof in file of acknowledging confidentiality and mandated child abuse reporting requirements. All personnel records reviewed met the required education and experience requirement. All personnel records reviewed had a completed physical exam on file. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Core Services, Specialty Mental Health Service, Trauma Informed Care, Client Personal Rights, and Administrative Duties. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to the facility to conduct a continuation of the annual inspection and interviewing of staff/client. Facility is being cited for ILS v Section 87065 (d)(1) Personnel Requirements and ILS v Section 87095.61(g) Documentation and Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator/Program Supervisor, Ethan Alli.

narrative: On April 16,2025, at 10:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management visit of the Short-Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) facility. LPA conducted a walkthrough of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. LPA Munoz met with Facility Manager Crystal Martinez to deliver findings for a case management investigation regarding an incident that was reported on 04/03/25. On April 3, 2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information that three clients C1-C3 (please refer to Confidential Names List LIC 811), were left alone without staff supervision in C1s bedroom. Per confidential interviews, C1 and C2 are assigned 1:1 supervision at all times. C1's bedroom is located on the second floor of the facility and clients C1-C3 were able to barricade themselves in the bedroom while unsupervised. Clients were then able to throw a mattress out of the second-floor bedroom window and once the mattress was on the ground all three clients jumped out of the window and left the facility. LPA interviewed two staff (S1) and reviewed clients' (C1-C3) Needs and Services Plan. Confidential interviews and records reviewed confirmed that C1 and C2 assigned 1:1 staff did not follow 1:1 supervision protocol and left C1 and C2 unsupervised. In addition, all clients were left unsupervised in the bedroom which resulted in clients barricading door and jumping out of second floor window which posed an imminent safety risk to the clients. The STRTP is being cited for ILS v Article 06. Continuing Requirements Section80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision . Exit interview was conducted with Facility Manager, Crystal Martinez. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and Appeal Rights were provided to Facility Manager.

On 05/16/25, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Administrator Ethan Alli, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve six ambulatory children ages 12-17 years-old and non minor dependents. The current census is six children. The Facility is current with their licensing fees. The Facility is a double story dwelling. A physical plant inspection was completed with an Direct Care Staff, Anna Rodriguez and included the following checks: kitchen, medication room, dining room, living room, den, two staff offices, and outdoor living space. Two bedrooms contain one twin bed, and two bedrooms contained two twin beds. The facility has three bathrooms but only two of the three bathrooms are for client use only. All beds were observed with appropriate bedding and mattress in good repair. Bedrooms contained adequate drawers and closet space. No bedroom occupied more than two clients and not used for other purposes. The water temperature was tested in bathroom one which measured 115 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The first aid kit was accessible to everyone and had all required supplies. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Foster Care Ombudsman poster, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the medication room. **Continued on LIC809C** **Continued from LIC809** Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. All client files are stored and maintained on a secure internet database. LPA reviewed five client files (C1 - C6) to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. Client files had education records, physical examinations, Needs and Services plans, and case manager notes. LPA reviewed five client medication records. All staff records are stored via a secured records portal. LPA reviewed five staff files (S1 - S5) to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Per a review of Guardian, all staff have a criminal record clearance. All staff files also had applications, job descriptions, resumes, physical health screenings, drivers licenses, and training certificates. LPA conducted three staff interviews (S1, S2, and S3 - See LIC Confidential Names List) and one client interview (C3). The other clients declined to be interviewed. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. One type B deficiency is being given per California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Client Records, Section 80069(c)(1) The medical assessment shall include the following: The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: based on interview and record review, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above in three out of six clients (C1, C2, C5) which poses a potential health and safety risk to persons in care. An exit interview was conducted, a plan of correction was created, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, LIC811, and appeal rights were provided to Ethan, Administrator. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file

On June 10,2025, at 9:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management visit of the facility. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Incident Report (IR) follow up visit. LPA Munoz met with Program Supervisor, Ethan Ali.. Community Care Licensing (CCL) has only been provided with Incident Reports for clients that are past the seven days required to report an incident. In addition, the facility has not been notifying the department with a 24 hour notification of incidents that include law enforcement involvement, manual restraints and other incidents. The STRTP facility is being cited for violation of Title General Licensing Requirements, Section Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was reviewed to Ethan Ali, Program Supervisor.

The STRTP facility is being cited for violation of Title General Licensing Requirements Section 87065(f) Personnel Requirements. On June 17, 2025, at 10:45 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Ethan Alli, Facility Administrator. This inspection is to discuss information that was reported to the Department and records reviewed by LPA on March 25, 2025. LPA interviewed one Client (C1), six Staff (S2-5, S8-9), and LPA was unable to interview three Staff (S1, S6-7), despite multiple attempts to contact them. LPA reviewed the facility documents. Refer to Confidential Names (LIC 811) dated 06/17/2025. Community Care Licensing became aware of an incident of S2 pulling on C1's ankles while C1 was laying in their bed. Confidential interviews indicated that S2 was waking C1 up and S2 placed their hands on C1's ankles to pull them out of bed. C1 told S2 to stop, and S5 redirected S2 not to place hands on the clients to wake them up, and S2 stopped pulling on C1's ankles. Documents reviewed indicated that the Facility did not report the incident to CCL as required. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility is being cited for a Type B violation of the Interim Licensing Standards STRTP 87072(c)(15) Personal Rights. Facility is also being cited for a Type A violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Facility was issued a civil penalty of $250.00 for repeat violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Refer to LIC809D. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed with Ethan Alli. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

Regarding the allegation that facility did not meet the medical needs of minor in care, confidential interviews confirmed that STRTP did not have a nurse on their staff and that medication responsibilities were delegated to residential managers. Confidential interviews revealed that residential managers had may tasks and medication management and administration were not the priority. Confidential interviews and records reviewed also revealed that C1 was not being administered their medication as prescribed and approved on JV220 dated 9/14/24. On 01/24/ LPA observed medication bubble pack left at the school that had not been administered to C1 due to lack of communication from the facility. Regarding the allegation that lack of supervision of minors in care led to inappropriate sexual contact, confidential interviews confirmed that due to C1's needs they were determined to have a 1:1 staff assigned to them while living at the facility. Confidential interviews and records reviewed also confirmed that on the night of the incident C1 was not assigned a 1:1 staff. In addition, records reviewed, and interviews conducted also confirmed that facility did not follow 1:1 supervision protocol and left C1 and C2 unsupervised which resulted in C1 being the victim of inappropriate sexual contact by C2. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegations that facility did not meet the medical needs of minor in care and that lack of supervision of minors in care led to inappropriate sexual contact are substantiated. The STRTP facility is being cited for violation of the and Interim Licensing Standards Version 5, Article 06. Continuing Requirements 87075(c) Health Related Services and Section 80078(a) Responsibility for providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 811 dated 06/10/25 were provided to facility designee. Confidential interviews also revealed that C1 does not like to bathe and needs many prompts and reminders to complete hygiene routines. Additionally, confidential interviews revealed that due to C1's behavioral needs and safety concerns, hygiene routines were not always prioritized. Based on confidential interviews and record review staff did not ensure minor's hygiene care needs were met may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to facility designee.

narrative: On June 15, 2021, at 10:41AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez, conducted an unannounced Post Licesning/Annual inspection of the facility. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on September 16, 2019. LPA was met at the facility by Administrator Joseph Hancock, Facility Manager Kevin Vivas and Program Director Rich Boyer. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office located in the downstairs hallway. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Two bedrooms contain one twin bed, and two bedrooms contained two twin beds. The facility has three bathrooms. The water temperature in the kitchen with the sink was tested at 12:06pm and registered at 108.1 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator Joseph Hancock is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. Cont. on 809-C The facility employs three Clinical Support Staff, four facility managers and 11 direct care staff that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee obtained Mental Health (MH) Certification in April 2021. Program Director has stated that National Accreditation through COA is currently being processed. The Accreditation audit began on 05/26/2021. Licensing fee payments are current. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Core Services, Specialty Mental Health Service, Trauma Informed Care, Client Personal Rights, and Administrative Duties. Due to time constraints and employee files being housed in their corporate office, LPA will return to the facility to conduct a continuation of staff file reviews. One facility staff was interviewed during the inspection. No clients were present at the time of the inspection. No deficiencies were found. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Program Director Rich Boyer.

On June 22, 2021, at 3:37PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez conducted an unannounced annual continuation inspection from June 15, 2021. LPA met with Facility Manager Mallory Mandell. Employee files were not located at the facility and required employee files to be reviewed at Southcoast-Santa Cruz located at Santa Cruz Circle, CA 92626. Five personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained off-site in the Human Resource office. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. No deficiencies were noted during time of inspection.

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed that the facility was contacted to clarify why C1 did not start their supplement after their physician's appointment and the facility did not have an answer to why C1 did not start the supplement as prescribed by their physician. Other confidential interviews stated the physician wanted C1 to start the medications and supplements a week at a time, over the span of four weeks, so the physician could monitor for side effects. Other confidential interviews also stated that the physician wanted C1 to try a prescribed allergy medication before starting the supplements. Confidential reports do not show the medication and supplements that were prescribed on the medical exam report to start over several weeks and do not report any delays in starting any of the medications or supplements. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that supplements are not being administered to C1 as prescribed by their physician may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with the appeal rights were explained and provided to Kevin Vivas, Facility Manager. A copy of the report was emailed due to printer not working.

On April 14, 2023 at 9:35am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct a Random Annual inspection of the facility. LPA was met at the facility by Facility Manager Kevin Vivas, and Administrator Joseph Hancock. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water from the kitchen sink was measured at 118.7 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible. The medications were stored and locked in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in locked cabinets in the laundry room. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Facility Manager Kevin Vivas. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Emergency Disaster Plan and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There is no swimming pool or body of water located on the property. Due to time constraints and the need to complete staff/client file reviews, and staff/client interviews, this inspection will need to be continued at a later date. Based on the facility inspection, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained to Facility Manager Kevin Vivas. Due to printer malfunction, this report will be emailed to Facility Manager Kevin Vivas, and Administrator Joseph Hancock.

narrative: Confidential interviews disclosed C1 and C2 would wait for staff to go downstairs or to the staff office in order to have sexual encounters with each other. Although S1 and S2 denied seeing any inappropriate sexual behavior between C1 and C2, other confidential interviews corroborated the allegation that staff was not providing supervision when the sexual abuse occurred. Confidential interviews disclosed facility staff are supposed to check each bedroom every 15 minutes the entire duration of the night, staff failed to follow these supervision requirements. Based on confidential information obtained, the allegations that C1 was sexually abused while in care and there was a lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate sexual interactions between C1 and C2 are substantiated which posed a health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care. The preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The facility is being cited for Title Regulation section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. A copy of this report, LIC 811 confidential names list and appeal rights were provided to Qoodseya Afredi, Facility Administrator.

narrative: On August 10, 2022 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with Abigail Anokwuru, Administrator, Brian Phillips, Facility Manager, Giovanna Verdin, Assistant Facility Manager, and Dave Detmers, facility maintenance. This Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program is a one story facility located in a residential area. The facility consists of 3 client bedrooms and 1 client bathroom, living and dining areas, kitchen, laundry area, gym, and detached counseling conference room. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There are no bodies of water on the facility premises. Fire arms are not allowed on the facility premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers are throughout the house. Smoke detectors are throughout the house and operational. Carbon monoxide detectors are located in the hallway, outside of the client bedrooms. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 105 degrees Fahrenheit. Staff records will be kept at Advent's main office in San Jose, and will be readily available for review. Client files and medications will be centrally stored and locked in the staff office. There is a taped area outside the staff office to show clients where to stand, when medication is administered. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked in the hallway closet. Extra bedding and towels are kept unlocked, in the hallway closet. Main food pantry will remain unlocked in the kitchen. The secondary pantry in the kitchen is allowed to be locked. There is a space utilized for a gym, with gym equipment. All gym equipment is in working order. Knives and sharps will be kept locked in the staff office. Site location has a live in staff bedroom and bathroom that is kept locked, and meets prelicensing requirements. Head of Services (HOS) for this location is Calvin Temple. Site location already has cameras installed. Cameras are ok to leave installed, while waiting for regulations to be written. Licensee keeps video footage for a maximum of 30 days. CCL will need access to camera video footage, at all times. Licensee agrees to meet current County safety guidelines. This property is ready for licensure, once their Plan of Operation/Program Statement (POO/PS) is approved. LPA Pavia will notify licensee, once POO/PS is approved and facility is licensed. Component II: LPA Pavia discussed with the following, with Administrator: - Administrator on site required hours - facility core services and support - facility emergency intervention plan

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield, Licensing Program conducted an unannounced case management inspection with the above facility on 7/20/2023 at 12: PM. Present during this inspection were four staff. Facility Manager Mark Carpenter assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this inspection is to follow up with the facility regarding the program operations. Currently there are no clients in placement. This program is licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to serve clients ages 7 to 17 and Non minor Dependents. The Interim Licensing Standards require that all referrals made to an STRTP be kept in a log and that an assessment be completed to determine program eligibility. Based on a review of the facilities program statement and confidential interviews conducted, the program is confirmed to be operating out of compliance with the licensing regulations and their program statement by not accepting STRTP eligible clients and not conducting assessments for determination. The program does not have a record of referrals received for placement's. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87068.1(b) Intake procedures and 87068.05(b) Admission Determination Procedures, as described on the following page LIC 809D. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to Facility manager Mark Carpenter, administrator Abigail Anokuwru and Licensee Daniel Mahan.

On October 1, 2021, at 9: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Shanae Pharaoh and Adelayci Caballero arrived at Starshine - 40th Street Short Term Residential Program (STRTP). LPA, was met by Administrator Felicia Williams and granted access to the facility. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At 10: AM, Administrator Felicia Williams, led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA Pharaoh. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1- Was furnished with two twin separate beds. Sleeps C1 & C2. Bedroom #2- Was furnished with two twin separate beds. Sleeps C3 & C4. Bedroom #3- Was furnished with two twin separate beds. Sleeps C5 & C6. Bedroom #4- Is designated as the staff office and has one bathroom inside. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility's kitchen area, three refrigerators/freezers, food storage areas, client rooms, two bathroom/showers, and community gathering area and dining area. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for client's recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client's bathrooms was measured to be an appropriate temperature. Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Licensee has Mental Health Program Approval that is valid through 06/2022. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF. The Accreditation is valid through 02/2022. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0. There were no clients present at the facility during the inspection. LPA Pharaoh discussed core services with the Administrator, based on discussion all licensing standards have been met. met_with: Antoinette Borders-Frazier, Program Coordinator and Sheri Heckman, Facility Manager II
narrative: On September 16, 2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cindy Hamilton and Adaleyci Caballero met with Antoinette Borders-Frazier, Program Coordinator and Sheri Heckman, Facility Manager II. The purpose of this visit was to conduct an annual inspection of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The facility converted from a Group Home to Short Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on September 14, 2017. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment is located in the backyard. Books/games were observed for client's recreation time in the dining area. There is also a laptop available for client use. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of non-perishable foods. Currently, there are no clients in placement so no perishable foods were on grounds. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked cabinet in the locked staff office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client's hallway bathroom was measured to be 117.1 degrees Fahrenheit, which is within the allowed range of 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. The facility does not have a pool. Per Program Coordinator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Licensee is in the process of being recertified for Mental Health Program Approval. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF). The Accreditation is valid through 02/28/2022. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0.00. LPA Caballero discussed the following with the Facility Manager, II and Program Coordinator: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Based on this discussion the facility appears to be meeting the mission values of the facility and needs of services when clients are present.. Due to facility not having placements, no client file reviews or interviews were conducted. No deficiencies were noted in the areas during time of inspection. A copy of this report was provided to Program Coordinator Antoinette Borders-Frazier, with the Confidential Names List, LIC 811 and appeal rights..

On January 26, 2023, LPA Enriquez conducted collateral interviews at the STRTP. LPA interviewed C1, C2, S1 and S2. Regarding the allegation that staff speak inappropriately to minors in care, it was specified that staff uses profanity words towards the minors. During investigation, confidential interview stated that staff was trained on staff and client relation topic which covered appropriate language used around the clients. Confidential interviews and witnesses denied ever saying inappropriate things or hearing other staff saying inappropriate things to clients. Other confidential interviews stated that client has never had a staff curse or say anything in appropriate any clients. It was added that client has never heard staff saying profanity. In regard to the allegation that staff force minors to clean the facility multiple times a day, it was specifically alleged that staff would "drag" the minors out of bed at AM to "force" them to clean four to five times throughout the day. Confidential interviews disclosed that staff wake up clients at 5: AM to do their chores, get ready for school and eat breakfast. It was added that clients only clean twice a day, in the morning and evening. Confidential interviews stated that clients get woken up at 5:00 to do chores and get ready for school. It was added that they only clean twice a day. LPA received a conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff speak inappropriately to clients in care and that staff force clients to clean the facility multiple times a day may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was reviewed and provided to facility representative.

On the above date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daniel Mena met with Administrator, Christina Garcia who guided analyst on an inspection to the home. The purpose of this visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The home was toured both inside and out with Ms. Garcia. Presently there are six foster children in placement and none were present during time of inspection (See LIC 811). The home is a one story, four bedroom and two bathroom home. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1- Was furnished with two twin separate beds. Sleeps C5 & C6. Bedroom #2- Was furnished with two twin separate beds. Sleeps C2 & C4. Bedroom #3- Was furnished with two twin separate beds. Sleeps C1 & C3. Bedroom #4- Is designated as the staff office and has one bathroom inside. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. Inside the facility there are operable smoke detectors located in each bedroom. There is also an operable carbon monoxide detector located in the TV room. The fireplace is properly screened. The medications are locked and stored in a locked box inside a locked medicine cabinet. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a locked cabinet inside the garage. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the office. The First Aid Kit is located in the kitchen and contains all required items. There are no guns or weapons in the home. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 107. Proper storage of all food was noted. The Emergency Disaster Plan posted at this time. A copy of the license was readily available to LPA during time of inspection. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. Games and equipment is safe, clean and age appropriate for the age group of children to be cared for both inside and outside the facility. A review of five staff records and all six clients residing in facility were made. All adults in the home or providing care and supervision to children have received fingerprint and child abuse index check clearances. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was reviewed and given to Ms. Garcia with the LIC 811.

On October 20, 2022, LPA Enriquez conducted collateral interviews at the STRTP. LPA interviewed FC1, FC2, FC3, FC4, S1, S2 and S3. On October 24, 2022, LPA conducted a collateral interview for FC5 and FC2 at San Gorgonio High school, LPA was unable to interview FC2 due to FC2 was in absence without leave (AWOL). Regarding the allegation that staff does not treat children equally, it was specifically alleged staff show favoritism among children and don't treat all children equally. Confidential interview stated that FC1 felt they were treated equally as everyone else. Additionally, confidential interview stated foster children like their relationship with staff. Confidential interviews stated staff treat all children equally. It was added that every child requires a different level of attention and if staff sees that a child needs more attention seeking due to any challenges then they provide the attention to the child needs. Confidential interviews denies treating foster children unequally. In regard to the allegation that staff speaking inappropriately about child in care, it was specifically alleged that a staff member saw FC5 without the mask and commented that FC5 "looked like a camel". Confidential interviews disclosed that they did not hear staff say FC5 looked like a camel. It was added that staff would not say anything inappropriate to foster children. Confidential interviews denied speaking inappropriately to foster children. The confidential interview reported that due to the children's ages staff sometimes need to speak very directly to them if there are any behavior issues. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff does not treat children equally and that staff spoke inappropriately to FC5, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was reviewed and provided to facility representative.

Regarding the allegation that staff hits minor(s) in care, it was specifically alleged that S4 has physically assaulted C1 on multiple occasions. During investigation, confidential interviews stated that C1 was hit by S4. It was added that C1 was punched in the shoulder, poked, ear flicked and slapped behind the head, and that happened multiple times, however, additional confidential interviews stated that they had not seen S4 hitting C1 or any other client in care. LPA unable to gather additional information. In regard to the allegation that staff handles minor(s) in rough manner, it was specifically alleged that a staff member placed C1 in a chokehold. Confidential interviews stated that C1 was put in a chokehold by S4. Additional confidential interviews stated that they had not seen S4 putting C1 or any other client in care in a chokehold. LPA unable to gather additional information. Other witnesses didn't provide information pertaining directly to the incidents. Concerning the allegation that staff speaks inappropriately to minor(s) in care, it was specifically alleged that a staff member taunted C1 saying, now I got your ass, what are you going to do. Confidential interviews stated that S4 had not spoken to C1 inappropriately but did to other clients. Additional confidential interviews denied that S4 spoke inappropriately to clients in care. LPA was not able to interview S4. LPA unable to gather additional information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that S4 hits minor(s) in care, staff handles minor(s) in rough manner and staff speaks inappropriately to minor(s) in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was reviewed and provided to the facility representative.

Confidential interviews revealed C1 and C2 were placed in the group home in July 2019. Additionally, when C1 and C2 entered the bedroom they were to sleep in they decided to clean it due to it appearing dirty to them. It was disclosed to LPA, while in the process of cleaning the bedroom, C1 and C2 moved the beds to clean the floor under the beds. Interviews revealed C1 and C2 saw a dirty underwear and trash such as food wrappers on the floor. Furthermore, C1 and C2 found condoms inside a storage compartment located in C2's bedframe. Based on confidential interviews, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the group home facility is dirty. The allegation is, therefore, found to be substantiated. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Regulation Section 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and LIC 9099-D was emailed to Tracy Mitchell for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file. The LIC 811 and Appeals Rights were emailed to Tracy Mitchell. Based on LPA observation and confidential interviews, the allegation that there is mold in the group home, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and was emailed to Tracy Mitchell for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file. Appeals Rights were emailed to Tracy Mitchell.

Upon arrival, LPM and LPA met with Designated Manager, Brigid Osonwa. narrative: On February 14, at 1:23pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland arrived to Stella Maris Growth Center II unannounced. While at the facility LPA conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the inspection LPA observed a plastic container with blue lid holding the sharps (Knives, scissors, etc.) in an unsecured area of the facility. Facility Manager stated that the facility uses this area of the facility as storage and refers to it as staff closet. The staff closet does not have any doors to the area. The area has three curtains hanging to cover the storage however, items in this area are not secure. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) Regulation Buildings and Grounds (g): Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, poisons, firearms and other items that could pose a danger if readily available to clients shall be stored where inaccessible to clients. An immediate civil penalty is assessed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Facility Manager Tracy Mitchell.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers & Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection on July 13,2022 @ 9:43 am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 9 out of Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated July 13, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Latricia Rogers observed documentation of completed training records indicating staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Charles Ohaeri, Administrator.

narrative: On April 28, 2022, at 12:25PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) S. Smith initiated the investigation at Stella Maris Growth Center Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). At 1:40PM, LPA S. Smith conducted a safety inspection, and no immediate hazards were observed. Additionally, LPA Smith conducted interviews with Staff 1 (S1), Client 1 (C1), Client 2 (C2), and Client 3 (C3). Client 4 (C4) refused to be interviewed. On April 21, 2022, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging that minor is not provided clothing. Confidential interviews stated that the STRTP provides clients with $150.00 clothing allowance. Confidential interviews further stated that clients shop for clothing on a quarterly basis. A confidential interview stated that C5 did not have a lot of clothes. It was disclosed that C5 had been expedited a clothing allowance due to the lack of clothing. Confidential interview further stated that C5 did complain that C5 was being made fun of at school for wearing the same clothes. Confidential interview further stated that this was an issue at beginning of C5's placement at the STRTP. A confidential interview stated that it took the STRTP longer to issue a clothing allowance for C5 than other clients who were placed at the STRTP. A confidential interview stated that C3 was in placement at the STRTP for two months and had not been awarded a clothing allowance. During file review, LPA Smith noted in the STRTP's program statement on page 313 of Adequate clothing, STRTP provides $75.00 clothing allowance per month to each child and NMD. Based on confidential interviews the facility is not providing clients with the monthly $75.00 clothing allowance as stated in their program statement. Confidential interviews stated that the STRTP provides clients with a $50.00 monthly clothing allowance. Based on confidential interviews and file reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that C5 was not provided clothing is supported and proven by evidence. The facility is cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Treatment Facility (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards Section 87022.1(a) PROGRAM STATEMENT Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager Tracy Mitchell. On April 28, 2022, at 12:25PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) S. Smith initiated the investigation at Stella Maris Growth Center Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP).At 1:40PM, LPA S. Smith conducted a safety inspection, and no immediate hazards were observed. Additionally, LPA Smith conducted interviews with Staff 1 (S1), Client 1 (C1), Client 2 (C2), and Client 3 (C3). Client 4 (C4) refused to be interviewed. On September 14, 2022, at 12:18PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena interviewed staff 2 (S2) at the STRTP. On September 19, 2022, LPA Urena conducted telephone interviews staff (S3), staff 4 (S4), and one County Social Worker (CSW). During the investigation alleging that minor had access to dangerous objects, confidential interviews denied witnessing that C3 had a knife or other dangerous object while C5 was placed at the STRTP. A confidential interview stated that law enforcement conducted a search of C3's room and did not find a knife or other dangerous object in C3's belongings. Confidential interviews conducted denied having a dangerous or sharp object in possession. Confidential interviews added not seeing clients with dangerous objects. Another confidential interview stated that C5 had self-harming behaviors while in care and may have used sharp objects, however, the STRTP did not report these incidents to CSW on a timely manner. Regarding staff yelling at minor while in care or staff did not treat minor with dignity and respect. A Confidential interview stated that staff do not yell at clients but stated that staff can be disrespectful at times. Another confidential interview stated that staff do not yell at clients, but when clients are not listening, it is not unusual for staff to raise their voices. Confidential interview continued stating not witnessing staff being disrespectful to clients. Another confidential interview stated not hearing staff yelling at clients. The confidential interview added that when clients were loud staff do raise their voices to be heard. Other confidential interviews denied yelling at C5 and denied being disrespectful to C5 when placed at the STRTP. Another confidential interview stated that C5 did not report any concerns about the staff treatment at the STRTP. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that C3 had access to dangerous objects, staff yells at C5 while in care, and that staff does not treat C5 with dignity and respect may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. There was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations, therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager Tracy Mitchell.

narrative: facility is not taking measures to ensure the facility is free of insects. Based on the allegations that staff do not meet C1's medical, and educational needs a confidential interview stated that as of January 19, 2022, C1 had not seen a doctor. Confidential interviews revealed that there were challenges in keeping C1 at the school of origin due to transportation issues with the STRTP, and there was a delay on the part of the school district in enrolling C1 into a new school. There was no documentation provided to ensure that staff did enroll C1 within the allotted time. Confidential interviews indicated that there was a delay by program staff in getting C1 to see a doctor to refill medication. Confidential interviews indicated that the reason for a child not receiving medical attention was due to issues with medical insurance. Confidential interviews continued stating that for non-medical emergencies clients are taken to urgent care. Another confidential interview stated that staff keep record and document each time a client requests to go to the doctor. Another confidential interview stated that medical appointments often get rescheduled due to client refusal. Based on the allegation that staff are not following plan for therapeutic needs a confidential interview stated that clients are seen by the therapist once a week. Confidential interview continued stating that staff keep a log of those meetings. Confidential interview also stated that therapeutic services vary from client to client and there are times when clients refuse therapy. Another confidential interview stated that C1 had not seen the therapist. Another confidential interview stated not knowing how often clients see the therapist. It is unknown if C1 refused services or if services were offered to C1. Based on the allegation that C1 is not accorded dignity a confidential interview stated that staff make comments that result in clients feeling bad. More specifically, staff clapped their hand in front of C1's face when C1 was speaking. Confidential interviews stated that clients are accorded with dignity and respect by program staff, and when issues among clients or staff arise the house therapist facilitates meetings to address any concerns. Interviews indicated conflicting statements. Based on the allegations that staff are allowing smoking on facility grounds confidential interviews denied witnessing staff smoking; and that smoking on facility grounds is prohibited. Another confidential interview also denied seeing staff smoking at the facility. There were no witnesses to the incident. Continued on LIC C Page Based on the allegation that facility is not taking measures to ensure the facility is free of insect's confidential interviews stated seeing ants throughout the bathroom, and that the facility is prone to getting ants during summertime however, the facility does have someone who comes and sprays. Confidential interview also stated that clients are advised to eat all food at the kitchen and not in their rooms to keep ants from getting into client's bedrooms. It is unknown how long the insects were in the facility prior to having an exterminator out to the facility. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff do not meet C1's medical needs, staff are not following plan for therapeutic services, staff do not meet C1's educational needs, staff do not accord dignity to C1, staff are allowing smoking on facility grounds, and facility is not taking measures to ensure the facility is free of insects. may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. narrative: Confidential interviews reported conflicting statements of resident's participation in and recruiting of residents for CSEC activity. A second allegation alleging lack of supervision resulted in minor (Child #1 [C1]) AWOLing (Absent Without Leave) while in care was received by Community Care Licensing (CCL). Confidential interviews and record review provided conflicting reports of residents AWOLing while in care and how AWOLing is handled at the facility. Some confidential interviews denied AWOLing occurs while other confidential interviews reported staff attempt to discourage the residents from AWOLing by talking with the residents and attempting to redirect them. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute the allegation. Community Care licensing (CCL) a third allegation alleging Minor (Child #1 [C1]) was being threatened by another minor (Child #2 [C2]) in care. Confidential interviews and record review provided conflicting reports of threats being made by C2 or any other resident in care. Confidential interviews reported C2 has a strong dominate personality and is a leader. Confidential interviews report residents followed C2 and did what C2 wanted to be accepted by C2, additional confidential interviews reported C2 uses C2's strong dominate personality to intimidate and threaten residents. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute the allegation. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegation of lack of supervision resulted in minor (Child #1 [C1]) engaging in CSEC (Commercially Sexually Exploited Children) activity while in care, lack of supervision resulted in minor (C1) AWOLing (Absent Without Leave) while in care, and Minor(C1) was being threatened by another minor (C2) in care may or may not have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Stella Maris Growth Center II Facility Manager, Tracy Mitchell.

narrative: On January 6, 2023 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced visit to Stella Maris Growth Center II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). Upon LPA Choi's arrival to the facility, facility staff advised their census was four clients. LPA Choi asked the staff member how many other staff members were present, and the staff advised they were alone in the facility and that the Facility Manager (FM) had left the facility to purchase tea. Within 10 minutes, FM returned to the facility and explained that since the clients were sleeping in their rooms, FM felt comfortable with leaving the facility for a few minutes. LPA Choi advised the FM that the facility would be issued a Technical Violation for violation of Interim Licensing Standards for Short Term Residential Treatment Facilities (STRTP) 87065.5(a)(1) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios (a) In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: (1) During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. FM was advised that a future violation may and could result in the facility being cited for a Type A or Type B violation of ILS regulations.

Confidential interviews reported that a minor in care (C1) "barely gets food" and that C1 does not like the food that the facility provides. Confidential interviews reported that the facility does not make enough food for the clients. Confidential interviews also reported that the facility staff had been told about the food clients do not like, but the facility continues to purchase the same food. Confidential interviews reported that the clients are provided with breakfast, lunch, and dinner and that the facility buys snacks. Confidential interviews reported that the clients have asked for a "variation" in the prepared foods. Confidential interviews reported that the staff tried to keep the clients happy by purchasing different foods. Confidential interviews reported that grocery receipts were provided by the facility, which showed a variety of food purchases for the clients. Confidential interviews reported that the refrigerator was fully stocked with perishable food during facility inspections, and the dry foods pantry was fully stocked with non-perishable food. Community Care licensing received another allegation that the facility has mold. Confidential interviews reported that the mold was in the client's rooms. Other confidential interviews reported that they had not seen mold in the facility. Confidential interviews reported that no mold was seen, but a little paint was peeling from the ceiling. Confidential interviews reported that the peeled paint was addressed by applying new paint. During a follow-up facility inspection, photos of all the client rooms were taken, and there was no paint peeling. Community Care licensing received another allegation that the facility is unkempt. Confidential interviews reported that the facility appeared clean and free of excessive debris during two unannounced visits conducted by LPAs. Confidential interviews reported that the facility staff only cleaned up if clients threatened to call Community Care Licensing. Other confidential interviews reported that staff "are pretty good at cleaning" the facility daily. Other confidential interviews reported that they do not know how often the staff cleans the facility. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility staff cleans up daily all around the facility. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegation that the facility does not provide adequate food, the facility has mold, and the facility is unkempt, may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and provided to Facility Manager, Tracy Mitchell

narrative: On March 1, 2023, at 3: PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena met with Stella Maris Growth Center II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Facility Manager, Tracy Mitchell, regarding a case management inspection at the facility. The purpose of the inspection is to obtain additional information regarding information received by LPA on February 15 ,2023. LPA Urena conducted interviews with three staff members (S1, S2, S3) and two clients (C1, C2). LPA attempted to conduct an interview with client #3 however, C3 refused to be interviewed. Additionally LPA requested copies of pertinent documentation to further assist with the case management. A copy of this report was provided to Stella Maris Growth Center II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Facility Manager, Tracy Mitchell

On February 15, 2023, at 3: PM, LPA Urena continued the investigation at the STRTP and conducted two client interviews (C2, C3) and one staff interview (S4). LPA attempted to conduct an interview with client #4 (C4) however, C4 declined to be interviewed. In regard to the investigation that staff are not ensuring education stability for minor in care, confidential interviews stated that C1 attends an independent study program that does not require C1 to be at school daily. Confidential interviews continued stating that whenever C1 wakes up and indicates to staff that C1 is ready staff would transport C1 to school. Other confidential interviews stated that C1 is not attending school as required based on C1's enrollment paperwork agreement. Confidential interviews further stated that when school staff attempted to reach the STRTP program staff to discuss C1's academic needs staff have not been responsive. Confidential interviews further stated that although C1's school program is not attendance base C1 is required to be present at school four times each week. Another confidential interview stated that C1 is not at school regularly due to health-related issues and because at times staff have refused to provide C1 with transportation. Another confidential interview stated that C1 admitted to making false statements about the school schedule and stated that staff did not question C1 because C1 is on top of schoolwork. Confidential interview continued stating that there have been occasions when staff do procrastinate to pick up C1 from school that has resulted in C1 becoming anxious while waiting for transportation. Another confidential interview stated not being aware that staff are not providing educational stability for C1 while in care. Confidential interview further stated that CSW recently learned that C1 is doing really well in school. Confidential interview also stated that a reason that C1 misses school can be a result of C1's absent without leave (AWOL) status. Another confidential interview witnessed staff refusing to take C1 to school and staff could not provide C1 with a reason for the refusal. Another confidential interview stated not knowing if staff provide clients with educational stability due to not being enrolled in school yet. LPA was provided inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Regarding the allegation that staff are not ensuring that minor is fed while in care, confidential interviews stated that C1 informed school staff that C1 had not eaten food in three days. Confidential interviews further stated that when school staff attempted to feed C1, C1 gagged and did not appear to be feeling well. Other confidential interviews stated that C1 was observed by program staff refusing to eat despite staff encouragement. Confidential interviews further stated that program staff informed C1's therapist about C1's refusal to eat. Another confidential interview stated that C1 refused to eat due to not feeling well. Confidential interview denied that program staff were not providing C1 with meals while in care. Other confidential interviews stated that there is food at the facility, and that staff occasionally cook warm meals for clients in care. Another confidential interview maintained that program staff did make the therapist aware that C1 was refusing to eat. Confidential interview further stated that following a school incident C1 was being monitored by program staff more frequently. Confidential interview further denied that staff refused to provide C1 with food while in care. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Based on the confidential interviews, and record review the allegations that staff are not ensuring educational stability for C1 while in care, and that staff are not ensuring C1 is fed while in care, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Stella Maris Growth Center II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Facility Manager, Tracy Mitchell.

narrative: The confidential interviews indicated that staff at the facility are trained to de-escalate situations by giving the clients verbal warnings. If that does not stop the situation, the staff will intervene by stepping in between the clients and separating them into different facility areas to calm the situation. investigation_findings: 13On 04/11/2023 at 10:02am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo met with Facility Manager, Tracy Mitchell to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation at Stella Maris Growth Center II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program.
