The investigation included interviews with Lead Facility Manager (LFM), Facility Manager (FM), two Child Care Workers (S1 and S2), and three Clients (C1-C3). Needs and Services Plans and case notes were reviewed. On March 10, 2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that stated that staff encourages minor (C1) to engage in physical altercations with other minor (C2) in care. It was reported that the staff encourages clients (C1 and C2) to fight with each other. The confidential interviews reported that staff at the facility would never encourage clients to engage in physical fights and have not seen any staff encouraging physical altercations. The clients are reminded to respect each other and follow the house rules. *This is an amended 9099 page that was originally issued on 04/11/2023* UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: It was also reported that clients know about the safe available for use, however, due to the tedious steps of checking in and out personal items, the client does not like using the safe facility box. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that stated that staff does not prevent children (C1) from smoking in the facility. The confidential interviews reported that when a client (C1) is seen smoking in the facility, C1 is verbally asked to stop smoking immediately, and if the client does not stop, law enforcement is contacted. Another confidential interview reported that a substance abuse program is being offered to C1. Confidential interviews disclosed that the County Social Worker is aware of C1 smoking and working with C1 to join a substance abuse program. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that stated that staff does not prevent Inappropriate interaction between children in care (C1 & C3). The confidential interviews reported that staff at the facility would never encourage clients to fight. The confidential interviews indicated that staff are trained to de-escalate situations by giving the clients verbal warnings. If that does not stop the situation, the staff will intervene by stepping in between the clients and separating them into different facility areas to calm the situation. In addition, confidential interviews reported that staff must notify the facility manager of the incident and report to law enforcement if needed. Another confidential witness stated that the staff makes attempts to stop the fight and separated C1 and C3. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation stating that staff does not ensure the child attends school. The confidential interviews reported that the staff makes multiple attempts in the morning to wake the clients up and get them ready for school. Another confidential interview reported that the Administrator had a meeting with the clients and spoke to them about the importance of going to school and have come up with an incentive program to encourage the clients to attend and stay in school. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff do not safeguard minors' personal items, staff do not prevent children from smoking in the facility, staff do not prevent Inappropriate interaction between children in care, and staff do not ensure that child attends school may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to Lead Facility Manager, LaKeicha Chaney..

investigation_findings: 13On April 21, 2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation stating that facility staff does not prevent youths (C1, C2, and C3) from smoking. The confidential interviews reported that when a youth is observed smoking in the facility, the staff will immediately ask the youth to stop, complete a room search, and confiscate contraband in the youth's possession. In addition, the staff will contact management and write a special incident report, and law enforcement will be contacted if the youth does not comply with the facility rules. Confidential interviews stated that the staff follows the facility procedures to prevent youth from smoking in the facility. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that stated that facility staff is not properly supervising youths in care. The confidential interviews reported that the staff checked on the youths every 15-30 minutes to see how they were doing. Continue on LIC 9099-C UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Another confidential interview revealed that a Child and Family Team meeting was conducted to address the concerns C3 was having, and the youths (C1 and C2) in the facility were made aware of not consuming C3's preferred food items. Other confidential witnesses stated they have always observed the facility to have adequate food in the refrigerator and pantry for the youths (C1-C3) in care. Confidential interviews indicated that the staff would ensure that C3's preferred food items are placed in a location that C3 will have access to, and staff will make sure that clients C1 and C2 will not eat C3's food items. In addition, during the inspection, LPA observed seven days of non-perishable food and two days of perishable food. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation stating that staff does not allow minor (C3) to manage their own money while in care. The confidential interview reported that C3 was denied purchasing food with allowance money because C3 has not been following the program nor attending school. Confidential interviews stated that the staff allowed clients (C1-C3) to use their (C1-C3) allowance money, and the client's (C1-C3) money allowance was not withheld for disciplinary purposes or any other reason. Other confidential witnesses stated that clients (C1 and C2) had never heard of the staff not allowing C3 to manage their (C3) money. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that the staff does not ensure that a minor (C3) has sufficient food while in care and that the staff does not allow minor (C3) to manage their own money while in care may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. narrative: On July 26th, 2023 at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted a collateral visit at Stella Maris Growth Center II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Tracy Mitchell, Facility Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an interview with a resident client. Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers conducted a case management inspection August 16, 2023, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 16, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. Lpa L. Rogers observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Tracy Mitchell- House Manager.

Additionally, a confidential interview indicated that S1 admitted to fault for not checking the dosage on C1's doctor's prescription against the medication prescription received at the pharmacy. Furthermore, a confidential interview stated that S3 had given C1 an extra dose of medication as a result of the overdose. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation that the staff over medicated a minor (C1) while in care is substantiated. The STRTP is being cited for violations of California Code of Regulation (CCR), Title 22, Division Six, Section 80075(b). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to Brigid Osonwa, Youth Care Counselor.

Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Stella Maris Growth Center II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), Tracy Mitchell, Facility Manager.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers conducted a case management inspection Tuesday, August 13, 2024, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 13, 2024). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Latricia Rogers observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to LaKeicha Donald- Lead Facility Manager

On September 13, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Velasquez conducted an annual inspection of the facility. Upon arrival, LPA was met by Youth Care Counselor, Brigid Osonwa. LPA was escorted to an adjoining office area for use during the inspection. The facility's census is 5, with 4 clients present in the home and 1 was attending school. There were 2 staff available and Lead Facility Manager, LaKeicha Donald, was available to meet with LPA. Record review was initiated at 11:05 am. Client files were made available for LPA. All files were complete with information necessary for placement, medical and dental examinations, needs and services plans, contact information, personal rights, and approved contact lists. Staff files were reviewed and had identification, drivers licenses, child abuse, CPR, continuing training documents, and educational requirements. The facility was toured inside and out at 12: PM with LaKeicha Donald, Lead Facility Manager. Facility grounds are clean; free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an abundant supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the hallway closet. The facility has 3 bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room. Each bedroom has two beds and there is one client per bed. Clients agree to share rooms, where applicable. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The facility has two bathrooms for clients' use. The bathrooms were in working order. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The therapy/office room was an additional room added to the home. It contains a couch, additional seating area, an office desk, and a refrigerator. There are activities for youth, air conditioning, and a group area. Available at all time for clients are books, extra sundries, snack boxes, and fresh fruits. Facility does not have a pool or any open bodies of water. Per Facility Manager, there are no firearms or weapons in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. There were no deficiencies cited at this annual inspection. An Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with LIC811, and Appeal Rights will be provided to the facility.

Although a witness statement reported assisting C1 sneak the adult into the facility, other confidential statements denied having direct knowledge of the incident or being aware of an unauthorized adult on facility grounds. Likewise, a confidential interview reported that C1 later recanted and denied all allegations. Additionally, multiple confidential interviews consistently reported that staff regularly conducted room checks during their shifts by opening client bedroom doors and visually checking to ensure each client was accounted for. On the day of the incident, documentation shows that facility staff observed C1 on the grounds before C1 eloped. The documentation also noted that while C1 was off the grounds, C1 was seen with an unidentified person. However, the documentation did not mention that staff saw the unidentified person on facility grounds and reported that C1 returned to the facility alone. In regard to the allegation that facility staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in youth (C1) engaging in inappropriate behaviors with unknown person(s) on the phone while at the facility. While confidential interviews acknowledged that C1 and other clients send time on their phones texting and calling friends, there were no witnesses to corroborate the allegation. Confidential interviews did not report a lack of supervision and denied any knowledge of C1 having inappropriate telephone conversations. Based on confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the allegations that facility staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in youth (C1) having sex with an unknown adult while at the facility and engaging in inappropriate behaviors with unknown person(s) on the phone while at the facility may have happened or be valid, but there is not preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, the LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and given to Facility Manager Doris Santiago.
investigation_findings: 13On February 13, 2025, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete made an unannounced visit to Stella Maris Growth Center Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Facility Manager, Doris Santiago, to deliver the investigative finding for the allegations mentioned above. The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator (Inv) Dennis Seng of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Bureau. The investigation included interviews with the clients in care (C1-C4), STRTP staff (S1-S8), and the County Social Worker (CSW). On August 15, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation facility staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in youth (C1) having sex with an unknown adult while at the facility. It was alleged on December 28, 2023, due to the lack of supervision C1 was able to sneak an unidentified adult into the STRTP without the facility staff's knowledge. During the investigation Inv Seng did not obtain any evidence to support the allegation. (Continued on LIC 9099C) UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent a minor from being physically abused, it was alleged that a minor hit another minor repeatedly in the face with a closed fit and pulled their hair while the minor was sitting on the front seat of the facility's vehicle. During the investigation, a confidential interview stated that C1 was seated inside the STRTP vehicle, waiting for S1 to return, while speaking with their social worker. At that time, C2 exited the STRTP, pulled C1's hair and initiated a physical altercation. The same interview reported that C1 called out for S1, but S1 did not hear. Another confidential interview stated that C1 refused to exit the vehicle because they had already planned to go out for dinner. S1 was inside the STRTP to address C2 and C3, who had recently returned from running away, and to document the incident in the logbook. While S1 was inside, C2 went outside again and attacked C1. Furthermore, it was reported that while C1 was inside the STRTP vehicle discussing C2's biological mother, C2 exited the facility and engaged C1 in a physical altercation without S1's knowledge. A confidential interview stated that S1 could not leave the facility with C1 because C2 and C3 had recently returned form runaway. This let C1 be upset and refuse to exit the vehicle. The same interview indicated that S1 moved in and out of the STRTP, but ultimately C1 refused to leave the vehicle despite encouragement. Additionally, S1 went back inside to contact the facility manager, at which point C2 struck C1. Reports indicate that S1 did not observe the physical contact or injuries on C1. When S1 was later informed that C2 had struck C1, S1 observed C1 with a flushed face while C1 remained seated with their seat belt on and no sign of distress was observed. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff (S1) did not prevent client #1(C1) from being physically abused may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the alleged violation. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, Appeal Rights, and LIC811 were provided to Ashton Porter via email due to technical difficulties.

On April 21, 2025, Community Care Licensing received information alleging that staff did not prevent a minor from being physically abused. On April 28, 2025, at 9:35AM, LPA initiated the investigation at STRTP and there were no immediate deficiencies observed. In addition, LPA Caballero visited the facility to conduct more interviews. During the investigation, LPA Caballero interviewed clients (C1, C2, and C4) and three staff. Client # 3 declined an interview and client #5 was on a home visit. The county social worker was not interviewed due to unsuccessful attempts. LPA reviewed pertinent documents from clients' files UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Regarding the allegation staff handled minor in a rough manner resulting in injury, it was alleged that a staff member put hand around a client's neck and a client began to hit staff as the client felt threatened by staff. During the investigation, a confidential interview stated that staff #1(S1) and client #1(C1) were going back and forth over keeping the light on or off in C1's bedroom and S1 slapped C1's hand and put S1's hands around C1's neck. The same interview reported that C1 punched S1 and S1 slammed C1 to the ground. Another confidential interview stated that S1 was trying to supervise the clients inside of C1's bedroom because C3 had sneaked into the STRTP during late hours from the other STRTP Stella Maris Growth Center III. The same interview reported that S1 had already called law enforcement due to C2 being there but wanted the lights on in the room to supervise the clients. The interview continued by stating that the clients turned the light off in the room and S1 turned the light back on at one-point S1 and C1 were turning the light on and off and C1 slapped S1 on the hand. Furthermore, it was reported that S1 turned the light on again and C1 started to punch S1 and grab S1 by S1's hair. S1 slipped from the ice on the floor and C1 and S1 were on the floor while S1 was trying to get C1 to calm down. CSW stated that she received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Other confidential interviews indicated that a slap was heard inside the room, however, no one observed either S1 or C1 slap each other's hand. The witnesses observed C1 and S1 on the floor. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the alleged violation. There were no other witnesses to this incident. In regard to the allegation that staff engaged in verbal altercation with minor, it was reported that staff engaged in an argument with a client regarding keeping the bedroom light on. A confidential interview indicated that S1 and C1 argued back and forth about the light but denied that it constituted a verbal alteration. Another interview described the situation as a power struggle between S1 and C1 over turning the light on and off. A separate interview reported no yelling from S1 but confirmed that S1 and C1 argued about keeping the bedroom light off. CSW stated receiving inconsistent information regarding the alleged violation. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff #1(S1) handled client #1(C1) in a rough manner resulting in injury and engaged in verbal altercation with C1 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, Appeal Rights, and LIC811 were provided to Head of Service Ashton Porter.

narrative: Regarding the allegation of Staff #1 (S1) speaking inappropriately to residents. Confidential interviews corroborated that S1 would use a derogatory term to refer to Foster Child #1 (FC1), Foster Child #2 (FC2), and Foster Child #5 (FC5). Confidential interviews revealed that S1 used this derogatory term towards FC1, FC2, and FC5 on more than one occasion. Regarding the allegation of Staff #2 (S2) threatening to "slap" Foster Child #1 (FC1). Confidential interviews revealed that on September 2019, FC1 and S2 got into a verbal altercation. The altercation was due to FC1 refusing to fill out paperwork that S2 asked FC1 to fill out. Confidential interviews corroborated that during the altercation, S2 told FC1, S2 was going to "slap" FC1. Based on confidential interviews and record review, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that facility staff (S1) spoke inappropriately to FC1, FC2, and FC5, and facility staff (S2) threatened FC1. The allegations are there found to be substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 84072 (d) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted. A civil penalty was assessed for a repeat violation of regulation Section 84072 (d) Personal Rights. A copy of the LIC 9099, LIC 9099-D and LIC 421FC was emailed to Charles Ohaeri for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file. A copy of the the LIC 811 and Appeals Rights were emailed to Charles Ohaeri. Regarding the allegation of Staff #1 (S1) not providing privacy to FC1 during a therapy session in the facility. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting statements provided to LPA. Witness interviews revealed S1 was standing outside the closed door of the therapy room and was listening to FC1's therapy session. Additional interviews revealed S1 was not standing outside the door of the therapy room. It was further revealed that S1 does not invade the privacy of the residents while they have therapy sessions in the facility. Regarding the allegation of facility staff not providing appropriate hair products to residents. It was reported that residents in the facility have specific hair care needs and staff only buys hair products from a discount store, which does not carry the specific hair products. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting statements provided to LPA. Witness interviews revealed facility staff will buy, from any store, the hair products needed based on the resident's hair care needs. Additional interviews revealed facility staff does not buy hair products specific to the needs of the residents' hair. Based on witness statements and confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff #1 (S1) did not allow Foster Child #1 (FC1) to have privacy during FC1's therapy session and facility staff do not give minors appropriate hair products, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, and Appeals Rights were emailed to Charles Ohaeri for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.

On June 16, 2021, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Natasha Dunlap and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jazmond Harris conducted a post-licensing inspection of the facility. Upon arrival, LPM and LPA met with Facility Manager, Doris Santiago. The facility was toured inside and out at 1: PM. There are currently six clients in placement (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated June 16, 2021. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean; free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. A complete First Aid Kit was locked and stored in the staff office as well. The facility has 3 bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room. Each bedroom has two beds and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The facility has two bathrooms for clients' use. The bathrooms were in working order. The hot water in the client bathroom sink was measured and deemed to be safe. Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with a wrought iron exterior. The enclosure was measured to be over 5 feet tall, with a self-latching gate that swings outward. During the facility inspection, LPM Dunlap and LPA Harris observed broken tile pieces by the pool area. LPM Dunlap asked for the tile to be removed from the area where clients have access. Per Facility Manager, there are no firearms or weapons in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Administrator, Charles Ohaeri is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employes Facility Manager, Designated Managers, and Therapist. Licensee is in the process of obtaining Mental Health Certification. LPM and LPA reviewed 5 clients files. Client files were complete. Client #5's updated needs and service plan will be sent to LPA Harris at a later time. Three staff files were reviewed. Staff files were missing Tuberculosis Test Results and documents will be sent to LPA Harris for verification. CPR/First Aid Certificates were observed and were valid. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. LPM and LPA discussed the following with Facility Manager: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts, as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPM and LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Based upon the inspection of client records and interviews with staff, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. Exit interview conducted and copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

On September 8, 2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jazmond Harris and Sarah Smith conducted an annual inspection of the facility. Upon arrival, LPAs met with Facility Manager, Doris Santiago. The facility was toured inside and out at 10: AM. There are currently four clients in placement (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated September 8, 2021). A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean; free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. A complete First Aid Kit was locked and stored in the staff office as well. The facility has 3 bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room. Each bedroom has two beds and there is one client per bed. LPAs observed adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. Per Interim Licensing Standards, clients should have a locked container available in order to store contraceptives and have access to the key. Per interview and observation, clients do not have the items. LPAs will provide technical assistance. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The facility has two bathrooms for clients' use. The bathrooms were in working order. The hot water in the client bathroom sink was measured and deemed to be safe. Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with a wrought iron exterior. The enclosure was measured to be over 5 feet tall, with a self-latching gate that swings outward. The pool appeared to be cleaned and free of excessive debris. Per Facility Manager, there are no firearms or weapons in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Administrator, Charles Ohaeri is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employes Facility Manager, Designated Managers, and Therapist. Licensee is in the process of obtaining Mental Health Certification. LPAs reviewed four clients' files. Client #2 and #4 is missing their updated needs and service plan; citation to follow. All four clients refused to be interviewed by LPAs. Five staff files were reviewed. CPR/First Aid Certificates were observed and were valid. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. During staff interviews, staff were unable to answer questions regarding needs and service plans, trauma informed care, and emergency intervention plans. LPAs discussed the following with Facility Manager: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts, as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPAs discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Based upon the inspection of client records and interviews with staff, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. Exit interview conducted and copy of this report, along with the LIC 811 and 9099-D will be provided to the facility.

deficiencies.title:
Modifications to The Needs And Services Plan



(a) The needs and services plan specified in Section 87068.2 shall be updated at least every 30 days to determine the following

narrative: Client #1 requested a couple of more minutes to finish getting dressed for work. At that time, Staff Member, Client #2, and Client #3 sat in the car while Client #1 finished. It was advised that as soon as Client #1 came outside, Staff Member began to pull out of the driveway and transport Client #2 to work. Information obtained from Administrator and County Social Worker stated the incident was not detrimental to the health and safety of Client #1 due to their age and behaviors. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation as interviews deny C1 was left unattended and other interviews state C1 was left unattended for a short period of time at the facility. It was also reported that Administrator referred to client in an inappropriate manner and failed to treat client with dignity. It was reported that Administrator stated, "We can not treat you like a retarded infant." Administrator denied making the claim. Administrator stated he attempted to help Client #1 understand that their cooperation in the program would be beneficial to everyone. Administrator stated that he said Client #1 is not a child anymore. Information obtained from staff and county social worker stated that everyone treated Client #1 with dignity and respect, but there was always a complaint or issue. County Social Worker stated Client #1 was not satisfied with any placement, very defiant, and has a history of making false allegations in order to be removed. LPA Harris received inconsistent information regarding the allegations. Based on interviews and information obtained, Administrator referred to client in an inappropriate manner, Staff Member left Client #1 unsupervised, and staff failed to treat client with dignity, may or may not have occurred; therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report will be provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On November 10, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jazmond Harris met with Facility Manager, Doris Santiago to deliver the findings for the investigation pertaining to the listed allegations. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection August 24, 2022 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care staff and 4 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 24, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and crisis management plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Latricia Rogers and LPM Angela King observed training records showing staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Charles Ohaeri, Administrator..

On August 31, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena conducted an annual inspection of the facility. Upon arrival, LPA met with Facility Manager, Doris Santiago. The facility was toured inside and out at 9:40AM. There are currently six clients in placement (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated August 31, 2022). A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean; free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/books/games were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. The menu was posted and it provided weekly meals, snacks and alternative food menu options. The following forms were posted. Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. LPA informed Facility Manager that the updated Personal Rights must be posted. LPA will email the updated form to Facility Manager. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. A complete First Aid Kit was locked and stored in the staff office as well. The facility has 3 bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room. Each bedroom has two beds and there is one client per bed. LPA observed adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The facility has two bathrooms for clients' use. The bathrooms were in working order. The hot water in the client bathroom sink was measured and deemed to be safe. Administrator, Charles Ohaeri is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employes Administrator, Lead Facility Manager, Facility Manager, Shift Managers, Head of Service, and Clinical Therapist. LPA Urena reviewed staff and client files. LPA Urena interviewed two staff and one client. There were 3 clients on grounds during the time of the inspection. All clients denied to be interviewed after LPA Urena made two request to be interviewed. Based on record review Facility cited, see LIC D for deficiencies. Exit interview conducted and copy of this report, along with the LIC 809-D and Appeals Rights will be provided to the facility.

On September 12, 2022, at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena conducted a case management inspection based on information received during the annual inspection that was conducted on August 31, 2022. LPA Urena met with Facility Manager Doris Santiago and conducted a walk through of the facility. LPA Urena observed that the facility did not have the updated personal rights posted as advised by LPA on August 31, 2022. Facility is being cited for the violation of Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) 87072(a)(1). Each facility licensed to provide foster care for children and nonminor dependents shall post a current listing of a foster child's rights, as specified in Health and Safety Code Section 1530.91. (1) The rights listed on this posting shall be consistent with the list of rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9(a) and as set forth in this Section. LPA conducted an inspection of all clients mattresses. LPA observed that C1-C4 have mattresses that were ripped, stained, and in need of replacement .C2 has a broken bed frame. The dresser that is located in C5's room has a top drawer that is missing handles. Facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) 87088(c)(1) (c) The licensee shall provide and make readily available to each child the following furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for personal care and maintenance of personal hygiene:(1) An individual bed maintained in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillow(s) which are clean and in good repair. Based on confidential interviews conducted by LPA on August 31, 2022 it was reported that clients are having issues with the food the facility is providing. Confidential interviews stated that clients are not being offered to be part of the menu planing or grocery shopping as they were before. LPA additionally observed that the weekly lunch menu options has the same food options for the weeks of 08/01/22 through 09/18/222. Facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standard 87076(6) As agreed, upon with a licensee, a child shall have the opportunity to plan meals, grocery shop, and store and prepare food. Continued on page Lastly, staff did to report the incident that occurred 09/03/22 within the required time frame as specified on Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) 87061(j)(1) The incident involved injury to C1, and law enforcement was contacted. Community Care Licensing received an email of the report on 09/07/22 which was four days after the incident had occurred. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) 87061(j)(1) The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE or a report containing all the information required in LIC 624-LE, regarding any incident that involves law enforcement contact with a child in the facility. (1) The licensee shall make an initial report to the Department no later than the next business day following each incident. The initial report shall include all information described in Section 87061(j)(2)(A) through (E) that is known to the licensee at the time the report is made.

On September 21, 2022, at 8:40AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena, conducted an in person visit to the facility to follow- up on the deficiencies noted on September 12, 2022. Lpa C. Urena met with Youth Counselor Tyressha Earl and conducted a walk through of the facility. LPA observed that updated postings of foster children's personal rights has been posted. Additionally, LPA observed that mattresses for all clients have been replaced and are in good repair. Regarding the food, Facility Manager Doris Santiago stated that clients are being included in the shopping list menu. Licensee provides an open space on the menu that allows clients to participate in food selections Additionally, Licensee provided LPA with a copy of the new menu. Regarding client furniture LPA C. Urena observed that the drawer located in room two has not been repaired or replaced as advised by LPA on September 12, 2022. Facility Manager LaKeicha Chaney informed LPA C. Urena that Licensee has a drawer and is in the process of replacing it. Facility Manager provided LPA C. Urena with a photo of the replacement drawer on the day of this visit. Licensee will send LPA C. Urena a photo further showing that the drawer has been replaced and located in C5's room.

On May 25, 2022, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging that staff did not prevent the spread of lice, shampoo is not accessible to minors, and staff did not provide a client with a safe place to store personal belongings. Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent the spread of lice, a confidential interview stated that C1 was provided a head lice shampoo treatment at the STRTP. Confidential interview continued stating that staff combed C1's hair daily. Confidential interview added that C1's lice problem did not go away and C1's former resource mother was treating C1's lice outside of the facility. Another confidential interview stated that C1 did not have lice while placed at the facility, however, another client placed at the facility came into placement with lice and was being treated for lice when C1 was placed at the facility. Confidential interview continued stating that C1 was concern about the client's head lice and was fearful that lice could spread at the STRTP. A confidential interview stated not knowing if C1 had lice when placed at the facility. Confidential interview continued stating that C1 did not report issues with lice. Confidential interview continued stating that CSW may have gotten a report of C1's lice but could not recall. In regard to shampoo not being accessible to minors, a confidential interview stated that STRTP staff provided shampoo, but it was locked inside the STRTP's office. Confidential interviews indicated that currently all clients have personal boxes that contain a variety of hygiene products. Confidential interviews continued stating that although when C1 was placed at the facility shampoo was kept locked in the office, but staff provided shampoo to clients upon request. Concerning staff not providing a minor with a safe place to store personal belongings allegation, a confidential interview stated that C1's personal belongings were stored in C1's bedroom. Confidential interviews stated that clients have storage space in their rooms, and dressers where clients can store personal belongings. A confidential interview stated that C1 did not report concerns about not having a safe place to store personal belongings. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff did not prevent the spread of lice, shampoo is not accessible to C1, and staff does not provide C1 with a safe place to store personal belongings, may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations, therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to STRTP's Lead Facility Manager, LaKeicha Chaney.

narrative: On October 11, 2022, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging that staff uses profanity towards minors and staff makes minors feel uncomfortable. In regard to the allegation that staff uses profanity towards minors, it was specified that S4 uses profanity towards clients. Confidential interviews denied that S4 uses profanity when speaking to clients. Confidential interviews further stated that C1 and C3 have not expressed concerns or stated that S4 was using profanity when speaking to clients. Confidential interviews stated that S4 was liked by clients and clients engaged in therapy sessions without concerns. A confidential interview stated that S4 was using profanity when speaking to C3. Confidential interview continued stating that S4 intimidated C3 when C3 talked back to S4. A confidential interview stated that during one-on-one visits with C1's County Social Worker, C1 has not expressed concerns about S4. Confidential interview further stated that C1 is very open and informs County Social Worker about everything but C1 has not reported any problems or concerns with staff. Confidential interview also stated that C1 has asked County Social Worker to stay in the program and expressed liking the placement. Another confidential interview further stated that C1 and C3 became aggressive towards S4 after S4 requested the removal of C3 from the program. Confidential interview further stated that C1 and C3 attempted to attack S4 due to S4's comments during a meeting. Another confidential interview stated that S4 was observed being professional and engaging well with clients. Another confidential interview stated that clients are the ones that use profanity during therapy sessions when expressing emotions. Regarding the allegation that staff makes minors feel uncomfortable, confidential interviews reported feeling comfortable around S4. Confidential interviews stated that the reason clients participate in therapy sessions was due to S4 making clients feel comfortable. Confidential interviews reported that staff have not heard about any statements or comments from clients that S4 makes clients feel uncomfortable. A confidential interview denied being inappropriate with C1 and C3. Confidential interview further stated that when S4 addresses clients it is with a trauma informed approach. Confidential interview further stated that C3 would become jealous when S4 would not speak to C3 first. Confidential interview further stated that clients and staff have made comments when C3 refers to S4. Another confidential interview stated that S4 made C3 feel uncomfortable due to the questions being asked and the way S4 looks at C3. Another confidential interview stated that it was difficult to pinpoint the truth due to client's behaviors and history of lying. Continued on LIC C page 3... Based on the confidential interviews, the allegations that S4 uses profanity towards clients, and S4 makes clients feel uncomfortable, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager, Doris Santiago

narrative: On December 12, 2022, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena arrived unannounced at Stella Maris Growth Center III Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for a case management. LPA Urena was met by Youth Care Counselor/Shift Manager Shawnte Arredondo. LPA Urena was informed that the census for the STRTP is six. At: 11: AM, LPA Urena conducted a Health and Safety inspection and no immediate deficiencies were observed. At 11: AM, LPA Urena attempted to view the STRTP's video camera recordings for the night of October 31, 2022, to November 1, 2022. LPA Urena observed Facility Manager (FM), Doris Santiago attempting to retrieve the recordings. LPA Urena was later informed that the recordings could only be accessed within 30 days, and the dates that LPA Urena was requesting to view were no longer available. Therefore, for those reasons LPA Urena was unable to view the recordings and no additional information could be obtained. Additionally, LPA Urena reviewed Client 1 (C1's) file and requested copies. On November 10, 2022, Community Care Licensing received a Special Incident Report stating that Client 1 (C1) was found unconscious on the facility's front yard by two staff members (S2, S3). Furthermore, it was stated that S2, and S3 observed unknown vehicle pass by on the STRTP's cameras and also saw someone knocking at the door. However, the report did not specify any details. LPA Urena provided FM a copy of the Special Incident Report, and a copy of the 24-hour notice that Community Care Licensing received from the STRTP on the date mentioned above. FM agreed that the report needed more clarification. This case management is being extended due to the need to gather additional information. A Copy of this report was discussed and provided to Facility Manager, Doris Santiago.

During the investigation, Confidential interviews stated that staff have expressed concerns to management about C3's ongoing behaviors, however, nothing has been done. Confidential interviews stated that C3 bully's clients, likes to stir up conflict among clients and threatens other clients. Confidential interviews stated that S3 and S4 have a relationship with C3's family members that is causing the program from removing C3 from placement. Confidential interviews further stated that the relationship between C3, S3 and S4 is affecting consequences to be enforced. A confidential interview stated that if S3 and S4 did not have a relationship with C3's family members C3 would have been removed from placement due to ongoing behaviors that have placed other clients at risk. A confidential interview stated that the altercation that occurred between C1, C2, C3, and C4 was due to C3 stirring up conflict among clients. Confidential interview further stated C1 has spoken up about the issues with C3 and C4, but it has not made a difference. Confidential interview further stated that when C1 has spoken up about the issues it has made C3 and C4 more upset. A confidential interview stated that there is a staff member at the STRTP that has a relationship with C3's family and has been cleared for placement of C3. Confidential interview further stated that management from C3's County Social Worker and management for the STRTP are aware of the relationship. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that staff are not providing a safe environment for minors is supported and proven by evidence. The facility is cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Treatment Facility (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards Section 87072(c)(11) PERSONAL RIGHTS. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and provided to Facility Manager, Doris Santiago During the investigation, a confidential interview stated that S5 and S6 were present during the altercation and attempted to diffuse the fight but were unsuccessful. Confidential interview further stated that S5 called law enforcement and reported the incident to management. Other confidential interviews stated that when staff witness a physical altercation among client's, staff are trained to break up the fight, talk to clients, and conduct group meetings with clients and staff to address the situation further. Another confidential interview stated that S1 assisted C1 in obtaining medical attention after the altercation. A confidential interview stated that C3 instigated the altercation between C1 and C2. Another confidential interview stated that C3 and C4 made the situation worst which resulted in C1's overall injuries. Another confidential interview stated that staff did not report the altercation to C1's county social worker. Confidential interview further stated that C1's county social worker found out about the altercation through a third party. Confidential interview continued stating that shortly after the altercation there was a meeting conducted and program staff did not have a solid plan. Confidential interview further stated that program staff were back and forth on whether to remove C3 from placement or not. Other Confidential interviews admitted that C1 and C2 were involved in a verbal altercation earlier in the day. Another confidential interview stated that C1 did not expect to get "jumped" by all three clients later that evening. Confidential interview further stated that staff were aware of the issues that were occurring between C1, C3 and C4. Based on the confidential interviews, the allegation that minors engaged in a physical altercation resulting in injuries due to lack of supervision, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager, Doris Santiago.

narrative: On February 1, 2023, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena arrived unannounced to Stella Maris Growth Center III Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA Urena met with Facility Manager, Doris Santiago to deliver the finding of a case management. On November 10, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a Special Incident Report indicating that Client 1 (C1) was found unconscious on the facility's front yard by two staff members (S2, S3). Additionally, it was reported that prior to the incident a vehicle was observed passing by the facility. It was also reported that S2 and S3 saw someone knocking at the front door of the facility, however, the report did not specify any other details. Due to the inconsistency of the report a case management was initiated to gather additional information. On December 12, 2022, at 11: AM, LPA Urena arrived at the STRTP to initiate a case management. LPA Urena was met by staff 1 (S1) who granted LPA Urena access into the home. LPA conducted a health and safety inspection, and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Furthermore, LPA Urena attempted to view the STRTP's video camera recordings for the nights of October 31, 2022, to November 1, 2022, however, LPA Urena was informed that the recordings were no longer available. LPA Urena also reviewed Client 1 (C1's) file and conducted an interview with one staff (S1). LPA Urena attempted to conduct an interview with C1, however, C1 could not be reached for an interview. LPA Urena also interviewed two witnesses. During interviews, LPA Urena received contradictory information related to the incident. It was reported that the staff member who witness the events was not the same staff member who wrote the report. Although the incident was reported to CCL within the required timeframe the report did not contain all the required information relevant to the incident that was being reported. Moreover, LPA was unable to obtain video footage as it was stated in the incident report that staff observed the incident via the facility camera. **Continued on LIC C page 2** **Continued from LIC 809 page 1** It was indicated that the videos were deleted and no longer available. Therefore, STRTP is being cited for not reporting according to Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) SECTION 87061(i)(1)(2) REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with LIC D, and appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager, Doris Santiago.

Continued from LIC 9099 pg 1** On January 26, 2023, LPA Urena interviewed another client (C2) and attempted to interview client#3 (C3). On February 1, 2023, LPA Urena interviewed client#4 (C4) and attempted to interview client #5 (5). During investigation, a confidential interview stated that staff use personal money when taking clients out on outings but stated that staff are reimbursed for the expenses at a later date. Other confidential interviews stated that there were times when client's outings were canceled due to the limited funds available for outings. Another confidential interview stated that Licensee provides S1 with weekly funds for outings that were scheduled for the week. Other confidential interviews reported that clients go out and funding is provided for client outings. Based on the confidential interviews, the allegation that staff are not ensuring they have enough money for outings may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Head of Service, Ogechi Nkwocha

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers conducted a case management inspection August 8. 2023 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 8 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 8, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. Lpa L. Rogers observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Doris Santiago- House Manager. This is an amended version of the original report created on 8/8/2023.

narrative: On April 25, 2024, at 5:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of conducting interviews. LPA Linley toured the facility with Charles Ohaeri, Facility Administrator. LPA inspected three bedrooms and two bathrooms. Upon inspecting bathroom #1, the bottom of the cabinet floor underneath the sink was wet and the board was warped and damaged. In bathroom #2, the walk in shower had mold on the bottom of the floor, the sides of the shower, and the shower door. The shower faucet was dripping and could not be fully turned off during LPA's inspection. There were missing drawer knobs to pull out the dresser drawers in bedroom #2 and #3. Based on LPA's observation, the facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, regulation 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was reviewed with Charles Ohaeri. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given to Charles Ohaeri. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: On September 25th, 2024, at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez met with Facility Manager LaKeicha Donald. During the inspection LPA M. Perez observed there to be four holes patched with dry wall and one hole patched with plywood. The wall with the one hole patched with the plywood needs to be painted over as part of their plan of correction. LPA observed the plywood was not painted over and the Administrator requested an extension. Based on LPA observations and the facility needing an extension the facility is being issued a technical violation of the California Code Regulations 80087(a). On October 18, 2024, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Maryjane Perez and Joon Choi arrived at Stella Maris Growth Center III Short-term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to conduct annual required inspection. LPAs met with Facility Manager (FM) Doris Santiago who granted us access into the home. Currently, there were 5 ambulatory clients in the home and licensed for a capacity of 6. The Facility was toured both inside and out with the Facility Manager. The home is a one story house and consist of: Office: That holds medications, allowance, locked sharps, and fire extinguisher #1 inspected Aug. Bathroom #1: Water runs at 119 degrees Bedroom #1: Furnished with 2 twin beds with fitted sheets and blankets as well as a closet and dresser with plenty of storage space. Bedroom #2: Furnished with 2 twin beds, a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps one client Bedroom #3: Furnished with 2 twin beds, a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps two clients and has Bathroom #2. The water in bathroom #2 reaches 105.2 degrees Living room: Has couches and TV as well as board games. Kitchen: Has plenty of food stocked with clean utensils, fire extinguisher #2 inspected Aug. 2024. Garage/ Laundry Room: Kept clean and holds back up refrigerator and freezers. Washer and dryer with detergent. Backyard: Enclosed with fence and had side gate along with a storage shed and therapy room with a bathroom. There is a pool with a 5ft'7in gate surroundings it. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. There were adequate drawer and closet pace for children's belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. The facility cars had proof of insurance and registration all up to date, there was a fire extinguisher #3 that was up to date, first aid kit with all supplies intact. LPAs interviewed 2 staff and 3 client. LPAs reviewed 5 staff files and 5 client files. During file review one deficiency was observed: CCR 80066 (a)(11) Personnel records tuberculosis test documents as specified in section 80065 (g). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the LIC 809D and 5 technical assistances were reviewed and provided to facility manager Doris Santiago.

narrative: On 01/02/2024 at approximately 10: AM, LPA Joon Choi conducted a case management with Facility Manager Lakeicha Donald. The purpose of the case management was to address two deficiencies that were observed during a health and safety inspection of the facility that was conducted during a 10-Day complaint visit. During the health and safety visit, LPA observed that the window in client room #1, would not open and was apparently stuck in place, and also a drawer in room #1 is inoperable. The dresser drawer in client room #2 is not on stable footing as it "wobbles." LPA also observed there was a distinct sewage related odor in the restroom of client room #3, which is the privilege room where the client's have their own restroom. During the case management, LPA interviewed one staff and three clients. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87072(c)(1), Personal Rights: The Licensee shall ensure that each child...live ina safe, healthy and comfortable home. Type A violation for the sewage related odor and Type B violations for the broken window and dresser drawers. An exit interview was conducted and Facility Manager Lakeicha Donald was provided with a copy of this report, LIC 809D and appeal rights.

Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documents, the allegation that staff did not prevent inappropriate interaction between youth may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Perez interviewed facility manager, client 4, staff 2 (S2), staff 3 (S3), staff 4 (S4), staff 5 (S5) as well as clients 2 and 3 (C2 and C3). narrative: On 1/30/2025, LPA Joon Choi arrived unannounced at Stella Maris Growth Center III, Short Term Residential Treatment Program and met with Direct Care Staff Trelanie. LPA explained the reason for the visit was to conduct a case management regarding Staffing and Client ratios in the facility. LPA arrived unannounced on a previous visit and observed that there was no staff present at the facility with youths in the home. Confidential interviews also reported that at previous times, there were only one facility staff in the facility with five clients present. The facility is being cited for violation of ILS 87065.5(a)(1): (a)In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows (1)During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. The above requirement was not met as evidenced by confidential interviews of facility staff and an admission of the violation by the operations manager.

It was further reported that C1 kissed C2 on C2's face and breasts and that C1 inserted C1's finger into C1's private area. Confidential interviews reported that C2 maintained that this incident happened within the facility. Confidential interviews reported that facility staff conduct routine room checks every 15 minutes, and the described incident was not observed or suspected. Other confidential interviews reported that C1 denied making the stated inappropriate gestures towards C2. Other confidential interviews reported that C2 modified their testimony to the San Bernardino County Open Case Investigator (OCI) and stated C2 indicated that these allegations happened at C2's classroom and not at the facility. LPA received inconsistent information. Confidential interviews reported that OCI evaluated out (aka EVO) their investigation after speaking with C2's school staff. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff did not prevent inappropriate sexual interactions between minors may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Direct Care Staff Trelanie Harris.

narrative: C1 feel uncomfortable because C2 "has been making sexual advances, comments, and talks about self-pleasuring" in the presence of C1. Confidential interviews reported that C2 engaged in inappropriate sexual behavior in the presence of C1 while in their assigned room. Other confidential interviews reported that it was C1 who was making inappropriate sexual gestures toward C2. LPA received inconsistent information. Confidential interviews reported that facility staff conduct routine 15-minute room checks to ensure the safety of the clients. Confidential interviews reported that neither C1 nor C2 alerted facility staff about inappropriate behavior. In regard to the allegation that staff (name not provided) does not prevent a minor (C1) from causing self-harm; it was reported that C1 engaged in self-harm behavior by making themselves vomit on purpose because of C2's inappropriate behaviors. Confidential interviews reported that C1 engaged in self-harm behavior (intentionally making themselves vomit), as a result of being exposed to C2's inappropriate sexual gestures. Other confidential interviews reported that C1 did not intentionally make themselves vomit, rather they "just felt like throwing up" as a result of being roommates with C2. Other confidential interviews reported that after C1 and C2 were no longer roommates; C1 had no feelings of wanting to vomit. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff does not prevent C1 or C2 from engaging in inappropriate sexual behavior while C1 or C2 is present and staff does not prevent C2 from causing self-harm may have occurred or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report (LIC 9099) and appeal rights were explained and given to Direct Care Staff Martha Garcia.

investigation_findings: 13On 03/27/2025, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced visit to Stella Maris Growth Center III Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Lakeicha Donald Facility Manager, to deliver the investigative findings for the allegations listed above. On 01/14/2025, Community Care Licensing received allegations that staff did not prevent the minors engaging in a physical altercation while in care, and staff did not prevent minors from engaging in inappropriate interactions while in care. On 01/02/2024, LPA Joon Choi conducted a health and safety inspection at the RFH, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, LPA Choi obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed client 1, 2, 3 and 4 (C1-C4) and staff 1, 2, 3 and 4 (S1-S4). In regard to the allegation that staff (names not provided) did not prevent the minors (C1, C2) engaging in a physical altercation while in care; it was reported that law enforcement responded to the facility due to continued on the next page UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: In regard to the allegations that facility staff (S2) are not providing nutritious meals to minors (C1); it was reported that the facility had limited food and that C1 was observed to have lost weight while placed. It was further reported that the facility would prepare food only when they knew social workers were going to visit. Confidential interviews reported that the facility had limited food prepared for the clients and that C1 lost weight while they were placed there. Confidential interviews reported that the facility only prepared real meals when they knew county representatives were going to visit. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility prepared all the required meals throughout the day and week and that it didn't matter who was visiting. Other confidential interviews reported that C1 was a "very picky" eater and would not eat the meals that other clients normally eat. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was allowed to choose their own meals that staff would then prepare for them. In regard to the allegation that facility staff (S2) behavior poses a risk to minors (C1) in the home; it was reported that S1 "smoked marijuana" while on duty and while S1 was in charge of driving clients to excursions. It was also reported that S1 used their cell phone while driving which caused them to be distracted. Confidential interviews reported that S1 smoked marijuana while carrying out their duties as a facility staff. Other confidential interviews reported that no facility staff including S1, were suspected of being under the influence of marijuana or other substances while on duty. Other confidential interviews reported that S1 was no longer an employee of the facility and that they declined a request for an interview to address the allegations against them. In regard to the allegation that facility staff (names not provided) do not intervene between physical altercations between minors (names not provided); it was reported that facility staff do not break up fights between clients (no other details were provided). Confidential interviews reported that when clients fight in the facility; the staff do not intervene. Other confidential interviews reported that all facility staff are trained to intervene and do intervene when clients fight in the facility. Confidential interviews reported that no current client in the facility has reported that there was an incident in which staff ignored clients when they involve in altercations. In regard to the allegation that facility staff (names not provided) are not dispensing medication as prescribed to minors (names not provided); it was reported that all the clients in the facility appeared to be over medicated. Confidential interviews reported that a client made an assessment that they believed other clients' medications made them "sleepy and tired." Other confidential interviews reported that the facility staff dispensed the clients' medication correctly according to their prescription orders. Other confidential interviews reported that no other clients or staff reported any issues with medication distribution within the facility. In regard to the allegation that facility staff (names not provided) are interfering with minors (C1) sleep schedule; it was reported that the clients would have to go to bed early and wake up at 4:30 am to get ready for school. Confidential interviews reported that facility staff made clients go to bed early because they had to wake up at 4:30 am to get ready for school. Other confidential interviews reported that the clients' usual bed time was encouraged to around 9:30 to 10:00 pm, and this was to ensure that all the clients got enough sleep to be ready for the next school day. Confidential interviews reported that "no clients were forced to go to sleep early." Other confidential interviews reported that the usual wake up time for the clients was around 6:00 am and this was to ensure there was plenty of time to wash up, get dressed and eat breakfast. Other confidential interviews reported that if clients woke up before 6:00 am, it was usually voluntarily. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff are not providing nutritious meals to minors, facility staff behavior poses a risk to minors in the home, facility staff do not intervene between physical altercations between minors, facility staff are not dispensing medication as prescribed to minors and facility staff are interfering with minors sleep schedule may have occurred or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report (LIC 9099) and appeal rights were explained and given to Facility Manager Lakeisha Donald.

On 02/26/2025, Community Care Licensing received allegations that facility staff are not providing nutritious meals to minors, facility staff behavior poses a risk to minors in the home, facility staff do not intervene between physical altercations between minors, facility staff are not dispensing medication as prescribed to minors and facility staff are interfering with minors sleep schedule. On 02/27/2025, LPA Joon Choi conducted a health and safety inspection at the STRTP, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, LPA Choi obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed client 2 (C2) and staff 1 (S1).
