narrative: On March 24, 2025, at 9:30AM, LPA initiated the investigation at the STRTP and interviewed Facility Manager. There were no immediate deficiencies observed. In addition, LPA Caballero visited the facility to conduct more interviews, and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA Caballero interviewed clients (C1, C3 and C4), two staff, and a County Social Worker. Client #5 declined an interview and Client #2's whereabouts were unknown due to C2's runaway status. LPA reviewed pertinent documents from clients' files. Regarding the allegations that staff did not prevent the minor from causing self-harm and staff did not prevent minor from possibly engaging in CSEC activity, it was alleged that a client was being a danger to self and that a client engaged in prostitution and had unprotected sex with older individuals. There were no further details regarding the alleged violations. During the investigation, a confidential interview stated that staff handled suicidal ideations well and that STRTP staff would send a therapist to talk to client #1(C1) when needed or to the office for supervision. Another confidential interview reported that clients have therapy, and it is a place to stop and speak about clients' emotions. One confidential interview stated that C1 did not self-harm in the STRTP, but the incident occurred outside during the runaway. Furthermore, it was reported that C1 would run away from days at a time and it was hard to pinpoint where C1 attempted self-harm. Other confidential interviews refused to disclose information about C1's CSEC activity. Another confidential interview reported that C1 began to open to staff about prostitution and needed to make more money, but C1 still was reluctant to talk about runaway activity outside of the STRTP. County Social Worker stated that they did not have major concerns about the care and supervision of staff. County social worker stated that C1 showed signs of prostitution here and there but C1 was introduced to trap homes when placed at this STRTP by client #2(C2). In regard to the allegation staff did not provide adequate supervision of minors in care, it was reported that a client was observed with bruises. A confidential interview stated that supervision in the STRTP was adequate with room checks every fifteen to twenty minutes. The same interview refused to provide information regarding the bruises on client #1(C1). Another confidential interview stated that C1 would run away from days at a time and it was difficult for C1 to open about things that happened outside of the STRTP. One confidential interview stated the supervision in the STRTP is adequate because staff conduct room checks. Another confidential interview disclosed that staff have activities for clients in care like Knotts Berry Farm, Soak City, pool parties, and other winter activities. Other confidential interviews did not have information regarding the alleged violation. A confidential interview reported that most of the time staff did not know that C1 was going to do harm but refused to disclose any information regarding the bruises on C1's body. County Social Worker stated that they did not have major concerns about the care and supervision of staff. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff did not prevent client #1(C1) from causing self-harm, staff did not prevent C1 from possibly engaging in Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children activities (CSEC), and staff did not provide adequate supervision to C1 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, Appeal Rights, and LIC811 were provided to Ashton Porter via email due to technical difficulties.
investigation_findings: 13On August 4, 2025, at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero met with Stella Maris Growth Center III Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Head of Service Ashton Porter to discuss the investigative finding for the above stated allegations involving client in care listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 08/4/25. On March 17, 2025, Community Care Licensing received information alleging that staff did not prevent the minor from causing self-harm, staff did not prevent minor from possibly engaging in Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children activities (CSEC), and staff did not provide adequate supervision to minor in care. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Staff stated that sometimes children go off-site on community passes. However, when children are on passes there have been no known reports of major incidents. Staff also state that facility protocol is to contact law enforcement to file a missing person's report if a child elopes from facility; if children were to get into trouble that warrant law enforcement contact, they would be aware. Additionally, children and staff stated they were aware of incidents occurring at the park and fights occurring between neighbors, but they did not know if the incidents were occurring with children from this identified home or the other neighboring home. Staff stated that at times they shadow the children when leaving the home and do not observe children vandalizing properties. Documents reviewed including special incident reports and police reports do not specifically identify any one child or being partaking in abuse with neighbors or vandalism within the park. The documents also do not identify which home the children or being reside in that are conducting the vandalism and abuse. The documents reviewed record that incidents in the neighborhood did occur but they do not clearly identify that the incidents occurred because staff were not providing adequate supervision. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail. There were no deficiencies cited during this tele-inspection.

narrative: Information obtained through confidential interviews and a virtual walk through inspection revealed that the GH has an ample amount of perishable and non- perishable foods available to clients. Staff indicated clients are provided three meals a day that adhere to U.S. Department of Agriculture guidelines with an option for snacks between meals. Staff indicated that some snacks (Sweat snacks) are locked up due to clients trying to make meals out of them causing an unbalanced diet. Information obtained from C1 and C4 revealed that the facility has plenty of food available and further disclosing that some clients like eating out every single meal if they could. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the GH Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was sent via email to the GH Administrator.

The purpose of the teleconference was to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegation. narrative: On 10/26/2020 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Juliet Robles and Janeth Chavez conducted a post-licensing virtual inspection of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with the Administrator Marcy Madison. The (LPAs) along with the facility staff conducted a virtual tour of the facility inside and outside. There are 5 clients currently residing in the home. Tour: (11:35AM) The following was observed during the inspection. The facility is a single-family home in a residential neighborhood. There is a family room, dining area, kitchen, 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, group home office, garage, patio and back yard. All areas are appropriately furnished. The facility is clean, safe, and sanitary. There is adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable food. Kitchen utensils, dishes, glasses were found clean adequate and in good condition. There is a refrigerator and freezer in the garage. The facility provides nutritious snacks between meals and the weekly menu is posted by the kitchen area. Medications, first aid kit, all cleaning supplies and laundry detergent, sharp knives, client files are stored and secured out of the reach of clients. The facility license, emergency disaster plan, activity calendar, ombudsman complaint procedure and personal rights were observed to be posted on the wall. The smoke alarm, fire extinguishers and carbon monoxide monitor are in good working condition. There are no bodies of water on the property. The Administrator stated that there are no firearms or any other item that may be considered as weapon in the Facility. Fire/earthquake drills are conducted once a month and kept in a log. There were no physical plant deficiencies noted at the time of this inspection. Report Continues on Next Page At 12: PM LPAs interviewed two staff. A file review was conducted at 1:00PM and included 2 staff files and 2 clients files. There are currently two clients taking medication. Client files contained an original admission agreement. Files for clients currently taking prescribed medication contained all the required documentation such as the medical consent forms and authorizations. Overall, clients are provided adequate services in accordance with their needs and services plan and are being updated. Staff files contained criminal record clearances or exemptions and child abuse index check, job descriptions, required training and work evaluations. All documents were complete and signed by employee. All staff requiring training, including Mandated Reporter, Emergency Intervention, initial and annual training, was current. All adult individuals who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemption. In accordance with California Code of Regulation, Title 22, Division 6. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809C, LIC 858, and LIC859 were provided to the facility representative.

On 09/27/21 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Janeth Chavez and Raymond Wu conducted an unannounced Annual/Required, on site inspection, at the Facility to evaluate compliance with rules and regulations, and to assess the Facility's continuing ability to meet regulatory requirements. The LPAs met with Facility Manager Supervisor, Delphine Luster and stated the purpose for the inspection. Facility Administrator arrived to facility at noon. Upon LPAs arrival there are 5 clients present in the facility. At 11: AM, LPAs along with Staff 1 conducted a walk through of the entire grounds and observed the overall maintenance and operation of the Facility. The Facility is licensed to provide 24-hour services and supervision to male clients ages 12 to 17 and Non-minor dependents. LPAs did not observe any bodies of water. At the time of this inspection, the LPAs observed the clients being supervised by two staff members and the staff appeared to be providing proper care and supervision. At the time of this inspection, the facility physical plant level of maintenance meets regulatory requirements and is in good repair. Passageways are unobstructed. No disinfectants/cleaning materials were accessible to clients. There are plenty non-perishable foods for one week and perishable food for more than two days, and there were plenty meal snacks. The medications are locked and only accessible to staff capable of administering the medications. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. The Facility license is posted in a prominent place. The fire extinguisher and smoke alarms including the carbon monoxide monitor are operational. The first aid kit is available and complete. During the inspection process the Administrator provided the following: Staff Training Handbook; Emergency Disaster plan, and facility file indicating emergency drills have been conducted, and their Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan; Facility Sketch and fire escape plan; Planned Activity Schedule; Meals Menu for past three months; Current Personal Rights Listing and reporting requirements; Neighborhood complaint procedures; Biannual review of Emergency Intervention Plan; Monthly Log of Restraints; Medication Log; List of staff certified (in writing) to use or participate in emergency intervention (restraints). At 11:30AM, the LPAs reviewed a random sample of staff/personnel and minor/non-minor dependents records. Client and staff records were complete and up to date. The Administrator provided the Client's Roster, Personnel LIC 500, and staff schedule. All individuals who work at the facility, or have contact with clients, have a current criminal record clearance or exemption, Child Abuse Index Check clearance/Live-Scan fingerprints and/or association. LPAs inspected the facility operational requirements, planned activities, register of clients, safeguards for children/youth's cash allowances, emergency procedures, emergency intervention plan, and emergency intervention staff training, documentation and reporting requirements. The facility staff ratio meets regulatory requirements. The Administrator and staff are fully qualified to perform their assign duties of their individual position. As per administrator, Staff are instructed to report personal rights violations and to provide a safe, healthy and comfortable environment to clients in care. All clients in placement attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Clients can contact CCLD or Foster Care Ombudsman in confidence without threats, punishment or retaliation. The facility uses a Toyota Sienna as a means for transporting clients to and from school, extracurricular activities and medical appointments. The van seats 7 passengers. The facility maintains a mileage and maintenance log of the vehicle and have current vehicle insurance. LPAs inspected the van and contains all safety fixtures required by law. The Facility Administrator ensures that Title 22 along with the Facility Program Statement, Staff Training Handbook and other Group Home requirements are followed and understood. Also, that reporting requirements are followed and enforced. At the time of this inspection, LPAs observed no specific reason for concern and did not observe hazards, and/or obvious health and safety issues in the Facility premises. At the time of this inspection the Facility is operating within Title 22 requirements. An exit interview was conducted and Copy of this report, Clients Record/Resident's Records Review (LIC 858), Staff Of Staff/Volunteer Records Review (LIC 859) were provided to the Facility Administrator.

An unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Pamela Silva and Timika Martin on 12/01/22 at 9: AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Marcy Madison, Administrator, and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed two (2) children's records and two (2) staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed two (2) children's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPAs were unable to interview children currently prescribed psychotropic medication due to refusal. LPAs provided a copy of this licensing report to Marcy Madison, Administrator. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs conducted exit interview with the Administrator.

On November 15, 2023, at 12:57 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived at the Stockdale Boys Center, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management inspection regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on November 6, On November 6, 2023, the Department received an SIR stating that on October 24, a client (C1) (see LIC Confidential Names list dated 11/15/23) had become angry after several incidents that morning led to C1 being shadowed by STRTP Facility Manager (S1). S1 interrupted what was perceived to be a drug purchase when an unknown vehicle approached the facility. C1 stormed into facility, again followed by S1, where C1 began destroying property such as walls and televisions and began making threats of violence against S1, another facility manager present (S2), and the Mental Health Specialist (S3). C1 broke into the facility's office, causing further destruction inside the office, including breaking open the facility's medication cabinet and ingesting prescription pills belonging to self and others. Paramedics were called upon staff observing C1 emptying pill bottles into mouth. Paramedics responded after police arrived, resulting in C1 being taken to hospital. During this inspection, LPA interviewed the three facility staff present on the day of the incident. LPA asked for pertinent documents such as C1's NSP, Staff and Client Roster, the Safety Plan devised for client upon placement, relevant SIRs, and staff training related to de-escalation techniques. No deficiencies were cited during this inspection. A signed copy of this report and LIC811 were provided to Delphine Lester. Exit interview conducted. Further follow-up is required.

On December 7, 2023, at 11:10 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived at the Stockdale Boys Center, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management inspection. LPA met with Delphine Lester, Facility Manager. During a tour of the facility on November 15, 2023, LPA observed a hallway bathroom for the clients, and three bedrooms for the clients. One of the bedrooms is a "master bedroom" which has its own restroom, only accessible through the bedroom itself. No deficiencies were cited during this inspection. The STRTP was issued a Technical Violation. See LIC9102TV. Exit Interview conducted. A signed copy of this report and LIC9102TV were provided to Delphine Lester. No further action is required. Appeal Rights provided.

On December 7, 2023, at 11:10 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived at the Stockdale Boys Center, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), for the purpose of following up on an unannounced Case Management inspection regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department. LPA met with Delphine Lester, Facility Manager. On November 6, 2023, the Department received an SIR stating that on October 24, a client (C1) (see LIC Confidential Names list dated 11/15/23) had become angry after several incidents that morning led to C1 being shadowed by STRTP Facility Manager (S1). S1 interrupted what was perceived to be a drug purchase when an unknown vehicle approached the facility. C1 stormed into facility, again followed by S1, where C1 began destroying property such as walls and televisions and began making threats of violence against S1, another facility manager present (S2), and the Mental Health Specialist (S3). C1 broke into the facility's office, causing further destruction inside the office, including breaking open the facility's medication cabinet and ingesting prescription pills belonging to self and others. Paramedics were called upon staff observing C1 emptying pill bottles into mouth. Paramedics responded after police arrived, resulting in C1 being taken to hospital. During the inspection, LPA interviewed the three facility staff present on the day of the incident. LPA asked for pertinent documents such as C1's NSP, Staff and Client Roster, the Safety Plan devised for client upon placement, relevant SIRs, and staff training related to de-escalation techniques. LPA also reviewed STRTP's Program Statement. Investigation and confidential interviews revealed that during the incident, STRTP attempted to de-escalate a situation and called law enforcement as per Program Statement procedure, but a manual restraint was not performed due to safety concerning size and weight ratio. . No deficiencies were cited during this inspection. The STRTP was given a Technical Violation and a Technical Advisory. See LIC9102TV and LIC9102TA. A signed copy of this report, LIC9102TV and LIC9102TA were provided to Delphine Lester. Exit interview conducted. Appeal Rights provided. No further action is required.

However, when the client is out on community pass, C1 does not watch their insulin and consume whatever they want to eat. C1 was taken to the hospital due to high sugar levels; C1 is not calculating intake of carbs. When C1 was first placed at the facility, staff cooked and prepared separate meals for them but they refused to eat. The physician informed C1 can have whatever they want to eat and check blood sugar levels and adjust with insulin. Trained staff observe the administration of insulin. Insulin is self-administered by the client. Statements obtained from the confidential interviews did not provide sufficient information to corroborate the allegation. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights explained and a copy of this report, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.

narrative: On November 13, 2024, at 12:27 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived unannounced at Stockdale Boys I Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting a Required - Year inspection. LPA met with Delphine Luster, Facility Manager Supervisor. A tour of the facility was conducted, and LPA reviewed the following domains in the Compliance And Regulation Enforcement (CARE) Tool: Physical Plant, Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention Plan, and Core/Therapeutic Services. LPA also interviewed or attempted to interview four (4) clients. Physical Plant: The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions are locked in a closet and sharps are locked in the office. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked in office. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Facility has one or more carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at 69 degrees F. The hot water temperature was within the required range. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. No more than 2 clients share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe sanitary and in good repair. ... Operational Requirements: Facility maintains a current, written plan of operation that meets licensing standards. Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. Facility maintains and implements written complaint procedures and the procedures are posted in a publicly accessible location in the facility. The board of directors regularly conducts meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. Cash resources are kept on the facility premises in a locked and secure location. Disaster Preparedness Plan: Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least every month for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Emergency Intervention Plan: Facility maintains a monthly log of each use of manual restraints that contains all required information. The log is available for review by the Department upon request. LPA observed documentation of Emergency Intervention Training and on-going training. Core/Therapeutic Services: Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. During today's inspection, the STRTP was provided four (4) Advisory Notes/Technical Violations (LIC9102TVs). An exit interview was conducted A signed copy of this report, LIC Confidential names list dated 11/13/24, LIC9102TVs, and appeal rights were provided to Delphine Luster. A follow-up is required to complete inspection.

On December 6, 2024, at 2: P.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-named facility the purpose of the visit was to review incident reports. LPA met with Delphine Luster- Facility Manager. On December 3, 2024, LPA met with Delphine Luster- Facility Manager and requested copies of incident reports and law enforcement reports for the last 3 months. On May 2, 2025, at 12:45 p.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Ashley Ruacho and John Bonilla conducted an unannounced Case Management - Incident inspection at Stockdale Boys Center, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident report (IR) received by the Department. LPAs met with Delphine Luster, Facility Manager. On March 27, 2025, the Department received an IR stating that an incident had occurred on March 26, 2025 regarding a client (C1) (See LIC Confidential Names list dated 05/02/25) who had been found in possession of two BB guns and two knives while away from the facility. During this inspection, LPAs requested documents including client roster, facility personnel report, school information, and viewed C1's needs and services plan. LPAs interviewed two staff and one client. No deficiencies were issued at this time. Exit interview conducted. Due to limited information, a continuation of this case management is required.

On January 14, 2025, at 11:45 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced follow-up inspection at Stockdale Boy Center I, a Short-Term Residential Program (STRTP), for the purpose of continuing an Annual inspection. LPA met with Delphine Luster, Facility Manager Supervisor. During this inspection, LPA reviewed the remaining domains in the Compliance and Regulation Enforcement (CARE) tool: Staff Records and Client Records. Staff Records: LPA reviewed four (4) staff records. Staff records contain documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training. All staff subject to criminal records review are fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility at the time of the inspection. Client Records: LPA reviewed three (3) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records reviewed include, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, appraisal/needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. During today's inspection, the STRTP was issued one (1) Type B deficiencies and provided six (6) Technical Advisory Notes/Technical Violations (LIC9102TVs). An exit interview was conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC809-D, LIC Confidential names list dated 01/14/25, LIC9102TVs, and appeal rights were provided to Ms. Luster. Inspection complete.

narrative: On August 4, 2025, at 12:00 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced Case Management - Incident follow-up inspection at Stockdale Boys Center, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident report (IR) received by the Department. LPA met with Delphine Luster, Facility Manager. On March 27, 2025, the Department received an IR stating that an incident had occurred on March 26, 2025 regarding a client (C1) (See LIC Confidential Names list dated 05/02/25) who had been found in possession of two BB guns and two knives while away from the facility. During this inspection, LPA discussed findings with the STRTP Facility Manager, including that the client did not store the weapons at the STRTP, and that the incident occurred away from the facility and staff supervision. Confidential interviews revealed inconsistent statements as to whether the client ever brought the items into the STRTP. Professional contacts did not have any concerns at this time. No deficiencies were issued at this time. Exit interview conducted. Signed copies of this report and LIC811 were provided to Delphine Luster, Facility Manager. No further action required.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Janeth Chavez conducted a case management virtual inspection for the purpose of addressing an Exemption Denial for Ref-1 received on 10/05/2020. LPA reviewed with Administrator the Exemption Denial letter stating that the request for a criminal record exemption for Ref- ID # 7512118225 has been denied. A denied exemption means that this individual may not work or be present in a facility licensed by the Department. This individual is also prohibited from having contact with clients of any facility licensed by the Department. If this individual was allowed to work or be present in your facility because he/she had a previous clearance, this individual must be immediately removed from your facility. Per Administrator, subject individual was a previous employee of the facility during the exemption process. However, the subject individual is no longer employed at this facility as of 10/12/2020. Administrator provided a signed copy of the Confirmation of Removal (LIC 300B) for Ref-1 signed and dated 10/12/2020. LPA interviewed Staff 1 & 2 and both staff stated that Ref-1 is no longer employed at this facility since 10/12/2020. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of LIC 809 & LIC 811 was provided to the facility representative.

On 09/08/21 at 12:27PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Janeth Chavez and Raymond Wu conducted an unannounced Annual/Required, onsite inspection, at the Facility to evaluate compliance with rules and regulations, and to assess the Facility's continuing ability to meet regulatory requirements. The LPAs met with Facility Manager Supervisor, Iraina Holiday and stated the purpose for the inspection. The Facility Administrator was not present during the inspection. At 12:40PM, LPAs along with Staff 1 conducted a walk through of the entire grounds and observed the overall maintenance and operation of the Facility. The Facility is licensed to provide 24-hour services and supervision to male clients ages 12 to 17 and non minor dependents. LPAs did not observe any bodies of water. At the time of this inspection, the LPAs observed the clients being supervised by two staff members and the staff appeared to be providing proper care and supervision. At the time of this inspection, the facility physical plant level of maintenance meets regulatory requirements and is in good repair. Passageways are unobstructed. No disinfectants/cleaning materials were accessible to clients. There are plenty non-perishable foods for one week and perishable food for more than two days, and there were plenty meal snacks. The medications are locked and only accessible to staff capable of administering the medications. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. The Facility license is posted in a prominent place. The fire extinguisher and smoke alarms including the carbon monoxide monitor are operational. The first aid kit is available and complete. An exit interview was conducted and Copy of this report was provided to the Facility Manager. An Annual Continuation will be conducted to complete the inspection tool and review clients and staff files. The are no deficiencies cited on today's inspection.

On 09/09/21 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Janeth Chavez and Raymond Wu conducted an unannounced Annual Continuation to complete the facility inspection. The LPAs met with the Administrator, Marcheletta Madison and stated the purpose of the inspection. During today's inspection there are 3 staff present and there are no clients present. During the inspection process the Administrator provided the following: Staff Training Handbook; Emergency Disaster plan, and facility file indicating emergency drills have been conducted, and their Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan; Facility Sketch and fire escape plan; Planned Activity Schedule; Meals Menu for past three months; Current Personal Rights Listing and reporting requirements; Neighborhood complaint procedures; Biannual review of Emergency Intervention Plan; Monthly Log of Restraints; Medication Log; List of staff certified (in writing) to use or participate in emergency intervention (restraints). At 11:10AM, the LPAs reviewed a random sample of staff/personnel and minor/non-minor dependents records. Client and staff records were complete and up to date. The Administrator provided the Client's Roster, Personnel LIC 500, and staff schedule. All individuals who work at the facility, or have contact with clients, have a current criminal record clearance or exemption, Child Abuse Index Check clearance/Live-Scan fingerprints and/or association. LPAs inspected the facility operational requirements, planned activities, register of clients, safeguards for children/youth's cash allowances, emergency procedures, emergency intervention plan, and emergency intervention staff training, documentation and reporting requirements. The facility staff ratio meets regulatory requirements. The Administrator and staff are fully qualified to perform their assign duties of their individual position.Report Continues on Next Page As per administrator, Staff are instructed to report personal rights violations and to provide a safe, healthy and comfortable environment to clients in care. All clients in placement attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Clients can contact CCLD or Foster Care Ombudsman in confidence without threats, punishment or retaliation. The facility uses a Toyota Sienna as a means for transporting clients to and from school, extracurricular activities and medical appointments. The van seats 7 passengers. The facility maintains a mileage and maintenance log of the vehicle and have current vehicle insurance. LPAs inspected the van and contains all safety fixtures required by law. The Facility Administrator ensures that Title 22 along with the Facility Program Statement, Staff Training Handbook and other Group Home requirements are followed and understood. Also, that reporting requirements are followed and enforced. At the time of this inspection, LPAs observed no specific reason for concern and did not observe hazards, and/or obvious health and safety issues in the Facility premises. At the time of this inspection the Facility is operating within Title 22 requirements. An exit interview was conducted and Copy of this report, Clients Record/Resident's Records Review (LIC 858), Staff Of Staff/Volunteer Records Review (LIC 859) were provided to the Facility Administrator.

narrative: The investigation revealed that the facility reported that Ref. #4 and #5 would come to the facility with different bicycles. It revealed that the facility reported that on one occasion Ref. #4 and #5 threw rocks at cars and were chased by a driver while away from the facility without permission. The investigation revealed that the facility reported while Ref. #5 left the facility without permission, Ref. #5 was hit by a train while intoxicated causing a small injury. It revealed that the facility provided first aid, but Ref. #5 refused to go to Urgent Care. A review of the reports indicating law enforcement involvement indicates that the facility followed their Runaway (AWOL) Plan as it relates to Procedures for Responding to a Runaway Youth. The reports indicated that according to the Procedures staff talked to Ref. #5 and offered alternatives, such as accompanying the staff to the park or swimming, instead of leaving without permission. An interview with the Probation Officer (PO) revealed that the PO had no concerns about the facility. The PO indicated that Ref. #5 was a chronic runaway, and constantly used drugs and alcohol. Interviews with the other witnesses and Ref. #5, revealed that Ref. #5 was intoxicated by liquor or high on drugs on more than one occasion. It revealed that when staff attempted to engage Ref. #5 or confiscate liquor bottles in Ref. #5's possession, Ref. #5 would leave without permission. The investigation revealed that the facility provided Ref. # Core Services and Trauma-Informed Care Services with their mental health personnel, but Ref. #5 would not engage with the therapists. The investigation revealed that on one occasion the facility requested that the Probation Department search Ref. #5's physical person, but nothing was found. It revealed that on one occasion staff searched Ref. #5's bedroom and found one empty liquor bottle. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegations. Based upon the above, it is determined that there is no preponderance of evidence to substantiate that the facility did not properly supervise Ref. #5; did not prevent Ref. #5 from bringing alcohol into the facility; nor report incidents that occur at the facility to the appropriate parties. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this complaint. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility representative.

On November 15, 2024 at 10:30 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived unannounced at Stockdale Boys II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting a Required - Year inspection. LPA met with Iraina Holliday, Facility Manager Supervisor. A tour of the facility was conducted, and LPA reviewed the following domains in the Compliance And Regulation Enforcement (CARE) Tool: Physical Plant, Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention Plan, Staffing Records, Client Records, and Core/Therapeutic Services. LPA also interviewed two (2) staff and attempted to interview one (1) client. Physical Plant: The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are locked in the office. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked in office. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Facility has one or more carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at 69 degrees F. The hot water temperature was within the required range. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. No more than 2 clients share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe sanitary and in good repair. Operational Requirements: Facility maintains a current, written plan of operation that meets licensing standards. Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. Facility maintains and implements written complaint procedures and the procedures are posted in a publicly accessible location in the facility. The board of directors regularly conducts meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. Cash resources are kept on the facility premises in a locked and secure location. (Continued...) Disaster Preparedness Plan: Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least every month for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Emergency Intervention Plan: Facility maintains a monthly log of each use of manual restraints that contains all required information. The log is available for review by the Department upon request. LPA observed documentation of Emergency Intervention Training and on-going training. Staff Records: LPA reviewed four (4) staff records. Staff records contain documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training. All staff subject to criminal records review are fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility at the time of the inspection. Client Records: LPA reviewed four (4) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records reviewed include, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, appraisal/needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. Core/Therapeutic Services: Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. During today's inspection, the STRTP was issued two (2) Type B deficiencies and provided thirteen (13) Advisory Notes/Technical Violations (LIC9102TVs). An exit interview was conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC809-D, LIC Confidential names list dated 11/15/24, LIC9102TVs, and appeal rights were provided to Ms. Holliday. Inspection complete.

deficiencies.title:
Modifications to The Needs And Services Plan

(a) The needs and services plan as described Sections 87068.2 and 87068.22, shall be updated at least every 30 days to determine the following

narrative: On January 9, 2025, as C1 was preparing for school, he was walking around with his phone, speaking softly to himself. At that moment, he encountered S1 and S3, informing them that they had been sexually assaulted earlier that morning while they were asleep. C1 was unable to provide any information regarding the alleged assailant and declined medical assistance. S1 reported that the Bakersfield Police had been informed, and soon after, Officer Nelson arrived at the STRTP to converse with C1; however, the information given by C1 was inconsistent, as C1 claimed that the sexual assault had been happening for the last eight months yet had only been living in the STRTP for two weeks. Because C1 provided conflicting details and declined to pursue medical assistance, Officer Nelson consulted with the staff and then left the STRTP. The staff members (S1, S2, and S3) refuted the allegation, asserting that all personnel are trained in trauma-informed care and recognize the significance of upholding a secure and healthy atmosphere for every client. S3 stated that on the night of the alleged incident, they were the only staff member on duty. They described the night as calm and confirmed that no one entered or exited the facility during that time. S3 expressed surprise at what C1 had reported the following morning. S2, the Head of Service, indicated that they have tried to arrange meetings with C1 three to four times weekly; however, C1 often rejected these meeting requests. Furthermore, S2 mentioned that they provided both individual and group therapy sessions and had enrolled C1 in a substance abuse program, due to C1's history of substance abuse, yet C1 has declined to participate in these sessions. S2 also disclosed that C1 frequently suffered from hallucinations triggered by this substance use, which intensified as C1 increasingly went AWOL. Information gathered from the PO indicated that C1 has a background of substance abuse and may exhibit delusional behavior at times. Before C1's absence without leave from the STRTP on January 21, 2025, they had made allegations of sexual abuse. These allegations were communicated to the relevant authorities, and C1 was referred for a medical evaluation at Urgent Care, where no irregularities were detected. Additionally, confidential statements obtained from facility clients refuted the allegation, asserting that they have never witnessed or heard of any staff behaving inappropriately with clients and that they are consistently monitored by staff. Clients also reported having access to mental health services and programs, and stated that they have no concerns regarding the care and supervision they receive. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation(s) are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation(s) occurred, therefore, the allegation(s) are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the STRTP Facility Manager. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the STRTP Facility Manager.

On September 23, 2025, at 11:15 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced Case Management - Incident follow-up inspection at Stockdale Boys Center II, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on a previous inspection conducted September 11, 2025 regarding an incident report (IR) received by the Department. LPA met with Marcheletta Madison, Administrator. On September 9, 2025, the Department received an IR stating that on September 7, 2025, a client (C1) (See LIC Confidential Names list dated 09/11/25) had a behavioral episode which resulted in the client acquiring a bottle of bleach, and drinking from the bottle, spitting the liquid out immediately thereafter. Throughout the Case Management, LPA interviewed three clients, three staff, and one professional contact. Staff denied that a lack of supervision allowed a client to retrieve a bottle of bleach, stating supervision was present, that client grabbed the bottle unexpectedly while another client was doing laundry, and that efforts were made to confiscate bottle from client. The professional contact stated having no concerns with the facility's ability to provide supervision. Client interviews returned conflicting statements regarding the incident. Based on the information provided during the inspection, there are no violations of Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations. No deficiencies were issued at this time. Exit interview conducted. Signed copies of this report and LIC811 were provided to Marcheletta Madison. No further action required.

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed inconsistent statements on what was in the bathroom; i.e. if it was mold, mildew, residue etc. Per interviews, there is housekeeping that clean the bathrooms and clients are encouraged to clean up after themselves and provided with their own cleaning supplies; however, interviews also indicated that clients do not get proper cleaning supplies to clean on their own. Documentation indicates that on 05/20/2020, a Mold Spore Analysis Report - Non-Viable Microbiological Analysis was conducted. Per documentation, the test results do not indicate a mold issue at the date of the analysis 05/20/2020; all inside test results are lower than the outdoor ambient air. In other words, the indoor air is safer than the outdoor air. Although this was the result of the analysis, the allegation was reported on 05/18/2020 and the analysis was conducted on 05/20/2020. Based on the information obtained during confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. investigation_findings: 13On December 14, 2020 at 1:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a tele-visit follow-up complaint inspection with St. Anne's STRTP and spoke with Vice President of Housing Programs Tony Weaver. The purpose of the tele-visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation of Facility is unsanitary, LPA conducted interviews with related parties and reviewed the following documentation: Mold Spore Analysis Report - Non-Viable Microbiological Analysis; C1's Needs and Services Plan; C1's CFT Notes; and Facility's head count. It was reported that C1 did not take a shower in 3 days due to there being mold in the shower. It was reported that residents were instructed not to clean the mold and therefore, C1 has not been able to utilize the shower. C1 confirmed that staff moved C1 to a different room with a different bathroom; however, it was indicated that C1 experienced the same situation. C1 confirmed it was her choice to not take a shower due to her not feeling comfortable showering in bathrooms that she perceived as mold. investigation_findings: 13On April 12, 2020 at 1:30 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cameo Banks conducted a follow-up complaint inspection via telephone to St. Anne's Maternity Home and spoke with Tony Weaver, Vice President of Housing Programs & STRTP Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation process, LPA conducted interviews and reviewed documents. Based on interviews, there were no statements collected to determine that staff failed to adequately supervise clients. Interviews with facility staff revealed that staff were present for the entirety of the incident. Staff gave verbal commands to de-escalate and redirect clients as well as seperating clients who were involved in the physical altercation. Interviews with clients revealed that staff were present and intervened as well. Clients who were involved in the alcercationed remained seperated for the evening without further incident. Facility was in ratio on the evening of the incident and had an adequate number of staff on duty. There was no documentary evidence or witnesses to corroborate allegation. Continued on LIC 9099C UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

met_with: Tony Weaver Vice President of Housing Programs
narrative: Food Service: LPA Martin's observations of facility's dinning and kitchen areas including, but not limited to, food storage, preparation, menus, and temperature controls of refrigerator and freezer storage produced no damaged containers, expired or food spoilage during this investigation period. Food was observed stored, prepared and served free from contamination and spoilage. Accommodations are made for those with special diets and/or allergies. Food quantities are observed ample for facility capacity. Interviews revealed that Clients believe that the food overall is "okay" but, believes the food could be seasoned better. Neglect/Lack of Supervision: A review of client file/records revealed Client #1 (C1) was first placed in the facility on 05/13/2020. At the beginning of placement through current date, the facility has and continues to provide C1 with Spanish translator/interpreter on demand for client's communication needs. C1 disclosed no concerns with the need for Spanish interpreter while in placement. LPA confirmed facility currently has assigned Spanish interpreters employed on each shift. There is at least one Spanish speaking Therapist available for Client's needs. Records reviewed revealed Client #2 (C2) was first placed in the facility on 05/15/2020 through 02/16/2021. During that stint of time C2 left the facility without permission(AWOL) on numerous occasions. A review of records and interviews indicate facility followed appropriate procedures including reporting appropriate parties for each occurrence. Records further indicates suitable measures were taken by facility to address C2's needs including, but not limited to, mental health services and the acknowledgment of the eventual need for a more appropriate placement to meet C2's need for a higher level of care. C2 was not interviewed after unsuccessful attempts during the investigation process due to AWOL status. Although the above allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Based on the gathered evidence the allegations of neglect/ lack of supervision and food service is Unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22. Exit interview was conducted; a copy of appeals rights and this report was emailed to Mr. Weaver.

narrative: On August 24, 2022 at 9:13AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management investigation regarding incident report. LPA met with Kamika Mason/ Associate Director who granted access to the facility. The department received a Special Incident Report SIR #823687 dated August 17, 2022. Kamika Mason stated was aware of the incident with Child #1. Stating that Child #1 was seen by medical doctor due to bites. The doctor determined bites were from bed bugs. Kamika Mason stated staff noticed red bumps and or rash on left arm, legs and stomach on Child #1 after returned from awol on 08/16/2022 about 8: PM. Child #1 stayed in room the whole night and in the morning Child #1 was taken to urgent care on 08/17/22 due to bites on body. The physician stated Child #1's bites were beg bugs. Child #1 admitted to staff that the home that Child #1 awol's to has bed bugs. After returning from urgent care a work order was placed as a preventive measure to exterminate the room and linens were removed and cleaned on 08/17/ Regular pest control maintenance was conducted on 08/18/2022. An additional work order was placed as a preventive measure for the entire circle. LPA observed Child #1's room and did not see any bugs. Talesha Payne / VP of Housing stated they are working to schedule CFTM due to chronic awol , bed bugs in home where Child #1 awols, and looking into providing family additional support to clean up bed bugs. Payne stated will reach out to DCFS to see if funds are available to assist family with dealing with infestation due to Child #1 is chronic run away to this home. Will work with CSW to support Child #1 and help family clean up home. Also in the CFTM looking to address possible approved visits to home to prevent future awol. con ton 809 c LPA requested a copy of the LIC 500, client roster, medical report from doctor, Needs and Services Plan for Child #1 and pest control invoice. All documents were provided to LPA Phillips. LPA Phillips reviewed association list and advised to remove names of employees no longer associated with the facility. Facility will provide LPA Phillips with completed extermination report and CFT notes once completed . LPA Phillips will follow up with facility once extermination is completed and request notes of upcoming CFT. LPA observed facility to clean safe and sanitary. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of the visit. Nothing further to report at this time. Exit interview was conducted and copy of report will be emailed to Talesha Payne / VP of Housing Program

Report amended to state purpose of visit: Licensee Initiated Capacity Reduction On December 21, 2022 at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made an announced visit to ST, ANNE'S STRTP for the purpose of conducting a Case Management, (Licensee Initiated). LPA met Talesha Payne, VP of Housing and Carlos Tobar, Director of Quality Assurance who granted access to the facility and together with LPA Phillips, a tour was conducted. The purpose of today's inspection was licensee initiated capacity reduction from fifity (50) to sixteen (16). This facility provide services to Ambulatory Residents Ages 11-17: Infants Ages 0 through 3. This facility also provide care to non-minor dependents. The census on the date of this visit is fifteen (15). Currently residing in the facility are DCFS and Probation placement. LPA Phillips observed the facility is located in a residential area with 18 bedrooms, located on the second and third floors, with private bathrooms in each room. The unit has a total of 3 pods, and each pod have a total of 6 bedrooms. LPA Phillips observed the following on the 2nd floor: Pod 1: Six (6) Rooms are equipped with 1-2 twin size beds, cribs, adequate drawers and closet space and private bathrooms in each room. LPA observed baby toys and car seats available in the bedrooms. LPA Phillips observed two (2) vacant bedrooms. Pod 2: Rooms are equipped with 1-2 twin size beds, cribs, adequate drawers closet space and private bathrooms in each room. LPA observed baby toys and car seats available in the bedroom. cont on 809 c LPA Phillips observed the following on the 3rd floor: one (1 ) pod Pod 3: Six (6) Rooms are equipped with 1-2 twin size beds, cribs, adequate drawers and closet space and private bathrooms in each room. LPA observed baby toys and car seats available in the bedroom. LPA Phillips observed one (1) vacant room. There are 2 laundry rooms, staff offices, 4 recreation rooms in each circle (equipped with television, cable, and dining area), a medication room, a recreation/activity room (computers, board games, reading books, arts and crafts) cafeteria supplied with sufficient perishables and non-perishables with a posted menu. LPA Phillips observed lockers to store client's personal belongings. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials were observed. Fire extinguishers were all properly charged and serviced. All posting requirements have been met. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the health services department. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Capacity reduction is approved based on LPA Phillips inspection of the facility. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the VP of Housing. There were no deficiencies cited at this time.

On May 16, 2023 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made an unannounced visit to St. Anne's Maternity Home for the purpose of an Annual Random Inspection. LPA met with Carlos Tobar/Quality Assurance Director, who granted access to the facility and a tour of the facility was conducted. This facility provides services to Ambulatory Residents Ages 11-17: Infants Ages 0 through 3. This facility also provide care to non-minor dependents. The census this day is 11. Currently residing in the facility are DCFS clients. The facility is located in a residential area with 18 bedrooms, located on the second and third floors, with private bathroom in each room. The unit has a total of 3 pods, and each pod have a total of 6 bedrooms. Pod 2B: Rooms are equipped with 1-2 twin size beds, crib or toddler bed, adequate drawers and closet space, desk with chair and private bathrooms in each room. LPA did not observe the rooms due to residents refused entry. Pod 2C: Rooms are equipped with 1-2 twin size beds, crib or toddler bed, adequate drawers closet space, desk with chair and private bathrooms in each room. LPA did not observe the rooms due to resident refused entry. Pod 3C: Rooms are equipped with 1-2 twin size beds, crib or toddler bed, adequate drawers, closet space desk with chair and private bathrooms in each room. LPA did not observe the rooms due to resident refused entry. Continue on 809-C There are 2 laundry rooms one on each floor, staff offices, 3 recreation rooms in each circle, equipped with television and couches. LPA observed car seats, strollers baby toys, and highchairs. A round table with adequate seating, computers, board games, reading books, arts and crafts. A locked medication room, a recreation/activity room, cafeteria supplied with sufficient perishables and non-perishables with a posted menu. LPA observed lockers to store clients personal belongings. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials were observed. There is a hardwired alarm system and copy of the fire clearance will be emailed at a later date. Fire extinguishers observed to be all properly charged and serviced. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the health services department. Licensee has provisions for contraceptives to be held by clients or held by facility in the health services department unit located on the 2nd floor. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. The hot water measured at 113.5 degrees and is within the acceptable temperature range of 105 and 120 degrees. Licensee has a plan to ensure core services are provided and all staff are aware of it and are supportive and trained in their respective roles. Licensee is utilizing trauma informed care practices to ensure effective outcomes that promote permanency and client well-being. Licensee has a plan to ensure individual treatment needs are assessed at least every 30 days and recommendations are implemented. Licensee is aware and has established policies and procedures for participation in the Quality Parenting Initiative and Quality improvement project developed by the placing counties. Licensee has a plan for engaging families and providing support to clients during and after placement to promote permanency/well-being. Licensee has a designated mental health head of service staff who communicates and collaborates with county inter-agency placement committees to ensure specialty mental services are delivered. Clients are advised of their personal rights and house rules. Gender identity, expression and orientation are respected and kept confidential. Clients receive services, activities and support and are included in child and family teams regarding decisions about their plans. Clients can file a complaint or elevate concerns without retaliation. Licensee provides resident councils and forms for clients to raise issues. Clients receive or are asked if they want information about healthy sexual development. Continue on 809-C Administrator is present at the facility a minimum of 40 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. LPA inspected facility van and observed valid registration and insurance, first aid kits and fire extinguisher. Licensee will submit Law Enforcement (LE) contact documentation to licensing.Administrator and LPA discussed emergency intervention protocols utilized and proper documentation.Licensee obtained the Mental Health Certification effective date 02/24/2023; expiration date 02/23/2024. The Medi-Cal recertification is effective 04/13/2023 and renewed by 04/13/2025.. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through Council of Accreditation. The Accreditation is valid through November 30, 2026. During the course of the inspection LPA conducted three (3) confidential interviews, reviewed five (5) staff files, five (5) client files. No resident interviews were conducted due to five (5) refused, three (3) sleep, and three (3) at school. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Law Enforcement contacts and incidents involving Emergency Interventions. The facility has a camera waiver and are meeting the terms and conditions. LPA discussed procedures for CFT (Child and Family Team) meetings. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at the time of the Annual Random Inspection. At the time of the inspection, the facility was clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Milena Melkonyan/ STRTP Director

investigation_findings: 13This report is being Amended from the original report dated 04/13/2023 to correct the violation Type and section code. On April 13, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White conducted an unannounced visit to St. Anne's STRTP for the purpose of concluding the investigation and deliver findings on the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator, Talesha Payne and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation, LPA interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed records. Staff interviews revealed the food served to the clients in the STRTP is different from what is served in the cafeteria; that they follow the National School Lunch Program guidelines to provide meals to the STRTP clients; and that food purchased for the STRTP kitchen is separate from food purchased for the main cafeteria. Client interviews revealed meals were not fresh, and that they have started using their own allowance to purchase food. Based on information obtained and documentary evidence, the preponderance of standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. Facility cited on the attached LIC D for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80076(a)(1) FOOD SERVICE. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

investigation_findings: 13On May 09, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made a follow up complaint visit to St. Anne's STRTP for the purpose of delivering findings on the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, confidential interviews were conducted, facility file, Program Statement review, and Incident Reports were reviewed. Statements were consistent that safety checks were conducted each time clients returned from unauthorized absences, school, and community passes. Statements indicated that staff reminded minors in care that anytime they left facility premises without a staff, a search of their person and belongings would be conducted upon their return to the facility. Confidential statements revealed searches were conducted on each minor in care and minors in care were instructed to pull out bra and shake, empty pockets, checking their ponytails, taking off shoes, checking hoodies, bags, strollers, and baby seats for contraband. Based on information obtained from confidential interviews and documentary evidence, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

investigation_findings: 13On April 27, 2023 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White conducted an unannounced visit to St. Anne's STRTP for the purpose of concluding the investigation and deliver findings on the above allegation. LPA met with STRTP Director, Milena Melkonyan and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation, LPA interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed records. Confidential interviews and records did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Staff denied the allegation and stated during the AM and PM shift they maintain a staff/client ratio of 1 staff to 4 clients and during the overnight shift it is 1 staff to 6 clients in addition to a facility manager. Client statements were inconsistent and did not produce corroborating evidence facility staff are out of ratio. Additionally, there were no specific dates or times provided to corroborate the allegation. Based on information obtained, the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Exit interview completed and a copy of this report was left with STRTP Director. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

investigation_findings: 13On April 27, 2023 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White conducted an unannounced visit to St. Anne's STRTP for the purpose of concluding the investigation and deliver findings on the above allegation. LPA met with STRTP Director, Milena Melkonyan and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation, LPA interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed records. Confidential interviews and records produced corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Staff interviews revealed cafeteria staff were not present at the facility to prepare breakfast and that direct care staff present at the facility did not prepare breakfast which resulting in clients in care not being served a meal. Client statements revealed that staff did not provide breakfast in a timely manner. Based on information obtained and documentary evidence, the preponderance of standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. Facility cited on the attached LIC D for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 87072 (c) PERSONAL RIGHTS. 87022.1. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

investigation_findings: 13This report is being amended from previous report dated 07/12/ On July 12, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips conducted an unannounced visit to St. Anne's STRTP for the purpose of concluding the investigation and deliver findings on the above allegation. LPA met with Carlos Tobar/Quality Assurance Director and discussed the findings. During the investigation LPA Phillips interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information regarding the allegation. Evidence revealed food served to the clients was undercooked, burnt and dry, there was insufficient juice brought up for the clients and their babies, the food didn't look appealing, clients and staff would not eat the food and food served was different from the menu. 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations by interviewing staff and Client 1. Client #2 could not be reached to be interviewed. LPA also observed the "STRTP Kitchen", an area where girls can cook their own meals if they do not want what is offered. The STRTP kitchen was fully stocked with all food groups and snacks represented and all of the utensils needed to prepare food. The stove and refrigerator were in working order. Based on interviews and observations, LPA Jones-Steward was not able to obtain conclusive evidence that Client #1 was not fed adequately or that she received "left-over" food. Therefore both allegations were resolved as unsubstantiated. Unsubstantiated means that even though an allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence that it did occur. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: LPA interviewed other involved staff who shared that the facility policy is for clients to ensure that their room is safe and clean before leaving on a pass C1 had not done this yet and we were trying to encourage them to do so. It is also facility policy to walk clients out of the facility when they leave, and to shadow them if clients AWOL. Since C1 was leaving and AWOLing without a pass S3 was sent to walk the client out and shadow. C1 and S3 soon returned, and S3 said C1 agreed to make their room safe first and go out on a pass. Then, when the elevator stopped, S3 stepped in between the doors to hold them open. C1 then hit S3 with an open hand. One staff member shared that "I saw the event happen live on the cameras. I think there was a mis-communication on whether S3 and C1 were returning to get a pass or clean the room. I don't think S3 was acting maliciously, and I think C1 just got overemotional and lost control of herself." LPA attempted to interview S3, but S3 declined and stated that they would only speak through their attorney. LPA was given the attorney's contact information and made multiple attempts to interview the attorney, but they never responded. LPA was shown the video interaction of the event in question. LPA observed, C1 and S3 enter the elevator. S3 pressed the buttons on the elevator. During the elevator ride C1 and S3 were talking with each other. The video did not have sound so their conversation was not heard. When the elevator reached its stop and opened the doors S3 stepped out and held the elevator door open for C1. C1 proceeded to step out and hit S3 with their left hand in an open palm. C1 and S3 continued talking and exited the elevator. LPA received conflicting testimonies regarding the incident in the elevator and staff's interaction with the client. The complaint alleges that S3 held C1 hostage and prevented C1 from leaving the elevator, resulting in an inappropriate interaction with the client. Staff testimonies stated that S3 was not acting maliciously and was following facility policies and procedures to shadow the client during AWOL's and to encourage room safety. LPA observed the video of the incident, and it did not appear as if S3 was trying to block or impede C1, though there was no audio available. LPA was also unable to gain facts from those involved due to the decline and refusal of interviews. . Based on the available information, LPA gathered from interview evidence from staff and clients, and from observations and video evidence review the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation that "Staff had inappropriate interaction with minor." is found to be unsubstantiated. Exit Interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to the administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On 8/21/25 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the above facility and met with Administrator Daisy Delgado for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff and client (C1). The complaint alleges that one day C1 was trying to leave the facility to pick up a check. C1 was not authorized to leave due to an "unsafe" room. C1 was asked to sign a pass paperwork before leaving and took an elevator with S3 to do so. S3 then used their body to block the elevator and stop C1 from leaving. C1 felt like they were being held hostage and slapped S3. C1 then exited the elevator and ran from the facility. LPA interviewed C1, but C1 did not want to talk about the incident. C1 only shared that "Staff made me paranoid and untrusting. I have trauma from the incident. I have not seen the staff (S3) since the incident." UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
