narrative: An announced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 05/05/2021 at 09:00am. This inspection was conducted via Microsoft teams due to COVID19 restrictions on conducting on site inspections at licensed facilities. LPA Segura sent Director of Continuous Quality Improvement Bill Webster and Administrator Ann Anderson a Document Request checklist on 04/14/2021. LPA received client documents via email on 04/27/2021. The facility has 37 clients in placement at this time. LPA requested to review 10 files of children who are taking psychotropic medications. On todays date LPA Segura interviewed 3 staff at 10am through 10:45am facilitated by Bill Webster. At approximately 9am - 10am LPA Segura initiated a medication count with the facility nurse Kathi Buada via facetime. Kathi and LPA resumed the medication count at 1pm and went through approximately 4pm which included a tour of the individual homes. No deficiencies were observed during this tele-inspection. Further time is needed to complete this inspection. LPA will arrange to deliver inspection findings at a later time. LPA Segura provided this report to the administrator and director of continuous quality improvement via email with a read receipt as acknowledgement the report was received.

An announced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 05/11/2021 at 2:00pm. This inspection was conducted via Microsoft teams due to COVID19 restrictions on conducting on site inspections at licensed facilities. LPA Segura sent Director of Continuous Quality Improvement Bill Webster and Director of Client Services Sarah Burton and Administrator Ann Anderson a Document Request checklist on 04/14/2021. LPA received client documents via email on 04/27/2021. The facility has 39 clients in placement at this time. LPA requested to review 10 files of children who are taking psychotropic medications. LPA met with Client Services Director Sarah Burton, Director of Continuous Quality Improvement Bill Webster and facility Nurse Kathi Buada. LPA Segura and two student assistants reviewed the child files. Review of the files revealed that the following items were observed to be out of compliance. Below LPA will reference each child file as C1 through C10, see confidential name list LIC 811 dated 05/11/2021. C1-10: Psychotropic Medication Administration Records were missing the number of refills as required by ILS (Interim Licensing Standard) 87070. C1, C3, C No Indication the child is participating or offered to participate in the development of their ANSP (Assessment Needs and Services Plan) as required by ILS 87068. C1 - C Services not identified in the ANSP as required by ILS 87068.2. The ILS requires the facility include the types of services necessary, including core services, supports, physical and mental health, substance abuse services and permanency and transition services. Out of the 10 files reviewed, only the ANSP for C10, detailed the services to be provided to the child. Note the facility did submit evidence all children are receiving services; however, these are not noted in the ANSP. Continued on 809C C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, C7, C8, C9, C Assessment Needs and Services Plan (ANSP) not signed by the child, authorized representative or both. C2, C5, C7, Current court or parental authorization for psychotropic medication not present in the child's file. The facility provided copies of emails sent to the county social workers for their efforts to obtain copies of the court authorization On 05/05/2021 at approximately 9am LPA Segura and facility Nurse Kathi Buada conducted a medication count at the four homes; Mitty, Riordan, Hanna and McKenna. The medication count was conducted via Facetime. The facility uses a pharmacy that bubble packs their medication which made viewing the medication more convenient. LPA conducted the count by counting when the medication was started according to the centrally stored log and counted how many pills should remain on 05/05 when the inspection was conducted. Medication will be referenced as M1, 2, 3... etc (medication will be listed on confidential name list LIC811, dated 05/11/2021). The following was observed during the medication count: Hanna: C1 - · 9:45am medication count was found to be correct. C4 - · 9:30am M1 was found to have extra two pills that could not be accounted for through the PMAR or centrally stored medication log Mitty: C2 - · 1:30pm M2 was found to have 2 extra pills that could not be reconciled from the PMAR (Psychotropic Medication Administration) or centrally stored log. C8 - · Medication count was found to be correct C10 - · 1:15pm M1 count found one extra pill that could not be accounted for in the PMAR or centrally stored log Riordan: C3 - · 8:50am M1 was in a liquid form, unable to conduct a pill count. Other medications count were found to be correct. C9 - · 9am medication count was found to be correct. McKenna: C5 - · Medication count was found to be correct C6 - · M1 was found to have an extra 3 pills. M2 had correct amount of pills remaining; however, facility staff were not documenting pills given to the child on the PMAR, meaning they were not signing when pills were dispensed to the child. C7 - · Medication Count was found to be correct On 05/06/ LPA Segura reviewed 3 staff files and did not observe any deficiencies. Staff interviews were conducted on 05/05/2021 at approximately 10am -11am. Child interviews were conducted on the following dates: 04/28/2021 at 3pm C1, C2, C4, C8, C10 04/29/2021 at 3pm C3, C5, C6, C7 04/30/2021 at 3pm C LPA conducted exit interview with Bill Webster, Sarah Burton and Kathi Buada; appeal rights discussed and provided. LPA provided the summary report via email upon completion. LPA requested the documents be signed by the facility administrator and returned at their earliest convenience. ANSP and medication deficiencies were observed and cited form the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, and Health and Safety codes during the inspection. Refer to 809D for citations issued.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett conducted an unannounced inspection for the purposes of completing an Annual/Required Continuation Inspection and met with Administrator Ann Anderson.
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett conducted an unannounced inspection for the purposes of completing an Annual/Required Continuation Inspection and met with Administrator Ann Anderson.

On10/19/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required visit. LPA Hiett met with Administrator Ann Anderson and inspected the facility, inside and out. Currently 3 of 4 houses are in use (Hanna, McKenna, Riordan). All homes are clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There are no bodies of water. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom. All bedrooms have adequate closet and drawer space. The homes are maintained at a comfortable temperature. Sharps are kept locked in the kitchen cabinets and toxins are kept locked in cabinets in the kitchen. Medications are kept locked in the staff office. There are carbon monoxide and smoke detectors throughout the facility. There were operable fire extinguishers in the facility. There are complete first-aid kits located in the facility. Applicant understands that the hot water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. There are no firearms on the property. All required postings are present. 9 staff files and 9 client files were reviewed. 5 staff and 5 clients were interviewed. The Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve 67 boys ages 6-17. There are currently 28 residents. The inspection was continued during the following days: 10/20/2021 10/22/2021 10/26/2021 10/27/2021 10/29/2021

narrative: An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Jessica Rodriguez and Lidia Tinoco at Success in Recovery in Visalia, CA. LPA's met with Administrator Shawnaa Supnet and inspected the facility, inside and out. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 75 degrees. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Fence surrounding the pool is in compliance. There are no pets at the facility. Facility has cameras in common areas as well as sensors in all client bedrooms. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. LPA's reviewed client files and conducted staff and client interviews. There were no deficiencies to be cited on this date. A copy of this report was left with Shawnaa Supnet. An annual continuation will be completed at the facility main office.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Jessica Rodriguez and Lidia Tinoco traveled to the Success in Recovery main office in Visalia and met with Brad Harness, Executive Director for the purpose of continuing the facility annual inspection. LPA's reviewed Staff files. Licensee has obtained Mental Health Certification Including the following: Mental Health Program Approval valid through September 19, 2020, a review was conducted on June 18, 2021, and have been in contact with the state, the state report has been finalized and is set to be sent to the agency by October 5, 2021 as verified by an email provided to LPA's. The facility has a county contract through July 2023. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF valid through April 30, 2023. LPA's discussed with Brad the sensors in the client bedrooms. LPA's discussed staff interviews with Brad and covered areas of concerns which included: staffs knowledge of program statement, trauma informed care including but not limited to how it relates to direct care staff, and steps for reporting physical or sexual abuse. No deficiencies were cited during this inspection, a copy of this report was left with Brad Harness.

On 10/17/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to Success in Recovery in Visalia, CA to conduct an announced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection at 10: AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Galvan met with Shawnna Supnet , Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. At 10: AM LPA inspected the facility inside and out. LPA observed all medication, knives, and disinfectants locked. All medications were stored in a lock container inside a locked cabinet. All required documentation was posted and accessible for both staff and client's review. The facility was clean and in good sanitary conditions. Each client was provided a bed, linens, and storage space in their bedrooms. The facility had 3 days of perishables and 7 days of non-perishable. The facility's refrigerator, freezer, and water temperature were all at a safe range. The front and back outdoor areas where free from dangers and hazards. At 10: AM LPA reviewed 3 client's medications and medication records. At 11: AM LPA reviewed Staff and Client files on site at the facility. At 1: PM LPA interviewed 3 clients currently prescribed psychotropic medication. At 1: PM LPA interviewed 2 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA conducted exit interview with Administrator, Shawnaa Supnet at 2: PM. No deficiencies were observed and cited on today's visit. A copy of this report was left with Shawnaa Supnet at the conclusion of the inspection.

On August 17, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to Success in Recovery Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program located in Visalia, CA, and met with Shawnaa Supnet, Administrator. The purpose of this unannounced inspection is to conduct a Case Management regarding a late incident report that the facility submitted to Community Care Licensing. On August 3, 2023, the facility submitted an incident report for an incident that occurred from April 28, 2023. Based on the LPA's investigation and observation, it was determined that the facility has failed to submit an Incident Report within the seven days the incident occurred. The facility is being cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted to discuss this report and appeal rights. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Shawnaa Supnet, at the conclusion of the inspection.

On September 27, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to Success in Recovery located in Visalia, California to conduct an unannounced visit and met with Maria Arteaga, Mental Health Technician. The purpose of the visit was to conduct staff and client interviews for the Required/Random Inspection initiated on 9/22/2023. LPA Galvan conducted interview with 4 clients and 2 staff. No deficiencies were issued or observed at this time. A copy of this report was provided to Tiarena Hunt at the conclusion of this inspection.

On November 28, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to the Success in Recovery Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program in Visalia, CA, to conduct a Case Management and met with Administrator, Shawnna Supnet. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss an incident report that was submitted to the department on 11/21/2023 regarding client 1 (C1) being administered incorrect medication by Staff 1 (S1). (See attached LIC 811) On November 20, 2023, at 8:24 pm, C1 was given incorrect medication, C1 was given C1's morning medication by S1 instead of the evening medication, the mistake was realized after C1 swallowed the medication. C1 stated that it would interfere with sleep pattern. S1 called and reported this incident to the Administrator (ADM). ADM made sure that all staff were checking on C1 regularly throughout the night. LPA Galvan reviewed files and conducted interviews. LPA discussed with ADM the concerns of S1 administering incorrect medication, the importance of all staff verifying & confirming the correct medication is being administered and maintaining medication quality assurance. Based on interviews and record review, the Agency is being cited for the Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, Section Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted to discuss this report and appeal rights. A copy of this report, appeal rights, and LIC 811 were provided to Shawnna Supnet at the conclusion of the inspection.

On March 29, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to the Success in Recovery Main Office located in Visalia, CA, to conduct a Case Management and met with Administrator, Brad Harness and Program Director Elizabeth Reynaga. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss the updates to the Agency's Program Statement. No deficiencies observed or cited during the inspection. A copy of this report was provided to Elizabeth Reynaga at the conclusion of the inspection.

On September 17, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to the Success in Recovery House One Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program located in Visalia, CA, to conduct an unannounced Case Management and met with Facility Representative Toni Brown. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss an incident report that was submitted to the department on 09/12/2024 regarding a medication error. On 09/11/2024, Staff 1 (S1) failed to administer client 1's (C1) (see LIC 811 for confidential names) evening medication. The medication error was noticed the following morning on 09/12/2024. C1 did not report feeling any changes or side effects due to the missed dosage. Administrator met with S1 and counseled S1 on medication procedures. Based on document review, the Agency is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, Section Health Related Services and a civil penalty is being issued. An exit interview was conducted to discuss this report, appeal rights, and LIC 811. A copy of this report, appeal rights, and LIC 811 were provided to Toni Brown at the conclusion of the inspection.

On September 27, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to Success in Recovery I located in Visalia, CA, and met with Administrator Shawnna Supnet. The purpose of today's inspection is to conduct a 2-year required inspection. Success in Recovery II has a census of (4) children and a capacity for 6 clients. A tour of the facility was conducted, a physical plant inspection was completed and included the following observation: All required forms are posted. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility has an above ground that is enclosed with a locked gate meeting regulatory requirement. All required forms are posted. The temperature of the facility was a comfortable temperature of 75 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order and all fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The kitchen has a full-size refrigerator and is operating at safe temperature. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the food menu is available for children to view. A supply of emergency food is stored at the facility. Knives, sharps, medications, chemicals, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are key locked and inaccessible to children in care. LPA observed medications are centrally stored. The dining room is equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all children in care. There are three bedrooms- for double occupancy, all bedrooms are located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings and storage space. Six individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and in good repair. The facility has 3 bathrooms, 1 is used for children, 1 for Direct Care Staff, and 1 for Mental Health Staff, all are operable. All restrooms are stored with hand soap, toilet paper, and paper towels. The facility water temperature is at a safe temperature range. The First Aid kit is complete with all first aid items. The facility has a staff office and is inaccessible to children. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Continued on Page 2... Continued from page 1... There are currently Chief Executive Officer, Program Director, Administrator, Social Worker, Clinician, Direct Care Staff, Head of Service. LPA reviewed 4 children and 5 staff files. A review of the background clearances was conducted September 27, 2024, indicates that all facility staff associated to the agency have DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. The facility currently holds a Mental Health Program Approval valid through September 19, 2025. The licensee has obtained National Accreditation through The Joint Commission valid through April 30, 2026. LPA will need to continue the inspection to complete review documentation, staff, and children's interviews. There were no deficiencies issued today. A copy of this report was provided to Shawnna Supnet at the conclusion of the inspection.

A copy of this report and the technical violation was provided to Shawnna Supnet at the conclusion of this inspection.

On April 10, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to the Success in Recovery Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program in Visalia, CA, to conduct a Case Management and met with Administrator, Shawnna Supnet and Social Worker Joseph Lovett. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss two incident report that was submitted to the department on 04/02/2025 and 04/09/2025. The incident reports disclosed that Client 1 (C1) engaged in sexually inappropriate activities with Client 2 (C2) and Client 3 (C3). (See LIC 811 for confidential names) According to the reports, the activity was consensual among the clients. During the inspection, the LPA conducted confidential interviews and discussed supervision, safety, and bedroom-sharing arrangements as well as compatibility among the roommates/clients. LPA also conducted a physical plant check. The Agency is being cited for the Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, Section Buildings and Grounds. (See LIC 809D) An exit interview was conducted to discuss this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights. A copy of this report, appeal rights, and LIC 811 were provided to Shawnna Supnet at the conclusion of the inspection.

On 06/23/21 at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Pamela Silva and Zeyda Loera conducted an unannounced Annual Required inspection at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPAs met with Administrator Tina Klock and Case Manager Raylene Reyes. The facility currently has a provisional STRTP license. The STRTP's Mental Health Program Application is pending approval. The facility is licensed to provide services to six (6) female clients ages 10-17 and non-minor dependents. There are currently six (6) clients in placement. This STRTP is a single level house located in a residential neighborhood. The facility consists of 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, living room, kitchen, dining area, laundry room, 2 car- garage, and backyard. At 9: AM, LPAs along with Case Manager Raylene Reyes conducted a walk- through of the entire grounds and observed the overall maintenance and operation of the facility. PHYSICAL PLANT Overall, the facility is clean, safe and sanitary. All passageways are unobstructed, and all doors open freely. There are no bodies of water in the facility. There are no firearms or ammunition in the facility. The hot water temperature is maintained between 105 and 112 degrees (F). Temperature in clients' rooms are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). All sinks, showers and toilets were clean and in working order. The fire extinguishers are fully charged. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors were tested and observed to be operable. The last fire drill was conducted on 05/23/21. CARE & SUPERVISION The staff to client ratio at the time of inspection is 1: 2. Facility has non-perishable food items for at least one week and perishable food items for at least two days. A review of weekly menu indicates that facility provides nutritious meals and snacks. Medications are locked in the closet hallway and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. First Aid Kit was readily available and complete. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and other hazardous items are kept inaccessible to clients in a locked cabinet. Knives and other sharps were observed to be locked in a cabinet in the hallway. PERSONAL RIGHTS Facility posts license, client's personal rights, foster youth rights, ombudsman poster. Facility maintains a suggestion box for clients in the living room to utilize. Facility has their daily activity schedule and meals posted. CLIENT RECORDS LPA reviewed all six (6) client records. Facility maintains client cash resources, personal property, and valuables. Client records contain authorization for medical care, admission agreement and copies of the current appraisal & needs service plan. All medications are recorded and logged. Psychotropic medications have current JV220 court order, medical consent authorization is current and is available for review. STAFF RECORDS LPA reviewed four (4) randomly selected personnel records. One (1) out of the four (4) staff did not have DOJ/FBI clearance or exemption, Child Abuse Index Check clearance and/or association. Facility personnel meet staff qualifications and training requirements. Administrator's CPR/First Aid Certification was not current. Staff files contain the Mandated Reporter/Acknowledgement Form. ADMINISTRATION Facility's program statement, emergency intervention log is current and available for review. The Emergency Disaster Plan has not been updated per Provider Information Notice (PIN) 21-03-CRP. The Administrative Organization LIC308 needs to be updated (see Advisory Note LIC9102). LPA was provided with current LIC500 and current Board Meeting Minutes.. At 12: PM, LPAs interviewed one (1) client and two (2) staff members present during the inspection. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, LPAs observed deficiency for an uncleared staff working in the facility. Facility staff assumed that they followed new Guardian Background Check procedures. A Civil Penalty has been issued for 5 days at $100 per day, for a total of $500 (see LIC809-D). Administrator's CPR/First Aid Certification was not current (see LIC809-D). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, along with LIC 809, LIC 809C, LIC 809D, LIC9102, LIC 858, LIC 859 and appeal rights were provided to Administrator Klock.

narrative: On October 12, 2023 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez made a case management inspection to the facility and met Tina Klock, Administrator. The purpose of the case management was to follow up on the Special Incident Report (SIR) the Department received regarding physical altercation between two clients. On 09/19/23, the Department received the SIR dated 09/13/23 regarding the incident. The SIR stated that two clients had physical altercation when one client (C1) grabbed from client (C2) a laptop. The staff was present at the time of the incident, and redirected the clients however, C2 pushed C1, and the latter retaliated hitting C1 on the eye. They both had scratches on the arm. No medical attention needed and both clients refused it. The clients were separated and the therapist and met with the clients to address the issue. At the time of the inspection, LPA spoke to Administrator Klock regarding the incident. She stated that they talked to the clients about the incident and both clients tell their story. The clients patched up things and no similar incidents that happened after that. LPA suggested to Administrator Klock ways to report reportable incidents within 24 hours from the occurrence of the incident either by faxing, emailing to or calling in the incident to Community Care Licensing. No deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection. A copy of LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to the administrator

Continue from page 1 . . . The staff denied the allegation and stated that the staff directed the clients to stop the behavior while in the vehicle. The information indicated that the staff was driving the clients back to the facility (GH) and were in a stop light when a client threw the headphone hitting the staff and then hit another client in the front sit. The information indicated that a client on the back sit hit another client in the back sit a couple of times but was told to stop by the staff driving the vehicle. The information indicated that the client stopped the behavior in the vehicle and there were no other incident on the way to the GH. Other information indicated that the vehicle was waiting at a stop light and was surrounding traffic around the GH vehicle and the incident only took place while the vehicle was stopped at the red light which lasted a few minutes. The confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements about the allegation. There was information that indicated that clients were being taken back to the GH and two of the clients were talking about school when a third client became aggressive because the client thought that the other clients were talking about her. The confidential interviews indicated that the client threw a pair of headphone and hit a client in the front while hitting a client on the back sit a few times. There was information saying that the staff told the clients to calm down and to get along while other information indicated that the staff did not say anything to the aggressive client. Other information indicated that the staff kept driving and other information indicated that the staff slowed down while driving and locked the door to the vehicle. Additional information indicated that the incident lasted about two minutes and the client came down while other information indicated that it was not sure of how long was the incident. The County Social Workers indicated having no concerns with the care and supervision in the GH and indicated that the GH follows up with the clients. Two of the clients in the incident were interviewed and a third one was not available to give a statement. Based on the interviews and records reviewed, the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegation. Copies of LIC9099, LIC9099C, LIC811 and Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.

deficiencies.title:
Criminal Record Clearance

(e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility

narrative: The facility later received notification that the identified staff did not have a criminal record clearance so the staff was not hired. Facility records reviewed show that the identified staff was associated to the facility but no documentation of either a criminal record clearance or exemption was found in the identified staff's file, as required by the Department. A review of Guardian records show that the identified staff is "not eligible." Based on the above information, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the allegation is substantiated. A deficiency citation is issued under California Code of Regulations (CCR) Section 80065(i)(1) Personnel Requirements - Prior to employment or initial presence in the facility, all employees and volunteers subject to a criminal record review shall obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by law or Department regulations. The facility is being issued a civil penalty due to criminal background check violations prescribed by California Health and Safety Code section 1522, 1568.09, 1569.17, or 1596.871. As a result, a civil penalty of $100 per person per day for a maximum of 4 days is being assessed. A total of $400 is being assessed. A deficiency citation is also issued under CCR 80066(a)(12)(B) Personnel Records - The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. For employees that are required to be fingerprinted pursuant to Section 80019, each personnel record shall contain documentation of either a criminal record clearance or exemption. These violations pose an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care. A Plan of Correction was discussed with the facility representative. An exit interview was conducted, and copies of the following licensing reports were provided: LIC 9099, LIC 9099-C, LIC 9099-D, LIC421BG and LIC Confidential Names Form. Appeal rights forms were provided and explained.

On March 20, 2025, at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Timika Martin conducted an unannounced follow up case management inspection at the facility mentioned above and met with Facility Manager, Towana Bryant regarding Special Incident Reports (SIRs) dated February 26, 2025, and February 27, 2025 submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on March 3, 2025, along with Special Incident Reports (SIRs) dated February 26, 2025, and February 27, 2025. The SIR dated February 26, 2025, indicated that C1 was on an unauthorized absence from the STRTP. The SIR indicated that C1 was able to exit the facility by using a sliding door to the backyard, then left out of the East gate. S1 saw that C1's Instagram account was open on the computer, read messages between C1 and 30-year-old male and saw that C1 provided the male with the facility address. S1 and replied informing the 30-year-old male of C1's age and reported that information to law enforcement and CCL (reference confidential names form LIC 811 dated March 20, 2025). The SIR dated February 27, 2025, indicated that C1 was on an unauthorized absence from the STRTP. During the time of the unauthorized absence, S2 member from Corona Transit Center called to inform S2 that he witnessed C1 is in his presence, witnessed C1 orally copulating an adult male in their elevator and the adult male ran away. The SIR indicated that S2 informed management and picked up C1. Both SIRs indicated that C1, left the facility due to not having access to the facility computer. During the inspection, LPA Martin conducted a tour of the facility, reviewed and requested copies of C1's needs and services plan, school information, current Special Incident Reports (SIRs), C1's safety plan and CFT meeting notes. LPA requested staff contact information, staff shift schedule and the STRTPs unauthorized absences polices and procedures, and facility rules for computer use. During the inspection, LPA conducted an interview with facility manager. Based on records reviewed and interviews, the STRTP is following reporting requirements, unauthorized absences policies/procedures and ensuring client to staff ratios are maintained. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was left with the FFA representative listed above. No additional follow up is needed at this time.

The staff denied the allegations and stated clients are schedule to see their doctor or are taken to urgent care if needed. There was statements indicating that the allegations did happened to the minor and other statements indicated the the allegation did not happened or were not aware if it did. The County Social Workers for the minor stated having no concerns with the care and supervision in the facility. There were no witnesses and LPA did not find corroborating evidence to substantiate the allegations. Based on the interviews and records reviewed, the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Copies of LIC9099, LIC9099C, LIC811 and Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.

narrative: On August 28, 2025, at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Timika Martin conducted an unannounced follow up case management inspection at the facility mentioned above and met with Administrator, Laverne DuBose regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) dated August 9, 2025, that was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on August 13, 2025. The purpose of the inspection is to address the incident below that was not reported to the CCL in a timely manner. The SIR indicated that C1 disclosed to the facility clinician of sexual abuse/assault by her ex-boyfriend and his friend while under the influence of mushrooms and alcohol. Based on a record reviewed, C1 recalls waking up to the two males "touching her weirdly" and seeing blood and bruising in her genitals upon waking up. C1 denied reporting the incident to law enforcement or any adult. C1 refused to report the incident. The facility clinician reviewed the limitations for confidentiality with the client and offered to report the incident collaboratively. The STRTP did not report this incident to CCL within the initial 24 hours. This is a violation of regulations California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Section 80061 (b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were discussed and left with Administrator, Laverne DuBose whose signature on this form confirms receipt of these documents.

On August 10, 2022 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with Abigail Anokwuru, Administrator, Suzanne Lopez, Facility Manager, Karen Rivera, direct care staff, and Dave Detmers, facility maintenance. This Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program is a one story facility located in a residential area. The facility consists of 3 client bedrooms and 1 client bathroom, living and dining areas, kitchen, laundry area, gym, and recreation room. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is a pool on the facility premises, and meets safety standards. Fire arms are not allowed on the facility premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers are throughout the house. Smoke detectors are throughout the house and operational. Carbon monoxide detectors are located in the hallway, outside of the client bedrooms. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 110 degrees Fahrenheit. There is a donation room that has an extra bed, to be used for COVID positive isolation only. Staff records will be kept at Advent's main office in San Jose, and will be readily available for review. Client files locked in the office. Medications will be centrally stored and locked in the pantry. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked in the hallway closet. Extra supply of feminine hygiene products are locked in the hallway closet. Extra bedding and towels are kept unlocked, in the hallway closet. There is a space utilized for a gym, with gym equipment. All gym equipment is in working order. Knives and sharps will be kept locked in the staff office. Site location has a live in staff bedroom and bathroom that is kept locked, and meets prelicensing requirements. Head of Services (HOS) for this location is Shannon Combs. Site location already has cameras installed. Cameras are ok to leave installed, while waiting for regulations to be written. Licensee keeps video footage for a maximum of 30 days. CCL will need access to camera video footage, at all times. Licensee agrees to meet current County safety guidelines. This property is ready for licensure, once their Plan of Operation/Program Statement (POO/PS) is approved. LPA Pavia will notify licensee, once POO/PS is approved and facility is licensed. Component II: LPA Pavia discussed with the following, with Administrator: - Administrator on site required hours - facility core services and support - facility emergency intervention plan

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA's) Shikya Belfield conducted an unannounced inspection on 1/6/2023 at 10:40 am and met with Tanya Ivanov, who assisted with the inspection. The facility is licensed for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 7-17 and Non-Minor dependents. There are currently no client present in the facility. During this inspection, the entire facility was toured. The facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions. There is adequate indoor activity space and materials. Chemicals are stored in a locked closet. Locked cabinet where centrally stored medications are kept was observed. Individual beds are in good repair, mattresses and pillows were observed. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings and storage. Adequate food storage space observed. Sufficient food supply was observed upon inspection, as of todays date there are no clients in the facility. A discussion was had regarding the quantity of food supply for the facility. Weekly menu is posted in the kitchen. Fire extinguishers were observed as well as the facility license, client rights, and activity calendar. A review was conducted of 2 client and 3 staff files. During a walk through of the facility LPA observed that there are cameras that observe the public areas of the facility. Facility will submit a waiver request to the department by 1/11/2023. During a review of client files it was observed that 2 out of 2 clients, were missing documents such as needs and services plan, consent forms, immunization records, and admissions agreement. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards Version 4, Section 87068. Needs and Services Plan and 87068. Intake Procedures. During a review of staff files, it was observed that staff associations had not been completed. Advisory issued. S1, S2, ( see LIC 811 dated 1/6/2023). An exit interview was conducted with staff Tonya and staff Genesis. A copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to Administrator Abigail and staff Tonya.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Carolyn Flynn, and LPA Monica Povia, conducted an announced case management meeting with the above facility on 1/12/2023 at 10: AM virtually on Microsoft Teams . Present from the facility are, Licensee Daniel Mahan, Administrator Abigail Anokwuru, Shannon Combs, Michelle Jimenez, Tereasa Roush and Faith Byrd. The purpose of this meeting is to address concerns the department has observed with the program's operations. During a post licensing inspection conducted on 1/6/2023, LPA Belfield met with Staff Tanya Ivanov and Genesis Flores. During this inspection the following concerns were observed by LPA Belfield: Client files were missing forms and information including Admission agreements, needs and service plans, and consent forms. staff are not informed of STRTP regulations. Incident reports show that clients personal rights are being violated on at least two occasion. Facility is operating outside of their plan of operation / program statement by, not ensuring that staff receive the proper training topics to work in the Short-Term Residential Treatment Program, not utilizing trauma informed practices as outlined in the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) and the program statement, not following proper intake procedures, not following program crisis protocol, and conduct that poses an immediate risk to health, safety, or personal rights. During the post licensing inspection conducted on 1/6/2023, LPA Belfield discussed with Staff an incident that occurred on 1/4/2023. This incident involved C1 (see lic 811 dated 1/12/2023) was removed from the facility by law enforcement. After this discussion and review of the incident report received on 1/10/2023, it was confirmed the conduct of the facility resulted in the client causing property damage and being removed by the police. The facility is being cited for violation of ILS, version 4, section 87072 (c) Personal rights, welfare and institution code subsection (a)(7). Facility is assessed a civil penalty. An exit interview is conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to licensee Danial Mahan and administrator Abigail Anokwuru, with a read receipt and request for signature to be returned to the department by close of business 1/13/2023.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield, Licensing Program conducted an unannounced case management inspection with the above facility on 7/20/2023 at 9: AM. Present during this inspection were four staff see LIC811 dated 7/20/2023. Assistant Facility Manager Nancy Lustre assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this inspection is to follow up with the facility regarding the program operations. This program is licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to serve clients ages 7 to 17 and Non minor Dependents. The Interim Licensing Standards require that all referrals made to an STRTP be kept in a log and that an assessment be completed to determine program eligibility. Based on a review of the facilities program statement and confidential interviews conducted, the program is confirmed to be operating out of compliance with the licensing regulations and their program statement by not accepting STRTP eligible clients and not conducting assessments for determination. The program does not have a record of referrals received for placement's. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87068.1(b) Intake procedures and 87068.05(b) Admission Determination Procedures, as described on the following page LIC 809D. During a review of guardian system, LPA Belfield observed that the maintenance person (MM) was not associated to the facility however they were criminally record cleared. HR Teresa R. was able to associate MM while LPA was in the facility. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to Assistant facility Manager Nancy Lustre, Facility Manager Brandon Patterson, and administrator Abigail Anokuwru.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced inspection visit to the administrative offices for Summitview Child and Family Services on 7/28/21 at 1: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Residential Programs to discuss three incident reports for this facility. LPA informed Ms. Randle that the visit is related to three incident reports. The first report is dated 5/23/21 regarding C1 (see LIC811 dated 7/28/21) who reportedly is engaging in a relationship with an unidentified male, age 19. LPA informed Ms. Randle that additional information is needed on this issue and Licensing is questioning if the agency did their due diligence in reporting this information to law enforcement, child protective services or any other agency as required according to the Mandated Reporting Policy? Ms. Randle states that the agency did contact the biological mother and did obtain additional information that was not provided in the report sent to Licensing. Ms. Randle shall ensure that the report is updated with the additional information and resubmitted to Licensing. The second report is dated 5/24/21 and is related to C2 attempting to have an inappropriate conversation with another youth about two other youth in the facility. When staff intervened in this conversation, C2 alerted facility staff that two youth were engaging in inappropriate touching and possible sexually inappropriate boundaries between these two other youth. The report does not detail who the clients involved are, what steps the facility staff were taking to ensure the safety of youth or what the outcome of the incident were. LPA asked that Ms. Randle provide additional information and resubmit this incident report to ensure that all details and information are on the report as required. The third report is dated 5/25/21 and this is related to C3 and S1 having "inappropriate conversations through social media (Twitter)". LPA informed Ms. Randle that the report states that there were attached documents but that the report was not accompanied by any additional documents. LPA asked Ms. Randle what those documents were and it was reported that the actual conversation between C3 and S1. LPA did request that the attachments be provided to Licensing in addition to the internal investigation conducted by the agency. In addition, LPA has already requested S1's entire employment file as a result of an incident at another facility for this agency. Ms. Randle states that in her opinion, there are items that S1 may have deleted from the conversation in an effort to show that the conversation was not inappropriate. Ms. Randle states that the agency policy regarding contact between staff and clients is that it must be approved through management prior to conversing with youth and that staff cannot, at any time, ask youth for their social media contact(s). Requests of this nature must be initiated by the youth and a team discussion and approval provided prior to contact with youth but staff employed by the agency. S1 violated this policy and was terminated by the agency. Exit interview conducted and document provided.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
met_with: Michelle Good, Director of Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) made an unannounced call on 10/28/20 at 2: PM and met with Michelle Good, Director of Residential Programs to discuss some concerns. LPA asked Ms. Good about the houses and the plan when the houses lose power due to Pacific Gas & Electric shut-offs when the winds are especially high, increasing fire danger in the area. Ms. Good states that the facility plan is still to acquire the generators so as to now have to rotate the facilities to other facilities to complete hygiene tasks for the youth. Ms. Good states that the plan for the generators is a costly plan and they are still working to acquire the generators for the sites but that there are at least one or two facilities that still have power when the power is shut off in the other houses and that youth are rotated in to those houses. LPA did ask that an emergency plan be submitted to explain how the facility continues to operate with the power out. This plan should address meal preparation, hygiene, bathroom facilities use when use of a well is required and not functioning, schooling, activities, etc. LPA also is requesting that a plan for the purchase or acquiring of the generators be provided as it appears that this is going to be an on-going issue that needs a long-term solution. LPA also inquired about searches and the policy surrounding conducting searches in the home and Ms. Good states that the protocol is usually to notify youth's placement that a search is needed and the reasons for the need to search. Ms. Good states that usually they wait for consent from placement prior to initiating the search unless the search is requested by placement. Ms. Good states that if they have suspicions of dangerous items, they do not wait for permission to search but that placement is notified when a search is conducted and what the result of the search was. Ms. Good states that it is always best practice to conduct searches when youth are present but that sometimes when youth leave the facility on an unauthorized absence or youth are otherwise unable to or unwilling to be present, then the search is conducted without youth presence. Ms. Good states that it is always the procedure to complete an incident report immediately following searches and provide those reports to placement and Licensing as required. LPA did discuss that she has received notices of the searches in the past but that she does not recall a recent search conducted and an incident report being submitted recently. Ms. Good states that she will follow up on this and provide additional information once obtained. LPA also asked Ms. Good about chores being requested of the youth while at the non-public school site and Ms. Good reports that chores are required of the youth at this site but that they are normal chores and nothing too in-depth that they are being asked to complete. LPA asked what kinds of things are asked of the youth and Ms. Good states that tasks such as wiping of desks, taking out classroom trash, vacuuming of classrooms, etc. are asked of youth. LPA asked if youth are asked to clean the bathroom at the site as well and Ms. Good confirmed that they are asked to do normal cleaning of the youth bathrooms. LPA did inform Ms. Good that this is inappropriate and that there should be janitorial staff that conduct this type of cleaning at this site. Ms. Good states that she would take this up with the leadership team and discuss an appropriate plan to address this. LPA did request that the facility provide some kind of feedback on the issue surrounding chores at the non-public school site.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced inspection visit to the administrative offices for Summitview Child and Family Services on 7/28/21 at 1: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Residential Programs to discuss an incident reports for this facility. LPA informed Ms. Randle that the visit is related to an incident report dated 5/31/21 involving C1, S1 and S2 (see LIC811 dated 7/28/21) where C1 was complaining of knee pain. When staff attempted to suggest to C1 some self help remedies for the pain, C1 rejected the suggestions and instead took the house phone and went outside to make an unauthorized phone call. C1 was supervised while outside by S2. S1 unplugged the phone from inside the facility to prevent C1 from making any calls. When the call could not be made, C1 entered the facility angry and screaming about the phone not working and S1 responded to C1 that it was because C1 did not show the staff the number dialed and because C1 was attempting to have an unauthorized call. C1 demonstrated to staff that they had dialed 911. LPA advised Ms. Randle that instead of S1 speaking to C1 in a trauma informed manner and attempting to de-escalate youth, S1 was very antagonistic and provoking toward C1. LPA reminded Ms. Randle that the facility staff need to be reminded about the obligation to approach youth in a trauma informed manner and speak to youth in a way that would de-escalate situations and not cause more trauma or escalate youth. Ms. Randle states that she was not even aware of the incident and that she would look further into this issue and provide an update regarding this incident. LPA requested that the update, counseling note or other documentation related be provided to LPA by 8/11/21. Exit interview conducted and document provided.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Hill and Mary Shelton made an unannounced annual inspection on 10/15/21 at 11: AM and met with Eryn Dixon, STRTP Administrator, who assisted with the inspection. LPAs Hill and Shelton conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. There were no clients present during the inspection due to school and company barbecue happening at their school location. LPAs observed four client bedrooms, two bathrooms during the inspection. LPAs Hill and Shelton inspected and/or reviewed the following: Postings of facility license, Personal Rights Poster Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible Refrigerator Temperature was at or below 45 degrees F and Freezer Temperature at or below 0 degrees Nonperishable Foods for one week and fresh perishable for foods two days minimum were present Menu was present and but not posted Working telephone was present Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detectors were functioning First Aid Kit was present but missing tweezers Common Room (living room) was available as was a separate room for relaxing Dining area with enough seating was present and in good condition Medication was centrally stored, locked/inaccessible LPAs did not observe a staff office area as the agency believes that the staff should be present with the clients in care and not in the office doing administrative work with clients present. All relative documentation is locked an inaccessible to clients in care. Hot Water was between 105 -120 degree F Fire Extinguisher was observed to be last inspected on 2/15/ Toilets, wash basin, bath and shower fixtures appeared to be in good repair, no leaks and delivering hot water. LPAs observed there to be soap and paper towels available in the bathrooms. Laundry Facilities were available and LPAs observed posted assigned washing days for clients. Bedrooms appeared to be clean and organized with required linen and furnishings Motor Vehicle was observed to have working seat belts, lights and adequate tires. Facility appeared to be free of vermin LPAs observed no citations during the physical plant inspection and no citations were issued for the physical plant of the facility. Exit interview conducted and documentation provided to the facility.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced collateral inspection on 6/9/22 at 9: AM to the administrative office located at Placerville Drive, Placerville to discuss incident reports. LPA discussed the following incident reports while at the administrative office: 5/2/22 - C1 appeared to have been targeting a staff (unclear as to what staff) and it does not appear in the report that staff removed themselves knowing that C1 was targeting them. LPA discussed with CEO that in writing the reports, if staff are switched out then it need to be articulated. If the staff targeted in this incident did not remove themselves, the staff should be cognizant of the target and in the future remove themselves when a youth appears to be targeting them. 4/23/22 - C2 allegedly snorted a substance but the substance was never defined in the report. C2 informed staff that it was a substance that came from a previous client but there is no indication that the substance was searched for or if C2 was ever asked if there was more "substance". 4/19/22 - C2 was involved in two restraints at the facility and as written, both incidents appear to be unnecessary restraints. LPA informed Ms. Gleason that Licensing is looking at restraints and the "eminent danger" presented when restraining a youth in care. LPA informed Ms. Gleason that the reports need to articulate the danger(s) presented that warrant a restraint when they do happen. 4/15/22, C1 attempted to leave a classroom while at the school site and were stopped by staff resulting in youth being violent and aggressive towards various staff in the classroom and additional staff that came to support the incident. LPA cautioned Ms. Gleason on stopping youth when they are leaving as this may be a personal rights violation. In addition, it was discussed that there are alternatives to youth being physically stopped including assigning a staff to walk about the property with youth. 3/5/ C3 was placed in a restraint to keep youth from jumping out of a window on a second level of the facility after breaking into a locked storage cabinet in the garage and being able to obtain razors. Staff held on to C3's wrists to get items from C3. LPA again cautioned the use of restraints in an unauthorized manner. 3/5/ C4 was found in a bathtub "unconscious" and when pulled out by staff, it took C4 a minute to respond. C4 was taken to the local emergency room and subsequently returned to the facility. When discussing the incident, CEO states that she learned that youth never lost consciousness, per the doctor. LPA informed CEO that any and all additional information needs to be put in the full report. 3/2/ C3 was again placed in a restraint to keep youth from exiting the house through the bedroom window. LPA cautioned CEO about the incident in that it does not appear that there was an eminent danger to the youth that would justify the use of restraints. 3/1/ C4 was on the roof of the house and staff were "collecting couches" as described in the incident report. LPA questioned what this meant and CEO states that to the best of her knowledge, it means that staff were putting couches together to break a youth's fall/jump from the roof. LPA indicated that there was no discussion of de-escalation techniques used to get youth to come of the roof and not jump. 2/28/ C4's room was searched due to how C4 "was presenting" and due to disclosure of using substances while in their home but this is not a justification for a search. LPA advised Ms. Gleason that searches need justification and consent. There is also no indication that parent/guardian was consulted. Later on this date, C4 attempted to leave the facility but was restrained; no indication this was necessary. 9/10/ C5 did a "smiley" piercing while in the facility; there's no indication when this happened and no indication that staff asked C5 about when it happened or what was used to do the piercing. LPA asked Ms. Gleason if there was more information about how this could happen without staff being aware. In general, LPA also discussed with Ms. Gleason the need to ensure that all reports are complete. LPA also advised that some of the full reports just need additional information to indicate that the staff are being proactive in preventing additional issues; i.e. one youth making calls to get someone to pick them up at the facility but not indicating what staff are doing for additional support or assistance. LPA also discussed accompanying youth when needed to do a walk-about on the property of the school or the facility grounds. There were incidents where youth were struggling and staff would not allow them to leave and other times where youth were struggling and staff allowed them to leave unattended. In both incidents, it was a struggle for the staff and clients. LPA advised that it is necessary to be consistent with the youth in order to maintain supervision and be consistent. LPA also discussed being thorough in the reports and providing additional information it the 24 hour reports being sent. Reports should include when medical is needed or not, contacting therapists when necessary, indicating what interventions or supports are utilized when youth indicate self-harm, what youth are doing (other than just stating "engaged in self harm"), use of restraints when there is not an eminent threat or danger, staff indicating completion of Suspected Child Abuse Report when disclosures are made by the youth in care, indicating reasons for and what is found when a room search is needed/warranted. Also discussed during the inspection on this date was the licensing fees that are all confused and not appropriated correctly. LPA did advise that the agency provide details about the fee assessments via email so that discussion can be held with the Department's Accounting Unit to appropriate the fees paid appropriately. LPA did ask additional information be provided for the following incidents regarding allegations with staff: 11/30/ LPA asked for clarification on this incident involving two staff and four youth in the facility. LPA requested any/all follow up regarding S1 having to be told by S2 to "remove herself and stay outside". LPA observed that the incident report indicates that S1 yelled at C6 "Do not touch me" when C6 pushed S1 back with their body. 11/29/ LPA requested additional information regarding alleged misconduct of S1 where S1 may have provided a vape pen to C4. LPA asked if there was an internal investigation regarding the incident and, if so, LPA requested a copy of the internal investigation conducted. 5/31/ C5 alleged that a staff had provided "vape juice" to a youth in the facility (staff not identified). LPA is requesting a copy of the investigation conducted. End of incident report review and exit interview conducted with Ms. Gleason.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
narrative: Staff working at the facility attempted to get S1 to return to the facility with C1 once it was observed that S1 was no longer visible by the staff. Another staff accompanied by another client walked down the driveway in the direction that it was thought that S1 and C1 had walked in and rustling was heard in the woods. C2 allegedly saw S1 and C1 on the ground together. C1 initially told staff and clients that nothing happened because C1 didn't want to get into trouble but later stated that S1 and C1 did have sex in the woods as suspected and that it was not all consensual. While Investigators with the Department and Detective from El Dorado County Sheriff's Office did attempt to make contact with S1, S1 would not agree to an interview and would not agree to a meeting to discuss the allegation. S1 informed the investigators and detective that S1 would need to contact their attorney to discuss and get back to the investigators. As of the finalization of the complaint, S1 had not come forward to schedule a meeting of any kind. Based on information obtained and interviews conducted by the Investigations Branch, the allegation that a staff sexually abused a minor while in care is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The facility is being cited for Personal Rights section 87072(c)(11) as the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, including the right to be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse as it pertains to S1 engaging in a sexual relationship with a client while in the facility. The facility is also being cited for Conduct Inimical as described in Health and Safety Section 1568.092(a)(2) as the department may prohibit any person from... continuing the employment of, or allowing in a licensed facility, or allowing contact with clients of a licensed facility by, any employee...who has Engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, welfare, or safety of either an individual, in or receiving services from the facility, or the people of the State of California as this pertains to S1 engaging in sexual contact with a client in the facility. The facility was advised that this matter is being referred to our Legal Department for further review and additional legal action. In addition, this citation shall be reviewed for Enhanced Civil Penalties as applicable. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Gleason and documentation and appeal rights were provided via email.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: On 11/9/22 at 9L AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted a case management inspection and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty for a violation of Personal Rights Section 87072(c)(11) The licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, including the right to be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse. The staff member of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) engaged in inappropriate sexual acts with a minor client of the STRTP. On August 26, 2022, LPA Tamara Hill delivered findings for a complaint investigation regarding the allegation that "staff sexually abused a minor while in care". Based on information gathered during confidential interviews it was determined the allegation of sexual abuse is substantiated. A staff member sexually abused a minor in care. This abuse is conduct inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety of clients in the STRTP. The Department has determined that the Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted for the physical abuse of a minor while in the care of the STRTP. The violation does meet the definition of Physical Abuse per Health & Safety 1548(e)(2); Physical Abuse to include Sexual Abuse as defined in Penal Codes section 11165.1(b) (1)-(2) describes sexual assault as including penetration, oral copulation, intrusion by one into the genitals of another, and intentional touching for purpose of sexual arousal or gratification. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty Law, Health & Safety Code section 1548(f)(1)(C) the Department will be issuing an Enhanced Civil Penalty of $2500. An exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle, and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - OAK
narrative: Interviews revealed that additional comments were said by S1 to other youth in the program about retaliating physically against youth that caused disturbances in the program, wanting to punch youth, or hurting youth enough to "make them cry". LPA interviewed a total of four previous staff and seven current staff. In addition, LPA interviewed complainant, three previous youth, one current youth, and C1's therapist at the facility. LPA also obtained an email dated 9/11/2020, detailing that C1 disclosed to her therapist during a session that C1 was feeling uncomfortable about statements and/or gestures made by S1. House Supervisor was pulled into this therapy session to hear youth's concerns; the House Supervisor then reported the information to her manager but that information was not investigated by the agency nor was it reported to Licensing. Shortly after this disclosure, S1 stopped working at the agency. Interviews conducted showed that multiple staff and clients were aware of, had witnessed, or had been told about S1's inappropriate comments about C1 and other inappropriate comments about other youth in the program. In addition, many of the staff disclosed that they reported that S1 displayed "inappropriate or poor boundaries" with youth in care, "acted more like a youth than staff", allowed youth to utilize their personal cell phone to access social media, watch videos, and listen to music which is a violation of company policy. Despite warnings from management, S1 allegedly continued to engage in this practice. As a result of the information obtained and interviews conducted, the allegation that staff member's conduct poses a threat to children in care is SUBSTANTIATED at this time. Facility was cited for violation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Section 87072(d): Personal Rights. Youth have a right to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. This did not happen as staff and youth were aware that S1's continued present in the facility was making youth uncomfortable. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Gleason and documents were provided via email for signature and return.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced tele inspection on 5/6/21 at 2: PM and met with Anna Gleason, Chief Executive Officer to discuss the findings of the allegation as stated. The allegation that staff member's conduct poses a threat to children in care is related to the allegation that S1 (see LIC811 dated 4/30/21) made comments that were not trauma informed in the presence of youth and made youth feel uncomfortable. Some of the reported comments were that of a youth's body, how cute youth was, how it was easy to forget youth was a minor, wanting to "hook up with" youth after youth left the program and S1 providing youth with their cell personal phone number to contact S1 after leaving the program. LPAs did not observe there to be screens on the sliding door but on all other windows throughout the facility where they are opened for ventilation and air circulation. facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - OAK
narrative: According to the interviews with staff, video cameras showed that another youth went down the hall and may have observed what C1 was doing in their room and alerted staff. At that point, youth had been alone in their room and not checked on for approximately 47 minutes. Interviews with staff, placement agency, and parent are consistent in that C1 was known to self harm with their own nails and with other objects and needed line of sight supervision or heightened supervision. C1's parent also felt that C1 was in need of heightened supervision and thought that C1 was placed in the facility to receive that level of supervision. Review of the documentation from the hospital demonstrates that the hospital staff believed that C1 had injured themselves over a period of two days as some of the injuries appeared to be infecting and older than others observed. When interviewed, staff state that C1 normally wore long sleeve clothing and did not expose much of their skin so marks of self harm were not visible until entering C1's room and C1 disclosing the injuries. Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, the allegation that staff did not prevent youth from self harming is SUBSTANTIATED meaning that the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The facility was cited for Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision 80078(a) as the licensee is required to provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. C1's Needs and Services Plan indicates that C1 engages in self harm daily, thus requiring an additional level of supervision that C1 did not receive in the facility, including being left alone for lengthy periods of time, allowing C1 to self harm and cause significant damage to their arm. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Gleason and documents and appeal rights were provided via email. items to the facility for C1, the parent thought that all items would have been inspected and searched and if any item(s) would have been deemed to be dangerous to C1, taken away and stored elsewhere or destroyed. The parent had no knowledge of the search policy in that they were unaware that the child's belongings, person, or room was not searched regularly to keep dangerous items away from C1. The allegation that staff did not seek medical attention for child in a timely manner is related to the severity of the injuries observed at the hospital and the suspicion by the medical staff that some of the wounds were starting to infect, indicating that the wounds happened over a period of 48 hours. During interviews conducted with staff, C1 was known to wear long sleeves which would have hidden the wounds inflicted the day prior. Until C1 was found in their room bleeding from the wounds, staff had no knowledge of existing wounds. As soon as staff saw the wounds, facility staff called 911 and C1 was transported to the hospital for evaluation and treatment. Based on investigation, interviews conducted and review of the documentation obtained, the allegation that C1 had access to a dangerous object is true but culpability by the staff to be aware and be able to remove the item is subjective and cannot be proven as youth are to be free of unreasonable searches. The allegation that staff did not seek medical attention for C1 in a timely manner cannot be proven as well since the staff, upon learning of the injury immediately called 911 and had C1 taken to the hospital. As a result, both of these allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Gleason and documents were provided by email.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection on 8/26/33 at 9: AM and met with Anna Gleason, Chief Executive Officer to discuss the finding of the allegation. Hospital records for C1 (see LIC811 dated 8/26/22) were obtained on 5/9/22. C1 was not interviewed in relation to this complaint due to C1's instability in their current placement and C1's parent requested that C1 not be interviewed. LPA also conducted interviews with staff about the supervision of C1 and it was disclosed that C1 was not supervised as required by the staff in the facility, leaving C1 alone for great periods of time, longer than what the program states should have happened. Staff believe that this directly contributed to C1's ability to self harm. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - OAK
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: The allegation that staff did not prevent inappropriate sexual interaction between minors is related to an incident that took place in the facility between June 24, 2022 to June 27, 2022, where C1 and C2 (see LIC811 dated 10/6/22) shared a room together and engaged in inappropriate sexual contact. LPA Hill conducted confidential interviews with staff and clients and obtained documentation related to staff supervision during these overnight shifts in the facility. The allegation is directly related to inappropriate contact between C1 and C2 during the overnight shift(s) and the lack of supervision which lead to this. LPA obtained documentation from the facility and conducted interviews that staff which lead to the discovery that the staff on duty during the dates indicated did not conduct the required bed checks on clients per the program statement. This lack of bed checks as documented by the facility left clients unsupervised and vulnerable to inappropriate interactions. As a result of the investigation, the allegation that staff did not prevent inappropriate sexual interaction between clients is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The facility was cited for 87078(b) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision as the licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's or nonminor dependent's needs and services plan, Transitional Independent Living Plan, and/or individualized health care plan or each child with special health care needs, as applicable, as necessary to meet the child's or nonminor dependent's needs. The licensee identified that the youths' needs include heightened supervision including bed checks every 15 minutes throughout the overnight shift. This did not happen during the date(s) indicated leading to the identified inappropriate interactions between C1 and C2. Exit interview conducted and documents were provided to Ms. Randle via email along with appeal rights.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - OAK
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Tamara Hill and Monica Roberts made an unannounced inspection on 1/19/23 at 9: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs to discuss an incident report. LPA discussed a cross report received in December 2022 related to C1 (see LIC811 dated 1/19/23). LPA spoke to youth about the cross report and asked youth information about the report. LPA then spoke with youth's therapist about the conversation and asked that therapist check in with youth when possible to ensure that youth is in a good place. LPA also discussed another incident dated 12/3/22 in which C2 got upset over not being allowed a cell phone charger to charge their phone. There is no mention in the report that youth was given the opportunity to have the phone charged by staff and then returned to the youth. LPA discussed that it has been observed that there is an up-tick in medication related incident indicting that they are either not administered or incorrectly administered doses. LPA advised that the agency needs to do something to ensure that youth are given their medications as prescribed and missing medications for youth is not acceptable. LPA discussed 24 hour reports with the agency as well. LPA pointed out that there are incidents in which there is little to no information about the incidents and why or how things happen.
