facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - OAK
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Res Programs
narrative: happened on 12/9/22 where C1 and C2 left the facility and broke into a neighbor's home and vandalized the home. Investigation showed that there were two staff present at the facility with six clients. When C1 and C2 left the facility on an unauthorized absence, one of the staff were going to follow but then another client, not related to the incident, left the facility on an unauthorized absence as well, and staff followed that third client. While away from the facility, C1 admitted to breaking a neighbor's window in an attempt to burglarize the home but the residents of that home were there, scaring C1 and C2 off, and they fled the neighbor's property. Sheriff deputies did issue felony citations to C1 for the damages and the break in but the clients were not arrested or transported to juvenile hall. During the confidential interviews conducted, it was disclosed that staff observed C1 and C2 were possibly preparing to leave the facility on an unauthorized absence as they were talking about "getting up and getting ready to go". Staff indicated that they were on high alert and had alerted the management of the need but they felt that there should have been an additional staff at that facility as C1 had been struggling during the days leading up to this incident. Staff felt that they needed the additional support but the agency didn't provide that additional staff. When LPA Hill reviewed incident reports, it was noted that the day prior to this incident, 12/8/22, C1 had left the facility on an unauthorized absence and went to a different neighbor's house claiming to have killed someone and buried their body as part of a gang initiation. In addition, there was another unauthorized absence on 12/6/22, and two incidents related to inappropriate interactions with two different clients on 12/2/22 and 12/7/22, one of which was a sexual interaction. An additional staff did respond to the facility when summoned after three clients left on an unauthorized absence and this staff person did assist in transporting clients back to the house. While the facility was within the required staff ratio requirements set by Short Term Residential Therapeutic Programs, the facility is also required to meet the needs of the clients in care which would include having additional staff at the facility to assist as needed. As a result of this, the allegation that staff did not provide adequate supervision to the minors is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The facility was cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Section 80065(a) Personnel Requirements. The facility did not have the necessary staff at the facility to meet the needs of the clients in care in that there were only two staff with the six residents. Staff knew, or should have known, the propensity of the clients and had a sufficient number of staff present to meet that need. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Randle and documents were provided with appeal rights.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - OAK
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Res Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 4/13/23 at 9:30 am and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs to discuss incident reports and lack of full reports being received. LPA Hill informed Ms. Randle on 4/6/23 via email that Licensing had not received any of the required full reports for the month of March for the 24 hour reports that were provided. Administrator Danielle Bingle provided those reports for the Month of March on that same date via email. LPA Hill did inform Ms. Bingle and Ms. Randle that the Department still has to cite for not providing the full written report within the required timeline of seven days as prescribed in 80061(b) "a written report containing the information specified... shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event." LPA Hill also discussed an incident report dated 3/13/23 for C1 in which C1 allegedly felt uncomfortable sleeping in the same room as their roommate. LPA Hill questioned Ms. Randle about this report as there is no indication of why C1 was uncomfortable, how it was addressed the following day (was C1 referred to their therapist to discuss, were room changes conducted, etc.) After discussing the incident report, Ms. Randle stated that C1 was uncomfortable due to an incident involving two other youth from the same house. LPA Hill asked Ms. Randle to update information on the report to give reasoning, what the facility did, and how the issue was resolved and resubmit the report to Licensing. LPA Hill discussed medication incident reports received since January 1, 2023, detailing medication errors due to medications not being picked up, staff forgetting to administer at time(s) prescribed by doctors or other staff/facility errors. LPA Hill informed Ms. Randle that the Department is not concerned for medication errors due to pharmacy not having medications but errors that are within the control of Summitview and staff, are of concern. LPA Hill asked Ms. Randle how the facility has addressed or is planning to address this issue to ensure that there are no medication errors due to staffing and/or Summitview not having the prescribed medications on site? Ms. Randle states that medication training was conducted with all residential staff and the agency has begun to track for medication patterns and staff responsible for any medication errors moving forward will be retrained immediately and/or corrective actions conducted with said staff. In addition, Summitview's Health Services has met with transporters to ensure that refills and notifications are sent to transporters a minimum of seven to ten days prior to medications running out and refill requests are completed. Controlled medications are counted daily and other medications are counted twice weekly. When these counts happen, staff are to notify Health Services for refill of medications a minimum of ten days prior to the medications running out in an effort to prevent the facility from running out of medications. LPA Hill requested a written policy that would indicate how all of these things will be defined and/or put into place shall be provided to Licensing by 5/1/23. Lastly, LPA Hill discussed the closure of this location with Ms. Randle in that the agency has decided to relocate all of the youth from this location by 4/14/23. With the house vacant, the agency has decided to sell the property but will be relocating this facility to another one of their properties currently under renovation. Ms. Randle states that they will be submitting something to Licensing as soon as their board has approved of the plan and provides the board resolution for the relocation. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documentation provided with appeal rights.

Ms. Good states that this is the very reason that they have a policy about using the facility vehicles only to transport youth and the staff not transporting youth in their own personal vehicles as they cannot ensure that staff do not smoke in their vehicles. As a result of the investigation, the allegation that staff had an inappropriate sexual relationship with an client under the age of 18 in care and that staff engaged in an improper sexual relationship with clients in care is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The facility is being cited for Personal Rights section 87072(c)(11) as the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, including the right to be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse as it pertains to S1 engaging in a sexual relationship with a client while in the facility. The facility is also being cited for Conduct Inimical as described in Health and Safety Section 1568.092(a)(2) as the department may prohibit any person from... continuing the employment of, or allowing in a licensed facility, or allowing contact with clients of a licensed facility by, any employee...who has Engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, welfare, or safety of either an individual, in or receiving services from the facility, or the people of the State of California as this pertains to S1 engaging in the exchange of nude photos and making sexually explicit statements to client in the facility. The facility was advised that the matter is being referred to our Legal Department for further review and additional legal action. facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - SHADOW RUN
narrative: On 8/11/22 at AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced collateral case management inspection to the administrative offices for Summitview Child and Family Services and met with Anna Gleason, Chief Executive Officer to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty for a violation of Personal Rights Section 87072, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, including the right to be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse and Conduct Inimical, Health & Safety Code Section 1568.092(a)(2), a staff member of the licensed Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) owned and operated by Summitview Child and Family Services engaged in inappropriate sexual acts with a foster child in care. On July 15, 2022, LPA Tamara Hill delivered findings for a complaint investigation at the facility. The complaint investigation revealed that "staff had an inappropriate sexual relationship with an underage client in care" and "staff engaged in an improper sexual relationship with minors in care". Based on information gathered during confidential interviews it was determined the allegation of sexual abuse was substantiated. A staff member sexually abused a minor in care. This abuse is conduct inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety of clients in the home. The Department has determined that the enhanced civil penalty is warranted for the physical abuse of C1 while under the care and supervision of the STRTP. The violation does meet the definition of Physical Abuse per H&S 1548(e)(2) Physical Abuse to include Sexual Abuse as defined in Penal Code section 11165.1, which defines sexual abuse means sexual assault, AND Penal Codes section 11165.l(b)(l)-(2) describes sexual assault as including penetration, oral copulation, intrusion by one into the genitals of another, and intentional touching for purpose of sexual arousal or gratification. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty Law, Health & Safety Code section 1548(f)(1)(C) the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2500.00. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were provided.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - VISTA
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced inspection visit to the administrative offices for Summitview Child and Family Services on 7/28/21 at 1: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs to discuss two incident reports. LPA informed Ms. Randle that the visit is related to an incident report involving C1 (see LIC811 dated 7/28/21). The 24 hour notification for the incident clearly states that youth had just returned from a psychiatric hold and had glass in their pocket which they refused to turn in to facility staff as part of the agreed upon safety plan prior to discharge from the psychiatric facility. This subsequently lead to youth being restrained for their own safety. In reading the full report received from the facility, the information is not consistent between the 24 hour report and the full report. The full report does not detail any information about glass but instead details a struggle over a "plastic spoon" which they were not allowed to have as part of the safety plan agreed upon when discharged from the psychiatric hospital. Youth attempted to leave the facility and became aggressive towards staff and was subsequently placed in a restraint. LPA informed Ms. Randle about the inconsistencies and did ask that the report be updated and resubmitted to ensure the accuracy between the 24 hour report(s) and the full reports. LPA also asked that the facility clearly define in the report the efforts that were made by the staff to de-escalate youth prior to engaging in the physical restraint as it is not evident in the way that the report is written. LPA also discussed another incident report involving C2 whereby C2 disclosed an incident that took place while on a home pass visiting family. The incident was reported to law enforcement in C2's home county and El Dorado County as C2 is currently living at the facility in this county. Agency reports that an attempt was made to report the incident to Child Protective Services as well but were informed that they could not take reports with "unknown perpetrators" and were informed that it was a law enforcement issue. Agency did inform placement agency of the disclosure. Exit interview conducted and document provided.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Children's Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced inspection on 9/23/21 at 11: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Children's Residential Programs to tour the facility. The inspection on this date is for the purposes of relocation of one of the other facilities by the same licensee to this location. As such, all of the furnishings or other items were not present in the facility as would be expected for new licenses. LPA did observe some non perishable food items, chemicals used for cleaning and other furniture items in the facility but not all. During the inspection today, the following items were noted: This is a three story house with a large amount of storage space for clients and the facility staff. LPA observed a fire extinguisher near the kitchen area with an inspection tag dated 7/7/21. LPA discussed that this location will be doing schooling for youth as well as group therapies for clients admitted to the facility. LPA observed that there was adequate space for these services and more based on the size and make up of the home. LPA observed that there are two dual occupancy client bedrooms and two single occupancy client rooms in the facility that were all well stocked with dresser space, beds and night stands as required. There are no lamps but LPA did observe that each of these rooms had central lighting in the rooms. LPA observed that the screens for the windows in the client rooms were present. LPA observed two client bathrooms: the front bathroom was equipped with two sinks, toilet and tub and shower combination. There are a total of three full bathrooms and one half bathroom in the facility. Hot water was not available to be tested as there was a company installing a new HVAC system today which meant that they needed to disconnect the hot water lines. LPA observed that water delivery locations are receiving water and functioning and toilets were flushing. LPA was informed that shower doors were being replaced prior to accepting clients. The facility was observed to have viable exits from each level of the facility. LPA did advise that the facility ensure that the banister is safe and/or inspected as it was secure but seemed a bit loose near the stairs on the side of the house. LPA observed that the laundry facilities are in the garage as well as additional storage space facility supplies as needed. LPA observed an that the medication cabinet is located in the kitchen, near the refrigerator. The main entrance for visitors, staff and clients will near the driveway and garage area. LPA observed the cameras throughout the facility are still be installed. LPA did observe that the cameras are in the common areas only and on the exterior of the facility. The use of cameras shall not violate the personal rights of youth in care as they do not capture audio and are not used in client bedrooms or bathrooms. Fire clearance has not been received yet as facility needs to clear the exterior of the facility for defensible space as defined by fire marshal. LPA did observe that the exterior of the home did appear to have had a lot of the work done recently as some trees were cut down and stacked with ground cover ready to move. LPA was also informed that there is a great number of things pending at this time that the agency would like to do to the house prior to accepting clients, including painting of the interior of the home. The only obstacle that LPA observed at this time is the fire clearance. LPA did inform the agency that once the fire clearance is received then the license can be issued. LPA shall update the license information as this is not an accurate name for this facility at this time. LPA shall correct the document so that upon licensure, it is accurately reflected in the documents produced. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and document was provided via email.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced post licensing inspection at the facility on 3/25/22 at 11: AM and met with Abigail Nelson, administrator within the agency. There are no current clients in care in this facility. The agency anticipates beginning to accept clients beginning next week some time but that there is maintenance that needs to be done on the property prior to accepting any clients. LPA facility outside and observed that there are many fallen branches that could be dangerous to clients. LPA advised that they all be removed prior to having clients in the facility. LPA also observed that some of the boards on top of the patio cover are lose and could be seen from one of the client bedrooms with large nails indicating that they are not nailed in place. LPA advised the facility to ensure that that is taken care of prior to accepting clients. LPA toured the inside of the facility was in substantial compliance during the inspection. LPA observed that the house was equipped with three dual occupancy client bedrooms and multiple bathrooms accessible to clients in care. All bedrooms were fully equipped with appropriate furnishings as required. There was no bedding on the beds as the facility does not have clients at this time. The bathrooms were properly clean and had toilet paper but otherwise had no supplies due to being vacant at this time. LPA observed that the smoke detectors were functioning as required and that there are numerous fire extinguishers on all levels of the home. There was no food in the facility at this time as there are no clients in care. LPA observed that there are some nonperishable but not a great number. There are no client files to review at this time. LPA reviewed only administrator's file as there are no clients or staff that work at this location at this time. No citations were issued. Exit interview conducted and document was provided to the agency.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility administrative office on 3/25/22 at 12: PM and met with Anna Gleason, Chief Executive Officer. The purpose of the inspection on 3/25/22 was to discuss the following incident reports: 1/31/ AM incident - this report indicates that C1 was on a "stop-run" and subsequently restrained in the classroom, after leaving the relaxation room, and upon getting outside the building. LPA asked about the "stop-run"as leaving is part of youth's personal rights. The agency states that this is for the youth that are most at risk due to recent suicide attempts and other self harm behaviors and that these orders are evaluated frequently. LPA asked that the agency provide something in writing about the policy of these orders including how they are derived, how long they last, how frequently they are evaluated, and what input the youth have in making these decisions as they are to have a say in their needs and services and voices in their child and family team meetings. 1/31/ PM incident - this report indicates that C1 was set to leave the non-public school site at the end of the day and was asked to sit in the back of the vehicle due to previously exhibited behaviors but C1 refused. The reports indicates that there were four staff surrounding C1 as they stood by the van. C1 dropped their belongings and attempted to leave, running towards a busy roadway where they were subsequently restrained. LPA explained to the agency about how intimidating it appears on paper and that this must have felt pretty intimidating to C1, standing there surrounded by four staff. LPA further explained that the report does not indicate any verbal de-escalation techniques as they were all standing there or even some of the staff removing themselves from the immediate physical proximity to allow youth to build rapport or speak to youth about what was happening - all protocol for de-escalation. LPA did not issue citations on this date but did discuss additional training needs for staff regarding restraints, de-escalation techniques, and incident report writing. LPA is aware that the agency is undergoing some major changes including a change in facility type. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Gleason.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Res Programs
narrative: Regarding the allegation that the facility has physical plants deficiencies that impacts the health and safety of the clients (e.g mold problem), this is related to a leak that was observed prior to July 2022 and continued through November 2022 and December 2022, per the photos received during the investigation. Documentation received indicates that the facility was aware of the leak and possible contamination in July 2022, per the notation from ServPro that was provided on 3/20/23 by the facility. The notation clearly states that a moisture check was requested by Summitview (or a representative of the agency) as a result of a leak identified and that ServPro clearly found that the "upstairs has drywall affected common wall to backside of shower", vinyl flooring in the bathroom read moisture, and that the scope of the work indicated removal of the affected ceiling downstairs, removal of the vinyl and particle board flooring in the bathroom, removal of the baseboard and drill holes to dry the backside of the shower if no mold growth was found. Note states that the [customer] only wanted the moisture check and they would follow up for an estimate and services. Photos received indicate that the facility knew or should have known in November 2022 the leak issue was not resolved adequately as the photos show additional dark ceiling stains were present with new stains appearing daily and/or weekly. Photos received show spots on ceilings on the first floor as well as walls and floors on the second level of the facility and were taken from November 6, 2022 through February 10, 2023. Interviews with staff also indicate staff knew about the leak and thought that the agency was addressing the issue by shutting the facility down and making the necessary repairs in February 2023. As a result of the information obtained, documentation provided, and interviews conducted, the allegation that the facility has physical plant deficiencies that impact the health and safety of the clients is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The facility was cited for Title 22, Division 6, General Licensing Requirements Section 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds as the facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of the clients, employees and visitors. The facility knew about a leak and possible mold issues in the facility prior to July 2022 but did not address the issues appropriately until February 2023. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documentation was provided along with appeal rights. indicating that overtime was mandatory but that the mandatory overtime didn't actually happen. The facility did indicate that they were having some staffing shortages but not to the point that they couldn't meet the Title 22 ratio requirements of three clients to one staff. When speaking with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs, and Anna Gleason, Chief Executive Officer, it was discussed that the program statement reflects the ideal staffing levels for their short term residential therapeutic program at one staff to two clients but since the pandemic, finding qualified individuals to work has not been easy and they have not been able to maintain their desired staffing levels and have had to work with the one staff to three clients staffing ratio set by Title Regulations. As a result of the investigation and interview conducted, the allegation that the facility is understaffed is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that while the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documentation along with appeal rights was provided.

met_with: Haley Randle, Acting Director of Residential Programs
narrative: When interviewed, S1 states that S1 works in a House Supervisor role and does not hold an administrator certificate. Further, S1 does not have the same responsibilities as that of the administrators of the facilities even though the position titles are both "Administrators". While S1 never told individuals that S1 held an administrator certificate, there is some confusion due to the use of the term "Administrator" in the position title and the agency plans to rectify that in the coming weeks as there will be a leadership meeting related to staffing where these position titles, as well as many other topics, will be discussed at that time in an effort to alleviate the confusion as well as employee retention. S1 has worked for the agency well since prior to the transition to STRTP and thus remains qualified to work with the agency due to her tenure. The allegation related to client personal information being discussed in the presence of or disclosed to unauthorized individual(s) is related to individuals not directly involved in client care or treatment being present in or participating in meetings about client treatment services, child and family team meetings, or any other meetings that deal with client sensitive and confidential information or treatment. Staff interviewed talked about meetings being held in rooms where individuals not directly participating in the meeting being conducted were present or speaking up during these meetings. Confidential interviews revealed that youth were not consistently asked for their approval for the presence of these individuals in said meetings. As a result of the confidential interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, the findings of the complaint allegations that staff do not meet the minimum qualifications as required by licensing and staff are disclosing client personal information with unauthorized individual(s) are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the allegations occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Gleason and documentation and appeal rights were provided via email for signature.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced tele-inspection on 9/11/20 at 6: PM and met with Haley Randle, Acting Director of Residential Programs to discuss the complaint findings. LPA informed Ms. Randle that the investigation included an initial tele-inspection on 6/11/20, interviews were conducted with complainant, 21 staff and six clients from 6/18/20 to 9/11/20 and documentation provided was reviewed. The allegation about to the minimum qualifications is related to S1 (see LIC811 dated 9/11/20) having the working title of "Residential Administrator" but not having the required minimum qualifications per the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) for "Administrator". When interviewed, it was confirmed that S1 does not hold a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Administrator Certificate nor does S1 meet the required minimum education requirements for this position. When asked about the difference between "Administrator" and "Residential Administrator", Chief Executive Officer (CEO) states that there is no official job duty statement for "Residential Administrator" but that this position is a "facility manager" as defined in the ILS and is expected to fill in for Administrators in their absence(s). facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - LOTUS
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Hill and Mary Shelton made an unannounced annual inspection on 10/15/21 at 2: PM and met with Jose Navarette, STRTP Administrator, who assisted with the inspection. LPAs Hill and Shelton conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. There were no clients present during the inspection due to school and company barbecue happening at their school location. LPAs observed three dual occupancy client bedrooms and two bathrooms during the inspection. LPAs Hill and Shelton inspected and/or reviewed the following: Postings of facility license, Personal Rights Poster were appropriately posted Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible and locked as required Refrigerator Temperature was at or below 45 degrees F and Freezer Temperature at or below 0 degrees. There were multiple refrigerators and freezers on the premises that were well stocked. Nonperishable Foods for one week and fresh perishable for foods two days minimum were present Menu was present and posted Working telephone was present Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detectors were functioning First Aid Kit was present but missing tweezers Common Room (living room) was available as was a separate room for relaxing and activities Dining area with enough seating for clients in care was present and in good condition Medication was centrally stored, locked/inaccessible LPAs did not observe a staff office as the agency believes that the staff should be present with the clients and not in the office doing administrative work when clients are present. All relative documentation is locked and inaccessible. Staff utilize a laptop to conduct daily record updates. Hot Water was between 105 -120 degree F Fire Extinguisher was observed to be last inspected on 6/3/ Toilets, wash basin, bath and shower fixtures appeared to be in good repair, no leaks and delivering hot water. LPAs observed there to be hand soap and paper towels available in the bathrooms and kitchen area. Laundry Facilities were available and LPAs observed posted assigned washing days for clients. Bedrooms appeared to be clean and organized with required linen and furnishings Motor Vehicle was not observed as the staff had taken the facility vehicle to pick up clients from company activity at Golden Plaza location. Facility appeared to be free of vermin and other pests as required. LPAs observed no citations during the physical plant inspection and no citations were issued. Exit interview conducted and documentation provided to the facility.

narrative: Services where they spent approximately two hours on the phone with both individuals. The agency's Chief Executive Officer (CEO) stated that they spoke with the parties on the phone and requested that the conversation be paused long enough to get C1 and the other youth back to their assigned house. facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - LOTUS
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced collateral inspection on 6/9/22 at 9: AM to the administrative office located at Placerville Drive, Placerville to discuss incident reports. LPA discussed the following incident reports while at the administrative office: 9/13/ C1's bags were searched when returning from Golden Plaza but there is no indication as to probable cause that would warrant a search of belongings. LPA advised that this may be seen as a violation of client rights as search does not seem to be warranted. 9/16/ C1's room was searched and medications were found in a gum container. LPA questioned the medications found, how they were obtained or prescribed to C1. LPA also cautioned that the agency needs to articulate the permission requested and/or obtained for rooms searches and what the probable cause was that prompted the search. 11/16/ C2 was identified as being on "Safety Watch" and it is indicated that there were to be daily room searches due to this Safety Watch. LPA advised the agency that this cannot be a blanket policy. CEO states that this has been removed and now the policies when on a Safety Watch are individualized, spelled out in Needs and Services Plans and signed off by parent/guardian or child welfare. 2/15/ C3 has a history of going after their medications when the medications were passed. LPA questioned change in the procedures following an incident that took place a few months prior to this about lunging for medications. In addition, C3 was able to get medications and ingest an excessive amount of medications. C3 was transported to the hospital for further evaluation and released the next day back to the facility. 3/18/ C4 was on a "Heightened Supervision" and room search was conducted. LPA advised that being on a heightened supervision is not probable cause to warrant search of their room. CEO states that this is a term used to ensure that staff are increasing supervision of the youth due to recent incidents to more than what they normally did with the youth. LPA again advised the agency of the policy to conduct rooms searches cannot be simply because the youth is on "heightened supervision". 4/18/ C5 was restrained after making remarks about self harm by running into traffic. LPA advised the agency that the report does not articulate any eminent danger to youth or other youth in the facility and thereby this use of restraint may be an unauthorized restraint. LPA requested that the agency provide documentation of advisement to all staff about the items discussed and CEO states that she continues to work with staff on writing of incident reports to ensure that they are clear and concise and meet expectations per the Licensing standards. Also discussed during the inspection on this date was the licensing fees that are all confused and not appropriated correctly. LPA did advise that the agency provide details about the fee assessments via email so that discussion can be held with the Department's Accounting Unit to appropriate the fees paid appropriately. Exit interview conducted and documents provided.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - LOTUS
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: While C2 did pursue C1 in the facility in an effort to get C1 to respond to C2, C1 did barricade themselves in the bathroom and C2 continued to bang on the door to gain access to C1. During another incident in the same month, C1 was on a phone call and had to enter the laundry room to get away from C2 that was again pursuing C1. Staff at the facility reported that while C1 was on their phone call, C2 almost broke the door by banging and kicking the laundry room door attempting to get at C1. During an interview with C2, they admitted to pursuing C1 stating that they were annoyed that C1 would not respond to C2 and would not talk to them. C2 denied banging on the door, bathroom or laundry room, even though this was reported by staff. The allegation that a minor physically abuses another minor is related to the same incident(s) where C1 was allegedly pursued by C2 and C2 physically assaulting C1. When LPA asked C2 about C2 allegedly hitting C1 with the phone one time, C2 states that it wasn't a big hit but more of a tap on the shoulder while C1 and C2 were passing one another in the facility hallway. C2 states that they believe that C1 did call law enforcement about that incident and they did respond but that nothing happened. C2 denied hitting C1 on any other occasion that they could recall. LPA did not interview C1 about this complaint as LPA was advised by C1's social worker that they did not want C1 interviewed due to C1's current placement being unstable at this time. As a result of the investigation conducted and information obtained and the inability to interview C1, the allegations that staff do not properly supervise minors, facility did not keep youth safe, and a minor physically abuses another minor is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documents, including appeal rights, were provided. Staff went on to disclose that as a result of not having consent forms allowing the facility to discuss C1 with this individual, the communication(s) were not returned nor was the communication forwarded to another individual within the agency that could speak to the individual. Staff also informed LPA that they did not have access or passwords to check the voice messages at the house at the time of the communications but have since obtained access to the voice messages but did not appropriately address the voices messages. As a result of the investigation and information obtained, the allegation that the facility did not return communications made to the facility is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The facility was cited for STRTP Interim Licensing Standards 87072(c)(4) Personal Rights. In addition to Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, the facility shall ensure that each child is accorded personal rights including to have communications to the facility from relatives and/or authorized representative(s) answered promptly and completely. The facility did not return communications to an individual that they knew regularly spoke with C1 while in the facility nor did the facility engage anyone at the agency level return said communications as required by this regulation. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documents, including appeal rights, were provided to the facility.

The time youth left was 5: PM but there is no mention on what time they returned to the facility. * 5/15/ Incident report has only initials for all staff and clients. LPA Hill requested the full report to be provided without initials. This incident also indicates that C4 was not provided their medication prior to eating as prescribed. LPA Hill requested proof that staff was provided with the re-training as indicated on the report. In addition, LPA Hill requested going forward that the name of the staff be revealed in medication errors, date of the re-training as this needs to be completed immediately, and date of the write up as applicable. The report does indicate that the facility called poison control but the date of the "written warning" or name of the staff was not provided. LPA Hill requested that this incident report be updated with the requested information. Facility was cited for 80075(b) Health Related Services. C4 was administered double the medication that was prescribed on 5/23/23 which is a potential risk to the health, safety or personal rights of youth in care. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection to the administrative offices for Summitview on 10/12/23 at 12:00 noon and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill discussed incident reports with following incident reports with Danielle Bingle, administrator: * 8/10/ This report is related to C1 and C2 (see LIC811 dated 10/12/23) engaging in a behavior that may have been sexual between two youth but the report does not indicate that it was sexual in nature. Ms. Bingle states that it was reported by one of the youth as sexual. LPA Hill advised Ms. Bingle to put additional information in the reports to ensure that it is clear. * 8/1/ This report details an alleged sexual incident between C4 and C2 that was not consensual. met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 2/8/24 at 12: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs, to discuss a serious incident. LPA Hill informed Ms. Randle that the circumstances surround an unauthorized absence for C1 and C2 (see LIC811 dated 2/8/24) are currently being looked at. The incident included two youth absconding from the facility at approximately 1: AM on 2/7/24. The facility was acutely aware that both youth were planning to leave the facility days prior and had implemented an additional staff in the facility in case this should happen. When this did happen, there was additional staff present (S1) that followed youth as they left. Unfortunately, S1 lost sight of the youth. Youth were found on 2/7/24 around noon and transported to the hospital. LPA Hill discussed with Ms. Randle the reporting requirement related to the 24 hour notice. LPA Hill informed Ms. Randle that while the Department appreciates the expeditious nature of the reporting by the agency, the agency should first pause to assess incidents that require 24 hour notification to ensure that accurate and thorough information is being provided. LPA Hill advised the agency to pause to get as much information as possible prior to sending the notification to Licensing. In this instance, the rush to get the notice to Licensing caused some confusion over additional information as it was trickling in. LPA Hill reminded Ms. Randle that it is more important to get accurate and thorough information rather than trying rush to get the 24 hour report to Licensing, possibly missing certain critical information. LPA Hill is looking further into this incident and shall return at a later date for additional interviews as necessary. LPA Hill did request the Needs and Services Plans for C1 and C2 and training for S1. End of document.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA ) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 4/16/24 at 2: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs to discuss some issues related to a recent complaint investigation. Recent complaint investigation included review of documentation related to bed checks. The documentation obtained indicated that S1 did not conduct the required bed checks per the agency's policy. However, when interviewed, S1 indicated that the required bed checks were conducted despite the documentation indicating otherwise. S1 went on to sat that if the required bed checks had not been completed, S1's supervisor would have observed this via the video camera review and addressed it with S1 but this had not happened. LPA Hill reminded the facility that documentation is key to compliance and part of their Program Statement, in that their program statement indicates that they are to document the bed checks every 15 minutes. As such, LPA Hill issued a Technical Violation (TV) regarding the need to document bed checks per the agency's program statement. LPA Hill also discussed internal investigations with the agency as it pertains to their responsibility to investigate allegations or issues alleged by clients in care and take appropriate actions based on those allegation(s) to ensure the safety of all youth in care. Investigation indicates that during confidential interview(s), "failed to thoroughly document and follow up with the status or completion of [an] internal review of the incident". LPA Hill informed the agency that these report(s) if not investigated by Community Care Licensing via a complaint or case management inspection, is the responsibility of the agency to investigate and follow through with any/all appropriate actions to ensure the health, safety and personal rights of all clients in care. This advisory was also included on the Technical Violation (TV) indicated above as the agency's program statement indicates that they will investigate and/all allegation(s) and take appropriate actions to protect the health and safety of all youth in care. Lastly, interviews conducted for a complaint investigation revealed some issues or potential violations observed. The first is related to the facility's obligation surrounding room compatibility. Per Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Buildings and Grounds, Section 87087(e), the licensee is required to document bedroom sharing arrangements ensures the health and safety of each child. In the case involving C1 and C2, investigation indicated that even after a reported disclosure of inappropriate touching between C1 and C2, the youth continued to be roommates for 11 weeks following the disclosure. This is a violation of the youths' rights to be in a safe and healthy environment. Facility was cited for violation of Personal Rights, 87072(c) including the right to live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home. Despite knowing that the youth were no longer compatible due to the allegation, the facility did not move the youth to another room or facility. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to Ms. Randle along with appeal rights.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - LOTUS
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Resdiential Programs
narrative: LPA Hill informed Ms. Randle that the investigation of this incident included interviews with staff and C1, C2, along with other youth in the facility at the time of the alleged incident. Investigation shows that C2 was inconsistent in their statements during interviews and follow up interviews conducted by the investigator. Despite C2 naming several staff and clients as witnesses, investigation failed to show any witnesses that could corroborate the alleged incident(s). In addition, S1 was specifically named as the awake night staff during the alleged incident(s) and when interviewed, S1 denied any knowledge or unreported incident(s) where youth were awake during the overnight shifts as reported. A review of the facility's documentation of the overnight shift did indicate that bed checks are required every 15 minutes but the documentation indicated inconsistent bed checks being conducted. Per the agency's policy, the bed checks are required to be conducted every 10 to 15 minutes. This not being conducted as indicated in the policy which would have left youth unsupervised for periods of time to include 30 to 45 minutes. When interviewed, S1 stated that while they did not document all room check(s) conducted, S1 was adamant that the room checks were completed per the agency policy and that camera review would indicate such but cameras were not available for review and/or reviewed. As a result of the investigation of the allegation that a lack of supervision resulted in a minor inappropriately touching another minor in care is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle, and documentation was provided along with appeal rights.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 5/16/24 at 11: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill made the inspection to discuss an incident dated 5/9/24 where C1 (see LIC811 dated 5/16/24) discharged from a psychiatric hold and was prescribed a new medication. The new medication was sent to a local pharmacy but they did not have this medication in stock and it had to be ordered, rendering it not available until 5/10/24. C1 was not administered the medication the evening of 5/9/24 and 5/10/24. While this is not fault of the facility, LPA Hill did discuss with the facility the potential of obtaining a limited number of medications, one to two day's worth, while still at the hospital or other treatment facility that would allow the facility time to fill any prescriptions to avoid situations such as this in the future. When speaking with the therapist about this situation and C1's situation as a whole, therapist states that it is hard to depend on this for each type of hospitalization as each institution's policies and procedures could be different and/or preclude a policy such as this for discharges. LPA Hill obtained Needs and Services Plans for C1, along with C1's face sheet, Child & Family Team Meeting information, and other documentation relevant to C1's placement. No citations were issued during the inspection. Exit interview was conducted and document was provided to Ms. Randle.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 7/18/24 at 2: PM and initially met with Jose Navarrete, Residential Manager. Mr. Navarrete informed LPA Hill that the administrator of the home was present so LPA Hill worked with Administrator, Alyson Chavez. Mr. Navarrete signed documentation related to the inspection because Administrator Chavez needed to get to the residence. LPA Hill discussed the following incidents with Administrator Chavez: 7/2/24 - C1, C2 were escalated and C1 cause property damage and assaulted staff. Law enforcement was contacted and subsequent removed C1 for a mental health evaluation. C1 was able to commit to safety with the crisis worker and was returned to the facility. LPA Hill asked about an emergency CFT and citations/court date and was informed that while C1 was issued a citation, Administrator states that they do not feel that there will be a court date and feels that the charges will be dropped. Administrator states that they did a CFT following this incident and C1 was moved to another facility within the agency. No follow up is necessary and no citations were issued for this incident. 7/9/24 - C3 was not administered their PM medication on 7/8/24. Administrator states that there was a lot going on at the facility and it was an oversight of staff. Administrator states that they did counsel staff responsible and did provide a reminder to staff about the importance of the medication passing. No citations applicable and no further investigation needed. 7/13/24 - C4, C3, C5 were in one room together sleeping. C4 refused to listen to staff prompts to return to their own room for sleeping and fell asleep on the floor of the youths' room. Administrator states that staff were counseled about how to redirect youth. Administrator states that staff was provided additional training on how to properly deal with these situations. Administrator states C3 is no longer at the facility due to an unauthorized absence and C4 was relocated to another facility. C5 was a visiting youth and was only there for the weekend. Youth are no longer socialized due to noncompiance. No citations issued and no additional investigation needed. Exit interview conducted and documentation was provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 8/16/24 at 11: AM and met with Jose Navarrete, Residential Manager. LPA Hill conducted the inspection on this date as a follow up regarding an incident report dated 8/9/24 where C1 (see LIC811 dated 8/16/24) went on a home visit with family and was not provided their medications to take with them. LPA Hill questioned Mr. Navarrete regarding the staff who neglected to provide the medications and what the recourse for them not sending the medications as required. Mr. Navarrete states that it appears from the facility's documentation that these three staff (S1, S2, S3) were not given a corrective action, nor was there additional training provided to ensure that this does not happen in the future. LPA Hill advised Mr. Navarrete that because the facility failed to ensure that staff were provided training or counseled about this error, the facility will be cited for Title Regulations, Section 80075(b) Health Related Services as the facility is responsible for ensuring that medications are given to youth as prescribed. When youth left the facility on an authorized home visit, the staff did not provide the medications to the parent or guardian to ensure that medications were administered during the youth's home visit. LPA Hill provided the documentation and appeal rights to Mr. Navarrete.

met_with: Hayley Randall Director of Youth Residential Programs Alyson Chavez Administrator
narrative: An announced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie on 08/21/2024 at 09: AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Goldie met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs to review staff and client files at the Administrative office. LPA Goldie met with Alyson Chavez , Administrator who assisted with the inspection at the facility. LPA inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed one child's record electronically. LPA reviewed three staff personnel files at the administrative office. LPA reviewed one child's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed three staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed one child currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA provided one technical violation. This is not a deficiency. During the inspection the LPA observed one type B deficiency (see attached LIC809D). LPA Goldie cited Interim Licensing Standards Needs and Services Plan 87068.2(g). Plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. Licensing Program Analyst Michelle Kyane conducted a case management inspection on 08/22/2024 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, August 22nd, 2024). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Michelle Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Alyson Chavez.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Hill and Brittany Crass made an unannounced annual inspection on 8/28/24 at 9:20 am. LPA Hill arrived and maintenance were at the home making repairs as a result of an incident that took place at the facility the night prior. LPA Hill alerted Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs of LPA's arrival and Ms. Randle came to the facility to assist in the inspection. LPAs Hill and Crass conducted a physical plant inspection of the facility inside and out and observed the following: There are five youth in the facility. LPAs observed that there are three dual occupancy rooms that are equipped with bedding, storage, dressers and closets. There are two client bathrooms that have hot water that meets requirements, water measuring at 116 degrees Fahrenheit, toilets flush and showers working. Paper towels and toilet paper are present in the bathrooms for client use. LPAs observed that while chemicals in the garage are locked and not accessible to youth, LPA advised that the facility lock chemicals in an additional locking cabinet for the safety of the youth that may accompany staff into the garage for any reason. The facility has operable smoke and a carbon monoxide detector in the hallway but it was not operating initially during the inspection. Maintenance was on site and batteries were replaced. It was operable by the end of the inspection. LPA observed that there is fence not attached during the physical plant inspection. LPA did advise that this needs to be attached as this is light enough to be picked up by youth and/or used as a weapon. LPA observed that all seatbelts were functioning, the vehicle had valid registration and proof of insurance in the vehicle and the vehicle started and runs. LPA observed that one of the screens was on the ground outside the window and advised that it be placed back in its place. Fire extinguisher was mounted on the wall near the kitchen and was last inspected on 7/30/24. While there are no youth at the facility at the time of the inspection, they are in school at another location at the time of the inspection. LPAs advised that they would be going to that location to conduct interviews with staff and clients. LPAs also advised that additional inspection will occur on another undisclosed date to include inspection of the youth and staff records. LPAs issued advisories for Outdoor Activity Space and Buildings and Grounds. Exit interview conducted and documents provided. End of inspection on this date.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Hill and Brittany Crass made an unannounced Case Management - Annual Continuation inspection on 8/29/24 at 9:45 and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs to conduct review of the staff and client records. LPAs Hill and Crass reviewed staff and client records during the inspection and observed the following issues as it relates to the record review of the staff and client records: Records reviewed included two staff persons and two youths in care, Emergency Interventions and Emergency Intervention Log, Disaster Preparedness and Drills, and Core Therapeutic Services. The Emergency Intervention Log does not have the outcome of the licensee's review of emergency interventions when used in the facility. As a result of this, the facility was cited for 87095.61(g)(6) Documentation and Reporting Requirements as documenting the outcomes of restraints is required. LPAs issued a Technical Advisory indicating that the agency must maintain the educational qualifications of applicants via transcripts and/or degrees as applicable for staff. No other citations were issued on this date.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 9/6/24 at 11: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill made this inspection to discuss the finalizing of an open case management inspection initiated on 8/23/24, regarding a youth allegedly finding a pill on the ground. LPA Hill interviewed staff supervising youth during the time that the alleged incident was to have happened and it was determined that it was not possible as staff was supervising youth and was with youth in crisis at the time of the alleged incident. Further discussion with Ms. Randle revealed that youth was supervised the entire time they were outside and in the house when this allegedly happened. LPA Hill was not able to interview youth in question as youth has been hospitalized since this incident and subsequently removed from the facility due to safety of the youths in the facility. This concludes the investigation related to this incident. LPA Hill also discussed the results of the annual inspection conducted 8/28/24. During interviews with youth and staff, LPA Hill was made aware that youth are not happy with the lunches provided in that they indicated that it's "always a sandwich" consisting of "bagels and cream cheese". LPA Hill advised Ms. Randle that when meals are provided by the facility, they need to have acceptable alternatives so that youth have a choice if they do not like or do not want what is prepared. Ms. Randle indicated that youth can request alternatives to the lunches provided. LPA Hill informed Ms. Randle that this was not indicated in the interviews conducted with staff or youth in care. LPA Hill also discussed outings with Ms. Randle in that it was discussed that if youth do not want to attend a planned outing, they are given consequences, including a frozen program, which includes youth having to be in their room the duration of the outing but allowed out of their room for fifteen minutes of each hour. LPA Hill advised Ms. Randle that youth cannot be given consequences if they choose to not participate in outings. LPA Hill also discussed with Ms. Randle a denied exemption for S1. Ms. Randle indicated that the agency utilizes S1 for groups related to substance use and abuse. During the inspection, Anna Gleason, CEO, was contacted and indicated that it is their intent is to sponsor this individual in receiving an exemption with the Department. In the mean time, S1 was fingerprint cleared via "Accurate", which is utilized by the agency for fingerprinting services for staff employed by the agency for services other than in residence working with youth in care. Some of these services include their Wellness Team (therapists, family specialists, and other school based services), and Outpatient Support. The agency is contracted to provide mental health services to youth in the surrounding school districts. No citations were issued related to this issue. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to Ms. Randle.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: cognitive development, social development, cleanliness, gender identity, and sexual orientation of each youth to determine if they are compatible or not. Compatibility assessments also include discussion with each youth when they are admitted or if a youth needs to be switched rooms. Confidential interviews conducted revealed that these youth were in a previous placement prior to coming to this facility and were familiar with one another. When the opportunity presented itself for either of the youth to switch rooms, the youth refused to move rooms or to stop being roommates. The allegation that staff did not prevent minors from possessing restricted items is related to the agency policy prohibiting items containing alcohol to be in youths' possession and prohibiting that youth be in possession of items that youth could use to cause self harm, including sharp objects. The agency policy dictates youth must lock up these items with their hygiene items that contain alcohol. During the facility inspection, it was noted that C3 did have two bottles of perfumed body sprays in their restroom that were not locked according to this policy. Review of C3's Needs and Services Plan does not indicate that these items pose a danger to C3 and therefore C3 has a right to have these items in their possession. While the agency policy is to have these items locked, there is no regulation stating that youth cannot safely manage these items. Regarding having other dangerous items in youths' possessions including sharp objects, LPA Hill did not observe other dangerous items accessible to youth as reported. Confidential interviews indicated that sharp items are locked up and not accessible to youth in care. As a result of the investigation conducted including interviews conducted and documents reviewed, the allegations that staff did not ensure minors sharing a room were compatible and that staff did not prevent minors from possessing restricted items are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided along with appeal rights.
