narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced inspection on 7/28/21 at 9: AM and met with Anna Gleason, CEO to tour the facility. The inspection on this date is for the purposes of relocation of one of the other facilities by the same licensee to this location. As such, all of the furnishings or other items were not present in the facility as would be expected for new licenses. LPA did observe some non perishable food items, chemicals used for cleaning and other furniture items in the facility. During the inspection today, the following items were noted: Kitchen had some of the required dishes, appliances and silverware for client use. LPA also observed that the kitchen has a locked storage cabinet where medications are to be stored. The kitchen had a covered trash can. There is an island with plenty of additional storage space for storage of other cooking supplies as needed. LPA did observe a missing drawer handle and was informed that maintenance is out attempting to obtain longer screws to fix this drawer. LPA observed a refrigerator and stove for cooking in the kitchen. LPA observed a fire extinguisher near the kitchen area with an inspection tag dated 7/7/21. LPA observed a closet near the front door of the facility that has a lock for storage of the cleaning supplies for this house. LPA observed that there are three dual occupancy client bedrooms in the facility that were all well stocked with dresser space, beds and night stands as required. There are no lamps but LPA did observe that each of these rooms had central lighting in the rooms. LPA observed that the screens for the windows and slider in the client rooms were present. LPA did not observe any missing screens on any of the windows. LPA observed two client bathrooms: the front bathroom was equipped with two sinks, toilet and tub and shower combination. LPA observed that there is hot water in the sinks and shower. There is an abundance of storage space in this bathroom. LPA did advise that the shelves in the vanity be removed/replaced as they are glass. Back bathroom was equipped with a shower, toilet and sink for client use. LPA observed that this bathroom also has adequate storage space. Back patio was observed to have two exits and the south exit was observed to have a broken stair. LPA was informed that the side with the broken step will be permanently blocked and stairs removed. Currently, that side of the patio is temporarily blocked by wood. LPA observed that the laundry facilities are off the kitchen as well as additional storage space for cleaning supplies and other toiletries such as toilet paper and paper towels. LPA observed that this room also housed the wifi equipment and DVR (cameras) system. LPA observed that the property has a locked well house (as the property functions off well water), a locked storage shed is located outside the converted garage area (not converted by the agency rather converted prior to purchase by sellers), LPA observed an additional dwelling located on the other side of the storage shed. The agency has not decided if that dwelling will be strictly storage or what the purpose of this building will be. Agency shall notify Licensing upon reaching a decision but shall maintain this dwelling locked and inaccessible by clients at all times. The main entrance for visitors, staff and clients will be the converted garage area and not the front entrance of the house as the entrance into the converted garage is closer to parking. This area shall also serve as storage for the facility and activities as necessary for the clients in care. LPA discussed the cameras observed throughout the facility and LPA did observe that the cameras are in the common areas only and on the exterior of the facility. The use of cameras shall not violate the personal rights of youth in care as they shall not capture audio and are not used in client bedrooms or bathrooms. LPA verified via email with fire inspector on 7/28/21 that the facility does have a fire clearance per their inspection. Inspector neglected to fax over the STD 850 to verify but agreed to do that first thing 7/29/21. LPA observed that the facility appears ready to receive clients and is recommending that the facility be licensed as of 7/28/21. Exit interview was conducted with Anna Gleason, CEO and document was provided via email.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Monika Gleason, Youth Residential Program Administrator
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 11/12/21 at Placerville Drive, Placerville at 1: PM and met with Monika Gleason, Youth Residential Program Administrator and Anna Gleason, Chief Executive Officer to discuss an incident report. LPA informed Ms. Gleason that the incident involves two youth from this location, C1 and C2 (see LIC811 dated 11/12/21) where one client is alleging that an other client is being sexually inappropriate with them. LPA was able to interview C1 while at the agency during this visit. LPA could not speak with C2 as they were not present at the agency. LPA informed Ms. Gleason that additional investigation on this case management is needed and an additional visit will be necessary another day. LPA discussed with Anna Gleason another incident report including one from 9/23/21 where C3 refused to comply with medications and curfew and subsequently left the facility on an unauthorized absence following a statement about suicidal ideation. The report indicates that staff was not able to follow due to being the only staff in the facility at the time. LPA discussed the report with Anna Gleason in that it appears that C3 was struggling and had been struggling from the time that they were supposed to be sleeping until well after 12: AM and there was not an additional staff present to assist staff with client. LPA learned that behavior was common for this youth and was not alarming to staff until C3 left on the unauthorized absence. Anna Gleason states that the staff did respond quickly and C3 was returned to the facility but not articulated in the incident report. LPA reminded the agency that they need to have a full picture of the incident report and this should include the antecedent or what was happening prior to the incident, what happened during the incident as well as what happened after the incident. Anna Gleason states that she will send out a reminder to all staff of this. No citations were issued and exit interview was conducted. Document was provided to the agency.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced post licensing inspection at the facility on 3/25/22 at 11: AM and met with Anna Gleason, Chief Executive Officer . LPA toured the facility inside and out and found that the physical plant of the facility was in substantial compliance during the inspection. LPA observed that the house was equipped with three dual occupancy client bedrooms and two bathrooms accessible to clients in care. All bedrooms were fully equipped with appropriate bedding and furnishings as required. The bathrooms were properly equipped with appropriate supplies and LPA did not find anything in that bathrooms that should not otherwise be accessible to clients. LPA observed that the smoke detectors were functioning as required and that there is a carbon monoxide detector in the home. LPA did advise that the carbon monoxide detector be moved to be closer to client bedrooms rather than be in the living room of the facility. LPA observed that there was adequate food, perishable and nonperishable, in the facility for the clients in care. LPA observed that the facility looked clean and tidy during the inspection. All clients were at their school program during the inspection. LPA observed that the exterior of the home is well taken care of and that there is adequate room for clients to do activities outside. LPA advised that the couple of branches observed in the yard be removed so as to not present a trip hazard to clients. LPA also advised that the additional building needs to have access during the annual inspection that will be happening in July or prior to. LPA looked inside of the additional buildings on the property through the windows and it is obvious that nobody is living in the building and it is empty. LPA also looked inside the shed in the driveway and LPA observed that there are a couple of ladders in there and that there was nothing else of substance. LPA returned to the administrative buildings to review staff and client files on this date but there was not enough time to complete all of the review. LPA informed the agency that an additional visit will need to be conducted to interview client and staff and to review documents. LPA obtained client copies of files during the visit and will complete documentation related to client and staff files at a later visit. LPA will review staff files at a later visit with the agency as well. LPA did not observed any violations during the visit and an exit interview was conducted with Anna Gleason, Agency Administrator.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility administrative office on 3/25/22 at 12: PM and met with Anna Gleason, Chief Executive Officer. The purpose of the inspection on 3/25/22 was to discuss the following incident reports related to the facility: 2/20/22 - C1 experienced an episode in the bathroom lasting 2.5 hours and staff informed C1 that they were calling emergency services for an evaluation and youth acknowledged that it might be best for them. The report does not indicate that they were called. LPA informed Ms. Gleason that there is a lot missing from this report and not a clear picture of what happened or why they did not call emergency services or if they did. LPA asked that the agency rewrite the report with a clear picture of what transpired and resubmit it to LPA. 12/9/21 - C1 was restrained for trying to go AWOL. Youth was pulled back into the facility through an open window. LPA explained to the agency that restraints are not allowed strictly for attempts to AWOL. LPA provided that the agency needs to constantly evaluate situations such as these as the youth have a right to leave the facility as part of their Personal Rights. 12/1/21 - C2 was on a "Safety Watch" as indicated in the incident report but there is no information as to why. LPA explained that a youth being on a safety watch does not automatically mean that they do room searches or any other action that violates a youth's personal rights. LPA did not issue citations on this date but did discuss additional training needs for staff regarding room searches, restraining of youth, safety watches, and incident report writing. LPA did provide that when physical intervening a youth that is attempting to leave the facility, this requires additional documentation to accompany the incident report. LPA is aware that the agency is undergoing some major changes that would include a change in facility type and understands the struggles regarding staffing. Exit interview was conducted and document was provided to Ms. Gleason.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection to this facility on 9/23/22 at 10: AM. LPA was unable to immediately conduct the physical plant inspection as there were no staff persons present to accompany LPA on the walk through. LPA placed a call to Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs and eventually a staff person was sent to the facility to assist in the walk through for the physical plant. LPA toured the facility inside and out and found no issues in the facility or on the exterior or grounds of the facility. LPA then went to the "Golden Plaza" to review staff and client files. LPA reviewed two staff files and the administrator file while at the facility and found that there were no issues with the file review for all staff. LPA also reviewed two client files while at the administrative office and did not observe any violations during the file reviews. LPA did inform the agency that there are other topics still needing review including the facility Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention Plan, Core/Therapeutic Services, as well as additional review of some client and staff and other operational files. These reviews will be conducted another date and time, unannounced by Licensing. LPA did not observe any violations during the physical plant review or the file reviews. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided via email.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Tamara Hill and Monica Roberts made an unannounced inspection on 1/19/23 at 9: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs to discuss an incident report. LPA discussed the incident report dated 12/5/22 in which C1 (see LIC811 dated 1/19/23) left the facility unauthorized and law enforcement provided a ride to the local cafe. LPA interviewed C1 and one staff person present for the incident. LPA explained to Ms. Randle that the incident report needed to indicate additional information since the report is not clear about why youth are not given access to wifi in the resident, who called law enforcement, why youth was transported to a local cafe by law enforcement, and how long youth was at the cafe. LPA discussed with staff at the facility other information that is necessary to be in the incident reports (particularly the 24 hour reports) when submitting the reports to Licensing. LPA also discussed with the staff that it has been observed that there is an up-tick in medication incident reports where medications are either not administered or incorrectly administered for doses or medications. LPA advised that the agency needs to do something to ensure that youth are given their medications as prescribed and that missing medications for youth is not acceptable. LPA discussed 24 hour reports with the agency as well. LPA pointed out that there are incidents in which there is little to no information about why a youth is restrained or information is missing that is vital to know on these reports. LPA provided examples of the 24 hour incident reports that need additional information on them so that staff are aware of the missing or incomplete reports. No citations were issued as a result of the inspection and exit interview was conducted.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 5/25/23 at 2: PM and met with Anna Gleason, CEO and Jose Navarrete, Administrator, to discuss an incident report. This incident report details that a youth was not administered a medication on 5/18/23 as a result of a medical appointment in which C1 was not allowed to take the medication prior to the scheduled appointment. LPA Hill asked for more information about the appointment, permission to pass the medication, who gave the authorization to pass the medication at a time different than the regularly scheduled prescription time, and what was done about the "staff" that forgot to pass the medication at the newly authorized time. facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
narrative: not communicating with authorized representative about incidents that lead to C1 missing appointment(s) until C1 was discharged from the facility. When interviewed, the authorized representative stated that the communication received was after C1 had already left the facility and that it was that C1 had an orthodontic appointment that had to be rescheduled twice due to behaviors. Authorized representative states that they had conducted two Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings while C1 was in the facility but that this was never brought up or discussed during those meetings. Authorized representative states that had this information been shared prior to discharge, the authorized representative could have made additional visits to the facility to assist in the transport to the necessary appointment(s) or stabilization of C1's placement prior to C1 being displaced. When LPA Hill interviewed agency staff, LPA Hill learned that there is no specific documentation or policy related to appointments made or cancelled for clients. Since this complaint investigation, they have now implemented procedures for documenting appointments made, reasons for cancellation when necessary, and notifications to placing agencies. As a result of the investigation, documents obtained and interviews conducted, the allegation that staff did not communicate with minor's responsible party [about the missed appointments] is SUBSTANTIATED meaning that the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. Facility was cited for violation of Reporting Requirements, 80061(f) as the facility is required to make report(s) to the client's authorized representative of incidents, including but not limited to any unusual incident which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. LPA Hill observed that the facility did not provide C1's authorized representative information including the need to cancel medical, dental, and vision appointments as a result of behaviors. Exit interview conducted and documentation provided. requirement that the facility obtain a written medical assessment of clients admitted "prior to or within 30 calendar days following [their] acceptance". Complaint also alleges that C1 was not taken or provided access to dental or vision services. When reviewing the documentation related to C1, there is documentation that a physical was completed, by the placing agency, the week prior to placement. Related to dental services, it is documented that C1 had two appointments for orthodontia care but those appointments were cancelled due to unsafe behaviors. There is no documentation related to vision services being provided but the regulations do not speak to time frames for this to be conducted and C1 was in the facility for a month. As a result of the investigation, documents received, and interviews conducted the allegation that the facility did not ensure that C1 attended scheduled appointments is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Documentation was provided to the facility along with appeal rights.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 10/6/23 at 1: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill met with Jessica Maglietta, Administrator, to discuss the incident reports in detail: * 10/2/23 - Facility reported a possible bed bug infestation at the facility after a client presented with some bites that were abnormal. The facility responded appropriately by taking the youth to urgent care for proper diagnosis and second opinion. The facility was proactive in removing all bedding and washed all clients' bedding in hot water and dried on high heat as well as contacting an outside pest control company, Terminax, to come out to the facility for possible treatment. Terminax professional determined that there was no evidence of bed bug infestation in the home but did place traps around the bedding to ensure this. * 8/15/23 - Facility reported that C1 (see LIC811 dated 10/6/23) was struggling as a result of a substance dependency and the facility utilized a harm reduction approach to keep C1 from leaving the facility. LPA Hill advised that the facility maintain written documentation in the client's file, i.e. documentation of acknowledgement from the county social worker. * 8/13/23 and 8/3/23 - Facility provided a report that details C2 being inappropriate in their use of their cell phone in the facility, i.e. taking inappropriate pictures. LPA Hill discussed cell phone appropriateness, education, and usage with facility staff. LPA Hill also discussed another report with the facility that appeared to give C2 more than one consequence for the same violation. LPA Hill cautioned staff about this. * 6/24/23 - Facility provided a report about C3 regularly not sleeping in their own room. Continued on LIC809C * 4/8/23 - Facility provided a report about multiple youth in the facility, (C2, C4, C5) engaging in an inappropriate manner at the facility, including being able to obtain dangerous items and threatening staff with these items. LPA Hill asked the facility about contacting law enforcement. LPA Hill advised that once youth in the facility are able to obtain sharp items and threatening to staff or youth, they should call. LPA Hill also discussed some medication issues reported to Licensing and Ms. Magelietta states that she has worked with the facility staff about putting reminders on, in particular for the mid day medication reminder to ensure that youth are no longer missing medications. LPA Hill did not cite the facility for any of the incident reports discussed as the facility followed protocol and did what was supposed to be done in each of the incidents. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Randle and documentation was provided on 10/6/23.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: LPA Hill interviewed three youth and the administrator about the air conditioning unit being in disrepair and the comfortable environment for the youth. During interviews, it was indicated that the facility did contact an outside vendor to service the unit once it was noted on 8/9/23 that it was not functioning. The vendor came to the facility on 8/14/23 and 8/15/23, repairing it, but it stopped functioning again within 48 hours. The same vendor was asked to return to the facility on 8/17/23 and determined that a part needed to be replaced, but that it would take a few days for the part to come in. Final repair of the air condition unit was conducted on 8/22/23. During the time that the air conditioning unit was not functioning properly, the agency did supply the facility with an industrial-sized swamp cooler and fans for the youths' rooms to use during this time. The youth were offered to relocate to the administrative offices during this time but declined this option as they preferred to be in the facility where their bed and belongings were at. In addition, the agency provided LPA Hill with an invoice indicating annual maintenance with the same vendor dated July 13, 2022. Interviews conducted with staff and youth, indicated that while it was hot with the air conditioning unit not functioning, the agency did accommodate youth as best as possible by providing fans and an industrial-sized portable air conditioning unit in the facility until the necessary repairs could be completed. In addition, the agency offered to relocate youth temporarily to the administrative offices until the unit could be repaired but the youth opted to stay in the facility instead. As a result of the information obtained, documentation provided, and interviews conducted, the allegation that the facility air conditioning unit is in disrepair and that staff are not providing a comfortable environment for minors is UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred as the agency made attempts to get a vendor to the facility for repair of the air conditioning unit and did attempt to make youth more comfortable by relocating youth to the agency's administrative offices while waiting for the unit to be repaired. Exit interview conducted and documents were provided to Ms. Randle.

When the air conditioning unit stopped working a day later, the vendor returned to the facility, 8/17/23 and informed the agency that additional repairs were needed. The invoice indicates that the vendor finally completed the repairs for the air conditioning unit on 8/22/23. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Investigation showed that maintenance was alerted to a possible incontinent issue in one of the facilities with youths beds prompting an agency-wide inspection which included all facilities operated by the Summitview Child & Family Agency. As a result of this inspection, mattresses were replaced if they were identified as soiled, stained, or showing signs of wear. It was alleged that one of the youth had removed the mattress cover after having an accident without telling staff so a new cover was not placed on the bed to prevent the soiling of the mattress. Staff interviewed indicated that the agency did an inspection of all the facility beds throughout the agency and replaced multiple mattresses throughout their facilities including the youth(s) who were identified as having incontinence issues. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted, the allegation that youth was not provided with a mattress in good condition is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The facility was cited for Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards Section 87088(c)(1) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies as the licensee is to provide and make readily available to each child an individual bed maintained in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress and investigation showed that one or more youth had been sleeping on a mattress that was soiled or mattresses that were identified as soiled or in need of being replaced as they did not meet this standard. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documentation, including personal rights were provided. odor present as a result of the youths' incontinent issues, staff were cleaning the youths' rooms, doing the youths' laundry daily, and working with both youths on this issue in private so as to rid the facility of the smell. Interviews indicated that while it was difficult due to youths' behaviors of hiding clothes or not wanting to tell staff when there was an issue when youths' first arrived at the facility, staff tried. None of the staff and clients interviewed felt that staff were neglectful or dismissive of the issue and did take the youths' health and cleanliness issues seriously. As a result of this, while there was a smell that lasted in the house for about a month, the staff were working with youths in care to overcome the issues for a clean and safe environment for all in the facility. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted, the allegations that licensee did not properly address minor's incontinence needs and did not ensure that the facility was kept odor free are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The allegation that a youth is engaging in a relationship with an adult is related to a youth talking with an adult male while at the facility via a tablet furnished by Summitview Child and Family Services. During interviews, when it was discovered that youth was initiating conversations with this adult male. Subsequently, the tablet was removed and cleaned by the agency's technology department followed by firewalls being installed to prevent further contact with this individual. While the agency cannot prohibit calls due to youth's personal rights, the agency did discuss this further during youth's Child and Family Team meetings and is no longer a concern. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted, the allegation that youth is engaging in a relationship with an adult is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Randle and documents provided, including personal rights.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: medical condition. Some of the recommendations on the documentation include the need to make lifestyle changes, including a healthy diet, an avoidance of processed foods and foods high in refined sugars and carbohydrates, and regular exercise. In addition, the paperwork indicates that the doctor recommended allowing youth to work with staff in selecting food choices for the shopping list and "snack box" at the facility that were conducive to youth's medical diagnosis. When interviewed, C1 indicated that initially the facility did not cater to C1's medical condition and options for snacks in the facility included inappropriate choices such as crackers and cups of noodles. C1 indicated that when C1's medical condition escalated and became emergent, then the facility began to work with youth on food choices, but this did not happen until C1 was about to leave and go home. Interviews conducted indicated that when the doctor provided suggestions on eating and logging food intake, they worked with youth to ensure doctor-recommended snack options were available and that food alternatives were offered including wheat bread versus white bread, wheat pasta versus bleached pasta, etc. LPA Hill requested copies of the menus for the facility from August 2023 to December 2023, that do not indicate alternatives as suggested or required by the doctor. The menu shows many food items specifically listed on the food avoidances list provided by the doctor. While substitutions may have been provided, there is no evidence that this happened as the menus provided do not indicate substitutes for items such as pancakes, sliders, sugary cereals, toast, rice, spaghetti, hamburgers (buns), baked potatoes, etc. to name a few. As a result of the information and documentation received, the allegation that the facility did not follow the doctor's orders is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility was cited per Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87076(d) Food Services as food served shall meet special dietary needs...as recommended by a physician. The allegation that the facility leaves sharp objects accessible to clients in care is related to an incident where C1 had access to sharp objects and being able to access these sharp items without staff knowledge. LPA Hill observed an incident on or about 10/4/23, facility staff did not lock a staff drawer containing sharp items, including scissors, resulting in C1 accessing the drawer and getting some scissors without staff knowing. C1 then took the scissors into the bathroom during their shower time and cut their own hair without staff knowledge and without parental permission. While interviews indicated that the drawer was to remain locked, it was indicated that youth knew when staff neglected to lock the drawer as required. As a result of the information and documentation received, the allegation that the facility left sharp objects accessible to clients in care is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility was cited per General Licensing Standards, Title Regulations, Section 80087(g)(1) Buildings and Grounds as dangerous items were not locked as required. The allegation that the facility is not conducting child and family team meetings (CFTs) as required is related to C1 not having the CFTs every 30 days as required by regulation. The reporting party states that while in care, the facility failed to conduct the required monthly Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings for this facility type of facility. During the investigation into these allegations, LPA Hill learned that C1 was initially placed into a different facility type with the same agency in April 2023. The licensee was informed that C1 required a Short Term Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP) where the expectations and requirements were different. C1 was placed in the STRTP on 8/24/23, and a documented CFT meeting was conducted on 11/8/23. C1 was discharged from the facility 12/21/23. During this time, only one documented CFT was conducted, and no Needs and Services Plan was obtained for C1 from 8/24/23 to 12/21/23. As a result of the information and documentation received, the allegation that the facility is not conducting child and family team meetings (CFTs) as required is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. While regulations do not require a CFT every thirty days, the Needs and Services Plan are required to be updated every 30 days and shall consider recommendations of the child and family team, eluding to the requirement to have CFTs every 30 days. The facility was cited per the Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87068.3(b)(2) Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan. The allegation that the facility did not assist with discharge and aftercare services planning as required is related to C1 being discharged back to the care of their family with no aftercare services in place and no plan to continue to see youth until youth could get established with another provider for mental health services. The reporting party states that because C1 is a post adoption youth, they were informed that it was the family's responsibility to coordinate and look for services for C1 for ongoing mental health services after leaving placement because they lived so far away from the placement agency. When questioned, LPA Hill was informed that the therapist is responsible for postdischarge services for youth leaving care. When asked for proof of aftercare services coordination for C1, LPA Hill was informed that there were no aftercare services provided or coordinated for C1. Additional documentation provided shows there was a lack of communication with the Health Services Department within Summitview "on several things related to [C1's] health". As a result of the information and documentation received, the allegation that the facility did not assist with discharge and aftercare services planning as required is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility was cited per the Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87089.1(d)(3) Mental Health as the facility shall ensure continuity of care, services, and treatment as a child moves from their short-term residential therapeutic program placement to home-based family care for at least six months postdischarge from a short-term residential therapeutic program. In this case, C1 went home without the required array of services as required. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documentation was provided including appeal rights. indicated that they have asked for additional training related to good choices and getting C1 engaged in making healthy choices. C1 tends to refuse these services. Food shoppers were given healthy alternatives to purchase to have on hand for the house but cannot force youth to make those healthy choices. Regarding the allegation that the facility is threatening C1 with discharge is related to C1 needing to go to the emergency room due to their health condition and the facility informing the reporting party that if C1 were to go and be formally diagnosed with a medical condition that they could not handle or may not be able to accommodate, C1 would be discharged from the program. In speaking with the staff that regularly interacted with the reporting party and Chief Executive Officer, it was denied that C1 was ever threatened with discharge from the facility for diagnosis of this medical condition. The allegation that facility staff were discussing employment and/or discipline topics with youth in care is related to staff complaining about specific aspects of their employment with youth in care or where youth could hear these discussions. Staff were discussing topics such as not being paid enough to deal with youth, that staff are leaving their jobs to find employment that pays more, or being written up for things that youth do, and other personnel issues around youth in care. LPA Hill obtained proof of the facility's knowledge that at least one staff member was doing this via an email dated 10/19/23 to that staff person identifying that this is an issue when youth are present. In addition, there were multiple notices for staff about discussions in front of youth in care including 3/30/22, 8/17/23, 11/9/23 and 1/31/24. While this was happening at the agency, it was addressed, staff were counseled/reminded that this is not an acceptable practice. LPA Hill did not find additional personnel speaking about personnel issues around youth in care following the email reminder to not discuss personnel issues or other inappropriate topics in the facility. The allegation that staff did not appropriately intervene in adult/child interactions is related to an interaction that C1 had with outside medical personnel during a routine medical appointment. It was alleged that C1 reported that the interaction was a "deep conversation" with the medical personnel individual and may have been inappropriate as it was related to what drugs do to the brain. When interviewed, staff indicated that they would not always stop those conversations as youth benefit from hearing the same message from multiple individuals, not just the facility staff. Staff indicated that these messages go further when heard from multiple different sources. When interviewed, C1 indicated that staff accompanied C1 during the entire time of the appointments. During interviews, staff indicated that they would not intervene unless youth are having inappropriate conversations about the benefits of illicit drug use or how to obtain or use drugs. Staff indicated that the transport never reported an inappropriate conversation during a medical appointment, indicating that staff did not feel any conversations had been inappropriate. As a result of the investigation, interviews conducted, and documentation reviewed, the allegations that the facility did not meet the need of C1 as it relates to C1's health condition, the facility threatened to discharge C1, facility staff discussed employment and/or discipline topics with youth in care and facility staff did not appropriately intervene in adult/child interactions are all UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documentation, along with appeal rights were provided.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 4/11/24 at 2: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill made this case management inspection to discuss the conclusion of an investigation related to an incident report related to C1's return to the facility from a home visit on 4/1/24 and C1 not being given their morning medications upon return. C1 had gone with family for the weekend and when C1 was returned, C1 arrived at the agency's non-public school site, Monday morning, 4/1/24. C1's regularly scheduled medications are to be administered at 8:00 but C1 arrived at the non-public school site after 9:00 am. While the school site staff assumed that the parent/guardian had already given the youth their medication, nobody specifically asked C1 or their parent/guardian which resulted in C1 missing morning medications. LPA Hill discussed this incident with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs and did interview the facility administrator and school aid supervisor about C1's arrival at the non-public school site. LPA Hill observed that the agency's policies and procedures are not clear about receiving youth at the non-public school site, who or how youth are to be checked in at the school site, or how to ensure that youth are given their medication(s) upon return. After reviewing the medication transfer documentation, LPA Hill did advise the agency to add some details to this medication transfer documentation to indicate when youth are being given medication by the parent/guardian during their home pass. This documentation would be similar to what the facility is required to do, i.e., date, time and signature of parent/guardian who administers the medication. In addition, LPA Hill advised that on the medication transfer sheet there be a note informing the parent/guardian of the responsibility to administer the medications if they are returning the child after any regularly scheduled medication time. As a result of the interviews conducted and documentation received and reviewed, LPA Hill did not issue any citations during the inspection and investigation related to this incident but did issue a Technical Advisory related to the medication transfer procedure(s) on the attached LIC9102TA. While at the agency on this date, LPA Hill also spoke to the agency regarding another incident involving C1 in which C1 was not administered a prescribed medication on 4/3/24. LPA Hill learned from Ms. Randle that overnight staff are to pack any medications that are to be administered while at the non-public school site for youth but on 4/3/24, this particular medication, being that there had been a change in the administration, was not packed accordingly. While the incident report received indicates that staff responsible, S1 and S2, were counseled and training was to be provided 4/8/24, LPA Hill learned S2, S3, and S4 were all responsible but only S1 was provided the required training. As a result of this, LPA Hill did cite the agency for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Section 80075(b) h LPA Hill conducted an exit interview related to this incident and provided documentation to Ms. Randle.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE

narrative: When arriving at the nonpublic site, S1 and C1 got into S1's vehicle and C1 observed S1's vaping device in the vehicle. S1 admits that the vaping device was in plain sight in the vehicle but that they put the device away immediately upon getting into the vehicle but that C1 had already seen it. Confidential interviews indicate conflicting statements as to whether or not S1 allowed C1 to use their vaping device during the transport. As a result of the information obtained and interviews conducted, the allegation that staff allowed a youth to smoke in staff's personal vehicle is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The allegation that staff disclosed personal information to youth is related to an alleged disclosure that S1 shared personal information about themselves to C1 that may have been inappropriate or triggering to youth in care. When interviewed, C1 disclosed that S1 shared a traumatic event that had happened to themselves and that this information and/or disclosure was triggering to C1 due to their own trauma. During an interview with S1, they denied that they shared more than peripheral information about themselves in an effort to demonstrate to youth that it is possible to overcome their circumstances. S1 denied sharing any traumatic information about themselves as they understand that personal stories can be triggering to youth in care and can take the focus off of youth in care. As a result of the information obtained and interviews conducted, the allegation that staff disclosed personal information to youth is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The allegation that staff spoke inappropriately to youth is related to a disclosure made by C1 that S1 spoke to C1 about a romantic text between S1 and S2. During confidential interviews, both staff denied any romantic interest and/or text messages between themselves. C1 refused interview with LPA Hill and would not elaborate on any information to assist in the investigation. As a result of the information obtained and interviews conducted, the allegation that staff spoke inappropriately to youth is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Randle and documentation was provided, along with appeal rights.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 4/30/24 at 11: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill made the inspection to discuss an incident report related to an incident report dated 4/23/24 indicating that C1 (see LIC811 dated 4/30/24) had missed their midday prescribed medication. Upon arrival at the administrative site for Summitview Child & Family Services to discuss the issue, LPA Hill met with Alyssa Polk, Special Ed Learning Coach Supervisor who supervises the educational staff. Ms. Polk discussed that last week was a bit of a different scheduled for C1 due to state testing which required C1 to arrive at the administrative site later than normal, causing the missed medication dosage as the required staff were no longer present to administer the medication to C1. When discussing the issue, Ms. Polk indicated that it came to their attention that C1 did not have a refill for this same medication and had missed their medication. Upon further review, it was determined that C1 missed their medications the evening of 4/29/24 and the morning 4/30/24. While the facility has already ordered the medication and it will arrive today, C1 still missed the medication 4/23/24, 4/29/24, and 4/30/24. When asked who is responsible for ordering refills, Ms. Polk states that it is the administrator and while the house administrator was on vacation last week, this did not conflict with or should not have impeded the responsibility to refill the medication. As a result of the information discussed, LPA Hill informed Ms. Randle that due to the repeated missed medications, the facility was cited for Title 22, Division 6, General Regulations, Health Related Services, Section 80075(b). The facility is required to assist clients with self-administration of prescription and nonprescription medications. This did not happen as evidenced by the medication errors 4/23/24, 4/29/24, and 4/30/24. This is a repeat violation within the previous 12 months, resulting in a civil penalty today. Exit interview conducted and documents provided to the agency.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 5/16/24 at 11: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill made the inspection to discuss an incident dated 5/3/24 where C1 (see LIC811 dated 5/16/24) disclosed self-harm and showed staff the marks "up and down both right and left legs". C1 was engaged on the phone with a crisis hotline and medical services were summoned to the facility. Ms. Randle states that a room search was conducted after C1 informed staff that they had "gotten rid of" the object they were using to self-harm. Ms. Randle states that the staff in the facility informed C1's social worker that the room search was being completed while C1 was at the hospital. Upon discharge, the agency picked C1 up at the hospital and they were informed that they found "multiple" items hidden in C1's hair that could be used for self-harm and these items were removed by hospital staff. Ms. Randle states that following this information, C1's therapist contacted C1's social worker to request a change in C1's Needs and Services Plan to include wanding C1 when returning from school or is otherwise outside of the facility's supervision. LPA Hill questioned Ms. Randle about the supervision of C1 as indicated in the incident report that the staff that encountered C1 was passing by C1's room to check on another client in care. In review of the cameras in the facility, it was observed that while there were three staff present at the facility, two of the staff were observed to be sitting at the kitchen table for approximately 20 minutes and one staff was in the living room supervising two youth. LPA Hill observed that C1 was not supervised for approximately 30 minutes and no staff were engaging with C1 during this time. The facility was cited for Title 22, Division Six, General Licensing Standards, Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision, Section 80078(a) as the facility is required to provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. The facility was not supervising C1 which resulted in C1 engaging in self harm without staff knowledge. Citation was issued and documentation was provided to Ms. Randle.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: in an effort to combat the pests, the facility staff and clients were also advised to wash all of the clothing, bedding, and maintain a clean the facility. While the facility did all of this, the bed bug issue persisted and the youth in the facility continued to complain about bed bug bites. Documentation shows that the facility became aware of the bed bug issues in the facility on 4/1/24 and began treatments including spraying the facility, washing youths' clothes, stripping of the beds and laundering of the clothing and bedding for the youth. Based on interviews with staff and clients, staff attempted to launder youths' clothing and bedding and this proved unsuccessful and the pests persisted. As of 4/12/24, the facility maintenance, in consultation with a local pest control, attempted to rid the facility of the pests by spraying the interior of the house with chemicals on a weekly basis as advised by the local pest control and advising all staff to pack up youths' belongings, including soft items, into bins once laundered but this did not resolve the issue. As of 5/6/24, documentation obtained from the facility indicates that the initial treatments were not successful and the agency hired a local pest control, Hangtown Pest Control, to conduct a more thorough treatment, including "three treatments over three weeks". This treatment required all clothing items to be washed and dried on hot settings and other items to be placed in large containers and stored until the treatment was complete. Beds were to be stripped daily and the rooms deep cleaned for the three weeks and all personal items could not be returned to the youths' bedrooms for the three weeks. The agency knew about the bed bug issue in the facility and attempted to address the issue in-house in April 2024 but they were not successful at combating this issue until hiring a professional pest control in May 2024 to render the services necessary, prolonging the treatment and presences of the pests in the facility. While the facility did not sit idle and ignore the pest issue, they did prolong treatment by attempting to address the pests in-house and not using a professional service as needed. As a result of this, the allegation that the facility did not address pests is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documentation was provided, including appeal rights.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: This complaint investigation named S1 in addition to S2, S3, and S4 as providing vaping devices, including tobacco and marijuana, to youth in care. S1 was interviewed for the previous complaint investigation and S1 denied ever providing a vaping device to a youth in care. S1 made statements eluding to the agency not paying them enough to purchase vaping devices to give to youth in care. S1 did acknowledge that one youth (not connected to this investigation) saw their personal vaping device in their car during a transport one time and requested to "hit it" but S1 denied allowing youth to use the vape. S2, S3, and S4 were all interviewed and all staff denied supplying vaping devices to youth in care. S1 did not continue to work for the agency following the previous investigation due to reasons not solely related to the allegation. Law enforcement interviewed C1 and this is where additional staff were named (S2, S3, S4) and that disclosure indicated that they directly provided vapes, had direct knowledge about the vapes and who was supplying them, or were in collaboration with staff providing vapes to youth in care. C1 also disclosed that C4, and C2 and C3 (who do not live at this facility) all knew about the vapes and knew the staff named were providing vapes to youth in the agency. Following the complaint allegation, C1 did not return to the facility. When interviewed, S2, S3, and S4 all denied ever providing vaping devices to youth in care and denied knowing that youth were getting vaping devices from any staff working for the agency. Staff indicated that they thought youth were bringing in vapes when returning from home passes, from youth who attended public schools in the area, or when the youth residing in the facility interact with outside youth that come to the agency for therapy and groups in the afternoons. Staff stated that they thought the vapes were brought in by youth and subsequently passed to other youth in the agency and through the different facilities as this is what youth indicated when vaping devices were recovered. C2 and C3 were interviewed on 6/27/24 and neither could confirm that they paid staff or requested that staff provide vapes or that they saw a transaction of this nature. Both youth stated that they only heard rumors about this happening but had no direct proof or knowledge and no staff ever confirmed this directly to either youth. Both youth talked about S1 taking money from youth for snacks and bringing back snacks to youth but neither disclosed any information about S1 or any other staff providing vapes. C4 was interviewed in conjunction with the previous complaint investigation and they too denied knowing about, receiving, or seeing any staff provide vapes to youth in care. All youth confirmed that they heard about S1 providing vapes via rumors throughout the agency but none indicated that they had any proof. The allegation that staff threatened minors in care is related to the providing of the vapes and alleges that S1 threatened to get youth kicked out of the program if they told administrative staff or anyone about S1 providing the vaping devices. The interview conducted by law enforcement indicates that C1 denied being threatened by staff about the vaping devices but a subsequent interview of C1 conducted by C1's social worker indicated that C1 revealed they felt threatened and did not want to return to the agency as they felt that they would be retaliated upon or that C1 would be targeted as a snitch for making the report. No other youth confirmed any threats as they denied being involved with or receiving vaping devices. As a result of the interviews conducted and investigation completed the allegations that staff is providing smoke contraband to minors in care and that staff threatened minors in care are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Gleason and documentation was provided.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: The allegation that staff were providing vaping devices to minors in care is related to an allegation that S1 and S2 were providing vaping devices, including tobacco and marijuana, to youth in care. Confidential interviews conducted by the Sheriff's Office alleged that S1 was providing vapes to youth in care without it being asked of S1 or the youth directly requesting them. It was also alleged that S1 never requested youth to pay for the vaping devices or that any money was exchanged for the purchase of the vaping devices. A vaping device was turned in to LPA Hill during an interview that youth alleged came from S1. This vaping device was given to Director of Youth Residential Programs by LPA Hill immediately following the interview. At the time of this disclosure, S1 had recently been discharged from their employment with the agency due to this being the second allegation involving vaping devices and other reasons, not related. A previous investigation and interview with C5 alleged that S1 allowed C5 to use S1's vaping device during a transport in S1's personal vehicle but S1 denied that this happened. S1 stated that the vaping device was in plain sight in their vehicle initially and that when C5 remarked about the vaping device, S1 removed the vaping device from sight and did not allow C5 to use it. This allegation was not substantiated. One youth originally alleged that S1 and S2 were providing vaping devices to youth in care but when interviewed by this LPA, that same youth denied any knowledge about staff providing vaping devices to youth. Youth stated that they heard one time a youth say something about obtaining a vaping device from staff but that they didn't believe the allegation and had no additional information about the allegation. When interviewed, S2 denied ever providing a vaping device to a youth in care. S2 went on to state that they do not smoke at work as they do not want youth to smell anything on them. S2 denies that they would ever provide a vaping device to youth in care. Interviews with additional staff indicated that youth tend to recirculate old allegations and rumors, sometimes allegations even prior to the youth arriving at the agency, including this same allegation related to staff providing vaping devices or allowing youth to take a hit off their personal vaping devices but there is no evidence or proof of this currently happening. The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) states these recirculated rumors only makes it harder for the agency decipher \what is happening now versus what is being drug up about old stuff. CEO states that all of this has prompted the agency to implement a policy whereby staff are prohibited from having vaping devices on their persons in the facility, not being allowed to have vaping devices left in plain sight in their vehicles, and their vehicles needing to be locked at all times while on the facility property to deter youth from attempting to obtain them from staff unknowingly. Other confidential interviews with staff and clients failed to corroborate that any staff are providing vaping devices to youth in care. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted and based on the information obtained from the El Dorado County Sheriff's Office, there was not a preponderance of the evidence that staff providing vaping devices to youth in care despite the allegations made by youth. As a result, the allegation that staff are providing vaping devices to youth in care is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Gleason and documentation, along with appeal rights were provided.

met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 9/6/24 at 11: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill made this inspection to discuss the finalizing of an open case management inspection initiated on 7/18/24 regarding an incident report dated 6/27/24, where youth were taken on an outing and were able to abscond from a store with alcohol without staff knowledge. LPA Hill interviewed youth in care about how this happened and youth indicated that they planned, in advance, to outnumber staff during outings. LPA Hill found that staff did not know that this was planned and upon seeing it unfold, they got the youth out of the store and returned to the facility. LPA Hill did provide counseling to the agency about conducting searches when situations such as this come about. In addition, LPA Hill advised that the staff, knowing that youth were out of sight during the outing and inside a store where contraband is readily available, call ahead of their return to the facility to allow time for the facility staff to contact responsible parties and obtain permission to search youth prior entering the facility. Exit interview conducted and documentation provided to Ms. Randle.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES, INC SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced Pre-Licensing Inspection on 6/27/24 at 8: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill toured the facility inside and out and observed the following in this home: * Main floor of the home has the kitchen area, dining area with seating for eight, living room area, one half restroom, staff room where chemicals and client files are to be stored. The dining room has a cabinet where the medications are to be stored and this cabinet has a two lock system for all medications and first aid supplies to be stored in. * Second floor of the home has two dual occupancy rooms and two single occupancy rooms that have all of the required furniture. Additional furniture, bedding and other needed supplies are coming with the relocation of the youth for their current location. This floor also has one restroom centrally located and accessible to youth and the other restrooms is in the master bedroom. These are full restrooms, including showers, sinks, toilets, and other necessary storage. Since the cabinets in the restrooms cannot lock, there will be nothing stored in these restrooms that cannot otherwise be accessible to youth in care. * Basement floor of the home is where the youth will be doing schooling, therapy or other activities in the home. This floor has a restroom as well as storage closets that will not be accessible to youth. There are desks in the garage that will be placed in this space for therapists and/or youth to use for schooling. * Linens and other excess items will be stored in the garage area. Laundry area is in the garage. * Outdoor area of the facility was observed to have rubbish from trees and log/wood piles that all need to be removed. Ms. Randle informed maintenance that this needs to be attended to immediately. LPA Hill also observed tree rounds in the yard and suggested possibly a seating area be designed for youth to sit outside on using these rounds but if the facility is not going to utilize them then they need to be removed. * Smoke detectors were functioning and carbon monoxide detectors are on every floor. LPA Hill and Ms. Randle discussed the submission of the Program Statement and Plan of Operation by 7/1/24. LPA Hill observed that the facility is ready for licensure and will provide the recommendation as needed to the management. End of document.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 8/16/24 at 11: AM and met with Jose Navarrete, Residential Manager. LPA Hill conducted the inspection on this date as a follow up regarding an incident report dated 8/14/24 where C1 (see LIC811 dated 8/16/24) went on a 1:1 visit with a staff member at the agency and where youth gained access to unauthorized medications. When interviewed staff states that they watched C1 enter the restroom during their outing but did not clear the restroom prior to allowing youth to enter. In the restroom were several first aid supplies and a bottle of pills marked "pain killers" but staff did not think to clear the restroom prior to allowing youth to enter. Staff has only been working with the youth and agency for two months and was provided subsequent training immediately after this incident about clearing public restrooms or asking youth to wait until they return to the facility if clearing is not possible. LPA Hill provided the documentation and advisory note (TA) to Mr. Navarrete.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 8/23/24 at 12:40 and met with Joy Rose, Learning Coach/MHS II. LPA Hill made the case management inspection to discuss an incident dated 8/19/24 that allegedly took placed at this house during the facility's schooling hours. While the youth (C1, see LIC811 dated 8/23/24) does not reside in this house, C1 attends schooling and group hours at this location. LPA Hill spoke with S1 who spent time with C1 outside of the classroom on 8/19/24 and did participate in one of C1's coping mechanisms while C1 was struggling. Youth was not available during the case management inspection today due to another incident that took place that removed youth from the agency. End of documentation.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 1024/24 at 1: PM and met with Sarah Rodriguez, Administrator to discuss some incidents at this facility. LPA Hill discussed the following with the administrator: Incident report dated 10/23/24 where C1 (see LIC811 dated 10/24/24) threatened to report an inappropriate touch for removing C1's cell phone from their bedroom following a consequence being given for inappropriate use in the facility. LPA Hill informed the agency that further investigation is needed at this time and no conclusion was indicated. Incident report dated 10/8/24 where C2 was administered an incorrect dosage of medication. LPA Hill learned that the staff administering the medication was not the typical house staff but was responsible for transportation on the date of the incorrect dosage provided. LPA Hill obtained the medication transfer sheet and will follow up on this incident as further investigation is needed. Incident report dated 9/23/24 where C2 was sent home from public school due to a behavior and being placed on "sick day protocol" which included being in their room and secluded from peers and staff for the day. LPA Hill cautioned the facility about being excessively punitive regarding behaviors as this type of consequence does not appear to be trauma-informed. LPA Hill informed the agency that further investigation is needed at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Ann Barlett and documentation was provided.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 11/21/24 at 2: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs, to discuss some incidents at this facility. LPA Hill discussed the following with Ms. Randle: Incident report dated 10/23/24 where C1 (see LIC811 dated 10/24/24) threatened to report a staff for inappropriately touching them for removing C1's cell phone from their bedroom while sleeping and that C1 was placed on a cell phone restriction due to "multiple violations". LPA Hill advised the agency that when writing incident reports, the staff need to be detailed on what violations the youth violate that caused the restriction from the phone. Staff should not be writing "multiple violations" as this is too vague and could lead to further allegations/investigations related to personal rights violations. This concludes the investigation related to this incident report. No citations was issued. Incident report dated 10/8/24 where C2 was administered an incorrect dosage of medication. LPA Hill was unable to obtain the medication transfer sheet, but did obtain proof of staff retraining related to this medication error. This concludes the investigation related to this incident. No citations were issued. Incident report dated 9/23/24 where C2 was sent home from public school due to a behavior and being placed on "sick day protocol" including being in their room and secluded from peers and staff for the day. LPA Hill advised the agency about being excessively punitive regarding behaviors as this does not appear to be trauma-informed. Ms. Randle states that they are send a memo to all staff indicating that no youth should be placed on "sick day protocol" unless truly sick and/or displaying symptoms that may deem youth contagious. Ms. Randle to provide the written direction put out to staff. No citation issued. Youth closing bedroom doors - LPA Hill discussed with the agency youth being in their rooms when alone and being able to close their bedroom doors. While the Department is sympathetic with the nature of the program, the agency has an obligation to look at each youth as individuals and develop individual treatment plans and needs and service plans for each youth to meet their individual needs. and not implement blanket type policies that could be interpreted as personal rights violations. Each youth should be assessed individually, and if deemed safe, be able to utilize the time away as a coping skill as long as individual youth safety could be ensured. If safety cannot be maintained, this should be noted in their Needs and Services Plan and a plan to achieve this should be expressed. No citations were issued at this time. Cell phone policy for youth. LPA Hill discussed that the cell phone policy should not include staff going into client bedrooms to remove or retrieve youths' cell phones if they fail to turn cell phones in per their cell phone policy. LPA Hill advised that review of the cell phone policy, as well as other policies youth sign upon admission, should include frequent review of the policies to ensure youths' understanding of policies signed upon admission and are required to follow. This policy is under review at this time by Licensing as it is part of the agency's Program Statement submitted during relocation of the facility. No citations were issued at this time. LPA Hill concluded the inspection and exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 2/6/25 at 2: PM to the administrative offices for the agency and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs to discuss incident reports. LPA Hill discussed an incident report dated 1/31/25 in which C1 was given a double dose of their prescribed medication due to staff error. LPA Hill did obtain the counseling and/or disciplinary documentation for S1 and S2 related to the medication error. LPA Hill was advised and provided proof that both staff were also provided additional training to ensure this does not happen again in the future. LPA Hill advised the agency that the number of medication errors are becoming alarming and the agency needs to be reviewing policies and procedures to ensure that future medication training meets the expectations so as to lessen incidents related to medication errors. Exit interview conducted and documents provided.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: Youth and staff interviews failed to identify any witnesses to the alleged hit. Further interviews with staff to whom the disclosure was made indicated that when C1 made this disclosure, C1 had no bruises or marks to indicate being hit. As a result of the information obtained, interviews conducted and documentation obtained, the allegation that C1 was hit by S1 is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The allegation that staff deny youth time away is related to staff not allowing youth to take space during the schooling hours at the facility. LPA Hill conducted confidential interviews with staff and youth present at the facility during schooling hours and it was revealed that the agency is temporarily providing educational services in the residential facility until their educational site, same as the administrative site, has completed their construction to allow youth to move back to this site for educational instruction. S1 and S2 indicated that on most days they are the primary staff responsible for educational services to youth in care as well as the supervision of youth during the schooling hours. Staff indicated that this facility is a tri-level facility and that having youth on different levels presents a challenge for supervision during the educational hours so they typically keep all youth in the lower level of the facility during schooling hours. Staff state they typically have five or six youth attending the educational services provided at this location with two to three staff present to supervise and assist. Staff interviews indicate they are responsible for supervision of youth during these hours, including maintaining visual of youth. While staff try to give youth options of taking space when feeling overwhelmed or agitated, it is restricted to direct line of sight of staff. Staff states that when the staffing allows for additional staffing at the facility during schooling hours they can accommodate walk-abouts or other services youth request. Confidential interviews with youth also indicated that they can walk outside if they want to take space or need a break as long as they remain in sight of staff supervising. As a result of the information obtained and interviews conducted, the allegation that staff deny youth time away is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Maglietta and documentation was provided.

During an interview conducted with C1, C1 alleges they, S1 and C1, were not within the camera's view at the facility so there would be no proof via camera footage.
