narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 3/7/25 at 11: AM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs, to discuss an incident report. LPA Hill conducted the inspection to discuss an incident report dated 1/30/25 regarding a medication error. During the inspection LPA Hill obtained documentation related to the medication error, including the Master Medication Schedule and Medication Administration Record (MAR) which identified that the pharmacy provided a different medication strength than what the child had been taking. While the MAR was correct, the previous MAR indicated a different instruction. It is not clear if the staff person(s) read the old MAR and administered the medications based on that instead of the new MAR. LPA Hill was informed that counseling and/or training was provided to the staff responsible for the medication error. Staff responsible for the counseling were not available to provide proof so LPA Hill requested that the documentation be provided when available. LPA Hill observed that the agency is preparing for an Open House to commemorate their move to their new administrative office and schooling program location. LPA Hill informed the agency that further investigation is needed regarding this incident. End of documentation regarding this incident.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 5/21/25 at 12: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs. LPA Hill conducted the inspection for the purposes of following up on a referral provided to Licensing involving C1 (see LIC811 dated 5/21/25). It was reported that C1 was provided a vaping device by S1 while C1 was in care and that S1 and S2 may have been providing devices to other youth in care for some time. Discussion with Ms. Randle and the Human Resources Generalist indicated that S1 admitted to agency staff that the allegation was valid but that S2 denied the allegation. S2 was terminated from employment on 5/20/25 and S1 resigned their employment from the agency on 5/20/25. As a result of the internal investigation conducted, C2, C3, C4 also alleged that S1 and S2 were providing contraband to youth in care. The agency was alerted by youth interviewed that S3, S4, and S5 either provided vaping devices to youth in care and/or had knowledge of this happening but this information could not be confirmed. LPA Hill conducted interviews with Human Resources Generalist, Ms. Randle, and S3 and obtained relevant hire documents for S1 and S2. LPA Hill advised that the agency was being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, section 87072(c)(1) Personal Rights as youth have a right to live in a safe environment. S1 and S2 provided vaping device(s) to youth in care that are working a program for mental health issues and/or substance abuse issues when they need to be free from undue stress related to these devices in the program. Exit interview was conducted with staff and documents were provided to Ms. Randle, along with appeal rights.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: While C1 left the facility on an unauthorized absence and upon apprehension by law enforcement, was taken for further assessment. Youth were told by staff that C1 would not be returning and to move on and not speak about the events. C1 returned to the facility prior to youth waking up in the morning and without warning to youth in care. Other youth in care reported that they did not feel safe with C1 returning to the facility due to the magnitude of the events that took place. Following such events happening in the facility, youth typically have access to an on-call therapist, via teleservices but youth in care expressed that there was a need to be able to process the events of the incident as a group but this was not offered or conducted. Confidential interviews indicated that youth did not feel that staff could keep them safe due to the seriousness of the incident with C1 returning to the facility without preparing youth in care and without providing youth the ability to process the incident in a trauma informed manner. Additional confidential interviews further indicated that the seriousness of this incident scared both, youth and staff, and brought about past traumatic experiences that youth would have benefitted from having a therapist present to assist in processing the events immediately following the incident. Confidential interviews indicated that youth and staff alike expressed that having a therapist come to the facility when an incident of this magnitude occurs would allow the youth to process as a group and assist youth in feeling safe, heard, and supported. It was further discussed that telling youth to stop talking about the event and not giving youth an avenue to discuss the events of the incidents in a safe and supportive space, is not trauma informed and does not allow youth to process their past traumatic experiences brought up by incidents of this nature. Confidential interviews further indicated that having the therapist available via a video chat is not the same as the in-person collaboration and youth tend to not engage in the video collaboration offered. As a result of the investigation conducted, including confidential interviews, the allegation that staff did not provide a safe environment for youth in care is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The facility was cited for violation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Programs, Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87078.2(a)(3) Trauma-Informed Interventions and Treatment Practices as staff are required to understand the types of trauma experienced by children..., how to provide care and supervision that is trauma informed..., and how to reduce risk of re-traumatization. The youth were not provided the trauma informed care necessary following a serious incident that would have allowed youth to process their trauma experiences and move forward in a trauma informed manner.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 7/3/25 at 1: PM and met with Anna Gleason, CEO, to discuss an incident report dated 6/28/25 involving C1, C2, and C3 (see LIC811 dated 7/3/25). LPA Hill conducted the inspection to discuss this incident report regarding inappropriate interactions between youth from 6/28/25. During the inspection LPA Hill discussed the documented lack of supervision including the ability for youth to be in other youths' rooms and/or be in their own rooms with other youth and staff not be in the vicinity to supervise as required and as detailed in the agency's Plan of Operation. As a result of this, the facility was cited for violation of Title Regulations Section 80065(a) Personnel Requirements as facility staff was not competent to provide the services necessary to meet the individual client needs and were not sufficient in number were not provided the supervision necessary to ensure youth needs are being met. This was observed by staff not being sufficient in number at the facility on 6/28/25 to provide the supervision necessary to prevent inappropriate interaction(s) between youth in care. End of documentation regarding this incident.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
met_with: Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an annual inspection on 7/23/25 at 1: PM and met with Haley Randle, Director of Youth Residential Programs, who assisted with the inspection. LPA Hill toured the facility and observed the following: Facility is a tri-level facility with client bedrooms on the top floor, kitchen, living room, and dining room on the middle floor and extra rooms used for relaxation and visitations with family. The middle floor is considered the main floor of the house and is the main entrance of the facility. The facility has an attached garage that is storage for freezer and another fridge, holiday decorations, art supplies, sports equipment and other supplies for the house including additional linens. The facility has a large property filled with numerous trees and bushes but no grass. The facility has three fire extinguishers that were last serviced on 1/20/25. There are three restrooms accessible to youth on the main floor and upstairs. The client bedrooms had required bedding, storage space, and closet space for youths' belongings. There are two dual occupancy client rooms and two single occupancy client rooms. The restrooms were stocked with paper towels, toilet paper, and had the covered trash can. The smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors in the facility were tested and functioning. There are carbon monoxide detectors on each floor of the facility. The kitchen is stocked with the appropriate perishable and non-perishable food as required with additional supplies in the garage. The sharps in the facility are locked and stored under the kitchen sink where youth do not have access. The agency was issued two Advisory Notes during the physical plant inspection. The Advisories were issued for the master bathroom sink was not clean and one of the beds in the mast bedroom did not have the fitted sheet as required. LPA Hill and Ms. Randle discussed a pending change of location for this facility to their current adult facility and the adult facility to be moved to this location. Ms. Randle states that this would be submitted to the Department by the end of the month of July 2025. No citations were issued at the time of the inspection and exit interview was conducted with Ms. Randle and documents were provided.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES - SUGAR PINE
narrative: On Thursday, August 21st, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass, arrived Unannounced at the Agency's Administrative Office to continue an annual inspection which began on 7/23/25. LPA met with Anna Gleason who assisted with the inspection. LPA reviewed 5 staff files. All five staff members are fingerprint cleared. LPA observed all staff have current and valid CPR certificates. LPA viewed one Facility Manager's Prudent Parent Standard training. LPA viewed staff Mandated Reporter training's. LPA discussed annual, 40 hour training requirements, and issued one Technical Advisory, which is not a citation, to clarify training requirements. LPA will need to return on another date to complete the inspection. Exit interview conducted with Anna Gleason. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given.

On 03/04/2022 at 9am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection. LPA met with Administrator, Daisy Delgado who granted tour and access to the facility. LPA Karnsrithong conducted the health and safety risk assessment upon arriving at the facility. There are currently no clients in the facility. There are no bodies of water in the premises. The facility is located in a residential neighborhood. The entire campus is fenced in and gated. The Administrative Office is located in the front part of the campus. Covid- Health and Safety checks are conducted in the front reception area. The facility is to provide care and supervision for male youth ages eleven (11) to seventeen (17) and non-minor dependents with a capacity up to sixteen (16) clients. LPA Karnsrithong has observed the following during the Pre-Licensing Inspection: The facility composes of three (3) cottages: Baldwin, Swartzott and Hutter. Baldwin Cottage: This cottage has four (4) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, a staff office, dining room, kitchen, laundry area, living room and laundry room. It has one (1) storage rooms to store supplies for the cottage. The utility shut-off valve for this cottage is at the back. There is a separate laundry room in this cottage equipped with storage cabinets and individual lockers. It has a working washer and dryer unit. Bedrooms: Each bedroom is equipped with a twin-size bed with linens, a cabinet with a locker, adequate lighting, a desk and a chair. There is a window with screens that is in good condition. One bedroom next to the Living Room is currently being used by the other STRTP for one (1) client. It has one bed with mattress and linens, a desk, a cabinet with a locker, and adequate lighting. (Page 1 of 3) Bathrooms: One full size bathroom is being used by staff. It has a toilet, sink, and shower all in good working condition. There is one bedroom that has a half bathroom with toilet and sink. All bathrooms are clean and water temperature are in safe range. There are cabinets to be used for storage in all bathrooms. Kitchen/Dining Area: The kitchen and dining area is next to the Living Room. It has a table and chairs to be used for meals and for studying. It has a full-size kitchen with a four (4) gas stove oven with a hood range, a microwave, dishwasher, and toaster. There is sufficient cabinet space for non-perishable food items and dry goods. There is a French door style refrigerator in the kitchen. There is fire extinguisher in the kitchen area. Living Room: The living room is next to the Kitchen/Dining Area. It is equipped with a television, a coffee table, couches, a media center with books and a video game console. Licensing postings and children's rights are posted in the Living Room area. There is fire extinguisher in the living room. Swartzott Cottage: This cottage has four (4) double bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, living room and kitchen. The utility shut-off valve for this cottage is at the back. There is no laundry room for this cottage. Bedrooms: All bedrooms are equipped with twin size mattress, with linens, two (2) cabinets and one (1) desk and a chair. There is a window with screens that is in good condition Bathrooms: There are two (2) full sized bathrooms in this cottage. It is equipped with toilet, sink, and shower all in good working condition. All water temperatures are in safe range. There are cabinets to be used for storage in all bathrooms. The showers in this cottage have shower doors instead of shower curtains. Kitchen: The kitchen is equipped with a four (4) burner gas stove, a microwave, French door style refrigerator, toilet, sink, and dishwasher. There is adequate cabinet space for kitchen items and food supplies. There is a working fire extinguisher in the kitchen area. All food preparation area is clean and well maintained. Living Room: The living room is next to the kitchen. It is equipped with a television cabinet, coffee table, media center, and couches. There is a fire extinguisher in the Living Room area. (Page 2 of 3) Hutter Cottage: This cottage has four (4) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, laundry room and living room. The utility shut-off valve for this cottage is out in the front. There is a laundry room in this cottage that has a separate door entrance outside. It has a working washer and dryer. Bedrooms: All bedrooms are equipped with twin size mattress, with linens, two (2) cabinets and one (1) desk and a chair. There is a window with screens that is in good condition. Bathrooms: There are two (2) full sized bathrooms in this cottage. It is equipped with toilet, sink, and shower all in good working condition. All water temperatures are in safe range. There are cabinets to be used for storage in all bathrooms. The showers in this cottage have shower doors instead of shower curtains. Kitchen: There is a fire extinguisher in the kitchen area to be used in case of emergencies. It is equipped with a gas stove, a microwave, French door style refrigerator, toilet, sink, and dishwasher. There is adequate cabinet space for kitchen items and food supplies. There is a working fire extinguisher in the kitchen area. There is trash can with a tight fitted lid in the kitchen. Living Room: The living room is next to the kitchen. It is equipped with a television cabinet, coffee table, media center, and couches. There is a fire extinguisher in the Living Room area. All clients have access to outdoor space. The campus has patio seating and tables throughout. It has a outdoor garden next to Hutter Cottage, a recreational hall, a basketball court, exercise equipment, swing set that is all securely bolted in to the ground. There is a pergola with patio furniture next to the other STRTP campus. The facility has an Emergency Disaster Plan in place. All staff are regularly trained for emergency safety quarterly. Each cottage has its own basic first aid supplies. Most medical and first aid supplies and equipment are stored in the nurse's office. The facility has its on-site nurse that provides basic medical care and administers medication for clients as needed. All medication is centrally stored in the nurses office. Medication logs for clients are stored in the nurse office and available for review and audit if needed. LPA Karnsrithong reviewed ten (10) staff files. All staff assigned to this facility have criminal background clearance. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Administrator, Daisy Delgado. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility. (Page 3 of 3)

met_with: Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Programs
narrative: On 12/29/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility at 11am for the purpose of case management verifying cottages being used by the Sycamores Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) South Campus. Health and safety risk assessment was conducted upon arriving at the facility. LPA Karnsrithong met with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Programs who granted tour and access to the facility. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision to up to sixteen (16) children ages six (6) to seventeen (17) ambulatory only and to Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). The current census for the facility during the visit is ten (10). The facility is composed of two (2) cottages that are being utilized by clients, Hutter and Swartzott. Hutter Cottage has four (4) bedrooms and two (2) bathrooms. Each bedroom has two (2) twin sized beds, closet space, a desk and adequate lighting. Each bathroom has its own toilet and shower. This cottage also has its own laundry room and a kitchen/dining and living room area. The current census for Hutter Cottage is five (5). Swartzott Cottage has four (4) bedrooms and two (2) bathrooms. Each bedroom has two (2) twin sized beds, closet space, a desk and adequate lighting. Each bathroom has its own toilet and shower. This cottage also has its own laundry room and a kitchen/dining and living room area. The current census for Swartzott Cottage is five (5) during the visit. Currently Family Cottages and Baldwin Cottage is being used for isolation for COVID-19. Baldwin Cottage is also being used for storage. The isolation areas are labeled "Red Zone" when it is in use. The facility has updated its program statement to reflect the changes regarding the facility's designated isolation area and storage.

met_with: Vice President of Sycamores - Gina Peck-Sobolewski
narrative: On March 28, 2023, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an unannounced visit to Sycamores STRTP South Campus, for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA met with the Vice President of Sycamores, Gina Peck-Sobolewski, who granted access to the facility and together a tour of the entire interior and exterior physical plant was conducted. The facility is a Short Term Therapeutic Residential program that provides care and supervision for up to sixteen (16) male youth ages 11 - 17 years old, and non-minor dependents, ambulatory only. The census at the time of this inspection was 9. The Facility is located in a residential neighborhood and is composed of three (3) cottages: Swartzott, Hutter, and Baldwin. Each cottage is set up as follows: Swartzott Cottage houses 8 clients and it is composed of the following: Living room, Kitchen, four (4) bedrooms, and two (2) bathrooms. The cottage census at the time of this inspection was four (4). Living room: is equipped with couches, a coffee table, a mounted enclosed television cabinet, a TV, and a regulation fire extinguisher. Kitchen: is equipped with refrigerator/freezer, a four (4) burner gas stove, a dishwasher, a microwave, a regulation fire extinguisher, and a trash can with a lid. LPA observed the cottage to use paper plates, cups, and plastic utensils. Food is prepared in the main dining area of the facility and brought over to the cottage. Bedrooms: each bedroom is equipped with two (2) twin beds, two (2) cabinets, working lights, and windows. LPA observed each bed to have clean linens and pillows. Bathrooms: one (1) bathroom is located at the end of the hallway near bedroom #1, and one (1) bathroom is located inside of bedroom #3. Each bathroom is equipped with a toilet, sink, and a shower all in working order. The water temperature was tested and found to be between 105 -120 degrees F. Hutter Cottage houses 8 clients and it is composed of the following: Living room, Kitchen, Laundry room, four (4) bedrooms, and two (2) bathrooms. The cottage census at the time of this inspection was five (5). Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 3). Living room: is equipped with couches, a coffee table, a mounted enclosed television cabinet, a TV, and a regulation fire extinguisher. Kitchen: is equipped with refrigerator/freezer, a five (5) burner gas stove, a dishwasher, a microwave, a regulation fire extinguisher, and a trash can with a lid. LPA observed the cottage to use paper plates, cups, and plastic utensils. Food is prepared in the main dining area of the facility and brought over to the cottage. Laundry room: is located adjacent to bedroom #4 and accessible from the outside. It is equipped with a washer and dryer. Bedrooms: each bedroom is equipped with two (2) twin beds, two (2) cabinets, working lights, and windows.LPA observed bed to have clean linens and pillows. Bathrooms: are side by side and are located along the hallway. Each bathroom is equipped with a toilet, sink, and a shower all in working order. The water temperature was tested and found to be between 105 -120 degrees F. Baldwin Cottage is used as the facility's isolation area and satisfies ILS regulation 87075(e): it is composed of a Dining room, Living room, Kitchen, Conference room/Staff office, Laundry room, four (4) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, and a Storage room. There were zero (0) clients in isolation at the time of this inspection. Dining room: is equipped with a table and chairs. Living room: is equipped with couches, a coffee table, a mounted enclosed television cabinet, a TV, video game console, and a regulation fire extinguisher. Kitchen: is equipped with refrigerator/freezer, a four (4) burner gas stove, a dishwasher, a microwave, a regulation fire extinguisher, and a trash can with a lid. Conference room/ Staff office: is located next to the laundry room and accessible from outside. The room is equipped with a table and multiple chairs. Laundry room: is located outside next to the conference room/staff office and it is equipped with a washer and dryer. Storage room: LPA observe this room to be empty. Bedrooms: each bedroom is equipped with two (2) twin beds, two (2) cabinets with built in lockers, working lights, and windows. Bathrooms: one (1) bathroom is located inside bedroom #2 and it is equipped with a toilet and sink; one (1) bathroom is located in the hallway next to bedroom #3 and it is equipped with a toilet, sink, and shower; one (1) bathroom is located next to the dining room, and it is equipped with a toilet, sink, and shower. All bathrooms were observed to be in working order. The water temperature was tested and found to be between 105 -120 degrees F. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 2 of 3). Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kits checked and found to be complete. LPA observed the cottages to have cameras in the common areas and on the outside perimeter of the buildings. The cameras are monitored by the administrative staff and the IT Department. There is a camera waiver on file. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are stored in the maintenance room and made inaccessible to clients. All medication is centrally stored in the nurse's office and the facility has an on-site nurse that provides medical care and to administer medication. Medication logs for clients are stored in the nurse office and available for review and audit as needed. Overall LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Clients have access to the following outdoor space: an outdoor garden next to Hutter Cottage, basketball court, recreational hall, swing set, and exercise equipment. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. The facility has an Emergency Disaster Plan in place. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Emergency Plan, Personal Rights, and menus were posted in each of the cottages. Transportation: The facility has a total of 7 vehicles to transport clients. LPA inspected 3 out of 7 vehicles and found seat belts and horn in working order, travel first aid kits, and current registration and insurance. Vehicles are insured by Nonprofit Insurance Alliance of CA and expire 11/1/2023. There are no deficiencies observed or cited at this during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with the Vice President, and this report was left at the facility. (Page 3 of 3).

narrative: On October 27, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Sycamores STRTP South Campus, for the purpose of conducting a Plan of Correction (POC) inspection in order to clear the deficiencies cited during the Annual/Required visit, conducted on 09/28/2023. LPA met with Administrator, Daisy Delgado who granted access to the facility. The deficiencies previously cited were: Type B - There were no pillows in any of the bedrooms. Section. 87088(c)(1). Type B - There were no linen in any of the rooms. There were no bath towels, hand towels, or wash cloths in any of the cottages. Section 87088(c)(2). Type B - There were no personal hygiene products in either of the cottages. Section. 87088(c)(3). Type B - The Living room, Bedroom #1, and Bedroom #4 in Hutter's cottage is being used for storage. Section. 87087.3(a). During this inspection, LPA was provided a tour of Swartzott Cottage and Hutter Cottage. LPA observed all bedrooms in each cottage to have pillows and new linen. Each cottage was equipped with a supply of personal hygiene products, bath towels, wash clothes, and hand towels. Additionally, all storage items had been removed from the living room, Bedroom #1 and Bedroom #4 in Hutter's Cottage. All deficiencies were cleared at the time of this inspection. LPA printed out the Deficiency Clearance Letter and provided it to the Administrator. There are no deficiencies cited California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.
Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was emailed to Trina Sanford for signature. Original signature on file.

LPA contacted Trina Sanford to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. LPA Carol Anderson conducted a tele-inspection on October 12, 2020 at 11:10 am. Three of four children, five staff and county social worker were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff #1 (S1) hit client #1 (C1) causing a mark/bruise. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 had self-injurious behaviors and aggressive behaviors. C1 would start destroying the facility property and there was a possibility that C1's mark/bruise on C1's shin could have been a result of C1's self injurious behaviors. LPA was not provided any other specific details or decisive information regarding the alleged allegation that would confirm whether or not the allegation occurred. Based on interviews and record reviews the allegation that S1 hit C1 causing a mark/bruise, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. narrative: On October 21, 2020 at 10:30am, a virtual office conference was held with The Refuge. Due to COVID-19 this office conference was conducted utilizing a conference call. The following individuals were in attendance: Licensing Program Managers (LPM) Christina Barnes and Cynthia Gray, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes, Licensee Grace Williams, and The Refuge's therapist, Alyssa de la Torre. The following concerns were discussed during the meeting: 1. Loss of the Administrator and additional experienced staff. CCL expressed concern with the facility loosing staff members who had experience in licensed facilities. Licensee expressed this was a concern for the facility as well. However, Licensee stated the ratios have been maintained and a facility manager is always on site. Licensee expressed due to the loss of experienced staff members, the facility has decided to maintain a census of two for the time being. The lower census will remain in place until the facility retrains staff, fortifies the rules and develops a clear system for the staff members and the facility. Licensee stated until the additional training and new systems are in place the facility will always have two staff members on each shift and will have frequent staff meetings to discuss new procedures and debrief incidents. In addition all parties discussed the qualifications and role of an Administrator during this meeting. 2. Serious Incident Report (SIR) LPA Zirbes expressed there have been concerns regarding recent incident reports submitted by the facility. The concerns involved how the staff react to situations and potential violations of the residents personal rights. Licensee expressed the facility has reviewed and evaluated the SIR's. Per the facility's review, trends were observed and the facility is starting to implement new systems. Licensee expressed all staff are trained in CPI techniques. Report continued on page two Report continued from page one Licensee stated some of the staff are receiving a refresher CPI training in the upcoming weeks. LPA Zirbes suggested the facility utilize real life scenarios that have occurred at the facility. LPA reminded the facility to ensure they are debriefing each scenario with the staff members and the residents. LPM Barnes reminded the facility that staff members should be proactive instead of reactive to situations. LPA Zirbes expressed the incident reports should be detailed, tell a story and indicate all the staff and residents involved in the situation. 3. Personal Rights violations LPA Zirbes specifically talked about the incidents involving the staff threatening to call law enforcement, searching residents rooms without permission, and cell phones. LPA Zirbes expressed the facility must abide by the residents personal rights. LPM Barnes suggested the facility maintain communication with the authorized representatives when issues arise and reach out to outside resources for support. LPM Barnes expressed herself and LPA Zirbes, are available for consultation however the Refuge is responsible for the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). In closing, LPA Zirbes and Barnes expressed the facility is on a provisional license and advised them to reach out to Community Care Licensing (CCL) for consultation at any time. When this report was reviewed with the Licensee, LPA Zirbes suggested the facility review SIR requirements within the STRTP regulations and have the staff retrained on Personal Rights. A copy of this report was emailed and provided to Licensee Grace Williams.

On November 4, 2020 at 10:30am, a virtual office conference was held with The Refuge. Due to COVID-19 this office conference was conducted utilizing Microsoft Teams. The following individuals were in attendance: Licensing Program Managers (LPM) Christina Barnes and Cynthia Gray, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes, Licensee Grace Williams, and The Refuge's facility manager Rachel Beck. The following concerns were discussed during the meeting: 1. Neighborhood Complaints. Facility Manager and Licensee acknowledged the recent concerns of the neighborhood. Per Facility Manager the facility has responded to the neighborhood concerns by composing a letter which addresses who the facility is and what services the facility is providing to youth. The letter will also address what the neighbors should do if concerns are observed. Facility Manager expressed the letter will be provided to each of the neighbors. Community Care Licensing (CCL) encourage the facility to continue to find ways to engage with the community and suggested the letter include contact information for the facility. 2. Incident Reporting CCL provided clarification that the incidents must report the full names of all the youth involved in the incident. Furthermore, LPA expressed the facility must report all Law Enforcement contact, and suggested the facility utilized the LIC 624-LE, and refer to the Provider Information Notice regarding Law Enforcement contact. LPA reminded the facility, that the facility is responsible for meeting the reporting requirements according to the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). During the phone call, CCL and the facility discussed recent incidents which have occurred at the facility. CCL and the facility collaborated on the incidents and provided guidance. LPA reminded the facility to follow the approved Plan of Operation and Program Statement. LPM Barnes expressed the facility is responsible for the well-being of the youth in care. Report continued on page two Report continued from page one 3. Facility Administrator CCL expressed the recent incidents may be attributed to the facilities lack of a current Administrator. LPA expressed the facility must have an approved Administrator within 10 days. Licensee stated CCL will be provided with an updated resume for the purposed Administrator within the next two days. In closing, LPM Barnes expressed the importance of maintaining compliance with the Program Statement and Plan of Operation while on a provisional license. LPM Barnes reminded the facility that CCL is available for consultation to navigate through the licensing process. A copy of this report was reviewed, emailed and provided to Licensee Grace Williams. A copy of the signed report is located in the facility file.

An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes on November 17, 2020 at 04:00pm. Due to Covid 19, a tele-inspection was conducted. During the inspection, LPA met with Licensee Grace Williams via Google Duo. A facility safety inspection was conducted at 04:35pm on November 17, 2020. There were no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The purpose of the case management inspection was to issue a citation regarding the facility administrator position. On October 3, LPA was advised that the administrator for the facility resigned. On October 21, 2020, and November 4, 2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) held virtual office conferences with the facility. During the conference the Department discussed the need to fulfill the administrator position. As of this date, November 17, 2020 the facility does not have a qualified and currently certified Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) administrator. The facility currently has two youth in placement. Based on confidential interviews and record review the facility failed to ensure a qualified and currently certified administrator was employed by the facility. This poses an immediate risk to the youth in care. The facility was cited for a violation of the STRTP, Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3.1 regulation 87064 (b): Administrator Qualifications and Duties. A copy of this report was reviewed with the Licensee. The report and the appeal rights were emailed to licensee Grace Williams. A signed copy of the report in within the facility file.

This instance also occurred when the staff and minors were on outings and minors wanted to use unsupervised time. Per the facility emergency intervention plan, when minor's runaway or walk away from staff supervision, staff are to follow the minors and try to encourage the minors to return to the supervised area. A CSW expressed concern that the facility was not enforcing the program rules and continued to allow M1 and M2 to go on unsupervised community walks even though they had not earned the privilege to do so. LPA's review of the facility records documented M1 and M2 were on neighborhood walks at the same time. Record review also confirmed that even though M1 and M2 were not following the program rules and continuing to AWOL, M1 and M2 were still allowed unsupervised time for neighborhood walks. Furthermore, LPA's record review provided evidence that the staff failed to follow the approved emergency intervention plan while at the facility and on facility outings. Based on confidential interviews and record review, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the facility staff are not properly supervising minors (M1, M2) resulting in minors (M1, M2) wandering the neighborhood. The Facility is cited under the Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3, regulation 87022 (f) Plan of Operation. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator Amaneece Harrison. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file. CSW's confirmed M1 and M2 had a history of AWOLing. LPA's review of the facility records, and pictures provided by confidential sources, revealed evidence that M1 and M2 left the facility. However, the evidence provided did not demonstrate there was a lack of supervision at the facility. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that there was a lack of supervision resulting in minors (M1, M2) AWOL'ing may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator Amaneece Harrison. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On February 4, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Administrator Amaneece Harrison via Google-Duo to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. Due to COVID 19 a tele inspection was conducted. During the investigation, LPA interviewed two of two minors (M1 and M2), two of two County Social Workers (CSW), and four staff members. Furthermore, LPA completed a review of the facility records, and conducted a facility tele-inspection on November 16, 2020 at 03:00pm. On November 13, 2020, the Department received an allegation that on multiple occasions prior to November 13, 2020, M1 and M2 were observed walking unsupervised around the neighborhood during day and evening hours. All interviews confirmed M1 and M2 were allowed unsupervised individual neighborhood walks. The timeframe for the walks varied from 20 minutes to one hour at a time. Statements made by confidential witnesses and staff, confirmed M1 and M2 went on unsupervised neighborhood walks together instead of individually. Staff interviews reported that when M1 and M2 left the facility for their neighborhood walks together, staff did not follow them or discontinue the unsupervised time for not following the rules. Report continued on page two SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

met_with: Licensee Grace Williams and Facility Manager Teri Smallwood
narrative: An unannounced Post-Licensing Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes February 18, 2021 at 11:10am. During the inspection, LPA met with Licensee Grace Williams and Facility Manager Teri Smallwood. LPA and Licensee inspected the facility inside and out. The facility was licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on June 10, 2020. The facility is a two-story building with three bedrooms, three and a half bathrooms, a school room, staff office, kitchen, dining area, and prayer/meditation/quiet room located on the upper floor. The lower floor includes a therapy office, laundry room, and a two-car garage that is used as a recreational room. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/video games/books/games were observed for youth's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. The facility was advised to post the Foster Care Ombudsman poster and visitation rules. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked closest in the locked staff office. Five individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. At 2:45pm, LPA observed hot water temperature in the bathroom registered 109.7 degrees F. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The facility does not have cameras. The facility has a hot tub which was equipped with a cover that is locked on each corner. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility and smoking is prohibited. Personnel Files and youth files were maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in the locked staff office. LPA reviewed five staff files and three youth files. All staff have caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index clearance. Staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection and they were in accordance with the regulations. An exit interview was conducted with Facility Manager Teri Smallwood. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

All interviewees denied Y2 or another youth in care has received a concussion. Staff reported that when the verbal altercation started between Y1 and Y2, staff utilized various de-escalation techniques. Staff reported the incident occurred very quickly. According to staff interviews, as Y1 was leaving the area, Y1 picked up the drying rack and threw the drying rack at Y2. Staff reported that S1 was able to deflect the drying rack however the object hit Y2. All staff interviews denied any of the youth in care received a concussion. One CSW reported they had no concerns regarding the physical altercation while another CSW reported they were unaware of the physical altercation. LPA's record review documented this was the only physical altercation at the facility. Based on confidential interviews the allegation that staff (S1, S2) failed to protect youth (Y2) from being harmed by other resident (Y1) may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator Amaneece Harrison. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

Furthermore, LPA completed a review of the facility records. LPA Zirbes completed a virtual safety inspection of the STRTP on March 9, 2021 at 10:15am, there were no deficiencies noted. On March 1, 2021, the Department received an allegation that on an unknown date, youth 1 (Y1) gave two unknown youth concussions. Confidential interviews reported there was one physical altercation that occurred at the facility. According to the confidential interviews, youth 2 (Y2), youth 3 (Y3), Y1, staff 1 (S1) and staff 2 (S2) were present during the altercation. Confidential interviews reported Y1 threw a drying rack at Y2, which hit Y2 on the side of the head. Confidential interviews reported the staff utilized de-escalation techniques and could not have prevented the altercation. Other confidential interviews reported that if the staff had intervened sooner, Y1 may have been prevented from throwing the drying rack. narrative: An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kendal Zirbes and Danielle Garcia on June 7, 2021 at 11:00am. During the inspection, LPA's met with facility manager Nika Nettles. LPA's inspected the facility inside and out. The facility was licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on June 10, 2020. The facility is a two-story building with three bedrooms, three and a half bathrooms, a school room, staff office, kitchen, dining area, and prayer/meditation/quiet room located on the upper floor. The lower floor includes a therapy office, laundry room, and a two-car garage that is used as a recreational room. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds were clean and free of debris. LPA's observed one hole in the wooden patio that was twelve inches long and three inches wide. In addition, LPA's observed three additional wooden planks which had exposed nails and felt unstable when walked upon. The facility has a hot tub which was equipped with a cover that is locked on each corner. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Video games/books/games were observed for youth's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked closest in the locked staff office. Six individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. At 4:30pm, LPA observed hot water temperature in the bathroom registered 107 degrees F. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The facility does not have cameras. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility and smoking is prohibited. Personnel Files and youth files were maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in the locked staff office. LPA reviewed six staff files and three youth files. All staff have caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index clearance. LPA's observed that the staff training did meet the staff training matrix per the plan of operation. Report continued on page two This is an amended document When LPAs arrived to the facility, the staff training records were not in the staff files. LPA's were advised that the training records were located on the Extended Reach System. LPA advised the facility that the training records must be available to the Department. Per the Facility Manager the training records will be added to the staff files or LPA's will be granted access to the Extended Reach system. Staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection and they were in accordance with the regulations. Based on LPA's observation the facility failed to ensure a safe outdoor area and failed to follow the approved program statement/ plan of operation. This poses potential risk to the youth in care. The facility was cited for a violation of STRTP interim licensing standard version 3.1 regulation 87087.2 (a) and 87022 (f). An exit interview was conducted with Facility Manager Rachel Beck and the Administrator. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

Based on record review, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the facility is not operating within their plan of operation. The facility is cited under the Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3, regulation 87022 (f) Plan of Operation. On June 7, 2021, the facility was cited under 87022 (f) Plan of Operation therefore, civil penalties will be assessed. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the facility manager.
investigation_findings: 13On June 29, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Facility Manager Rachel Beck to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed the one direct care staff, one facility manager and the administrator. In addition, LPA completed a review of the facility records. On June 16, 2021 at 04:15pm a safety inspection was conducted by LPA Zirbes, no deficiencies were observed. On June 10, 2021 the Department received information that on May 28, 2021 the facility conducted an intake interview with Youth 1 (Y1). On June 8, 2021, the authorized representative was notified that Y1 would not be accepted into the program. LPA review the facilities approved Plan of Operation which stated: "After the intake interview, our agency will communicate acceptance or rejection of the referral within five business days...". Information received from staff members confirmed the facility failed communicate acceptance or rejection within time allotted by the program statement. Therefore, the facility notified the authorized representative seven days after the intake interview instead of five days as required in the approved in the program statement. narrative: Staff reported CSW could not provide transportation therefore, Y1's appointment was missed. CSW reported the facility did not tell the County about the appointment until the day of the appointment, April 20, 2021. CSW further stated that during the Child and Family Team Meeting on April 19, 2021, the facility did not mention Y1's appointment. CSW reported that if the facility had provided the County with more time, transportation could have been arranged. LPAs review of the program statement found the facility was following the transportation policy. However, the facility failed to inform the CSW about the appointment in a timely manner therefore Y1 did not have access to the medical appointment. Based on confidential interviews, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove staff (names unknown) did not provide resident (Y1) access to medical services. The facility is cited under the Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3, regulation 87072 (17) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the facility manager.
investigation_findings: 13On June 29, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Facility Manager Grace Williams to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed two youth, the Administrator, a facility manager, three direct staff care staff members, and one County Social Worker (CSW). In addition, LPA completed a review of the facility records. On May 13, 2021 a safety inspection was conducted by LPA Zirbes, no deficiencies were observed. On May 7, 2021, the Department received information that unknown staff members, failed to provide youth 1 (Y1) with access to a medical appointment. Confidential interviews reported Y1 had a medical appointment scheduled for April 20, 2021. Confidential interviews reported the appointment was missed due to a lack of transportation. Additional confidential interviews reported there were no problems with transportation to medical appointments. Staff reported that on April 10, 2021, Y1 made an appointment without the consent of the facility. Staff further reported that Y1 was informed, that the facility could not provide transportation to the appointment as indicated by the program statement. Staff members reported that on April 19, 2021, Y1's CSW was informed that transportation was needed for the appointment on April 20, 2021. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

met_with: Grace Williams, Licensee and Amaneece Harrison, Administrator
narrative: On October 8, 2021, at 2: PM, an office tele-conference was held with representatives from The Refuge Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) via Microsoft Teams video platform. In attendance were: STRTP representatives Licensee Grace Williams, Administrator Amaneece Harrison. Also in attendance were: Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Christina Barnes, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela, from the Department of Health Care Services (DCHS) David Gutierrez and Alexandria Valencia, from Harm Reduction unit Kelly Hartman, from System of Care (SOC) Marjana Jackson. The following was discussed with the facility: · Mental Health contract and Medi-Cal certification for the STRTP. · Compliance with HSC 1520.1(a)(2)(C). · HSC 1520.1(a)(2)(C) states: "... The short-term residential therapeutic program requires additional time to complete the mental health program approval as set forth in Section 1562.01. The department may require ongoing documentation to ensure progress toward mental health program approval. The department may also require ongoing documentation that the provider is ensuring access to specialty mental health services during provisional licensure." · Although it is preferred to have a mental health contract in the same county where the facility is located, The Refuge can obtain a mental health contract from any county and is not limited to San Diego County. · Complaint investigation. · Harm Reduction referral. During the meeting, Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook asked about the facility's status in obtaining a county mental health contract. Licensee Grace Williams stated the facility attempted to obtain a mental health contract with San Diego county but was told mental health contracts are only offered to STRTP's who have a contract with County Welfare System (CWS) of San Diego County. Currently, per Ms. Wlliams the facility does not have a CWS contract with San Diego county. (continued on 809-c) Ms. Williams added that the facility will continue to purse a mental health contract with San Diego county. Ms. Williams stated the facility also contacted Riverside county and will continue to pursue obtaining a contract from Riverside county. Ms. Williams stated she will be contacting other counties regarding obtaining a mental health contract, including: Fresno, San Luis Obispo and Los Angeles. RM inquired about a timeframe in which Ms. Williams will reach out the counties. Ms. Williams stated she would reach out to the counties by the end of the week. Ms. Williams stated she will provide updates to LPA Valenzuela regarding their mental health contract status. During the meeting, David Gutierrez and Alexandria Valencia from DCHS informed the facility about Specialty Mental Health Services which are to provide to children in care. DCHS representatives provided the facility with a website link to DCHS STRTP Regulations(https://www.dhcs.ca.gov/Documents/STRTP-Regulations-version-II.pdf) and an email address for the facility to send any questions they may have about the Mental Health Approval Process. During this meeting, Kelly Hartman from Harm Reduction advised the facility of the support, resources and training available to the help the facility meet the needs of the population they serve. Ms. Hartman provided the facility with an email address for the facility to contact Harm Reduction for consultation. In addition, System of Care (SOC) Marjana Jackson provided and email address for the facility to contact SOC to help in obtaining the contacts needed for their mental health contract and program. During the meeting, LPA Valenzuela provided information regarding substantiated complaint investigations involving the facility not following their Plan of Operation and lack of supervision. RM Cook inquired about the steps the facility has taken to ensure the facility is following their Plan of Operation. Ms. Williams stated the facility provided staff training on the intake and admission process and has recently trained her staff on how to recognize suicidal ideations, eating disorders and supervision. RM Cook inquired about newly hired staff, Ms. Williams stated there was an additional five staff recently hired. RM Cook asked if they are meeting client to staff ratios, Ms. Williams stated yes. At the conclusion of the conference, RM Cook thanked the facility representatives. LPM Barnes reminded the facility that a provisional license was issued through 12/08/2021, and the in order to continue to be licensed the facility must demonstrate progress being made toward obtaining a mental health contract and mental health program approval. A copy of this report was emailed to Licensee Grace Williams for signature. Original signed report in facility file.

On March 24, 2022 an informal conference was held with The Refuge Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to discuss current Mental Health Program Approval status and permanent licensure. Present at the meeting were: LaCresha Cook, Regional Manager (RM), Christina Barnes, Licensing Program Manager, Cheraki Davis, Licensing Program Manager, Lorena Valenzuela, Licensing Program Analyst, Grace Williams, Licensee, Cesar Argueta, Facility Administrator, Heather Flores, Consultant, and Marjana Jackson, System of Care Branch. The following information was discussed: · Mental Health Program Approval status · Mental health contract · Application withdraw · Facility closure plan During the meeting, RM Cook stated the meeting was to follow up on the facility status in obtaining a mental health contract. RM Cook stated that the STRTP provisional License expiration date is June 10, 2022. Licensee Grace Williams stated they have not had a county say yes to wanting to establish a mental health contract with the facility, and that Orange county has shown interest. Facility consultant Heather Flores stated she has contacted several counties regarding getting a mental health contract and most have said no but Ms. Flores is waiting to hear back from Imperial county. (continued on page 2) RM Cook inquired about the facility's plan in the case the facility is not able to ensure they have a mental health contract with a county prior to the license expiration date. RM Cook inquired as to whether the facility has a plan to operate a different facility type or withdraw their application. RM Cook stated that in addition to obtaining the mental health county contract, the facility would also have to get Medi-Cal certification, which is part of the Mental Health Program Approval process. RM Cook stated the process can take several months to complete. RM Cook stated that if the facility is not able to get a Mental Health Program approval, and the application is denied, the facility cannot re-apply to be licensed as an STRTP for 2 years. Ms. Williams asked RM Cook to explain further regarding not being able to reapply for 2 years. Ms. Williams stated she had received information that stated she could re-apply right away. RM Cook stated that if the facility withdrew their application for licensure the facility could apply at any time. RM Cook stated that if the Department denied the application, then the facility could not apply for 2 years. RM Cook inquired about what the facility would choose to do in case the facility was not able to meet the licensing requirements which includes having a mental health contract. Ms. Williams states the facility would choose to withdraw the application. Ms. Williams added that she understood that that meant the facility would have to close. RM Cook clarified that per statute, the maximum time a facility has to obtain a Mental Health program approval is 24 months, and that there are no extensions. Marjana Jackson from System of Care inquired about the facility's census and whether the facility has a closure plan. Ms. Williams stated the facility did not have a closure plan at this time. RM Cook stated LPA Lorena Valenzuela would be providing the licensee with information about a closure plan. A copy of this report was emailed to Grace Williams for original signature. A copy of Children's Residential Program, Provider Information Notice (PIN)-18-03, "Closure Plan for Community Care Licensing" was emailed to Grace Williams.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Strickland arrived unannounced to the facility. While at the facility LPA gathered documents from staff records, staff schedule, and facility records. LPA set a meeting with licensee Grace Williams for Monday August 8, 2022 at 12:00pm.

On August 8, 2022 at 4:00 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with The Refuge, Executive Director, Grace Williams to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL) the facility hired Staff #1 (S1) on March 2, 2022 to fulfill the role of Administrator. Record review revealed S1 worked on site at the facility on both 3/4/2022 and 3/9/2022 prior to S1 being associated to the facility on 3/16/2022. This is a violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) regulation 80019(e)(2). The facility is being cited for violation California Code of Regulations (CCR) regulation 80019(e)(2) CRIMINAL RECORD CLEARANCE (e)(2) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing, or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Request a transfer of a criminal record clearance as specified in section 80019(f). The facility will be assessed an immediate civil penalty per CCR regulation 80019(g) CRIMINAL RECORD CLEARANCE (g) an immediate assessment of civil penalties for violations of CCR Section 80019(e). A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with Civil penalty assessment and appeal rights to The Refuge, Executive Director, Grace Williams.

On August 8, 2022 at 3:32pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with The Refuge, Executive Director, Grace Williams to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL) the facility has been operating without a qualified and currently certified administrator. This is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87064(b). The facilities operation without an approved qualified and currently certified administrator as described in the facility's Plan of Operation approved by Community Care Licensing (CCL) is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87022(f). The facility is being cited for violation of ILS 87064(b) ADMINISTRATOR QUALIFICATIONS AND DUTIES (b) All short-term residential therapeutic programs shall have a qualified and currently certified administrator, and ILS 87022(f) PLAN OF OPERATION (f) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation and may be cited for not doing so. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to The Refuge, Executive Director, Grace Williams.

On August 18, 2022, at 1:38pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Michelle Hazelwood, House Manager of The Refuge to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL) the facility has been operating without a qualified and currently certified administrator and was cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87064(b) on August 8, 2022. On this date, the facility remains out of compliance with ILS 87064(b) and is being cited for violation of ILS 87064(b) ADMINISTRATOR QUALIFICATIONS AND DUTIES (b) All short-term residential therapeutic programs shall have a qualified and currently certified administrator. This is a repeat violation and the facility is being issued a civil penalty for the repeat violation. A review of the facilities board meeting minutes dated 3/26/2022, 4/8/2022, 5/23/2022, and 7/23/2022 revealed no documentation of review and discussion of incidents occurring at the facility involving contact with law enforcement. This is a violation of ILS standard 87063(8)(A) ACCOUNTABILITY (A)Review and discussion of short-term residential therapeutic program's operation shall include the incidents concerning a child in the facility involving contact with law enforcement that were reported to the department as specified in Section 87061(k). The review of board meeting minutes dated 3/26/2022, 4/8/2022, 5/23/2022, and 7/23/2022 revealed two additional violations regarding accountability. These violations include the boards accountability in ensuring that the facility employs an administrator who meets the requirements of ILS section 87063. Documentation obtained by CCL revealed that the facility has been operating without an approved Administrator. The board meeting minutes provided no evidence regarding this violation and did not include how the facility planned to come into compliance with the regulation. This is a violation of ILS 87063(5) ACCOUNTABILITY (5) Employ an administrator who meets the requirements of Section 87064, and 87063(a)(11) ACCOUNTABILITY (11) Ensure that oversight of program operations and internal controls are adequate and effective for the management of short-term residential therapeutic program and provide reasonable assurance of ****** compliance with applicable laws and regulations. Additional information obtained by CCL revealed a violation of 87061(i)(9) REPORTING REQUIREMENTS (i) Incident reports must include the following: (9) The licensee shall not interfere with the Department's investigation of an incident reporting requirements or any duties imposed pursuant to any provision of federal or state law or regulation. Record review occurring on August 16, 2022 revealed the facility conducted its own investigation into a complaint received by CCL. The facilities investigation included having staff go to a gas station to observe video footage and obtain photographs and gather written declarations from staff not present during the incident, these actions went beyond what was necessary to report the incident to the appropriate authorities. Staff records for Staff #1 (S1) provided by the facility to CCL revealed S1 was hired January 24, 2022 as a childcare worker. Record review of the LIC 500 dated August 4, 2022 submitted to CCL revealed S1 is listed as the Facility Manager. S1 fulfilling the role of facility manager which is not included in S1s job description is a violation of ILS 87065(k) PERSONNEL REQUIREMENTS (k)The staff assignment information specified in Section 87066(b)(2) shall be provided to all applicants during interviews for employment; to all staff during orientation or when changes are made which affect job assignments; and upon request to placement agencies. Also revealed during the record review was S1 does not have a current negative TB test on file, this is a violation of California Code of Regulation (CCR) regulation 80066(a)(11) PERSONNEL RECORDS (a)The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator, and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (11)Tuberculosis test documents as specified in Section 80065(g). A review of Staff #2 (S2)s staff record revealed no health screening for S2 and no Tuberculosis test for S2. These are violations of CCR regulation 80066(a)(10) PERSONNEL RECORDS (a)The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator, and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (10) A health screening as specified in Section 80065(g) and CCR regulation 80066(a)(11) PERSONNEL RECORDS (11) Tuberculosis test documents as specified in Section 80065(g). ****** A review of Staff #3 (S3)s staff record revealed a copy of S3's state identification card and number are in staff's record however, no evidence of a driver's license which is required for staff who transport residents. On August 5, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Strickland arrived to the facility as S3 was preparing to transport two residents to therapy. Due to LPA's arrival S3 did not transport the residents on this date. S3's staff record not containing S3's driver's license information is a violation of CCR 80066 (a)(2) PERSONNEL RECORDS (a) The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator, and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (2)Driver's license number if the employee is to transport clients. A copy of S3's job description was not observed to be in S3's record. This is a violation of CCR regulation 80066(a)(8) PERSONNEL RECORDS (a) The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator, and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information (8) Duties of the employee. On August 5, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Strickland arrived to the facility and was greeted by Staff #1 (S1) and Staff #3 (S3). Upon entry to the facility LPA asked to speak to the Administrator and was informed that there was no administrator on site. LPA then asked to speak to Executive Director (ExDir) and was told by S1, ExDir was on maternity leave. S1 and S3 stated House Manager (Staff #4 [S4]) was not present. S3 stated she would call S4 to inform S4 of LPA's presence at the facility. S3 stated that S4 did not answer the phone so S3 was going to text S4. After texting S4, S3 made another attempt to contact S4 which was successful. S3 was informed that Staff #5 (S5) was on his way to the facility and would be able to assist LPA. A review of S1 and S3's personnel record provided no evidence of S1 or S3 being designated to fulfil the role of House Manager when House manager is not present. Therefore the facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87065(f) PERSONNEL REQUIREMENTS (f) the licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when one or more children are present: A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with civil penalty assessment LIC 421 and appeal rights to The Refuge House Manager Michelle Hazelwood.

evidence. Confidential interviews denied allegations of a lack of supervision as well as staff not preventing child from self-harm. According to confidential interviews, Child # 1 (C1) and Child # 2 (C2) got into a verbal argument in which staff immediately intervened to de-escalate the situation and separated the clients, one in each bedroom. According to confidential interviews, despite staff intervention, C2 pushed thru staff and barged into C1's bedroom hitting C1 in the head with a closed fist. According to confidential interviews, staff stood in between C2 and C1, receiving the brunt of C2's blows. According to confidential information, there was proper supervision and adequate staff during all stages of this incident. Confidential interviews also denied that staff failed to prevent C1 from self-harming. According to confidential interviews, C1 became upset after hearing disappointing news and locked themselves in the bathroom while making suicidal threats. According to confidential information, staff was counseling C1 during the incident and subsequently contacted authorities to have C1 evaluated. According to confidential information, C1 had not engaged in self-harm during this incident, and only made verbal threats of self-harm. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations of a lack of supervision and self-harm had occurred, and that there was an inadequate response by staff during these incidents. Based on confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegations a lack of supervision resulting in Child # 2 (C2) causing harm to Child # 1 (C1) , as well as staff not preventing C1 from causing self-harm while in care, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.

narrative: On October 26, 2022, at 12:35 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with The Refuge, Children of the Immaculate Heart Administrator Peter Airewele and Executive Director Grace Williams to deliver a case management deficiencies report. The facility was initially issued a citation for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87064(b) ADMINISTRATOR QUALIFICATIONS AND DUTIES on August 8, 2022. The facility created a plan of correction which included Executive Director hiring a temporary administrator who meets the qualifications to fulfil the role until newly hired staff (Staff #1 [S1]) could. On August 18, 2022, the facility was issued a repeat citation for ILS standard 87064(b) which included an immediate civil penalty. On August 19, 2022 the facility sent LPA Strickland an email noting the plan of correction created and submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) was the facilities hiring of S1 to fulfill the role. On August 30, 2022, the facility was provided notification that S1 did not meet the qualifications for administrator based upon the information submitted to CCL on August 19, 2022. On September 23, CCL received an revised version of S1's resume for use in consideration of S1 meeting the qualifications as outlined in ILS 87064(b). The period between the repeat citation being issued, August 18, 2022 and the submittal of the revised resume September 23, 2022 the facility continued to operate without an approved certified administrator as required by ILS 87064(b). Therefore a civil penalty of $100 per day is being assessed for the period August 19, 2022 through September 23, 2022, as required by Health and Safety Code (HSC) 1548(b)(1). A copy of this report, LIC 421 with civil penalty assessment, and appeal rights were discussed with and provided to The Refuge, Children of the Immaculate Heart Administrator Peter Airewele and Executive Director Grace Williams Due to technical issues LPA was unable to obtain electronic signatures. Signed reports and paper copy of LIC 421 was signed and will be placed in facility file.

narrative: Confidential interviews stated that garage would sometimes become too hot despite ventilation and portable Air Conditioning unit. Based on interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that Facility Staff are not providing a comfortable environment for youths, more specifically that staff make youths do their school work in facility garage where it is sometimes too hot is substantiated. This posed a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to the children placed in care. The facility is being cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation 84072(d) Personal Rights. See attached LIC 9099D for cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided. although staff cannot physically prevent clients from leaving facility, staff always counsel and try and dissuade clients from AWOLing, as well as follow them as much as possible and explain to them the consequences and dangers of their actions. Confidential interviews also stated that staff do as much as possible to prohibit illicit substances from being brought into facility. According to confidential information obtained, staff will always search and go thru client's clothing and belongings to look from prohibited contraband, as well as use a metal detector wand whenever clients return home to the facility. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that staff was not doing enough to reduce the amount of AWOLs that C1 was involved in, as well as was not doing enough to prevent clients from bringing in drugs and over the counter medicines used to get high. Regarding allegation that S2 attempted to maintain a relationship with C1 outside of the facility. LPA Mena obtained conflicting information. Confidential interview denied that S2 attempted to maintain a personal relationship with C1 outside of facility and stated that S2 only attempted to say farewell to C1, as well as to give C1 a birthday gift. According to confidential information, S2 did not actually have physical contact with C1 outside of the facility and that C1 was not at relative's home when S2 arrived to give present. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that there appeared that there was "something going on" between C1 and S2. LPA Mena was unable to interview C1 regarding allegations, due to C1's current whereabouts being unknown. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff do not prevent youth from multiple AWOLs (Absence Without Official Leave) and from bringing illicit substances into the home, as well as of having an inappropriate relationship with youths, more specifically that Staff #2 (S2) attempted to maintain a personal relationship with Child # 1 (C1) outside of the facility, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.
