Additional witnesses stated no issues or concerns were advised regarding staff being "rough" with clients. It was reported that client did not have enough clothes and was not taken shopping. It was advised that San Diego County placements do not receive clothing allowance. It was reported that facility abides by the guidelines of San Diego County's clothing standard. It was advised that the inventory is conducted monthly and clients are allowed to shop with their peer counselor to meet the standard if the inventory is deficient. It was advised that due to the pandemic, shopping was conducted online. LPA Harris was provided clothing receipts and inventory documents. Confidential interviews stated that the clients have been placed at the facility and have not had any clothes purchased for them. It was reported that clients are also not allowed to do any online shopping with their peer counselor. It was reported that representatives are aware of the concerns. Information obtained from additional witnesses stated clients have an abundance of clothing. It was advised that clients always have clean and appropriate clothing on when observed; no concerns have been advised. In regards to the allegation that staff took minor's computer away, it was reported that staff do not allow clients to utilize their personal computers. Administrator advised that due to the CSEC population the facility houses, the clients are not allowed access to computers, phones, social media applications, etc. Administrator stated due to the Covid-19 pandemic, clients were required to utilize computers to complete schoolwork. It was reported that clients were abusing their computer privileges by downloading music and social media applications. Administration stated in order to combat the issues and ensure the clients are not being revictimized, the clients were switched to paper schoolwork packets. Administration stated therefore; the clients are no longer permitted to use computers. Confidential interviews stated staff took away thier computers due to clients not following the rules, but the computers were needed in order to complete school work. Information from the interviews also stated that it is not a privilege, but a right to have access to technology. Information from confidential interviews corroborated that due to the nature of the clients' past, clients are not permitted to have access to technological devices; no concerns. Staff members stated that clients are fully aware of the rules. Staff stated that that would be only reason that clients are not allowed to attend group. Information from confidential interviews stated that staff do not allow clients to attend group for small issues. It was advised that staff are too strict on the clients, even though the rules are often communicated. Information from additional witnesses stated no concerns have been advised regarding clients not being allowed to attend group. It was reported that participation is high for the facility. It was reported that a client was not allowed to be permitted back into the facility after they returned from AWOL. It was advised by Administrator that the client went on AWOL status during the Covid-19 pandemic and guidelines were put in place. It was advised that upon client's return to the facility, a mandatory quarantine must take place. It was advised that the client refuse to go on quarantine status until a negative Covid-19 test returned. It was stated that staff members contacted the probation department and was advised to transport the client to the juvenile facility in order for the client to be detained and quarantine at the facility. It was advised that the next day, the clients probation officer contacted the facility and did not agree with the decision; the client never returned to the facility. Information from confidential interviews stated thaty facility staff refused to allow client into the home and subsequently had to go to juvenile hall. No further information was advised. Additional witnesses stated they had no further concerns due to the facility being advised to act accordingly. Further information stated the decision was made to ensure the safety of the facility was not jeopardized. In regards to the mental and psychiatric needs of the clients not being met, it was advised that clients are referred to mental and psychiatric health to two outside clinics. It was reported that due to the pandemic, appointments were made slower than normal. It was advised that clients are allowed to speak with the facililty social worker and their own therapist. It was reported that clients are provided their psychotropic medication on a regular and scheduled basis. Information from confidential interviews stated clients did not feels supported during the pandemic by staff or therapist. It was also reported tha appointments took too long to schedule. It was also advised that some staff were sensitive to the needs of clients and ensured they were safe and comfortable. Probation officer and social worker stated there were no issues or concerns as clients are taken to therapeutic services regularly. It was also advised that no concerns were advised or addressed. narrative: On June 15, 2021 at 11: AM, an informal office conference was held virtually with Tiffany's Place Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) via MS Teams due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In attendance for Community Care Licensing (CCL) were: Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Managers (LPMs) Stephanie Hudak and Ann Valenzuela, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez. San Diego County Representatives were: Institution Evaluation Unit (IEU) Program Manager (PM) Natasha Hood, Protective Service Supervisor (PSS), Eileen Marshall, Senior Protective Service Worker (PSW), Andrea Hernandez, IEU Contracts, Sheila Lyn Worthington and Behavior Health Services (BHS), Trang Hoang. Sacramento County Representatives were Program Planner (PP) Linda Abelelbaki, Program Manager (PM) Leslie Olson. Lastly, for Tiffany's Place, present were Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Lynn Burgard, Program Administrator (PA) BriAnn Guillen. The following issues were discussed: · Complaints · STRTP Provisional License During the meeting, LPM Valenzuela discussed increase of complaints at STRTP since facility opened. In 2020, there were four complaints and in 2021, six complaints as of June 15, 2021. STRTP was licensed on September 26, 2019, however, began accepting foster youths in February of 2020. Most of the complaints have to do with personal rights and staff training. PA Guillen was given the opportunity to speak regarding the increase of complaints relating to personal rights training. PA Guillen stated that the staff receive personal rights training during the first 90 days upon hire as well as during staff meetings; and are in the process of updating what training should be done on an annual basis. PA Guillen stated that she does the training however CEO Burgard and the Facility Social Worker can also do the training. LPM Valenzuela stated that staffing needs to be according to the foster youth's needs and there is available funding to increase staff. PA Guillen stated they have reached out for support from San Diego County for additional funds in order to meet the foster youths' needs for additional staffing. PA Guillen stated their current census is two and there are ample staff for two foster youths. LPM Valenzuela asked facility representatives if they are scheduling Child Family team meetings (CFTs) and PA Guillen said yes; it is schedule by the County Social Worker or Facility Social Worker. PA Guillen said that sometimes she attends as well as CEO Burgard. See LIC 809C page Lastly, the status of the STRTP provisional license was discussed. LPM Valenzuela advised Tiffany's Place that their provisional license is set to expired on September 26, 2021. LPM Valenzuela asked if they had hired a Head of Service and CEO Burgard stated yes, they just hired this week and a Head of Service will start on the first or the second week of July 2021. CEO Burgard stated she wasn't aware that the license for Tiffany's Place was going to expire on September 26, 2021. CEO Burgard stated that she was under the impression that as long as she had the Mental Health Approval that the State of California would provide some leeway or an extension for the accreditation process. RM Cook stated that there is no extension beyond 24 months per statute. CEO Burgard had spoken to CARF (accreditation agency) and it was told to her that accreditation should be done within 24 months of receiving a provisional license. RM Cook reiterated that there is no extension to the provisional license past 24 months. LPM Hudak provided information that per the current STRTP guidelines, in order for CCL to justify the extension of the provisional license past the 12-month expiration date, the facility needs to be in the process of obtaining Mental Health Approval and/or Accreditation. CEO Burgard asked if STRTP does not have accreditation by September 26, 2021, then would they need to close the STRTP? RM Cook stated that if the STRTP does not have accreditation then they will need to close as there is no extension available beyond the 24 months. RM Cook asked CEO, what would be their plan? CEO Burgard stated they don't have a plan. CEO Burgard stated in order to get accredited they need to be operating to CARF standards for at least 6 months. She said they just hired a consultant to assist in getting accreditation through CARF. CEO Burgard has a contract with County of San Diego Behavioral Health. CEO Burgard said the accreditation audit will be conducted in December. CEO Burgard stated that the focus was changed when COVID-19 hit, from the accreditation process to the needs of the foster youth. RM Cook clarified for the CEO Burgard that CARF are their own entity and are not a part of CCL. Suggestion was given to check with the other accreditation agencies and see if they can expedite the accreditation process to be completed prior to the expiration date of the provisional license. It was suggested if they cannot complete the accreditation and mental health approval process by the expiration date, the STRTP can submit an application to go through the process to change facility type. Suggestions were given as to alternative facility programs; they can apply for a Group Home for private pay clients or Group Home for Regional Center clients. PA Guillen asked what will happen if they cannot meet the expiration date, can they apply for STRTP again. LPM Hudak said yes, but the STRTP has to wait a year after application denial; the provisional license is considered part of the application process. See LIC809c Page CEO Burgard stated she needs to get information from Department of Health Care Services Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Stephen Conn regarding if the accreditation is required to submit their mental health program application and she would be researching accreditation processes, deadlines and their available options. In lieu of the issues presented during this meeting, the STRTP is being required to submit a Corrective Action Plan (CAP) by June 29, 2021, detailing the following: 1) submit an addendum to the Program Statement regarding what personal rights training entails and who will be conducting the training. Also, PA Guillen had mentioned that she is currently revising the annual training, and CCL requested they include that information in the CAP, 2) submit the last two copies of the board meeting minutes; minutes to include what actions the STRTP will be taking as a result of today's office conference. All recommendations/suggestions and requirements given during the meeting by both CCL and STRTP representatives were acknowledged. In closing, all parties were satisfied with all information that was discussed during the meeting. CCL will follow-up with the STRTP in 14 days. A copy of this report reviewed and emailed to CEO Burgard. Original signature will be placed in file. Amended: A copy of this report was given to PA Guillen.

CEO stated that she used the word for clarification, but never called Client #1 the term. Information obtained from confidential interviews stated that no client has been called the term, but information advised stated that staff has told clients to "stop having a black attitude." It was reported that the facility did not have any food and that clients were forced to eat biscuits for dinner. It was advised by administration and staff that the facility has more than enough food. It was advised that the facility's food supply is replenished on Tuesdays and Saturdays. It was also stated that the facility obliges by the Community Care Licensing Standard for perishable and non perishable foods. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility has enough food and clients are fed well, but a lot of the food is expired. It was reported that minors are denied television usage and are taken on inappropriate outings. It was stated that clients are only allowed to watch documentaries and were taken to a cemetery for an outing. It was stated that clients do have media education time where they do what documentaries, but are able to watch their own shows at another time. Confidential interviews did not reveal any issues or concerns regarding television time. It was also reported that clients were taken to a cemetery for an outing. Information obtained from administration and staff denied the allegation. It was reported that clients are taken to parks, beaches, movies, etc. Information from confidential interviews corroborated the information. It was reported that the facility is dirty and has pest. Information obtained stated that staff members and clients are responsible to clean the facility. It was also reported that a cleaning company cleans the facility once a month. It was reported that the facility can get messy, but never dirty. No information was advised of the facility having pest. Information obtained from confidential interviews stated that the facility is dirty; especially the kitchen and refrigerator. Information did advise that staff and clients are responsible for cleaning the facility. Confidential information did state that pest are in the facility as well. It was reported that a staff did not keep minors personal information confidential. It was reported that recently a client did advise that a staff member revealed their medical information. Information from administration and staff stated that Client #1 told a new client their medical information which was corroborated by the new client. All staff denied that they shared any personal information regarding any client. Information obtained from confidential interviews stated staff do share their information, but could not provide any specific details. Based on interviews and information obtained, the allegations that staff made inappropriate comments towards minor, staff did not maintain adequate food supply on premises, staff did not provide enough allowance to youth, minors denied tv usage, minors taken on inappropriate outings, facility is dirty and has pests, and staff did not keep minors personal information confidential may or may not have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report will be provided the facility.

narrative: On May 10, 2021, the Department received allegations that facility did not notify clients and staff of exposure to COVID-19 and staff were not wearing face coverings inside the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that there was a COVID-19 positive individual in the facility, at which time the staff and the residents were not notify of possible exposure. Additional confidential interviews revealed that all in person appointments and outing were canceled, and clients were quarantine without any explanation. Confidential interviews revealed that staff have not been wearing face coverings since January of 2021. Additional interviews revealed that staff are told to wear face coverings when personnel from Child Welfare Services, Probations, and/or Community Care Licensing arrive to the facility. Based on confidential interviews and documentation reviewed the allegations that the facility did not notify clients and staff of exposure to COVID-19 and staff are not wearing face coverings in the facility are substantiated. This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to clients placed in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the Health and safety Code Health and safety Code section 1550 for conduct inimical . See page LIC809d for the cited deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights discussed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, LIC811 and appeal rights were given to the PA Guillen for signature.

On 06/03/2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that clients in care are not accorded with privacy. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility installed cameras inside the facility with audio. Confidential interviews revealed that clients were being record both video and audio in the living room and staff office. Additional information revealed that the facility installed cameras after an incident between staff and a client. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed that there are cameras in the staff office, living room, downstairs hallway, above the landing, and around the outside of the facility. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed a footage dated 06/10/2021 that C2 was in the living room and can be heard talking. Based on confidential interviews and documentation reviewed the allegation that C1, C2 and C3 in care are not accorded with privacy is substantiated. This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to clients placed in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the Interim Licensing Standards Ver 3. Personal rights: section code 87072(d)(10) See page LIC809d for the cited deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights discussed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, LIC811 and appeal rights were given to the PA Brooks for signature.

All confidential interviews revealed a client was sleeping in the therapy room because it was the only room the client felt safe due to the lock on the door. Confidential interviews revealed the facility implemented an "angry wall" where clients wrote other client's names and profanity on the wall and then used a plastic bat to punch holes into the wall. All interviews revealed conflicting statements on the rules and the purpose of the angry wall. Confidential interviews revealed only one client's name on the angry wall had holes. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegations are substantiated. This posed a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care, the facility is being cited for violation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Article 07. Physical Environment, Section 87087 (b) (4): Buildings and Grounds and Article 6. Continuing Requirements, Section 87072 (d)(11): Personal Rights. Confidential interviews and record reviews confirm a client was sleeping in a room for therapy and staff is making clients remain in a hostile environment. narrative: Specifically, it was reported S1 and S2 knew the C1 and C2 were bringing in alcohol [to the facility] and did nothing about it. Confidential interviews provided consistent reports of C1 and C2 bringing alcohol into the facility. Confidential interviews provided consistent statements of staff finding multiple empty bottles of alcohol in trash cans, in bushes, or other places at the facility. Confidential interviews also provided consistent statements regarding C1 and C2 drinking the alcohol in the presence of Staff #1 (S1), S2, and Staff #8 [S8] without staff intervention. CCL received and additional allegation alleging Staff (Staff #1 [S1]) provided minors (Child #1 [C1] and Child #2 [C2]) with vape pens. Confidential interview provided consistent statements regarding the use of vape pens by residents in the facility. Confidential interviews revealed consistent statements of S1 would vape with C1 and C2, and providing vape pens to C1 and C2. Based on confidential interviews the allegations of staff (Staff #2 [S2] and Staff #3 [S3]) negligence resulted in minors (Child #1 [C1] and Child #2 [C2]) consuming alcohol and Staff (Staff #1 [S1]) provided minors (Child #1 [C1] and Child #2 [C2]) with vape pens are substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations regulation 80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs, and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87072(d) Personal Rights (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Sections 16001.9 as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Tiffany's Place Administrator (ADM), Rushel Brooks. regarding how residents AWOLing is handled by staff. Confidential interviews reported when a resident attempts to AWOL from the facility emergency intervention techniques are used by staff. Confidential interviews and record review revealed anytime a resident walks off or is out of staff sight while on outings this action is considered a resident AWOLing. Confidential interviews reported C1 had a history of walking off and/or being out of staff sight both from the facility and while on outings however, how staff handled the walk-offs is unknown. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute that staff followed emergency intervention plan when residents AWOLed. CCL received an additional allegation alleging Staff (Staff #3 [S3]) did not adhere to facility dress code allowing minors to wear provocative clothing. Confidential interviews provided conflicting reports of residents being allowed to wear provocative clothing. Confidential interviews reported when residents are leaving the facility for outings staff remind residents to adhere to dress code in order to participate in the outing. Additionally it was reported if residents are in the facility depending on which staff is working dress code may or may not be enforced. Based on confidential interviews and record review the allegations of staff (Staff #2 [S2] and Staff #3 [S3]) did not follow Emergency Intervention plan when minors (Child #1 [C1] and Child #2 [C2]) AWOL'd from the facility and Staff (Staff #3 [S3]) did not adhere to facility dress code allowing minors to wear provocative clothing, may or may not have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Tiffany's Place Administrator (ADM), Rushel Brooks.

narrative: On 05/17/2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations that S1 did not provide adequate supervision to C1, S1 allowed C1 to consume alcohol, and S1 allowed C1 to bring alcohol into the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 and C1 went on a one-to-one outing in the community. Interviews revealed that S1 took C1 to Target to purchase a beauty product and C1 ended up stealing a bottle of alcohol. When S1 and C1 returned to the facility, C1 showed S1 the bottle. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 and C1 went on another one-to-one outing to an unapproved location where C1 used drugs and stole another bottle of alcohol while under the supervision of S1. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 did not attempt to remove the alcohol from C1. Additional interviews revealed that C1 was able to hide and consume alcohol in the facility due to S1 not informing other staff that C1 had the bottle in their possession. Other confidential interviews indicated that C1 provided C2 with alcohol for consumption. Furthermore, S1 resigned when S1 was told by another staff that management thinks that S1 provided C1 with the alcohol. Based on confidential interviews and documentation reviewed the allegations that S1 did not provide adequate supervision to C1, staff allowed C1 to consume alcohol, and S1 allowed C1 to bring alcohol into the facility are substantiated. This poses immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk of harm to clients placed in care. The facility is being issued a citation per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision 80078(a) and Health and Safety Code 1558(a)(2) Conduct Inimical. See page LIC809d for the cited deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC811, and appeal rights were given to the DOO Guillen.

The client was alleged to have stolen a staff member's vehicle, left the facility, returned, and was not allowed to enter the facility. Based on Confidential Interviews, the client SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: It was reported when "house lockdowns" occur, clients are not allowed to have any contact with anyone outside of the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that when the house goes on "lockdown or safety closure", clients are to remain in their bedrooms and are allowed to go to the backyard, eat meals in the dining room, and be supervised one-on-one with staff. Records reviewed if clients are on "level zero" they would be either in their bedroom or outside, have staff with them from 7 am-10 pm, and have no privileges. If a client does not complete the "level zero" requirements within 24 hours, they will be placed out of the program or discharged from the program. Confidential interviews report that restrictions consisted of no television, no electronics, no community excursions, and remaining in bedrooms except for going to the backyard or to the dining room to eat meals. This practice conflicted with the facility's approved discipline policy. Based on witness statements and record review of facility documentation, the allegation that staff is using inappropriate discipline towards minors is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, regulation 87072.1(a) Discipline Policies and Procedures. On February 22, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the staff are not properly trained. It was reported that staff is not properly trained, and some staff has not completed all of their Pro-Act Training within 90 days. During the investigation, LPA reviewed the Employee Roster, Staff Training History, and training certificates. During the records reviews of thirty-eight training certifications, there are five staff that are listed as not completing their Pro-Act Training within 90 days. LPA reviewed the facility's policy about staff training which states all staff must complete Pro-Act Training within the first 90 days. Based on witness statements and record review of facility documentation, the allegation that staff is not properly trained is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, regulation 87095.65 (b) Emergency Intervention Staff Training. On February 22, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the staff do not know how to perform emergency evacuations. It was reported that staff does not know how to perform emergency evacuations. Confidential interviews revealed that staff is aware of the exit doors in the facility and to meet SEE LIC 9099C outside at a designated location. However, interviewees were unable to provide the name of the relocation sites, which are equipped to provide safe temporary accommodation for clients, in case of evacuation. Confidential interviews revealed that the form was posted in the facility with the names of the relocation sites, and they would need to look at the form to know where to go in case of evacuation. Based on witness statements, the allegation that staff does not how to perform emergency evacuations is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, Chapter 1, Article 3, regulation 80023 (b) 2 (C), Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan. A copy of this report was provided to and reviewed with Carmen Powers, Program Manager, along with the appeal rights and the LIC 811. A signed copy of the report will be kept in the Facility file. Activity calendars were provided for October 2021, November 2021, December 2021, January 2022, and February 2022. Confidential interviews revealed that clients had participated in some community activities. Other confidential interviews stated that the facility did not have money to take the clients on outings. Records reviewed could not confirm if the activities actually took place. It was reported that clients are only offered one religious option and many speakers and presenters are Christian. Based on confidential interviews, C1 and C2 were interested in other religions and were given the opportunity to practice their believes. Other confidential interviews entailed that clients were not given an option when receiving therapeutic services as they were all Christian based programs. It was reported that staff members threatened clients with law enforcement. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements; staff members tell the clients they will call law enforcement to request the Psychiatric Emergency Response Team (PERT). Other interviews revealed that staff threatened to call law enforcement knowing clients were scared of law enforcement. Records review revealed that law enforcement has been called to the facility when clients are demonstrating "unsafe behaviors" or have run away from the facility. There were no witnesses to the alleged incident. It was reported that clients are not allowed to speak Spanish in the facility. Confidential interviews entailed conflicting statements; clients were speaking Spanish so the staff could not understand them, and clients would curse and make negative comments toward other clients. Other confidential interviews revealed clients were told not to speak Spanish in group therapy sessions since there was not a Spanish-speaking facilitator, and clients were told not to speak Spanish at the dinner table as there was not a Spanish-speaking staff member at the facility. It is unknown if the facility did not allow the clients from speaking Spanish due to the well-being of other clients or if Spanish is not allowed to be spoken in the facility. It was reported that clients were "pushed to AWOL" because staff did not want to work with them anymore. Conflicting statements revealed that interviewees could not recall if a client was removed against regulations. Records reviewed revealed that some clients were removed before required placement preservation strategies were implemented, including Child-Family Team meetings however, no confidential interviews supported the records. It was reported that clients snuck out several times and got high and snuck in without being noticed by staff. Conflicting interviews revealed that clients had left the facility to partake in illicit drug use and had returned to the facility without staff knowing they had left the facility; however, it is not clear how long the clients were away from the facility. It was reported that staff do not provide assistance with grooming or allow razors in the facility. Based on conflicting statements, clients are allowed to use the razors and check them out from staff and return them to staff when not in use. Other interviewees revealed that clients need permission from their authorized representatives before using a razor and are offered hair removal cream. It was reported that clients are required to use their own money to purchase grooming supplies and hair supplies. Conflicting statements revealed that the facility provides hygiene and grooming supplies and other statements revealed that clients have to purchase hygiene supplies because the facility will not purchase the supplies. Based on interviews and information obtained, the allegations that staff does not have planned activities for the minors, staff interfere with the minor's religious beliefs, staff threatened the minors while in care, staff are preventing the minors from speaking their native language, staff unlawfully removed a minor while in care, staff do not provide adequate supervision to the minors, and staff do not provide assistance with grooming may or may not have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Carmen Powers, along with a copy of the LIC 811.

Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection 05/24/22 at 9: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 13 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 05/24/2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dina Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Briann Guillen, Administrator.

On May 31, 2022, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza- Gonzalez conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility. LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Residential Program Manager (RPM) Carmen Powers. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct case management regarding a previous inspection. On May 23, 2022, LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed that there was a curtain in the doorway of bedroom #1. Bedroom #1 is occupied by C1 (see confidential name list, LIC811 dated May 31, 2022). Upon entering the bedroom, LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the bathroom door is missing. On May 31, 2022 at 9: AM, LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed there is no curtain in the door way or door of bedroom #1. RPM Powers stated that the bedroom door was removed for safety reasons. Based on interviews and LPA Meza-Gonzalez observation made on May 23, 2022, C1's bedroom did not have a door which is a violation of the facility's fire clearance which poses a health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care. The facility is being cited for Title Regulations, Section 80000(b) General. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to RPM Powers due to technical difficulties with the printer.

On May 11, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the facility is charging clients for food outside the menu. Confidential interviews revealed that C3 cooked steaks because C3 did not want to eat what was on the menu. Additional interviews revealed that C3 was charged for cooking steaks that were outside of the menu. Interviews revealed that C3 was charged for the steaks as part of restitution due to C3 had cooked all the steaks that were for a meal on a different day. LPA Meza-Gonzalez reviewed C3's LIC 405 which shows that C3 was charged for steaks. Based on confidential interviews and documentation reviewed the allegation that the facility is charging C3 for food outside the menu is substantiated. This poses potential health, safety, and personal rights risk of harm to clients placed in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with interim Licensing standards (ILS) V3.1 87072. Discipline Policies and procedures. See page LIC809d for the cited deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC811, and appeal rights were given to CEO Lynn Burgard. On May 11, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations that the facility does not have enough food for the clients. Confidential interviews revealed that there are inconsistencies to whether there was enough food for the clients in care. Additional Interviews revealed that allegedly a client had requested mangos however they were denied due to the fruit being expensive and exotic. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the facility had a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable however insufficient amount of fruits. Based on confidential interviews and record review, although the allegation that the facility does not have enough food for the clients may or may not have occurred, the allegation is not supported or proven by the evidence gathered. Therefore, the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, the appeals, and LIC 811 were given to CEO Burgard.

facility_name: TLC CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES-ORCHARD HOUSE
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez conducted a complaint inspection, via telephone, (in accordance with PIN 20-05-CRP) and spoke with Director, Brittany Burns. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA conducted a record review, reviewed incident reports, and conducted interviews with seven clients and one staff. C1 stated he felt staff did respond appropriately during the first incident; however, felt staff could have been more proactive so that the second incident did not occur. Although measures were in place to keep the clients separated, the two involved clients were still able to be in the same area and engage in a second altercation. LPA was unable to speak with staff present during the second incident and most clients reported they did not witness what had occurred. LPA could not prove with a preponderance of the evidence that the allegation occurred as reported. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Director for a signature. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

facility_name: TLC CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES-ORCHARD HOUSE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conducted an unannounced inspection of the facility. LPA met with Administrator Brittany Burns and toured the facility, inside and out. The STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) is licensed to serve 20 clients, ages 7-17 years old and Non-minor dependents. Currently in placement are 10 clients. Clients and staff were present during this inspection. The facility includes two houses, that can serve up to 10 clients each. Both houses are under the Orchard House license. LPA Bertoli inspected the Phoenix house, as the Orchard house was currently vacant. The Phoenix house appeared to be in clean, safe, and sanitary condition. LPA Bertoli interviewed the Administrator and two clients and discussed facility policies and procedures, including removal of youth, restraints, runaways and returns, and facility access from outside. No Title 22 deficiencies were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was sent to the facility Administrator to sign and return.

narrative: An announced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 06/09/2021 at 3:00pm. This inspection was conducted via MS Teams due to COVID19 restrictions on conducting on site inspections at licensed facilities. LPA Segura conducted SB Psychotropic Medication interviews on 06/08/2021 at 1:30pm with three staff , Administrator Brittany Burns, Medical Coordinator Dania Dudley and Facility Manager Janae Baddeley . At 3pm on todays date LPA Segura and Medical Coordinator Dania Dudley, counted medications and verified PMAR and centrally stored medication logs for three children. Dania also assisted with a physical plant inspection of the facility. No deficiencies were observed during this tele-inspection. A follow up inspection will be conducted to interview clients on 06/10/2020. LPA Segura provided this report to the administrator via email for signature and acknowledgment the report was received.

facility_name: TLC CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES-ORCHARD HOUSE
narrative: An announced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 06/09/2021 at 3:00pm. This inspection was conducted via Google meet due to COVID19 restrictions on conducting on site inspections at licensed facilities. LPA Segura sent the Administrator Brittany Burns a Document Request checklist on 05/25/2021. LPA Segura received client documents via email on 06/04/2021. The facility has 6 clients in placement at this time. On 06/07/ LPA Segura reviewed the child documents submitted by the facility. On 06/08/ LPA Segura conducted SB Psychotropic Medication interviews at 1:30pm with three staff , Administrator Brittany Burns, Medical Coordinator Dania Dudley and Facility Manager Janae Baddeley. LPA Segura and student assistant Stephanie Martinez reviewed the child files. Review of the files revealed that the following items were observed to be out of compliance with Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Below LPA will reference each child file as C1 through C5, see confidential names list LIC 811 dated 06/14/2021. Note facility submitted documents for C3; however, this resident is not a minor; therefore, not subject to this inspection. C1, C2, C4 and C5: Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) lists all psychotropic medications on a single PMAR rather than a separate PMAR per medication as required by ILS (Interim Licensing Standard) 87070(b)(12) C1, C2, C4 and C5: PMAR used by the facility does not include the quantity of medication and number of refills initially prescribed as required by ILS 87070(b)(12)(C). Continued on 809C C2, C4 and C5: Master Treatment Plan being used as the Assessment Needs and Services Plan (ANSP) not signed by the child, authorized representative or both. As required by ILS 87068.2(e) The facility was advised on 07/06/2020 that the use of a separate PMAR for each medication is required. Further the facility was also advised to review the health and safety code 1507.6(b)(2)(B) to ensure the required information was captured on the facility specific PMAR. The facility was also advised on 07/06/2020 that written approval from the child and authorized representative is required prior to implementing a Needs and Services Plan. According to the submittal of documents for this inspection, the facility did not implement the use of a single PMAR per psychotropic medication, incorporate specific details on the PMAR and written authorization of the NSP by the client and authorized representative; therefore a deficiencies will be issued for not complying with the Interim Licensing Standards. On the following day -06/08/2021- at approximately 3pm LPA Segura and Medical Coordinator Dania Dudley, counted medications and reviewed PMAR and centrally stored medication logs. In the course of conducting the medication counts Dania indicated that the facility has started to use the departments PMAR LIC 622B instead of the facility specific PMAR. Interviews of C2 and C5 were conducted on 06/10/2021 at 3:30PM. Client 1 did not participate in an interview as they were in crisis when LPA called for the previously scheduled interview. Client 4 had been discharged from the program the previous Monday therefore was not present to participate in an interview. Continued on 809C The staff file reviews were conducted on 06/11/2021 the documents submitted appeared to be in compliance of the Interim Licensing Standards. Three deficiencies were observed in the course of this inspection (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the California Code of Regulations, Title 22,

facility_name: TLC CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES-ORCHARD HOUSE
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Brian Bertoli and David Hiett conducted an unannounced inspection for the purposes of completing an Annual/Required Inspection and met with administrator Brittany Burns. Also assisting with records and the inspection were Treatment Director Karen Bergman and Operations Manager James Freeman and others. A pre-screening call was done prior to arrival, and Administrator Burns indicated that no one was Covid positive, symptomatic, or had known exposure. However, upon arrival it was disclosed that two youth had just become symptomatic overnight. Appropriate protocols were followed in the facility for the inspection and all interviews were conducted outdoors. The Physical Plant was toured inside and out by LPA Bertoli. Water temperatures were measured at 110 degrees. Seven-day Non-perishable food supply was inspected and was found to be adequate. Two-day perishable food supply was inspected and were found to be adequate and consistent with the menu. LPA inspected bedrooms and found that there was adequate linens and each bed had mattress pads. The home is clean and in good repair. There are no firearms in the facility. There are no open bodies of water on the property. Medications are locked in the office. Toxics and cleaning solutions are locked in the laundry room. Required documents are posted. Disaster drills are conducted quarterly, there are charged operable fire extinguishers, carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in the facility. Five clients and four staff were interviewed. Client files were partially reviewed at the administration office and will be completed on another date. Per Title Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Advisory notes were issued for the Disaster Plan, however those issued for HSC 1565(c) and CCR 80023(d)(2) do not apply, as documentation of compliance was received after they were saved on the system. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

facility_name: TLC CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES-ORCHARD HOUSE
investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli met with Administrator Brittany Burns regarding a complaint investigation at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA Bertoli inspected the facility, interviewed 3 youth, 4 staff, and 2 social workers, and reviewed documentation. LPA confirmed through interviews with staff and clients that staff engaged in a struggle with client C1 (see LIC 811 dated 10/29/21) over possession of a blanket that C1 wanted to take outside to keep warm. It was also confirmed by interviews with staff and clients and Incident Reports that doors were removed from client's bedrooms. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff violated personal rights of clients. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Title 22 deficiencies were cited regarding the struggle with the blanket and an Advisory Note was issued regarding door removal. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: 0

facility_name: TLC CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES-ORCHARD HOUSE
narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an announced visit to the facility for the purpose of reviewing the remodeling plans for the 'Phoenix House' portion of the facility. LPA Bertoli met with Administrator Brittany Burns, who assisted with the inspection. A COVID pre-screening call was made prior to the visit, and there were no known cases, exposures, or symptomatic youth or staff. LPA Bertoli toured the facility, reviewed plans, and discussed the nature of the changes and the potential impact on the youth. The youth that were previously in 'Phoenix' will be housed in the 'Orchard House' portion of the facility, which has eight bedrooms. The two houses combined constitute the licensed facility, which has a capacity of 16. The facility is converting two bedrooms to office spaces for the Facility Manager and the Medication Coordinator/Nurses office. The home will have eight bedrooms remaining, and they will not have more than six youth at a time in the home. The remodeling is expected to take approximately 3 months. LPA Bertoli has determined that the modifications to the facility are acceptable for the Short-Term Residential Therapy Program. No Title 22 deficiencies were found on this visit. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Burns and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

Staff Hallway leads to two office spaces, laundry area and bathroom. (Continued on LIC809-C) Office #1 will be reserved for individual/family therapy. It is equipped with soundproofing tiles and door leading to exterior. Office #2 contains cabinets for locked medications. Laundry Space will contain washer and dryer. Bathroom #3 contains functioning toilet, sink and shower with running water. Living Room contains adequate seating for clients, rug, fireplace that is inaccessible to clients. Switch is in locked office. Kitchen/Dining contains center island with three chairs, dishwasher, four burner stove and oven in operating condition, refrigerator and microwave. Adjacent to the refrigerator is a walk in pantry. There are sliding glass door that leads to exterior. Right Hallway leads to three client bedrooms, bathroom and sensory room. Bathroom #4 contains functioning toilet, double sinks and shower with running water. Breakout/Sensory Room contains large chair and soundproof tiles. Clients will be able to make phone calls here. On September 26, 2024 at 8:00am Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Enrique Hernandez conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection at TMHA-YOUTH TREATMENT PROGRAM, and met with the Facility Administrator Allison Jensen. During the course of the complaint investigation, it was revealed that on August 24, 2024, an incident occurred when Client #1 and Client #2, left the facility in the middle of the night. During a complaint investigation, it was discovered that During the period between 11: PM and 3: AM, Staff Member #2 (S2) performed bed checks. However, S2 was unable to visually confirm the presence of C1 or C2 in their beds as their bodies were not visible because their beds were covered with blankets. It was assumed that they were in their beds. Staff Member #2 (S2) arrived at the facility at 3:00 a.m. and performed bed checks. S2 observed that the beds had blankets, and after carefully checking for any signs of the clients, noticed that C1 and C2 were not in their beds and had left the facility. Additionally, C2 confirmed that both C1 and C2 planned to leave the facility at midnight. [See LIC Confidential Names List form (LIC811), dated 9/26/2024, for names]. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), the following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC809-D) Exit interview was conducted, and due to technical difficulties with the printer, a copy of this report will be emailed.

investigation_findings: 13On 9/25/2024 at 4:00pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the finding. LPA spoke with Allison Jensen Facility Administrator and together, discussed the investigative finding. During the investigative process by Licensing program Analyst (LPA), Enrique Hernandez, all relevant parties have been accounted for. It was reported that a Staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in minor being sexually assaulted by another minor in care. LPA Hernandez could not interview Client 1 (C1) because C1 had left the facility. LPA intended to contact C1 via the phone provided by the social worker, but it was disconnected. Lastly, statements alleging minor being sexually assaulted by another minor in care were not corroborated during the investigation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and due to technical difficulties with the printer, a copy of this report will be emailed. On December 9, 2024 at 10am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Pre Licensing Inspection. LPA was met by Administrator, Tanya Grazziani and allowed into the facility. The facility is a Short Term Residential Program that services Six, 12-17yrs old, ambulatory clients. The home opens to a large living area that has a couch and a covered fireplace. There are two sliding glass doors opposite each other. One facing the back of the home is kept locked and inaccessible to clients. The other sliding glass door is going to be used as an entrance for clients and staff. There is a dining room table for clients and staff to eat. The kitchen area has a stove, air fryer and coffee maker all in good working conditions. There is a pantry with non-perishables. Next to the kitchen is the laundry room which contains a washer and dryer. Above the washer and dryer is two locked cabinets that will contain medication and sharps and detergent and cleaning supplies. There is an access door that leads to the front of the home. Bedroom #1 has two beds that have storage attached to them. There is a closet space for two clients. There is a desk and a tv attached to the wall. There is a full bathroom in good working condition. Bedroom #2 has two beds that have storage attached to them. There is a closet space for two clients. There is a desk and a tv attached to the wall. Bedroom #3 & #4 are single occupancy rooms equip with a bed with storage attached and closet space for one client. There is a desk and a tv attached to the walls of each room. The bathroom located in the hallway is a full bathroom in good working condition. This bathroom will be used by clients in rooms 2, 3 and 4. Cont. 809-C The backyard is a spacious, fenced in area for clients to use. There is a concrete area that will be used for private visits for clients. The front of the home has a detached two car garage. The administrator hopes to be able to use the garage as a recreation room and an office space. Note: Administrator has been advised to make mention of this to the Fire Inspector when they arrive for inspection. There is a deck which has been fenced in and inaccessible to clients. Note: The fenced in deck is sturdy, however some areas need repair which is the reason for the fence. LPA advised Administrator to add an opening due to the shut off valves being located inside the fenced area. The facility vehicle is a Mercedes Benz M350 with current registration and insurance until June 2025. LPA has advised Administrator, Tanya Grazziani that the current RFH license needs to be vacated before the STRTP licensing process can be completed by me. A grievance box needs to also be put in place inside the facility for the clients use. A first Aid kit needs to be placed in the facility vehicle and a thermometer and tweezers added to the kit inside the home. This concludes the pre licensing inspection.

On February 21, 2025 at 10am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of observing the corrections from the initial pre licensing visit. LPA was met by Administrator, Tanya Grazziani and allowed into the home. The home is very clean and in order. The updates are as follows: LPA observed an empty home. The RFH license has been moved from the facility. A new fire inspection was conducted and the Administrator, Tanya Grazziani was advised to change the census from 6 clients to 5. A Grievance box is on the kitchen counter next to a new fire extinguisher. The sharps are in a locked cabinet above the washer and dryer. The 4th bedroom has been changed to an office. The closet contains a locked cabinet for medication. Room 3 is now single occupancy. On the outside of the home, the fencing around the deck has been completed and a locked opening has been added. The area will still be inaccessible to clients in care. The garage is will only be used as storage. There is a first aid kit in the facility vehicle and one in the home. All changes to the program statement have been submitted and are currently being reviewed. All corrections have been made and the home is prepared to receive clients. Nothing further to report at this time.

narrative: Confidential witness' statements revealed that the air conditioner in AD had broken down during a heat wave and the temperature in the dorm was uncomfortable. Confidential witness' statements revealed that AD was only provided fans for the common areas after clients threatened to file a complaint against the facility. Confidential witness statements revealed that several rooms in AD are hotter than others which caused clients to have bloody noses during the heat wave. Other confidential witness' statements revealed that the AD air conditioner has broken down during the summer months for the last few years and the air conditioner is never fully fixed. Confidential witness revealed that during the time that the air conditioner was not working, the temperature in AD reached 86 degrees Fahrenheit. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met that the facility air conditioner was not working properly which made the temperature in AD uncomfortable and out of the required range. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division Chapter Article 07. Physical Environment 80088 (a)(1) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Elizabeth Tamoush. Documents emailed to Elizabeth Tamoush. Original Signature on file.

narrative: the clothing without consent and then propositioned FC1 to pull FC1's pants down to which FC1 reportedly refused. Staff (S1) reported observing both FC1 and FC2 fully clothed standing three feet apart and that they were transported back to the facility individually. Staff reported to Investigator Lori Wood, that FC1 and FC2 were out of supervision for approximately 5-10 minutes. Additional staff (S2) reported physically seeing FC1 sitting outside of the dorm and within 2-3 minutes S2 was contacted by a separate staff notifying S2 that the youth had been found off facility grounds. However, a confidential witness disclosed that FC1 and FC2 were out of supervision for approximately 15-30 minutes. On the evening of 7/26/20, the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department was dispatched to the facility due to FC1's disclosure of being inappropriately touched on the genital area by FC2 and wanting to press charges. Documents provided during this investigation indicated that FC2 was cited by the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department due to the incident, however, an arrest was not required. Additional documents received during this investigation indicated that further disclosures were made after the incident alleging that a sexual assault had occurred between FC1 and FC2 on 7/26/20 during their unauthorized absence. However, confidential witnesses did not confirm these additional disclosures. Based on confidential interviews and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that there was a lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate interactions between FC1 and FC2 is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Title Regulations Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Facility staff failed to provide adequate supervision resulting in a youth being touched inappropriately on the genital area by another youth during an attempt to leave the facility unauthorized. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided.
investigation_findings: 13On November 20, 2020 at 1:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), LaTonya Wilson, met with Trinity - Apple Valley Campus Director, Elizabeth Tamoush, to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. During confidential interviews conducted by Special Investigator Lori Wood, it was reported that on 7/26/20 during an unauthorized attempt to leave the facility, FC2 touched FC1 on the genital area while fully clothed. Confidential interviews revealed that in the late afternoon, FC2 prompted FC1 to follow FC2 on an unauthorized absence while FC1 was sitting outside of the dorm. S1 admitted to providing FC2 with a cellular phone because FC2 had no one to talk to and compared their relationship to a "mother/son" relationship. narrative: During confidential interviews, the LPA received consistent information C1 went to the Aztec's dorm to get a heater. Staff #2 (S2) told C1 that C1's staff from the Panther's dorm had already came and got the heater. S2 told C1 the heater in the Aztec's dorm belonged to the Aztec's. Then S1 said," There's nothing you can do about it. You're not going to take this (heater)." S1 said to C1, "What are you going to do about it." C1 got really quiet. C1 said, "Okay, really," and walked out of the dorm quietly. C1 went back to the Panther's dorm. A few minutes later, C1 came back inside the Aztec's dorm. C1 was loud and said in a threatening way, "Oh, I'm not going to do nothing about it." C1 spat on S1's desk and S1's jacket. S1 stood up from behind the desk. S2 got in between S1 and C1 and told C1 to calm down. S1 told C1 to go back to C1's dorm. S1 also asked C1 why C1 spit on S1. C1 kept cursing. Staff from C1's dorm arrived and took C1 back to C1's dorm. The parties denied S1 cursed at, yelled at or threatened C1 during the incident. The LPA received other conflicting information regarding the incident. It was reported to the LPA, S2 would not give C1 the heater. C1 told S2, "For real." S1 stepped in and said, "She don't gotta fucking explain shit to you. What are you going to do about it?" C1 went back to the Panther's dorm. Ten minutes later, C1 went back to the Aztec's dorm common area and spat on S1. S1 said, "You fucking bitch. I'm going to fuck you up." S2 got in between C1 and S1. S2 pushed S1 back and said, "No don't do it, don't do it." S1 was yelling at C1, calling C1 a, "Bitch," and saying, "I dare you to do it again." C1 then walked back to the Panther's dorm. The facility provided the LPA with a flash drive of the surveillance camera footage of the 03/08/21 incident. There is no audio on the footage. The footage is from the camera four Aztecs East and camera three Aztecs West. The following was observed at the identified time stamps: 22:07: C1 comes into the common area holding a pillow. C1 stands in between the kitchen island and two conference tables while talking. 22:08: C1 leaves the common area and exits the dorm. 22:13: C1 enters the common area and goes behind the kitchen island. C1 stops a few feet past the end of the island. 22:13: C1 makes a spitting motion towards the first desk on the left hand side of the screen. *** *** 22:13: S1 gets up from desk and walks towards C1. S2 gets up from her desk and runs towards C1 and S1. S2 gets in front of S1 and is between S1 and C1. S2 walks backwards and uses her body to push S1 back. S2 also uses her outstretched arms to escort S1 backwards. 22:13: C1 turns around and walks to the door C1 came in from. S3 comes out from behind a desk on the opposite side of the common area and walks towards C1. A fourth staff comes in through the door that C1 used to enter the dorm and leaves with C1. 22:13: S1 and S2 walk back to their desks. Appears S1 is wiping off an object. Based on confidential interviews and surveillance footage of the incident, the allegations that S1 yelled at C1, threatened C1 and failed to redirect C1 while escalating the situation may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Ms. Tamoush for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.

narrative: This agency received allegation that facility staff did not allow clients access to their allowance. Confidential interviews disclosed that the staff are having the clients sign for their allowance but that it is being placed into their account to shop online. Other confidential interviews disclosed that the staff allow the clients to have $15.00 cash on hand to spend if needed. Confidential interviews revealed that clients were upset that they have had to shop online due to COVID. Interview with S1 revealed that the clients shop online due to the facility being positive for COVID and the facility being in lockdown. This agency received allegation that facility staff is serving food that is uncooked and the milk was curdled on at least one occasion. Confidential interviews disclosed that the clients would rather eat personal food, snacks due to not liking what is on the menu. Other confidential interviews disclosed the food looks greasy and disgusting. Interview with S1 revealed that the food is based off a healthy menu a lot like the school nutritional menu. On 03/03/21, LPA Flores observed the lunch brought to the dorm to be of a healthy meal and presented as edible. Record review of the food menu posted was healthy meals and of nutritional value. Other confidential interviews disclosed that the clients would rather eat junk food then the meals prepared and the staff offer alternate meals if the menu item is refused. This agency received allegation that staff are not assisting youth with educational needs. Confidential interviews disclosed that the staff will assist the clients with homework if the clients are asking for assistance. Other confidential interviews revealed that the staff will not assist C1 with scheduling for substance abuse classes or college course. Interview with Probation officer for C1 disclosed that C1 dropped a college course and wanted the staff to purchase a musical instrument for C1. Interview with staff #2 (S2) disclosed that the clients are scheduled for tutoring online when struggling with classwork or falling behind. . This agency received allegation that facility staff are conducting unauthorized searches of youth's belongings. Confidential interviews disclosed that staff are searching through C1's personal belongings without permission. Interview with S1, S2 and Staff #3 (S3) said the staff will conduct maintenance checks looking for broken drawers, graffiti, broken windows, and closets are in good repair. Confidential interviews disclosed that the staff allow clients to watch from outside the door during a maintenance check but most will watch television. Other confidential interviews revealed the staff will conduct room searches while the clients are outside. Interviews with P.O.'s and CSW's denied any issues with their clients while in the STRTP, clients have not complained about any of the allegations listed above. () Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that staff will talk rudely to the clients in care, that facility staff did not allow clients access to their allowance, that facility staff is serving food that is uncooked and the milk was curdled on at least one occasion, that staff are not assisting youth with educational needs and that facility staff are conducting unauthorized searches of youth's belongings, may have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC811 and appeal rights were emailed to Elizabeth Tamough, for signature. A signed copy report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: Additional confidential witnesses reported that there is a nutritionist who prepares monthly menus for the facility, however, the nutritionist may not always be aware of the preferred meal choices provided by the foster youth as the nutritionist works outside of the facility. During LPA's visit at the facility, the prepared meal for dinner was beef stew and there were no alternative meal options provided on the menu. During confidential interviews, it was disclosed that multiple youth preferred not to eat the beef stew and would have to prepare an alternative meal for themselves. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that the facility does not ensure the foster youth's nutritional needs are being met is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Title Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80076(a)(1): Food Services. Based on confidential interviews, there are no prepared meal alternatives provided by the facility and the youth are instructed to prepare a meat or peanut butter/jelly sandwich as an alternative meal which does not provide adequate nutritional value and poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to the youth in care. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided. S1 denied ever having a sexual relationship with any of the foster youth and reported never being alone with the foster youth as S1 does not work directly in the dorms where the youth reside. Several additional confidential witnesses reported never observing S1 or any other staff interact in an inappropriate manner with foster youth at the facility other than what has been previously reported and investigated by CCL. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that S1 sexually abused foster youth at the facility, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report, appeal rights, and LIC 811 were provided to facility representative.

LPA Wilson interviewed several confidential witnesses who reported that although there is food at the facility, the youth do not always want to eat the meals prepared by the cafeteria staff and are then instructed to prepare their own meat or peanut butter/jelly sandwich as an alternative. narrative: Confidential interviews revealed that they did not seen C1 behave manic. Campus director (S1) stated that facility staff had thought that C1 was administered the wrong medication, but assistant campus director (S2) reviewed the Medication Administration Record (MAR) and found that there weren't any errors. Other confidential witnesses stated that they had not been informed that clients were administered the wrong medication. S2 stated that C1 was discontinued a medication and this is where the confusion arose. S2 stated that facility staff talked to C1's authorized representative and explained the situation. S2 stated that he recalled a time where C1 seemed down after receiving news about C1's family. S2 stated that C1 was never extremely emotional or manic. Another confidential witness stated that C1 was informed by facility staff that C1 was administered the wrong medication and that this caused C1 to behave emotional and manic. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that on April 1, 2021, C1 was administered the wrong medication by facility staff and C1's authorized representative was not notified of C1 having spiraled into an emotional and manic state, may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Elizabeth Tamoush.

narrative: On September 8, 2021 at 10: A.M., Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Michael Almaraz, Darlene Almaraz, and Lisi Leon, conducted an Annual Required Inspection and met with Campus Director, Elizabeth Tamoush and Assistant Director, Ronnie Elenez. LPA disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility by the Campus Director and Assistant Director. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on September 14, 2017. At 10: AM a physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: The facility consists of 4 dorms with 6 bedrooms and three bathrooms each. Each dorm has a kitchen and living room area for clients use. Each dorm has an office space for staff and staff restrooms. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in Team Administrator's office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linen, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client's bathroom was measured to be 109 degrees. Facility has cameras in common areas of the dorms. The facility has an exception on file to use the cameras and are meeting the terms and conditions. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. (...) Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Personnel files were maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in staff office. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index checks clearances and exemptions. A review of client records was also completed on this date. Client and staff interviews were conducted and there were no health and safety concerns at this time. The facility was issued a technical violation due to LPAs observing that the facility did not provide locked containers for client's contraceptives. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809c and 9102 were provided and explained to Elizabeth Tamoush.

On December 15, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, met with facility assistant campus director Ronnie Elenez to complete a Case Management inspection based off information received in a special incident report (SIR) dated December 12, 2021. The SIR reported to the Department that facility staff #1 (S1) administered medication in error to client #1 (C1) Refer to Confidential Names (LIC 811) dated December 15, 2021. During LPA inspection of the facility LPA completed an interview with one staff and two clients. LPA collected copies of the information relevant to the case management. During LPA visit it was discovered that client #2's (C2) medication was issued to C1 and the medication error was not logged on C2's Psychotropic Medication Administration Record LIC 622B. Based on confidential interviews and record review the facility failed to log instructions for control and custody of C2's medication. The facility will be cited for a violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation 80075(k)(7)(H): Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Ronnie Elenez.
