narrative: On June 15, 2022, at 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, arrived at Trinity Apple Valley Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with assistant Campus Director Ronnie Elenez. The purpose of the inspection was to interview client #1 (C1) see confidential names list (LIC 811) dated June 15, 2022, in regard to a previous placement. A copy of the LIC 811 and LIC 809 was provided and explained to Ronnie Elenez.

On December 19, 2022, at 12: PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, arrived at Trinity-Apple Valley Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with campus director, Elizabeth Tamoush, to conduct a case management visit for the purpose of decreasing the capacity for clients' placement as requested by the licensee. The STRTP was licensed to provide care for 44 ambulatory clients. The licensee requested a capacity decrease to a total capacity 16 clients. The STRTP had 12 clients placed on the date of inspection. At 1: PM, LPA began the inspection of the facility with Elizabeth Tamoush. LPA toured the facility inside and out. LPA observed that there was a total of five buildings. Building one was the front office. Building two was the laundry, maintenance office. Building three was a cafeteria, training room and mental health offices. Building four and five acted as dorms for the clients. Building four had a team administrator's office along with two dorms. The dorms had six bedrooms, a staff office, staff break room, and four restrooms each. Building five had two empty dorms with six beds and four restrooms in each. No clients were being housed in building five at the time of inspection. Dorm one in building four Bedroom #1: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 13. Bedroom #2: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 14. Bedroom #3: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 14. Bedroom #4: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age Bedroom# 5: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 14. Bedroom#6: the room consisted of one single bed and slept a client age 13. Dorm two in building four Bedroom #1: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 10. Bedroom #2: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 16. (...) Bedroom #3: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 13. Bedroom #4: consisted of two single beds and slept two client age 15 and Bedroom# 5: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 13. Bedroom#6: the room consisted of one single bed was vacant. Bedroom were arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there was one client per bed. There was adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured to be 115 degrees Fahrenheit. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a locked cabinet located in the staff restroom. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in an office located in the cafeteria. The First Aid Kit is located in the team administrator office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors located in client's bedrooms and in the dorm dayrooms were checked and were operable. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Elizabeth Tamoush. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the team administrator office. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. Facility will complete a fire safety inspection for the approved decreased capacity of 16 clients and a copy of the approved fire safety clearance will be sent to the Department. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for the license capacity change will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Elizabeth Tamoush.

narrative: **Continued from LIC C page 1** In regard to the allegation that staff are not following doctor's order for resident in care, a confidential interview maintained that C1 had a follow-up medical appointment and was prescribed medication, however, staff did not transport C1 to the medical appointment or filled C1's medication as directed by a doctor. Other confidential interviews stated not being aware that staff did not refill C1's medication as directed. Another confidential interview stated having knowledge of a prescription medication refill for C1 but was not aware of the reason why the medication was not refilled. Other confidential interviews stated that staff provided medication as needed. A confidential interview stated recalling a time when their medication ran out for a few days. Another confidential interview reported not having issues in obtaining prescription medication at the STRTP. Regarding the allegation that staff do not treat residents with dignity and respect, a confidential interview stated after a verbal altercation with a staff member, another staff member was heard using profanity when speaking to C1. Other confidential interviews stated that staff treat clients with dignity and respect and denied being disrespected by staff. Another confidential interview witnessed staff using a firm voice when clients were not listening. Other confidential interviews denied witnessing staff behaving disrespectful towards clients. Regarding the allegation that staff do not take residents on scheduled outings, confidential interviews stated staff shortage have caused client outings to be cancelled. Other confidential interviews stated that some clients get to participate in outings while others do not. A confidential interview stated that some outings and activities are earned, and outings can be revoked due to client behaviors. Another confidential interview stated clients are taken on outings and added that when there is staff shortage program staff find other alternatives while considering client safety. Regarding the allegation that the facility is in disrepair, it was specified that the facility air conditioner (AC) has not worked for over five years. A confidential interview reported witnessing the air conditioner undergoing maintenance. **Continued on LIC C page 3** ** Continued from LIC C page 2** Confidential interviewed continued stating that the STRTP has issues with the air conditioning every year during summer. Other confidential interviews reported that program staff purchased portable AC units for clients while the air conditioner was being repaired. Other confidential interviews reported that client dorms were hot despite having portable AC units. Based on the confidential interviews, the allegations that staff were not following doctor's order for C1, staff did not treat clients with dignity and respect, staff did not take clients on scheduled outings, and facility was in disrepair may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. narrative: On September 13, 2023 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cynthia Urena met with Trinity Apple Valley Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Campus Director, Elizabeth Tamoush to discuss an issue that arose involving Client 1 (C1), Client 2 (C2) and Staff 1 (S1) (see LIC 811 confidential names list dated 09/13/23). During interviews conducted by Special Investigator (SI) Dennis Douglas with the California Department of Social Services, (CDSS), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), Investigations Branch Bureau, it was revealed that the facility operated outside of the State regulated staff to client ratio. Consistent confidential interviews disclosed on 04/23/23 the facility had 15 clients and 3 staff in which the facility was not within ratio. Confidential interviews disclosed that the facility was outside of ratio due to three staff members calling off on this date. Consistent confidential interviews further reported that while the facility operated outside of the State regulated staff to client ratio resulted in C2 breaking into a room at the facility, confining self in a room, and in an altercation between C1 where C1 sustained serious injuries while in care. Based on information obtained, the facility operated outside of required client to staff ratio; facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) version four SECTION 87065.5(b)(1)(C) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios which posed an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. A copy of this report was discussed, and provided along with appeal rights and LIC811 confidential names list to Trinity Apple Valley STRTP Campus Director, Elizabeth Tamoush.

During the investigation, all confidential interviews revealed that there was an altercation between C1 and C2 that resulted in C2 stabbing C1 while in care. Confidential interviews further stated that C2 was exhibiting ongoing aggressive behaviors towards peers and staff that included breaking facility windows, and handling glass, while in care. Confidential interviews also stated that S1 did not intervene during the altercation between C1 and C2 that resulted in another client intervening, where ultimately C1 sustained multiple stabbed wounds while under the care and supervision of S1. Other confidential interviews reported witnessing S1 giving verbal commands to C1 and C2 to stop the altercation from outside, but it was not enough to stop the fight and prevent C2 from stabbing C1 in care. Confidential interviews further maintained that S1 did not intervene during the altercation and that it was C3 who attempted to stop the altercation but was unsuccessful. Other confidential interviews stated that based on C2's history and individual needs C2 required one-on-one care however, the facility did not provide that type of care and supervision posing a risk to self and others resulting in C1 being stabbed by C2 in care. All confidential interviews reported that due to C1's stab wounds C1 required medical intervention due to the seriousness of injuries sustained from being stabbed by C2 while in care. Based on confidential interviews and record review the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that due lack of supervision, C2 stabbed C1 in care resulting in serious injuries is supported and proven by evidence, therefore the allegation is substantiated at this time. The facility is cited, and immediate civil penalty was issued for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) regulation 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. An enhanced civil penalty (ECP) determination is pending. If an ECP is assessed a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment. A copy of this report was discussed, and provided along with appeal rights, LIC811 confidential names list and LIC 421IM to Trinity Apple Valley STRTP Campus Director, Elizabeth Tamoush.

narrative: On November 8, 2023 at 4: PM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Kim Robinson met with the short term residential treatment program (STRTP) director, Gil Quinbar, by telephone and Teresa Valles, the Yucaipa campus administrator in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). On September 13, 2023, the Department concluded a complaint investigation alleging that staff #1 (S1) did not provide supervision to meet the needs of children in care, resulting in client #2 (C2) sustaining multiple stab wounds to the leg and arm. These allegations were determined substantiated, and the STRTP was cited from the Title 22, California Code of Regulations Section 80078 (a), Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The citation included an immediate civil penalty assessment of 500.00. See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated September 13, 2023. Based on the analysis of the interviews, medical reports and findings from the San Bernardino Sheriff report the Department has determined that an enhanced civil penalty is warranted for S1 neglecting to supervise and provide care and supervision to meet the needs of the children in care. The Penal Code Section 243 defines serious bodily injury as a serious impairment of physical condition, including, but not limited to a wound requiring extensive suturing. This section describes a number of more or less direct and (always) willful acts that constitute physical abuse. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, Health & Safety Code section 1548 (f)(1)(C), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2,000.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to the director and administrator. The signed copy will be retained in the facility file.

On October 3, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff did not prevent a minor from engaging in an illegal activity, and that staff did not prevent a minor from having access to an unknown substance. During the investigation there was no corroborating evidence to support the allegations. It was revealed that C1 had a history of substance use, specifically engaging in marijuana use prior to arriving at the facility. Some confidential interviews denied that C1 engaged in illegal activity on facility grounds while other confidential interviews reported witnessing C1 smoking marijuana on facility grounds without staff knowledge. Other confidential interviews denied observing C1 having access to an unknown substance specifically a white powder substance while in care. Confidential interviews further reported that C1 was out of the facility often and did not have access to a phone while on facility grounds. Confidential interviews also stated that C1 would "brag" to peers about engaging in illegal activity while out of care but was not observed engaging in these behaviors while at the facility and under staff supervision. However, it was reported to LPA that C1 was observed to be in possession of an unknown white powder substance in care, and the substance was confiscated by a facility staff member and discarded. Other confidential interviews denied the incident or having knowledge of the information. Confidential interviews further reported that incidences involving illegal activity or drug paraphernalia are reported, and items are provided to administrative staff for further action. There were no other known witnesses to the allegations. The department received inconsistent statements about whether the allegations of C1 engaging in illegal activity, and C1 having access to an unknown substance occurred while in placement and under staff supervision or while C1 was out of care. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegations that staff did not prevent a minor from engaging in an illegal activity, and that staff did not prevent a minor from having access to an unknown substance, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Campus Director, Elizabeth Tamoush.

narrative: The following allegations were made against the facility: Minors have access to illegal drugs while in care; minors are not being properly fed while in care; staff are not properly supervising the minors while in care; staff are not properly maintaining the facility; staff are not monitoring a minor's change in medical condition; staff are not addressing a minor's hygiene needs; facility is in disrepair, and staff interfered with CCL's visit to the facility. An unannounced inspection of the entire facility was conducted and each room was checked. Each facility room and the overall condition of the property were observed to be well maintained. The kitchen was fully stocked with food. Facility staff were following Covid-19 health and safety protocols with the use of masks, social distancing, and the facility had posters throughout the facility reminding staff and clients to follow Covid-19 safety protocols. The facility also had stock of sanitizers and personal protective equipment. Confidential statements obtained could not corroborate that clients had access to illicit drugs at the facility. The facility administrator also stated that a drug-sniffing dog used by law enforcement was also employed by the facility which did not result in discovery of illicit drugs. Confidential statements obtained also could not corroborate that clients were neglected by the facility regarding their hygiene needs, food, health and safety. There were ample supply of food and hygiene products at the facility. There were facility staff always present in each of the building that house the clients. Confidential statements obtained also could not corroborate that Community Care Licensing staff were purposely delayed in conducting their duties at the facility during unannounced inspections. Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis and LPA Juliet Robles went to Trinity - El Monte on September 14, 2021 at 8:45am for the purposes of a joint unannounced Required Annual inspection. LPAs met with Jaime Acosta, Assistant Director (AD), and together they toured the facility both inside and outside. The facility is licensed to serve forty-three (43) male clients ages 11-17 years old. The facility is a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and is located in a residential neighborhood. It also provides services to Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) as well. The campus consists of three individual dorms (Aztecs, Trojans, and Golden Bears) for client placement. There are five clients presently at the facility and all five reside in the Aztecs dorm. Sharp knives, cleaning supplies, and medications are kept locked in areas inaccessible to clients. The bedrooms in each dorm contained twin beds, dressers, and closet space. Smoke alarms were operable throughout the facility. There is adequate seating in the common areas of each dorm. All rules and regulations were posted at the facility. LPAs observed a weight lifting area, ping pong table, basketball court, several board games, computers, reference materials and books at the facility for client use. LPAs also observed ample food supply at the facility. LPAs observed the outdoor areas to be free of debris and hazards. The last earthquake drill occurred on July 07, 2021 at 8:55am. Bulletin boards were posted in each dorm that contained personal rights information, facility license, emergency disaster plan information, ombudsman information, foster youth rights, disaster plan information, accreditation, and other important information. The last fire drill was held on August 18, 2021 at 5:41pm. The last active shooter drill (lockdown) was held on July 28, 2021 at 6:36pm. The facility has nine available vans for client transportation. LPAs obtained a current copy of the facility's staff roster (LIC500) and a client roster. LPA also obtained a copy of the minutes of the most recent Board of Director's meeting that was held on June 11, 2021. Two clients and two staff were interviewed.

It was reported S1 had a history of yelling at C1. S1 denied the allegation. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff revealed S1 speaks firmly to clients in care but does not yell. Staff denied that S1 and C1 had a history of yelling at each other. Statements obtained from confidential interview conducted provided conflicting statements regarding S1 yelling at clients. Two of the clients interviewed reported S1 does not yell at clients, one reported S1 yells at clients for minor incidents and one client reported he has not met S1. It was reported S1 told C1 he was getting sexual with her when he pressed his body against hers while he attempted to push past her. S1 denied the allegation and reported saying "This is inappropriate". Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted and interviews with staff revealed there were no witnesses to the reported alleged comments made by S1. Based on information obtained through interviews conducted and records reviewed the allegations were Unsubstantiated. An unsubstantiated finding means that although the allegations may have occurred or are valid, the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative mentioned above.

narrative: On December 21, 2022, at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, arrived at Trinity Yucaipa Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with assistant campus director (ACD), Jason Mayo, to conduct a case management visit for the purpose of decreasing the capacity for clients' placement as requested by the licensee. The STRTP was licensed to provide care for 48 ambulatory clients. The licensee requested a capacity decrease to a total capacity 16 clients. The STRTP had 8 clients placed on the date of inspection. At 10: AM LPA began the inspection of the facility with ACD. LPA toured the facility inside and out. LPA observed that there was a total of seven buildings. Building one was the administration office, dining hall, and game room. Building two was the team administrator's office, student store and the independent living house. The independent living house is seven bedrooms, laundry room, seven and a half restrooms, a kitchen, living room and family room. The independent house will not be used for the STRTP program. Building three was conference rooms, mental health offices, and the STRTP laundry area. Building four and five acted as dorms for the clients. Each had six restrooms, a staff office and dayroom. Building five did not have clients at the time of inspection. Building six and seven used to be used as dorms for the STRTP but with the decrease in capacity they will not be utilized for the STRTP as dorms. Dorm one in building four Bedroom #1: consisted of two single beds and slept two clients age 16 and 17. Bedroom #2: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 17. Bedroom #3: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 14. Bedroom #4: consisted of two single beds and slept two clients age 16 and 16. Bedroom# 5: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 17. Bedroom#6: consisted of two single beds and slept one client age 17. (...) Dorm two in building five Bedroom #1: consisted of two single beds and did not have any clients. Bedroom #2: consisted of two single beds and did not have any clients. Bedroom #3: consisted of two single beds and did not have any clients. Bedroom #4: consisted of two single beds and did not have any clients. Bedroom# 5: consisted of two single beds and did not have any clients. Bedroom#6: consisted of two single beds and did not have any clients. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there was one client per bed. There was adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured to be 116 degrees Fahrenheit. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a locked cabinet located in the staff offices in dorm four and a locked closet located in the team administrator office. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet locked in a office located in the cafeteria. The First Aid Kit is located in the team administrator office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors located in client's bedrooms and in the dorm dayrooms were checked and were operable. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by ACD. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the team administrator office in a locked cabinet located in a locked medication storage room. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. Facility will complete a fire safety inspection for the approved decreased capacity of 16 clients and a copy of the approved fire safety clearance will be sent to the Department. (...) There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for the license capacity change will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Jason Mayo.

Other confidential witnesses stated that S1 and C1 were involved in a verbal altercation, but they did not witness S1 slapping C1. Furthermore, a confidential interview denied that S1 was physically aggressive toward C1 and added that it was C1 who was attempting to hit S1. LPA received conflicting information throughout the investigation. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that S1 slapped C1 may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. narrative: On October 11, 2023, at 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz conducted an Annual Required Inspection and met with Campus Director, Teresa Valles and Assistant Director, Jason Mayo. LPA disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility by the Campus Director and Assistant Director. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on September 14, 2017. At 12: PM a physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: The facility consists of four dorms with six bedrooms and a bathroom in each bedroom. Only one dorm is currently being used. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. Each dorm has a living room area for clients use. Each dorm has an office space for staff. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/books/games were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in Team Administrator's office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client's bathroom was measured to be 111 degrees Fahrenheit. Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with a rod iron/chain link fence. The enclosure was measured to be 6 feet high, with a self-latching gate that swings outward. LPA observed the pool gate to be locked as was confirmed by the Campus Director stating there was a double lock. (continued on page 2) Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. The facility has an exception on file to use the cameras and are meeting the terms and conditions. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews on this date, no deficiencies were cited. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. An exit interview conducted and a copy of the LIC 809 was provided and explained to Teresa Valles.

preponderance of evidence of C1 being sexually abused by S1 by S1 bribing C1 to participate in sexual activities. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations alleging Staff (S1) sexually abused a minor (C1) in care and staff (S1) bribed minor are substantiated. The complaint allegations are valid because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for two violations of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) v.4 standard PERSONAL RIGHTS (c)(11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning which posed an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The facilities violation of ILS v.4 standard PERSONAL RIGHTS (c)(11) which resulted in C1 being sexually abused by S1 requires the facility to be assessed an immediate civil penalty per Health and Safety Code 1548(c)(1). An Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending. If an ECP is assessed a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with Civil Penalty assessment and appeal rights to Trinity-Yucaipa Teresa Valles, Administrator.

On November 8, 2023 at 3: PM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Kim Robinson met with the short term residential treatment program (STRTP) administrator, Teresa Valles, and Gil Quinbar, Director via telephone in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). On October 20, 2023, the Department concluded a complaint investigation alleging that staff #1 (S1) engaged in sexual acts with 15-year-old client #1 (C1). The allegation was determined substantiated, and the STRTP was cited for the violation of the Title 22, California Code of Regulations Section 87072(c)(11), Personal Rights. An immediate civil penalty of $500.00 was assessed. See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated October 20, 2023. Based on the analysis of the interviews and record reviews, the Department has determined that an ECP is warranted for S1 engaging in obscene sexual conduct with a child in care. The Penal Code Section 11165.1 defines sexual conduct with a minor as physical abuse. This section describes a number of more or less direct and (always) willful acts that constitute physical abuse. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, Health & Safety Code section 1548 (f)(1)(C), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2,000.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to the administrator. The signed copy will be retained in the facility file.

On February 1, 2021 at 11:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced call through Microsoft teams in order to conduct a post-license inspection to the above-said facility, for the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with the administrator (A1) and the facility manager (A2). and they provided a tour of the entire physical plant both inside and out. The facility is licensed with a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license to care for 6 male children ages 13-17 years, Ambulatory only. Currently residing at the facility are five (5) clients. The home was inspected, and the following was observed: The Facility was set as follow: 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, Living room, kitchen and dining area, staff office and 2 car garage. All bedrooms were observed to be equipped with two twin size beds, drawer, dresser space and lighting was adequate in each bedroom. In bedroom no. 2 there was a dresser with a broken handle. LPA informed A1 and A2 of the need to have a dresser in good repair. LPA observed adequate non-perishable foods and perishable food. Facility is clean and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Rules, menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan and personal rights are posted at the facility. Outdoor space is free of debris and hazard. Hazardous and cleaning solutions, disinfectants, poisons, medication and sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients. Meds are locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. Home has working smoke alarms, one carbon monoxide detector. At the time of this inspection A2 said that there were two fire extinguishers in the facility. One was located in the garage and the second in the facility office. LPA observed that both fire extinguishers were empty. LPA told A1 and A2 that they have to get one immediately in case there is a fire at the facility. There is no bodies of water on the premises. No weapons or firearms on the premises. Report Continued on LIC 809-C The Facility states that children in care are supervised & protected at all times. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Children can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are encouraged to attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Facility reports client injuries requiring medical treatment. LPA observed that the facility's vehicle tag expired as of (November 2020). LPA informed the facility that they cannot drive the vehicle until they obtain the current vehicle registration. A1 indicated that during this inspection he called the rental company to inform them of the expired tag. The rental company notified A1 that they have the updated registration and he can pick up the registration today. LPA requested a copy of the current rental car registration form. A Review of the Facility's Personnel Summary on 2/1/ Reveals That Staff Have Doj/fbi Criminal Record Clearances and a Child Abuse Background Clearance. Based on today's inspections two deficiencies were cited PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7. Version 3.1. An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Corrections were reviewed and developed with the facility administrator. A copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility Administrator, in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file.

On 10/27/2021 at 9:30AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia made an unannounced to Trinity House 2 for the purpose to conduct the Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 10/28/21. Temperature and health checks are conducted at the entrance in the sign-in area. LPA met with Staff#1 (S1), who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant. This facility has a provisional licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) children ages 12-17 years old, Ambulatory only. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents. The facility is in the process of obtaining Accreditation with Joint-Commission. They are in the process obtaining Mental Health Approval. There are no bodies on water on the premises. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA Rosas inspected the following: This is a one (1) story (STRP) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood. There are three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, a living room, dining room, kitchen, staff office, backyard, and an attached garage for storage. There is one (1) facility vehicle parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition. Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves. The facility is surrounded by wooden fence and is observed to be good condition. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of Garage: The attached garage is used as storage and is kept locked. Laundry Room: The laundry room is located inside of the garage. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked in cabinets made inaccessible. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. There is a television and fireplace that is non-operable. Staff Office: It is equipped office furniture (i.e desk, computers, printers). The medication is triple locked inside of the staff office. All the children prescribed medications are locked in the staff office and children files are kept in a lock cabinet. Staff office is located inside the main facility. The First Aid kit has the required items inside (age-appropriate, and scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. Dining Area: One table with six chairs is next to the Kitchen: There is a gas stove/oven with four (4) burners, all operating. There is a microwave, refrigerator/freezer and a toaster oven. LPA's observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions made inaccessible to the children locked in cabinets. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Bedroom # 1: Occupied by two (2) clients, the bedroom is equipped two (2) twin sized beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) wall closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. This bedroom was a bathroom. Bedroom # 2: Currently occupied by two (2) clients, has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. S2 confirmed falling asleep while working with the clients, which was corroborated by the clients and S3. Based on LPA interviews and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations of Neglect/Lack of supervision are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. SW stated that during the time he was walking with C1, he did not see marks on C1's neck or arms. SW stated that C1 has not called him to let him know that he is not comfortable in the facility. narrative: On February 1, 2021 at 10:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced call through Microsoft teams in order to conduct a post-license inspection to the above-said facility, for the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with the administrator (A1) and the facility manager (A2). and they provided a tour of the entire physical plant both inside and out. The facility is licensed with a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license to care for 6 male children ages 12-17 years, Ambulatory only. Currently residing at the facility are five (5) clients. The home was inspected, and the following was observed: This is a one-story home, located in a residential area. The Facility was set as follow: 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, Living room, kitchen and dining area, staff office and 2 car garage. All bedrooms were observed to be equipped with two twin size beds, drawer, dresser space and lighting was adequate in each bedroom. There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. Children in care are supervised and protected at all times. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passage ways, stairways, inclines ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants/poisons are inaccessible. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks. Medications are locked and accessible only to employees supervising store medications. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Report continue on LIC809C Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. Facility records client cash resources, personal property, and valuables. Clients are allow to use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Clients can contact CCL or Foster Care Ombudsman person in confidence without threats or punishment. The facility has a Toyota Sienna passenger van the current automobile insurance is with Nonprofit Insurance Alliance of California expiration date 10/15/2021. A Review of the Facility's Personnel Summary on 2/1/ Reveals That Staff Have Doj/fbi Criminal Record Clearances and a Child Abuse Background Clearance. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7. Version 3.1, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility Administrator, in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file.

investigation_findings: 13On October 20, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan conducted a complaint inspection at Tuolumne Inn and met with Ramsina Oushana. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. The Department has investigated the above complaint allegations. LPA Barragan spoke with staff, clients, a Probation Officer and reviewed other predominant documents. Based on documents reviewed, an inspection, and conversations with staff and clients, all the information that was gathered was conflicting. "Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED." An exit interview was conducted with Ramsina Oushana. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Ramsina Oushana. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: 0

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Melikian and Vanessa Galvan on March 2, 2023 at 9:00AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code 1538.9(a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Monica Alexander, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed 3 child's records and 2 staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed 3 child's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed 2 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPAs interviewed one child currently on psychotropic medication as the other children were in school at this time. LPAs provided a copy of the licensing report to Administrator, Monica Alexander. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Monica Alexander, Administrator.

On March 13, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco met with Administrator, Monica Alexander and Program Director, Brandi Boehme for the purpose of conducting a Case Management. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss incidents dated 2/24/24, 2/25/24, 2/26/24, 3/2/24, 3/11/24 and 3/12/24 that indicated medication errors made by staff. LPA Tinoco reviewed incident reports from the Tuolumne Inn Facility (See LIC812 for details). LPA Tinoco discussed with Administrator the incidents. LPA highlighted the importance of administering medications appropriately. Administrator stated that the errors were caused due to lack of communication between staff. Staff responsible for the errors have been issued counseling forms and have been met with to discuss the errors. The agency plans to bring on a nurse that will begin conducting audits and meeting with small groups of staff for a period of time to potentially reduce the errors. As a result of the incidents mentioned above, The Agency is being cited for the Interim Licensing Standards Section 87075(c) Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

On April 09, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco met with Administrator, Monica Alexander for the purpose of conducting a Case Management. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss an incident dated 04/04/24, that indicated a medication error made by staff. LPA Tinoco discussed with Administrator the incident. LPA highlighted the importance of administering medications appropriately. The incident report stated that S1 (See LIC Confidential Names List) did not administer C1's medication on one occurrence. Administrator stated that the S1 was verbally counseled and a written counseling form will be addressed about the medication errors by the POC due date. The agency has brought in a nurse that conducts the medication audits and will potentially be meeting with small groups of staff for a period of time to potentially reduce the errors. As a result of the incident mentioned above, The Agency is being cited for the Interim Licensing Standards Section 87075(c) Health Related Services. The Agency was also issued a Civil Penalty for Repeat Violation. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

On April 29, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco met with Administrator, Monica Alexander for the purpose of conducting a Case Management. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss incidents dated 04/10/24 and 04/24/24, that indicated a medication error made by staff. LPA Tinoco discussed with Administrator the incidents. LPA highlighted the importance of administering medications appropriately. On 04/17/24, LPA Tinoco was was provided a Plan of correction which included the staff acknowledgement for the Medication Key Holder Responsibilities. On 4/24/24, LPA Tinoco was notified of the Medication Error dated 4/24/24. On 4/30/24, the agency will have a facility meeting where all the staff present will be retrained on medication administration and responsibilities. Additionally, the nurse will be conducting small group training to go over medications until all staff have been retrained. As a result of the incidents mentioned above, The Agency is being cited for the Interim Licensing Standards Section 87075(c) Health Related Services. The Agency was also issued a Civil Penalty for Repeat Violation. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

met_with: Administrator, Monica Alexander and Assistant Facility Supervisor, Cassandra Martinez Alvarez
narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco arrived at the Tuolumne Inn STRTP for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Annual/Random inspection. LPA met with Administrator, Monica Alexander and Assistant Facility Manager, Cassandra Martinez Alvarez and inspected the facility, inside and out. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke detectors were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, carbon monoxide detectors were observed, fire extinguisher is properly charged. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. There is at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 68 degrees. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs Administrator, Head of Service, 1 facility supervisor, 1 assistant facility supervisor and 13 direct care staff and 4 on call staff. Licensee has obtained Mental Health Certification Including the following: Mental Health Program Approval valid through September 24, 2024. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF (Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities). The Accreditation is valid through September 30, 2026. 5 records of clients were reviewed. Staff interviews were conducted. Staff Files and Children interviews will be conducted on a later date. One deficiency was cited on today's date and a Technical Assistance. A copy of this report was provided at the conclusion of the inspection along with Appeal rights.

All other cleaning supplies was locked and not accessible to youth in care. An incident report dated 10/29/24 involving C1. The incident involved C1 getting restrained due to Non-compliance. On September 16, 2021, at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Jesus Cervantes continued the unannounced annual inspection, which was started on September 13, 2021. LPA met with Compliance Manager, Crystal Maxwell at the ROP Corporate Office located at N. Tustin Ave. Suit #120. Santa Ana, CA 92705. At 8: AM, LPA reviewed sample of seven staff files. All files did not contain the necessary documents per Title Regulations and ILS. Technical Advisory notes were issued for the following: Staff records indicate that staff only receive yearly Emergency Intervention Staff Training. As specified in Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87095.65(e), Staff must receive on-going training to maintain certification. One of five client records did not have results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis as specified per California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80069(c)(1). Two of five client records had incomplete psychotropic medication logs, as specified in ILS 87070(b)(12)(F), (b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record: (12) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following: (F) The date and time of each dose taken by the child. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. All staff have proof in file of acknowledging the child abuse reporting requirements. Technical Advisory notes were issued and no citations at this time. Due to the need to complete staff interviews, this inspection will be completed on a later date. A copy of this report and LIC AT were reviewed and given to Compliance Manager, Crystal Maxwell.

On September 13, 2021, at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jesus Cervantes conducted an unannounced annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to a STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on September 24, 2018. LPA was met at the facility by Facility Administrator, Sylvia Arballo. There are currently five residents in placement. LPAs toured the facility inside and out at 9: AM. The facility consists of a common area, kitchen, pantry, laundry room, three client bedrooms, two client bathrooms, one staff bedroom, and one staff bathroom. The client bedrooms are set up so there are two clients to a bedroom and one client per bed. There is adequate closet and drawer space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water was tested in client bathroom #1 at 10: AM and registered at 118.2 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Cleaning solutions and hazardous items were observed to be stored in a locked cabinet in the staff's office. Sharp knives were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the staff's office. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet inside the staff's office. The facility's smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are electrically hard wired and observed to be operable. The fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by the administrator. LPAs observed facility posted items in the hallway that included: Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored inside a locked cabinet in the staff's office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. LPAs observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. See Page Two The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. One facility staff was interviewed during the inspection. Five clients were interviewed during the inspection. Due to the need to complete the inspection and continue staff/client file reviews, this inspection will need to be continued at later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Sylvia Arballo.

Licensing Program Analyst, Dahl Larios conducted a case management inspection on October 7, 2021, at 10:07 am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 confidential names dated October 7, 2021, were reviewed. 4 out of Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 6 youth were interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedure were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Sylvia Arballo, Administrator.

Confidential interviews reported that law enforcement was called for assistance. C1 was taken to a hospital for assessment and discharged from the hospital on May 8, 2021. On May 10, 2022, C1 was observed with several cuts on the left wrist, which were self-inflicted. However, LPA was unable to determine if the cuts were done while at the facility or at the hospital. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent regarding the allegation of lack of supervision and interviews did not provide any further specific details. Based on interviews and record reviews the allegation that staff did not adequately supervise C1, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Diana Bustamante.

Confidential staff interviews reported that once they arrived to the facility, C1 and C2 handed over a bag of marijuana and a vape pen. narrative: supervision. Specifically, it was reported that S1 grabbed C1 and that there was not enough supervision resulting in C1 going AWOL . It was also reported that C1 was observed with bruising on the forearm and hands due to staff having C1 clean toilets at the facility. During confidential interviews it was revealed that there were no observations made of S1 hitting or grabbing C1. Confidential interviews revealed that the residents are given chores to do but are always offered protective equipment such as gloves to perform these chores if the clients wish to use it. Confidential interviews revealed that the clients are never asked to clean the toilets. Additionally, confidential interviews revealed that when a client is threatening to AWOL the staff tries to will verbally redirect them and convince them to stay at the facility. If the clients leave the facility staff attempts to follow the client and take a description of what they are wearing, then an incident report is filed. No information could be obtained from C1 because their bed was closed due to the AWOL status and current whereabouts are unknown at this time. LPA was unable to obtain additional information regarding the allegations and there were lack of witnesses to the alleged incidents. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that Resident was sustained bruising while in care, Staff grabbed the resident, and Staff did not provide adequate supervision may have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and Appeals Rights were provided and explained to Facility Administrator, Diana Bustamante.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Torres conducted a case management inspection September 13, 2022 at 9:10 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated September 13, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA David Torres observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Diana Bustamante, Administrator.

On September 22, 2022 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Leslie Covarrubias and Jose Gonzalez, arrived unannounced at Tustin Family Campus Qualifying House- Female STRTP and met with Administrator, Diana Bustamante. LPAs conduced interviews for previous complaint. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

Confidential interviews also revealed that inappropriate noises were heard when S2 was locked in the bathroom or staff office when S2 goes to the bathroom or staff office. Additional, confidential interviews revealed that S2 stands at the foot of the bed staring at the clients, which causes clients to feel uncomfortable. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegations that staff (S2) hit minor (C1) while in care and staff (S2) is engaging in inappropriate behavior are substantiated. The facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 4, Personal Rights (c) (10). The facility did not ensure their dignity was accorded with staff while in care. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Administrator Diana Bustamante. Other confidential interviews denied staff not preventing clients from being absent from care and reported staff communicating the importance of not being absent without permission. Per confidential interviews, the staff is doing all they can to prevent clients from leaving the facility, and if clients do leave, staff will follow the clients to encourage them to return to the facility. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that there is no prevention made for clients to AWOL may have occurred, however, this is not supported by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Administrator Diana Bustamante.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Latricia Rogers and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection July 12, 2023 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, July 12, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, and Self Soothing Plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Rogers and LPM King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Diana Bustamante- Program Manager/Administrator.

On 08/25/2023, at 12:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Guadalupe Munoz and Jacqueline Garcia, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Facility Representative Charon Mitchell and Administrator Diana Bustamante via telephone. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a case management on a serious incident that occurred on 6/22/2023. Community Care Licensing (CCL) became aware that an incident occurred with Client #1 [refer to Confidential Names (LIC 811) dated 08/25/2023] on 6/22/2023 and was not reported to CCL till 6/26/2023. LPM Valenzuela stressed the importance of reporting incidents in a timely manner. This process is necessary to ensure the welfare and well-being of all residents that are in care. An exit interview was conducted appeal rights were reviewed and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Diana Bustamante.

narrative: On October 9, 2023, at 8: AM Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Charmaine Linley and Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced annual inspection. LPA's were met at the facility by House Parent, Flor Perez, and Program Manager, Destiny Ledesma. There are currently 5 residents in placement. LPA's toured the facility inside and out. The facility consists of a common area, kitchen, pantry, laundry room, three client bedrooms, two client bathrooms, one staff bedroom, and one staff bathroom. The client bedrooms are set up so there are two clients to a bedroom and one client per bed. There is adequate closet and drawer space for the client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water was tested in client bathroom #1 at 9: AM and registered at 105 degrees Fahrenheit and the kitchen was tested at 9: AM and registered 117 degrees Fahrenheit, which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Cleaning solutions and hazardous items were observed to be stored in a locked cabinet in the staff's office. Sharp knives were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the staff's office. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet inside the staff's office. The facility's smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are electrically hard wired and observed to be operable. The fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by the administrator. LPA's observed facility posted items in the hallway that included: Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored inside a locked cabinet in the staff's office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. LPA's observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. *** Two staff were interviewed during the inspection. Two clients were interviewed during the inspection. LPA's left the facility at 10: AM, drove to the main office at Tustin Ave Santa Ana, CA 92705 and arrived at 10: AM and reviewed a sample of five staff files. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. All staff have proof in file of acknowledging the child abuse reporting requirements (S1-5) (SEE LIC 811). LPA's left the office at 12: PM and arrived at the facility at 1: PM. LPA's reviewed five out of five client files. Client files were reviewed and all files did not have the necessary documents required per Title 22 regulations. The facility was cited for California Code of Regulations (CCR) Physical Plant 87075(b) Five of five clients did not have a Centrally Stored Medication Record completed. The facility was also cited for California Code of Regulations (CCR) Client Records 80069(a) five out of five clients did not have a medical assessment with the required information completed. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights was reviewed with Destiny Ledezma. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report will be emailed to Destiny. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: On 05/01/25, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Administrator, Destiny Ledesma, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve six ambulatory children ages 12-17 years-old and non minor dependents. The current census is six children. The Facility is current with their licensing fees. The Facility is a single story dwelling. A physical plant inspection was completed with Charon Mitchell, Senior Coach and included the following checks: kitchen, medication room, dining room, living room, den, one staff office, one leased vehicle, three bedrooms, a facility apartment for the house parents, and outdoor living space. All beds were observed with appropriate bedding and mattress in good repair. Bedrooms contained adequate drawers and closet space. No bedroom occupied more than two clients and not used for other purposes. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsman poster, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the medication room. **Continued on LIC809** **Continued from LIC809** Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are monitored through Tustin Family Campus; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. The water temperature was tested in bathroom one which measured 110 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The first aid kit was accessible to all staff and had all required supplies. All client files are stored and maintained on a secure internet database. LPA reviewed five client files out of six (C1 - C5) to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. LPA reviewed five client medication records. Per a review of Guardian, all staff listed on LIC500 dated 4/30/25 have a criminal record clearance. Staff files are stored and maintained on a secure internet database at another location called The Hub, N Tustin Avenue, Santa Ana. LPA conducted three staff interviews(S1 - S3) and two client interviews(C3 and C5). Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. No deficiencies cited during today's inspection. Due to time constraints LPA will return on another day to conduct staff file reviews at "The Hub" in Santa Ana. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Destiny Ledesma. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: On July 30, 2025, at 11:15 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Destiny Ledesma, Facility Administrator. The purpose of this inspection is for a case management involving an incident with Staff (S1), and two Clients (C1, C2). On July 24, 2025, Community Care Licensing observed a video involving S1, C1, and C2. The video footage was taken of the Cottage's back patio with windows and glass doors that were uncovered and allowed a clear view into the inside of the Cottage living area. LPA observed that on June 5, 2025, at 12:00 am, C1 knocked on the patio doors and entered the Cottage with a scooter. C1 began to ride the scooter in the living room area and S1 grabbed the scooter and C1 and S1 struggled over the scooter and S1 pulled the scooter with enough force that C1 stumbled on their feet. A few seconds later, S1 engaged in a restraint with C1, which led to C1 and S1 falling onto the ground and struggling with each other until S1 got up and walked away from C1. Based on LPA's observation of the video recording, S1 did not ensure that C1 was accorded dignity within their personal relationships with staff, due to grabbing the scooter away from C1 and engaging in a struggle over the scooter which resulted in C1 stumbling on their feet and based on LPA's observation of the video footage showing S1 mishandled C1 when S1 swept C1's leg causing C1 to transition onto the floor during the encounter which led to C1 and S1 struggling on the ground and S1 turning C1 on their back and held down until S1 got away from C1, the facility is being cited for one deficiency. The facility is cited for violating Interim Licensing Standards, STRTP, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, 87072(c)(15) Personal Rights. *** An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the facility. A signed copy of the report will be placed in the facility file.

Confidential interviews revealed that S1 and C1 were parked in an apartment complex waiting for C2 who was returning from a family pass when a shooting occurred in the area. Confidential interviews revealed that facility staff did report the incident to the facility supervisor upon return to the facility. Confidential interviews and a review of the Department's SIR database for the facility revealed that the SIR was not submitted to the Department within the required time frame. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met regarding the allegation that the facility did not report incident as required, therefore the allegation is substantiated. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the children in care. The facility will be cited for violating California Code of Regulations, Title 22, 80061 (b) Reporting Requirements. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811 dated 02/18/2021), and the appeal rights were explained and emailed to Program Administrator, Dana Centani, for signature. The original signed report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: staff treated the minor with disrespect and acts of bullying and intimidation. It was reported that staff woke minor up every fifteen minutes by pointing a light at them, which caused minor to be too tired to wake up to attend morning appointments. It was reported that the facility did not provide supplements provided by the physician to the minor. Confidential interviews revealed that staff treated C1 with dignity and respect. While other confidential interviews revealed C1 was not always treated with dignity and respect. Regarding the allegation that staff woke C1 up every fifteen minutes and pointed a light at them, confidential interviews reveal that C1 covered themselves up in a blanket and staff had to shine a flashlight towards them to ensure they were in their bed. Conflicting interviews revealed the flashlight was shined at the ceiling to illuminate the bedroom and not at C1's face. As far as the allegation that staff was not provided supplements approved by a physician, there is conflicting information. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 received physician's approval to take protein powder and facility did not allow C1 to take the protein powder. Some interviews revealed C1 had protein powder provided to them and other interviews C1 was taking other supplements provided by the physician. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed that C1 was not accorded dignity by staff and staff was not providing supplements to C1 approved by a physician, which may or may not have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was discussed with Vickie Rogers, Facility Manager. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights will be emailed to the Administrator. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

Other confidential interviews revealed that C1 phone calls with the biological parent are monitored per court order. Additional confidential interviews indicated that FS allows C1 to make and receive phone calls. Confidential interviews revealed that FS allows C1 privacy when making calls that FS does not monitor. CSW stated that C1 phone calls with C1's parent are monitored per court order. The Department also received an allegation that client #1 (C1) mental health needs are not being met. Additional confidential interviews indicated that C1 was provided therapy sessions at the facility. Confidential interviews disclosed that C1s refuse to participate in therapy. Other confidential interviews indicated that the home offered C1 different therapeutic groups and therapists. Confidential interviews disclosed that C1 was not receiving therapy. Additional confidential interviews indicated that C1 wanted to participate in therapy with a licensed therapist. It was disclosed that the facility offered C1 a therapist. It was also disclosed that C1 refused to participate in therapy. Confidential interviews reported that CSW provided C1 with an outside therapist and C1 continued to refuse. The confidential witness denied the allegation of mental health needs not being met. The Department received an allegation that Facility Staff (FS) caused client #1 (C1) to miss a scheduled court date. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 and FS arrived late to court. Additional confidential interviews indicated that the judge was upset with C1 for arriving late to court. Other confidential interviews revealed that C1 arrived at court on time. Additional confidential interviews indicated that C1 returned late to the second court session due to C1 still eating C1 lunch. A confidential witness stated that C1 never missed a court date. Additional confidential interviews disclosed that the facility did everything possible to meet C1 needs. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that Facility Staff (FS) are interfering with client #1 (C1) telephone visits, C1's mental health needs are not being met, and FS caused C1 to miss a scheduled court date may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator (AD) Diana Bustamante.
