narrative: On April 07, 2023, at 1: PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan conducted an unannounced annual inspection. LPA was met at the facility by Omar Landeros, PM Senior Coach. There are currently five residents in placement. LPA toured the facility inside and out with Victoria Rogers,AM Senior Coach. The facility consists of a common area, kitchen, pantry, laundry room, three client bedrooms, two client bathrooms, one staff bathroom, and one live in staff apartment. The apartment consisted of two bedrooms, one bathroom, one living room and a kitchen. The client bedrooms are set up so there are two clients to a bedroom and one client per bed. There is adequate closet and drawer space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. Cleaning solutions and hazardous items were observed to be stored in a locked cabinet in the staff's office. Sharp knives were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the staff's office. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet inside the staff's office. The facility's smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are electrically hard wired and observed to be operable. The fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by the Omar Landeros. LPA observed facility posted items in the hallway that included: Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. LPA reviewed client files and observed that the clients had all appropriate documents that are required per title 22 regulations. Due to the need to complete the inspection and continue staff files and staff/client interviews this inspection will need to be continued at later date and time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Omar Landeros.

This is a continuation of the annual initiated on 04/07/2023. The continuation was completed on 04/10/2023. On 04/10/23, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan arrived to the facility listed above in order to complete the client file reviews. All client's files contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. LPA interviewed staff and clients as well. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The hot water was tested in client bathroom and registered at 116.9 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA Barragan had to travel to the facilities corporate office in order to review staff files due to the staff files not being kept in the STRTP. The location was N Tustin Ave, Santa Ana, Suite 120. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Staff training were reviewed as well. LPA interviewed staff at the facility as well. No deficiency's are being issued during this visit. A copy of this report and appeal rights was discussed and provided to Gavin Hager, HR Assistant.

Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers conducted a case management inspection Tuesday, July 23, 2024, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection,10 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated July 23, 2023. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. Lpa L. Rogers observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Destiny Ledesma- Administrator

There are currently six clients in placement. LPA toured the facility inside and out with Vickie Rogers. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. The facility is a one-story residence and consists of a common area, kitchen, pantry, laundry room, three client bedrooms, two client bathrooms, one staff bathroom, and one live in staff apartment. The apartment consisted of two bedrooms, one bathroom, one living room and a kitchen. The client bedrooms are set up so there are two clients to a bedroom and one client per bed. There is adequate closet and drawer space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water was tested in bathroom #1 at 11:20 am and registered at 106 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored inside a locked cabinet in the staff office and inside a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored inside the staff office The facility's smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are electrically hard wired and observed to be operable. The fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and 2-day perishable supply of food. The hot water was tested in the kitchen at 11:50 am and registered at 118 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Vickie Rogers. LPA observed facility posted items in the hallway that included: Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. *** Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored inside a double locked cabinet in the staff's office. There is one camera at the facility located on the wall in the kitchen/living room area and one camera outside of the front door and one camera outside of the back door. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. All client files are stored and locked in the medication office. LPA reviewed five client (C1-5) files to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. LPA interviewed two clients. LPA interviewed two staff. Due to time constraints, LPA was unable to review staff files and will return at a later date. The licensing fee payments are current. Based on the facility inspection on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Vickie Rogers. LPA requested copies of an updated LIC 500 and LIC 308 to be emailed to LPA. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield made an unannounced complaint inspection with the above facility on 3/2/2021 at 9: AM. narrative: On 4/21/2021 at 3: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield, Licensing Program manager (LPM) Saxon Turner, and Regional Program Manager (RPM) Nelson Martinez, met with Tyler House representatives; Director of youth and family services for Encompass, Lindsay Steigner, program Administrator Janet Martin, and Quality Improvement Manager Linda Alves. The purpose of this meeting was to conduct a Case Management inspection. This inspection was conducted to present Enhanced Civil Penalties (ECPs). On 4/22/2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint (Control #26-CR-20200422101443) alleging a 13-year-old client (C1) had been sexually assaulted by an 18-year-old client (C2) (See LIC 811-Confidential Names List dated 4/22/2021. The complaint was investigated by CCL's Investigation Bureau (IB). At the time of the investigation, the police report was unavailable. Based on interviews conducted, IB came back with a finding of Unsubstantiated and findings were delivered on 8/21/2020. In November 2020, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Saxon Turner received information from the Santa Cruz County Juvenile Probation Department that C2 was in jail and awaiting trial for the sexual assault of C1. Based on this new information, a request was made to IB to re-open the investigation, which occurred on 11/30/2020. Based on additional interviews conducted with staff and clients, as well as in addition to obtained reports, including the police report, sometime prior to 4/11/2020, C2 forced C1 to orally copulate him in the facility living room when no staff were present. On or around 4/11/2020, C2 again tried to force C1 to orally copulate him, which C1 refused. C2 then forced C1 to masturbate him. Upon C2 ejaculating, C1 wiped her hand on the couch pillow. This second occurance happened while staff was in the living room; however, staff acknowledged he was not paying adequate attention to the clients. C1 informed staff on 4/21/2020 that she had been sexually assaulted. Staff contacted the Santa Cruz County Police Department (SCPD), who came to the facility and interviewed clients, as well as collected the facility couch pillow that C1 indicated would have DNA evidence on it. Testing on the pillow concluded that the DNA on the pillow was a match for C2. The SCPD issued a warrant for C2's arrest for sexual assault. Based on the evidence in this investigation, C1, a minor, was sexually assaulted by C2, an adult, due to a lack of care and supervision. On 3/2/21, the facility was issued the substantiated findings and a citation under Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Article 6, Section 87078(a)-Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. During a Non-Compliance Conference conducted on 3/16/21, licensee was informed that the issuance of an ECP based on Health and Safety Code 1548(f)(1)(C)(i) and (f)(1)(F)(2) was still being determined. CCL has conducted an analysis and has determined that an ECP is warranted for sexual abuse due to a lack of care and supervision under Penal Code 11165.1(b)(2) & (4). Today, 4/21/2021, CCL is issuing an ECP per Health and Safety Code 1548(f)(1)(C)(i) for $2,500.00.

Upon arrival LPA Belfield was greeted by staff Eddie M. who conducted a tour of the facility with this LPA. Observed at the time of this inspection were; client files, management visit checklist forms, program policies and procedures and management schedules. LPA Belfield also conducted interviews with two staff. During the inspection LPA obtained copies of the clients needs and services plans along with the signatures of staff reviews. LPA Belfield and administrator Martin discussed the current clients placed with Tyler House and that a new client was going to be placed within the week. A review of the management checklist shows that management regularly checks in on the facility and assist staff and ensures clients are receiving proper supervision. Staff are also provided with program cell phones in order to communicate when necessary and their private cell phones are locked and stored in the office. Based on interviews with two staff, communications with administrator Martin, and observations made in the facility, the program is currently following all guidelines described in the non-compliance conference. No violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, or Interim Licensing Standards were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with administrator Janet Martin and a copy of this report will be sent to administrator Janet Martin.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted an unannounced annual inspection at T&T House of Champions. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 30, 2020 . During the inspection, LPA met with Terry Pace Administrator as well as additional facility personnel. The STRTP is licensed to serve 6 clients. The facility consists of 3 bedrooms (3 for clients and 1 for staff) and 2 bathrooms. At 2: PM, LPA Rollins toured the facility with Administrator inside and out. Kitchen is clean. Water measured 113.4 degrees F. The facility has plenty of non perishable and perishable food supply. Medication and knives are locked away. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are up to date and working. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. There are no bodies of water on the property. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Personal rights, floor plan, food menu and Emergency disaster forms were posted in clear view. There were no Title 22 violations regarding physical plant observed at this time. three client files were reviewed. LPA observed all three client files and found no deficiencies. Needs and services plan are updated. The documentation is in the clients files are complete. LPA observed medication logs to be updated and current. LPA observed 12 staff files and found no deficiencies. Staff have completed there 40 hours annual training. All staff documentation is current. LPA interview staff about policy and program rules. LPA discussed with Administrator overview of required Core Services and Supports and based upon inspection of facility records. Licensee appears to be meeting requirements. Per Title Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during the inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

narrative: On 6/27/22 at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Ng and George Karkazis conducted an unannounced case management inspection at T&T House of Champions and spoke with Tracy Rawlins, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident involving sexual interactions between two clients and the use of restraints. LPA Ng received a completed report from Investigations Branch (IB) regarding complaint # 14-CR-20220214120547. After reviewing the report, C2 and C3 disclosed a sexual interaction they had when a staff member went to the bathroom for 10-15 minutes. When IB reviewed camera footage, it shows that the staff was in the office from 1801 hours to 1959 hours talking on the phone. During confidential interviews conducted by IB, it was reported that staff would use improper restraints during escalated incidents. Based on a review of the facilities Program Statement under Precautions To Protect Child Or NMD And Others, it says, T&T utilizes restraints as a last resort. All staff are trained in CPI, in the event that youth is an immediate danger to self and others, and all de-escalation strategies did not work, then staff will engage in restraint procedures. FM stated that they had a recent training in regards to restraints. They watched videos, shared methods on effective ways to de-escalate youth before using restraint as their resort, and safety precautions. LPA Ng requested training to be sent by July 4th at 4: PM. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision. One deficiency was cited. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and sent to Tracy Rawlins, Facility Manager.

Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the group home has bugs. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, regulation , 80088 (f) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. An exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Britanee Windom conducted a case management inspection on 08/03/22 at 9: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth were interviewed.(See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, August 03, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, monthly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma informed and evidence based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Windom observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. LPA Windom mentioned to Administrator Terry Pace that the Board of Director Meeting Minutes provided to LPA Windom had updated information about specific incidences that occurred. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Terry Pace.

On 3-1-23 2:42PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted a case management inspection to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) for a violation found during an investigation at the facility. LPA met with Facility Manager Tracy Rawlins. On 10/27/2022, the Department of Social Services, Community Care Licensing Division concluded an investigation into the allegation that the facility staff (S1) (See LIC Confidential Names List, dated (11-1-2022) caused injuries to minor (C1). The injuries included (C1) being stabbed by (S1). (C1) sustained a one-centimeter stab wound to the left abdominal wall, probable two inches, and a two-centimeter laceration over the client's lateral and proximal hand and forearm. Based on confidential interviews conducted during the investigation on 10/26/22, an incident occurred at the facility between (C1) and (S1). (C1) was upset with (S1) and threatened (S1) and started hitting the staff member, which resulted in (S1) stabbing (C1) in the left abdomen. The facility contacted the authorities, and (C1) was transported to the hospital by ambulance. (IB) obtained the medical records and police report. The medical records show that the client sustained a one-centimeter stab wound to the left abdominal wall, probable two inches, and a two-centimeter laceration over the client's lateral and proximal hand forearm. On 02/10/2023, the Department issued substantiated findings and a citation of Title 22, Division 6, Health and Safety Code 1568.092. The Department has concluded an analysis of applicable laws and regulations and has determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted for a violation resulting in physical abuse. Therefore, on this date 3-1-23 pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1548(f)(1)(C), the Department has issued a civil penalty of $2,500. See LIC 421, dated 3-1-23. The above information and appeal rights were discussed during the meeting, and a copy of this LIC 809 report, the referenced LIC 811 and LIC 421, and the appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager Tracy Rawlins whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

continued from LIC The medical records show that the client sustained a one-centimeter stab wound to the left abdominal wall, probable two inches, and a two-centimeter laceration over the client's lateral and proximal hand forearm. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the staff caused injuries to a minor in care. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility, and deficiencies were cited. The facility was cited for Health and Safety Code 1568. Conduct Inimical. At this time, the case is being reviewed for enhanced civil penalties. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Tracy Rawlins, Facility Manager..

narrative: On 9-13-23 12:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Case Management /Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) inspection at T&T House of Champions, and met with Terry Pace, Facility Administrator. On 6-30-23, Community Care Licensing held a Non-compliance conference. The purpose of the inspection was to review the progress of the facility since the facility had their NCC. The facility will be on NCC until 11-30-25. Inspections shall occur quarterly. The following conditions were stated and discussed during today's inspection and also during the NCC. Licensee agrees to do the following in order to bring the facility into compliance: 1. CRIMINAL RECORD CLEARANCE Ensure that all employees are fingerprint cleared, ( "Eligible Clearance", in Guardian ) no exceptions, before they begin employment at the facility. The facility to submit LIC 500 quarterly, starting 5-1-2023. LPA checked current LIC 500 against Guardian Roster. All staff have fingerprint clearance. 2. SUPERVISION REQUIREMENTS Facility Manager shall be present on site at all times when Facility Administrator is not present. Staffing levels shall be maintained at 1:3 ratio, and increased based on clients' needs, in order to maintain client/staff safety as needed. Plan has been received and is on file, LIC 500 indicates one facility manager on duty at all shifts and one direct care staff, except for overnight shift. 3. TRAINING REQUIREMENTS Quarterly training to begin June 1, 2023. in the following areas: trauma informed de-escalation techniques, restraint holds such as CPI or ProAct. . Quarterly training to be conducted by an outside company and not the Licensee. Training documents readily available on request by CCL. Observed training topics de-escalation, knowing triggers, signs of trauma and how to approach 6-1-23. Terry Pace stated that the next training topic will be CPI holds. continued on LIC 809-C continued from LIC 809 4. PROGRAM STATEMENT/PLAN OF OPERATION/ TO SUBMIT UPDATES Licensee shall update the Emergency Intervention PLan (EIP) within the T&T House of Champions Program Statement, and to include when to call 911 for assistance policy. Also, update all areas in PS/POO to reflect version 4 of PS/POO. Submitted and on file. 5. STAFF SELECTION REQUIREMENTS Facility to create a plan to enhance screening process to hire employees to include: checking references, use of LIC Form, create a questionnaire that checks the interactions with clients, staff, work performance, create work simulation questions during interview process. Terry Pace has created an assesment sheet for the interview. They are simulation based questions, such as: What if a client calls swears at you and calls you a name? How do you handle it? If a client is breaking a house rule, how do you handle it? If a client doesn't want to go to school because they have no clean clothes, how do you handle it. What do you do if a client becomes violent and destroys property and is a danger to self and others? Terry Pace provided a copy of the simulation sheet. 6. INSPECTIONS The facility is subject to increased unannounced inspections to ensure compliance. During today's inspection, the facilty was clean and in good repair. Staff and clients interacted peacefully 7. TSP Referral The facility was offered TSP referral. Terry Pace has enrolled in the program. Terry stated that the program is very helpful and had one session. They discussed head of service issues, hiring practices.

narrative: On 9/19/2023, at 11:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced continuation Psychotropic Medication Inspection to the listed facility. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Ng met with Terry Pace, Administrator. LPA Ng looked at 5 staff files. LPA reviewed training related to psychotropic medication and medication management. All files were observed to be complete. No clients were present during the inspection. LPA Ng will interview all three clients at their school. At this time, no deficiencies were cited. LPA conducted exit interview with Terry Pace, Administrator, at PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

continued from LIC Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff did not obtain child's records at admittance to ensure that child's basic needs were met. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation that staff did not ensure that child had required psychotropic medications: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff and clients. Interviewees provided inconsistent information. Some interviewees stated that the client was not prescribed or on medication at admittance while other interviewees stated they should have psychotropic medication. LPA conducted document research and found no evidence of client requiring psychotropic medication. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff did not ensure that child had required psychotropic medications. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation that staff do not prevent inappropriate sexual behavior between children: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff and clients. Interviewees provided inconsistent information. All clients state that inappropriate behavior is not allowed, does not happen, and describe methods staff uses to prevent it. Some staff state that inappropriate behavior is attempted and stopped, while other staff state it occurs and staff do nothing to prevent it. LPA conducted document research and found that staff prevented inappropriate sexual behavior. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff do not prevent inappropriate sexual behavior between children. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Tracy Rawlins, Facility Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On 9-22-23 10:37AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted an unannounced inspection at T&T House of Champions and met with Tracy Rawlins Facility Manager, who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the complaint findings. During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff and clients. Consistent information was provided. All interviewees stated that the staff member was working alone with three clients. The facility manager arrived for assistance after the incident occurred. LPA conducted document research. Law enforcement reports state that the staff member was working alone with three clients. The facility manager arrived for assistance after the incident occurred. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that insufficient staffing to meet the needs of children in care. Therefore, the above allegation is SUBSTANTIATED. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility, and deficiencies were cited. The facility was cited ILS, Article 6, Personnel Requirements, 87065(f). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Tracy Rawlins, Facility Manager. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 12-5-23 12:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Case Management /Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) inspection at T&T House of Champions, and met with Terry Pace, Facility Administrator. On 6-30-23, Community Care Licensing held a Non-compliance conference. The purpose of the inspection was to review the progress of the facility since the facility had their NCC. The facility will be on NCC until 11-30-25. Inspections shall occur quarterly. The following conditions were stated and discussed during today's inspection and also during the NCC. There were no clients present during the inspection. Licensee agrees to do the following in order to bring the facility into compliance: 1. CRIMINAL RECORD CLEARANCE Ensure that all employees are fingerprint cleared, ( "Eligible Clearance", in Guardian ) no exceptions, before they begin employment at the facility. The facility to submit LIC 500 quarterly, starting 5-1-2023. LPA checked current LIC 500 against Guardian Roster. All staff have fingerprint clearance as of 12-5-23, updated LIC 500 provided. 2. SUPERVISION REQUIREMENTS Facility Manager shall be present on site at all times when Facility Administrator is not present. Staffing levels shall be maintained at 1:3 ratio, and increased based on clients' needs, in order to maintain client/staff safety as needed. Plan has been received and is on file, LIC 500 indicates one facility manager on duty at all shifts and one direct care staff, except for overnight shift. 3. TRAINING REQUIREMENTS Quarterly training to begin June 1, 2023. in the following areas: trauma informed de-escalation techniques, restraint holds such as CPI or ProAct. . Quarterly training to be conducted by an outside company and not the Licensee. Training documents readily available on request by CCL. LPA observed training: Trauma continued on LIC 809-C continued from LIC 809 to Children Exposed to Violence and Indirect Violence, conducted 10-26-23. On 11-4-23, CPI Training was conducted. 4. PROGRAM STATEMENT/PLAN OF OPERATION/ TO SUBMIT UPDATES Licensee shall update the Emergency Intervention Plan (EIP) within the T&T House of Champions Program Statement, and to include when to call 911 for assistance policy. Also, update all areas in PS/POO to reflect version 4 of PS/POO. Submitted and on file. 5. STAFF SELECTION REQUIREMENTS Facility to create a plan to enhance screening process to hire employees to include: checking references, use of LIC Form, create a questionnaire that checks the interactions with clients, staff, work performance, create work simulation questions during interview process. Terry Pace has created an assessment sheet for the interview. They are simulation based questions, such as: What if a client calls swears at you and calls you a name? How do you handle it? If a client is breaking a house rule, how do you handle it? If a client doesn't want to go to school because they have no clean clothes, how do you handle it. What do you do if a client becomes violent and destroys property and is a danger to self and others? Terry Pace provided a copy of the simulation sheet. 6. INSPECTIONS The facility is subject to increased unannounced inspections to ensure compliance. During today's inspection, the facility was clean and in good repair. There were no clients present during the inspection. 7. TSP Referral The facility was offered TSP referral. Terry Pace has enrolled in the program. LPA asked Terry Pace what she got out of TSP. She said that the TSP Program gave her a different way of looking at different situations and approaches. Terry mentioned that the facilitator was a former administrator, which made training more meaningful.

On 08/28/2024 at 1:15 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brenda Rodriguez conducted an announced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the SB Psychotropic Medications Inspection. LPA Rodriguez met with Terry Pace, Administrator. The facility currently has a census of two clients in care who meet the SB484 inspection criteria. At 2:55 p.m., LPA Rodriguez observed Cresenia Allen, Facility Manager to conduct a pill count of the psychotropic medications. LPA Rodriguez did not observe deficiencies with the pill counts. LPA observed that the medications were kept in a locked cabinet inside of a locked room. LPA Rodriguez received and reviewed four staff files. LPA Rodriguez found no deficiencies. LPA Rodriguez conducted two staff confidential interviews. The SB Psychotropic Medications Inspection is not currently finished, LPA Rodriguez will interview both clients at a later date and time. LPA Rodriguez conducted an exit interview with Terry Pace, Administrator at 3:20 p.m. The signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On 9-13-24 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Terry Pace, Administrator and toured the facility inside and out. The Short Term Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve 6 clients. Present during the inspection were 2 staff and 1 client. At 10:45AM LPA Karkazis reviewed client and staff files. During staff file review, S1 did not have LIC Health Screening Form. S1,S4,S5, did not have a current CPR Certificate. During client file review, C1 and C2 did not have updated needs and service plans. At 1:30PM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 110 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 71 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in the locked office in a locked cabinet. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed 1 staff and no clients, client refused. At 2:00PM LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. continued on LIC 809-C continued from LIC The facility is being cited for California Code of Regulations 80066(a)(10) Health Screening, Interim Licensing Standards 87065.1(d)(6) Supervision, Evaluation, and Training Requirements (CPR), and Interim Licensing Standards 87068.3(a) Modification To Needs and Service Plans. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed/provided and a copy of this report was given to Terry Pace, Administrator.

narrative: On June 2, 2021 at 09: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Claudia Portillo and Jenny Mundo conducted a Case Management (SB Psychotropic Medications) tele-inspection of the facility via Microsoft Teams Meeting app. Remote "tele-inspections" of facilities are a part of Community Care Licensing Division's emergency response to the spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). During this tele-inspection, LPAs spoke with Kim Hundnall, Executive Director/Administrator, Paul Crews, Program Director/Administrator and Rosemary England, Facility Manager/Rehab Specialist. narrative: An unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jenny Mundo and Pamela Silva on February 3, 2022 at 9:30am. During the inspection, LPAs met with Kim Hudnall, Administrator. LPAs and Administrator inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed four (4) children's records on site at the facility at 10:05 am. LPAs reviewed two (2) staff personnel files on site at the facility at 11:10 am. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff on site at 11:30 am. LPAs were unable to interview children at the time of the inspection due to the children being at school. LPAs provided the Summary Report to Kim Hudnall, Administrator upon completion. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs conducted exit interview with the administrator at around 12:10 pm.

Additionally, the clients were unable to provide supportive documentation to support that they complained to anyone and clients denied ever observing anyone being mishandled while in a restraint. Interviews conducted with another client had similar statements of an incident occurring where they observed a child being restrained by staff. However, this third client was unable to specify the details of why staff restrained the client or if client was in distress based on the restraint. Another client stated that one staff did grab and restrained them till the point of almost breaking their arm. Client identified two staff members who conducted the restraint; however, client was unable to provide any witnesses that could attest to how the staff handled them during the restraint or when it specifically happened. Staff stated that multiple incidents have occurred with one client where client was having an issue of acting out causing harm to others and client was not listening to staff's redirection. Staff had similar recollections in stating that in these incidents that occurred client was restrained with their arms placed behind their back and staff asked client if they had calmed, client stated they had calmed so staff released them from the hold. However, staff stated once client was released client started attacking staff again. Client was placed back in the same restrained position until client in fact was calmed down. Staff stated client was checked over and did not express any discomfort or present with any injury. Staff stated that when clients are acting out in self injurious or harmful behaviors to others, they do place clients in restrained positions of holding the client's arms behind their back till they are calmed and listening for redirection. However, staff denied twisting a client's arm to the point of breaking or almost breaking client's arm. Staff had similar statements in that if a client calls out in distress of any sort during the restrained period staff release the client. Staff further stated that they consistently ask client if they have calmed to release them from the restrained position. LPA reviewed incident reports and supportive documents provided by facility and no complaints were made or incidents documented where a client was taken to the hospital for injuries after being placed in a restraint. LPA was unable to contact county social worker, but no documents identified a problem with clients placed in the home or facility staff. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: It was alleged that C1 was hit, handled in a rough manner, and spoken to inappropriately by S2 during an alleged physical altercation. Information obtained from confidential interviews with the above individuals revealed that an incident did occur involving S2 and C1. S2 denied the alleged allegations stating that C1 was questioned regarding C1's soiled garments and the feces left in the washer. S2 indicated that C1 was verbally redirected to C1's room after being belligerent and giving S2 the middle finger. S2 indicated that C1 walked towards the room and started breaking items in the room and attempted to stab S2 with a pencil. S2 further indicated that a standing MAB hold was attempted however C1 dropped to the floor and at this point, S2 was replaced by S3 to de-escalate the situation. Information obtained from S3 and S4 indicated that C1 has behavioral and defiant difficulties, which are addressed via a plan to assist C1 with finding alternative ways to self-deescalate. S1 denied the allegations further stating that the information reported to the hotline by (S1) was not accurately documented by the screener due to having S2 as the aggressor and punching C1 which is not accurate. S2 provided LPA with several SIR's involving C1 and notating aggressive behavior, as well as a letter from the Head of Services to the Department of Human Services, expressing concerns due to C1's conduct and its effect on staff and other residents' safety. Information obtained from C2, C3, and C4 denied the alleged allegation indicating that C1 was the aggressor. During interviews with C2, C3, and C4, it was further disclosed that staff are very professional with them and provides whatever is needed. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Facility Representative. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the Facility Representative.

narrative: On July 11,2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted a case management inspection at the STRTP and met with Kim Hudnall, Administrator The purpose of the inspection was to address violations that were revealed during the investigation of complaint 32-CR- During the investigation it was discovered that an incident report was not submitted to the Department regarding C AWOL. This is in violation of Title Division Chapter Article 6, 80061(b)(1)(E) on Reporting Requirements. A deficiency citation is being issued, see LIC809D. The staff members (S1, S2, and S3) refuted the allegations, asserting that all staff members are trained in trauma-informed care and have completed a sixteen-hour course on the Management of Assaultive Behavior (MAB) focused on crisis negotiation and intervention. The staff indicated that the facility is hands-off and will only use MAB intervention to prevent clients from self-harming or to prevent bodily injuries to others. The staff further disclosed that on the day of the alleged incident, S2 did restrain C1 from behind due to C1 attempting to strike S1 in the face with a closed fist, and in doing so, slipped and fell to the ground with C1. S2 noted that they remained on the floor for no more than ten to fifteen seconds before S1 assisted them in getting back on their feet and escorted C1 to their room without further incident. S2 indicated that no injuries were sustained, and the incident was reported promptly to all supporting agencies. The statement received from C1 revealed that they became aggressive towards the staff and tried to hit S1 in the face with a closed fist after being instructed to return to their room because of their inappropriate conduct at school. C1 denied sustaining any injuries during the incident and subsequently retracted the allegations during the interview. Information gathered from C2 and C3 confirmed that they were present during the incident and corroborated the details provided by the staff. C1, C2, and C3 expressed that they feel safe living in the facility and believe that the staff is helping them achieve their personalized plans. Additionally, CSW1 mentioned that the facility staff are highly attentive and supportive, frequently communicating with them about matters concerning C1. CSW1 further disclosed that they have no concerns regarding the care and supervision provided by the facility staff for their client. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation(s) is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the STRTP Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the STRTP Facility Administrator.

The investigation revealed that when FM#2 allegedly pushed Ref. #1, Ref. #1's hip began to hurt. It revealed that Ref. #1 recently had surgery of the hip. Ref. #1 denied being hurt. There was evidence that Ref. #1 went outside to play after the so-called incident. There were no witnesses to this allegation and the LPA was unable to corroborate it. There was an allegation that Ref. #1 was fat shamed by FM#1. FM#1 denied the allegation. FM#2 did not overhear FM#1 fat shame Ref. #1. There were no witnesses to this allegation. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. The investigation revealed that the CSW spoke with the facility staff immediately after the incident and informed the LPA that Ref. #1 was displaying defiant, disrespectful and aggressive behavior due to an in-home suspension which was the result of Ref. #1 beating up another client with developmental disabilities. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint along with the appeal rights were emailed to Ms. Hudnall.

narrative: On March 11, 2021 at 9:00AM, Humberto Flores and Jenny Mundo, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) conducted an announced Senate Bill 484 (SB484) Psychotropic Medication Inspection at Unicorn Gardens # Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Paul Crews, Administrator, via Microsoft Team Meetings Application and phone calls. The SB Inspection started on March 11, 2021 at 9:00AM. The inspection resumed on March 12, 2021, at 4:30PM. On 3/11/2021, LPAs Flores and Mundo conducted a tour inside and out of the facility at 9:00AM. No deficiency was observed. The STRTP has two days of perishable food and 5 days of nonperishable for the client in placement and the capacity of the STRTP. All medications are centrally stored, locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. LPA Flores and Mundo conducted interviews with 3 staffs at 9:30AM LPA Flores and Mundo conducted interviews with 4 children at 11:30AM and 1:00PM. LPA Flores and Mundo conducted a review of the 4 children's file at 10:00AM. The Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) for the last 2 months was reviewed. The PMARs contain the initials and signatures of part of the staffs that administer psychotropic medication. LPA Flores and Mundo observed that Child's Ref #4 (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 3/12/21) PMAR for medication Ref #1, on 2/4/21, the staff's initials are circled because C4 did not take the medication, but there is no notation in the back of the form to explain the reason why C4 did not take the medication. cont.# LPA Flores and Mundo observed that the 4 children's Needs and Services Plan (NSPs) was signed by the County Social Workers (CSWs) / Legal Representative. No deficiency was found. LPA Flores and Mundo reviewed the Program Statement (PS) and Plan of Operation (POO) of the STRTP. LPA Flores and Mundo conducted a review of 3 staff's' file. No deficiency was found. There is adequate staffing in the facility to provide care and supervision for the clients per facility's Plan of Operation/Program Statement. A copy of this report, and LIC811s was provided to the STRTP representative upon completion. LPA Flores conducted exit interview with STRTP representative.

It was alleged that an unknown facility staff had a sexual relationship with a client. Confidential statements obtained did not provide sufficient information to corroborate the allegation of sexual abuse by staff at the facility. All facility staff interviewed denied the allegation of subjecting a client to sexual abuse or witnessing any abuse at the facility. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

On July 22, 2025, at 12:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Humberto Flores, conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at Unicorn Short Therapeutic Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Executive Director Kim Hudnall. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information about the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). The STRTP reported that on 03/10/2025, Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 07/22/2025) was restrained because he charged Staff Ref #1 (S1) at the STRTP. During interviews with Administrator Kim Hudnall and Head of Services Mike Lyons, it was reported that C1 was caught at school watching adult content in the school computer and once he arrived at the facility was informed that the incident will be reflected in his behavior chart. C1 got upset and started to use profanities and throw things at S1, after C1 charged S1, C1 was placed in a restrain. The SIR did not specify who the staff that conducted the restraint was, nor the starting time of the restraint. After a review of the SIR LPA Flores determined that the facility did not meet the requirements in Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 5, Section 87061 (i) (7). An Advisory Note/Technical Violation was issued. A copy of this report, LIC9102 and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

On July 22, 2025, at 1:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Humberto Flores, conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at Unicorn Short Therapeutic Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Executive Director Kim Hudnall. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information about the incident below reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). The STRTP reported that on 03/08/2025, Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 07/22/2025) was banging on the walls and calling the staff names from his room. The staff had C1 come out to do a time-out in the kitchen, so he does not keep disturbing the other youth. C1 refused to go to the kitchen. The staff began to guide him to the kitchen for his time-out and C1 started to scratch and bite the staff. Due to C1 unsafe behavior and for staff protection the staff used a safety hold for approximately five minutes. The SIR did not state clearly who the staff that conducted the restraint was, how the hold was conducted and what part of C1's body was held by the staff involved, nor the starting time of the restraint. Staff Ref #1 (S1) and Ref #2 (S2) conducted the restraint. After a review of the SIR LPA Flores observed that the facility did not meet the requirements in Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 5, Section 87061 (i) (7). An Advisory Note/Technical Violation was issued. The STRTP representative stated that a training regarding "Reporting Requirements" for restrain will be conducted. cont.# A copy of this report, LIC9102 and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

S1's eyesight (when attempting to leave the facility unauthorized) and therefore the authorized representative did not need to be called. Further, staff understand that they are to notify the clients authorized representative (placement agency social worker) when clients leave the facility unauthorized. Staff also communicated that they notify their administrator and their agency social worker. Additional interviews with BPDP1 revealed that C1 runs away from the facility very often and is not aware that the authorized representative was notified of C1 leaving the facility; as BPDP1 was unsure of who the authorized representative was. BPDP1 states the restaurant down the street found the child and called the police and BPDP1 called CPS. Based on information obtained by LPA Palmer, there is not a preponderance of evidence to support the allegation, therefore, the allegation(s) is unsubstantiated. No deficiency cited. Copies of the following reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection: LIC 9099, LIC 9099-C.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an announced visit to the facility and met with Administrator Sky Gray and Program Manager Easter-Dawson. Also participating the inspection were Regional Manager (RM) Nelson Martinez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Isabel Mendoza. The purpose of the inspection was to review the planned addition of a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program facility to their existing operation. Prior to the visit, LPA Bertoli made a pre-screening COVID call, and Administrator Gray indicated they did not have any positive cases currently or known exposures or symptomatic persons. The facility was toured inside and out, including the administrative offices. The facility appears to be clean, safe, and sanitary. The current facility includes two wings for residential use and a common cafeteria between the residential wings. A large patio and playground surround the building. A review was done of which areas will be kept separate between the facilities, and which areas will be shared, and how the populations will be kept separate and supervised. The automated No Title 22 deficiencies were cited on this visit. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Gray and a copy of this report was left with the facility.

met_with: Mary Gray, Sharene Kacyra, and Briana Downey
narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with Briana Downey, Sky Gray, and Sharene Kacyra. This Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program is a one-story facility located in a building that is shared with their Temporary Shelter Care facility. The two facilities are kept in separate wings with their dining area in between. The facilities have separate dining times. Separation of youth is maintain by electronic system and key access by staff. The facility consists of 16 client bedrooms plus a bedroom for isolation due to illness and 8 client bathrooms, living areas, recreational room, shared kitchen, and office. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is no pool on the premises. Firearms are not allowed on the facility premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers and Smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors are throughout the facility and operational. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was in compliance. Hot water temperature measured at 117 degrees Fahrenheit. Staff records are accessible and kept at a separate office. Client records are electronic. Medications will be centrally stored and locked in the medication room. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked away from foods. Knives and sharps will be kept locked in the kitchen. The facility is found to be acceptable for a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program. This facility is licensed as of today, 6/5/23. LPA will mail Administrator a copy of the license. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the Facility Evaluation Report was given to the facility.

investigation_findings: 13On 12/10/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of delivering findings from a complaint investigation. At 2:40pm LPA met with met with Clinical Manager, Jaime Ott and informed Clinical manager the purpose of this visit. The Department received a complaint alleging staff inappropriately restrained minor in care and staff did not allow minor to use the restroom. LPA reviewed documentation and conducted confidential interviews. After the review of documentation and interviews with relevant parties, it was found that the allegations could not be corroborated due to inconsistent statements obtained. Although the allegations staff inappropriately restrained minor in care and staff did not allow minor to use the restroom may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 04/16/2021, an unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian at 9:00AM. During the inspection, LPA met with John Addington, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via FaceTime. narrative: On October 29, 2021, Licensing Program Analysts Rachel Bruce and Priscilla Zamudio (LPAs) arrived at Valley Teen Ranch for the purpose of conducting an unannounced annual inspection. On November 1, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst Rachel Bruce arrived at the Administrative Office of Valley Teen Ranch for the purpose of discussing the plans for the above STRTP. Currently the home is not accepting residents and would not be in the near future due to staffing issues/challenges. The staff currently is serving at the other home ( Rd 35) and serving the population at that residence. There are long term options to consider for the home at this time. The goal is not to surrender the license at this time to keep options open and to serve the clientele when necessary. The house is currently being renovated and Ms. Evans will notify CCL when clients can be accepted and an inspection will be completed at that time. The house will be physically ready within 14 days however staffing issues will not be resolved that quickly. Juanita Arroyo, Licensing Program Manager, was present on a phone conference during this visit. Ms. Arroyo will look into the options and will be conferring with the Regional office to determine the appropriateness for the tentative plan and the STRTP remaining in compliance. Other issues discussed included changing Administrators and decreasing capacity on the other home. Ms. Evans to follow up with LPA Bruce and submit correspondence accordingly.

narrative: On 06/24/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted an annual inspection at the above facility. Met at the facility by Administrator John Addington and Social Workers David Carrera and Kim Gearhart. Currently there are 7 clients at the facility. Client files were inspected on this date. Staff files are at the corporate office and will be inspected at a later time. Clients are not home as they are attending school. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazard. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Hot water measured 113 degrees. There are no firearms or pets at the facility. There is a pool at the other home on the facility grounds that is currently under renovation. The other home is under renovation and clients are not currently placed at that home. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. A copy of this report is left at the facility.

On March 17, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection and spoke with John Addington, Program Administrator. The purpose of the case management was to discuss an incident reported submitted to Community Care Licensing on April 7, 2022. Per the report, on March 30, 2022 a staff member transporting a client from Juvenile Hall failed to secure the client's medication in the lock box located in the back of the van. During a stop for gas, the client was left alone momentarily and confiscated the medication. The theft was noticed when logging the client's medication upon his arrival at the facility. The client returned the medication he had taken and no pills were missing. The staff member was subsequently retrained on the transportation of residents protocol. Additional training was highlighted during the staff's weekly training session. Based on the information obtained the agency is being cited for a personal rights violation. medication storage violation. See confidential names list attached. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to the agency.

On December 9, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce travelled to the facility listed above to conduct an initial pre licensing inspection. Facility Inspection conducted. Purpose of inspection is to issue a new license for decreased capacity, no program change or operational changes at this time. LPA was met at the facility by Administrator , David Carrera, 1. Facility Grounds inspected and observed to be free from hazard with appropriate activity space observed. 2. Chemicals, medications, and sharp objects are all stored in separate locked cabinets. 3. Observed locked cabinet inside locked closet for central storage of medications. Observed first aid kit and manual. 4. Individual beds and bedrooms are in good repair along with an appropriate amount of storage space. 5. Both House 1 and House 2 have 5 bedrooms each sufficient for double occupancy. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 6. Adequate food storage space observed. Perishable and non- perishable foods were observed at this time and found to meet regulatory requirements.. 7. Dining room observed with appropriate table and chairs. 8.. Licensee has a vehicle for use at the facility with appropriate insurance and registration. 9. Fire Clearance is pending. Facility has met requirements for initial licensure for decreased capacity. STRTP license to be issued reflecting capacity decrease from 20 to 16.

February 16, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted a case management visit at the above STRTP and met with Administrator, John Addington. The purpose of the visit is to issue a citation regarding dispensing medication to the clients in care. On February 3, LPA Bruce received an incident report which indicated a child was found with a bag of crushed pills in the pocket of his jeans. The client disclosed that he had been 'cheeking' his morning and nighttime medication. The term 'cheeking' refers to hiding the medication in his cheek and not swallowing. Client further explained that the crushes the medication and puts the powder in water to get high. A review of the STRTP's medication dispensing procedures indicates the staff will check the client's mouth after providing medication to ensure that the pill had been swallowed and not hidden. In this particular case, the client was able to hid the medication in his throat despite drinking water and the staff checking. Increased monitoring will be put in place with this client and if necessary protocol will be changed. Administrator will check in with LPA to communicate the efficiency of the current procedures in place. Please see LIC811 for confidential names list. No citations issued at today's visit.

On August 16, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce arrived at Valley Teen Ranch STRTP for an unannounced inspection for the purpose of delivering a case management report. On July 6, 2022 a minor in the facility was having an uneasy day and night. Ultimately this led to a verbal and physical altercation with another youth. Two staff intervened to separate the youths resulting in one staff member using excess force and placing the child in an inappropriate hold. The Sheriff department was called and at the conclusion of the incident, the staff member was placed on leave. On July 15, 2022 the staff member in question met with administration and accepted his termination without incident. A deficiency is bing issued today for the inappropriate restraint. On March 14, 2023, LPA Bruce arrived at Valley Teen Ranch STRTP for an unannounced inspection and met again with Jon Addington. The purpose of the visit today is to amend the citation code. The deficiency remains the same.

On February 16, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted a case management visit at the above STRTP and met with Administrator, John Addington. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd visited the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on February 26, 2024 for the purpose of clarifying recent incident reports. Client was seen with a white powder substance on 11/27/23, telling staff that he had gotten it from another client's medication. Staff Carrera told LPA that they check each client as they take their meds and verify that it is swallowed before the client leaves their sight. On this occasion, the client that had the white powder stated that he had gotten it from another client. Staff took extra precautions after this event, with that client, to ensure that his medications were swallowed appropriately. Client was questioned on 12/27/23 regarding the use of bleach while he was doing laundry. Staff had given the client bleach so he could add to his load of wash, but the client then took the bleach and added it to another client's clothes. Staff keeps the bleach locked in a cabinet, no client's have access to this cabinet.

narrative: On 12/02/2021 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an announced inspection at the above facility. LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Lance Hickman and Chief Operating Officer (COO) Drew Dahlstedt. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a pre-licensing for change of location. The facility services six ambulatory males from 12 years old to 17 years old and non-minor dependents. The facility sits on a 4-acre lot. The facility is a single-story home. The home has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, living room, lounge room, dining room, laundry room, and kitchen. Across from the walkway staff and clinical office, game and fitness room and bedroom with a bathroom. There is a water pump house in front of the main house. In the back of the house there are animal pens, a covered open barn and a house corral. On the side of the house there is a carport. The facility is set up a follows: Bedroom #1 is arranged for one client. Bedroom #2 is arranged for one client. Bedroom #3 is arranged for two clients. Bedroom #4 is across the walkway and is arranged for two clients. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed all the bedrooms to have adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. Bedroom #1 and #2 share a bathroom. Bedroom # 3 and # 4 has its own bathroom. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed all the bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured to be 111 degrees, which is in range (105 degrees and 120 degrees). The laundry room has a washer and dryer for clients' use. The facility's smoke detectors in the hallways and bedrooms were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector located in hallways were operable. There is a covered patio behind the house. See LIC809C page 2 for continuation The staff and clinical office is located across the walkway from the main house. The medication will be locked in cabinet in the locked staff office. All clients' files and staff files will be in locked file cabinets in the staff/clinical office. The office a kitchenette, three desks, three tables and three locked cabinets. Next to the office is the garage will be used as an indoor game and fitness room. The open barn behind the garage. The barn will be used sports court. Next to the barn are animals pens. The animals pens are not currently in use. Behind the barn is a horse corral that is not currently in use. Water Pump house is locked. Outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. No bodies of water were observed at this time. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by CEO Hickman and COO Dahlstedt. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. No bodies of water were observed at this time. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. narrative: On December 7, 2023 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility and met with David Salazar, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct an inspection. The facility services six ambulatory males from 12 years old to 17 years old and non-minor dependents. The facility sits on a 4-acre lot. The facility is a single-story home. The home has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, living room, lounge room, dining room, laundry room, and kitchen. Across from the walkway there is staff and clinical office, game and fitness room and bedroom with a bathroom. There is a water pump house in front of the main house. In the back of the house there are animal pens, a covered open barn and a house corral. On the side of the house there is a carport. The facility is set up as follows: Bedroom #1 is arranged for one client. Bedroom #2 is arranged for one client. Bedroom #3 is arranged for two clients. Bedroom #4 is across the walkway and is arranged for two clients. LPA Jauregui observed all the bedrooms to have adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. Bedroom #1 and #2 share a bathroom. Bedroom # 3 and # 4 has its own bathroom. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured to be 120 degrees, which is in range (105 degrees and 120 degrees). The laundry room has a washer and dryer for clients' use. Disinfectants, detergents and cleaning solutions are maintained in locked cabinets in the laundry room. The facility's smoke detectors in the hallways and bedrooms were checked and were operable. Continued.... The carbon monoxide detector located in hallways were operable. Fire extinguisher are properly charged and serviced. The last emergency disaster drill was held on November 14, 2023. The staff and clinical office is located across the walkway from the main house. The medication will be locked in a locked closet in the staff office. All clients' files are locked in a cabinet in the locked closet in the staff office. Sharps were observed locked in a cabinet in the locked closet in the staff office. The staff office is remained locked at all time. The office a kitchenette, two desks, one table, one couch and one locked cabinets. Next to the office is the garage used as an indoor game and fitness room. There is an open barn behind the garage. The barn is used as a basketball court. Next to the barn are animals pens. There are three goats, twelve chickens, and two pigs. Animals are therapeutic for clients. Outside grounds were also inspected and it were observed to be clean and well maintained. No bodies of water were observed at this time. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator. LPA Jauregui observed the following items posted and accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and activity schedule. LPA Jauregui reviewed five out five client files (see LIC 811 dated 12/7/2023), and conducted two staff interviews. LPA was unable to conduct client interviews at the facility due to clients being at school. This annual will be continued due to staff files located at the Corporate Office. Based on today's observations there are no deficiencies at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was discussed and left with David Salazar, Administrator.

narrative: Confidential interviews indicated C1 asked to get bread and was denied however C1 asked to have their medication and C1 was able to get inside the pantry for the bread. Confidential interviews indicated C1 went to the refrigerator to proceed making the sandwich and PA interfered by blocking refrigerator and shutting the refrigerator door. Confidential interviews indicated PA and C1 were yelling and screaming at each other during the incident. Confidential interviews indicated PA often speaks rudely to C1. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that PA speaks inappropriately to C1 in care and C1 in care is not provided adequate food service are SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence has been met. This posed an potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care, the facility will be cited for violating Interim Licensing Standards STRTP Article 06. Continuing Requirements Personal Rights (c)(15) and Personal Rights (c)(2). An exit interview was conducted and discussed. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Lance Hickman, CEO. Other interviews indicated that C1 is told to make their own appointments and find C1 has to find their own transportation. Confidential interviews indicated clients receive their allowance on Friday's. Confidential interviews did not provide consistent statements whether staff do not take C1 to their medical appointments and staff withhold money from C1 in care. Based on confidential interviews and documents reviewed, the allegation that staff has not taken C1 in care to their medical appointments and staff withholds money from C1 in care, may have occurred, however is not supported, or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report was provided to Lance Hickman, CEO.

narrative: Confidential interviews and a review of records revealed that on December 7, 2024, C1 absconded from the facility after an incident took place in which C1 was attempting to gain access into the staff office to retrieve a phone to contact an unknown individual. Confidential interviews and a review of records revealed C1 was on a restricted call log due to safety concerns and having inappropriate conversations with said individual. The review of records and confidential interviews reveal C1 was able to obtain a piece of wood by breaking facility furniture, which C1 used to make a hole through the wall of the office. Confidential interviews revealed S1 attempted to de-escalate the situation by talking to C1 and redirecting C1's attention. Confidential interviews reveal C1 was not receptive and became physically assaultive towards S1 by leaving marks and scratches on S1's arm. Confidential interviews revealed that after this situation, C1 became upset and went to their room and proceeded to abscond from the facility. Confidential interviews and a review of records did not corroborate the allegation that staff caused injuries to a minor while in care. Based on interviews and record review, the allegation staff caused injuries to a minor while in care is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Facility Administrator, Carmen Velarde. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Carmen Velarde, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.
