narrative: On July 8, 2025, at 12: PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Velasquez conducted an unannounced annual inspection of the facility. The outside perimeter was clean, and there were no hazards blocking the walkways or doors. Upon arrival, LPA was greeted by Christina Martinez, Direct Care Counselor. A review of two client files was conducted. All files had health passports, needs and services plans, current medical appointment contacts and case providers information. Due to staff files being housed at Human Resources Corporate Office, this annual inspection will be completed upon review of records. Upon entry into facility, the entry room had Bill of Rights Ombudsman Posters, Facility License, Grievance Forms, California Department of Social Services Let Us No poster, Smoking Cessation information, Imperial County Behavioral Health Service information, Commission On Accreditation of Rehabilitation (CARF) acknowledgement and information, and other upcoming events for the month. The Staff Office has 2 desks with storage area for client files, Refrigerated Medications, and Emergency Preparedness materials. California Labor Law information was posted as well as instructional materials for Behavioral Health Services, and emergency and crisis intervention contacts. The living room was clean and in an open space. There is a TV, 2 couches, and a desk/computer area for homework, and printing station. Posted here were additional posters of Children's Rights. There was a hallway leading towards the kitchen area that had the facility sketch, client handbook, and house rules posted. The kitchen was clean, and free of used dishware and pots. The counters contained fresh fruit options. There were 2 refrigerators with meats, fruits, and vegetables. A freezer was filled with frozen food options, breakfast items, and ice creams. There was more than 4-5 days of perishable items for clients. There were tightly covered waste baskets. The water in the kitchen area measured 110 degrees. There was plastic cutlery available for clients, as well as plates and bowls. All knives and sharp items are locked in a closet out of client reach. A walk-in pantry was viewed to have dry goods, cereals, and rice. The dining area had a table with 4 seatings for clients. A locked doorway inside the pantry is where medications not needing refrigeration are kept. There was a first-aid kid, medications log, and medications were housed in this area. The pantry remains locked by staff at all times. This facility has a carpeted stairway that leads to 2 bedrooms upstairs. Bedroom 1 has a queen bed with comforter, sheets, pillow shams, and mattress cover. The room has a keyboard area/hobby area with an adjoining full bath. There is a 3-drawer chest for clients use as well as a closet. Bedroom 2 was vacant, but there was a queen bed with storage space, a closet, 3-drawer chest, and comforter ensemble. Bedroom 3 had a queen bed, 3-drawer chest and a full closet. Bedding had comforter, pillow shams, sheets, and a mattress cover. There were 2 sinks, a full shower, and separated bath for this bedroom area. Bedroom 4 is also vacant, and has a queen bed with storage area. Bedroom 5 is vacant with 2 queen beds, a walk in closet, and a full bath, shower, and toilet. There were additional closets with paper products and supplies was inspected. There were plates, cups, and toiletries. A second closet housed games and crafting items. The outside of the facility had a staff bathroom and laundry area. The backyard has a cemented area for bbq, and sitting area. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was reviewed and given to Christina Martinez, Direct Care Counselor. Continuation of this annual inspection will be processed with a representative from their Corporate Office/Human Resources.

It was also reported that a staff crashed the company car while transporting clients. It was further reported that staff spoke about clients' personal information in the presence of other clients and staff would open the bedroom doors of clients while clients were changing. Confidential interviews revealed that staff are professional when speaking to minors; they may play around, but it is not inappropriate. Confidential interview stated that if clients use profanity they are redirected by staff, but staff do not engage with clients. Confidential interview stated that clients speak inappropriately to other clients, not the staff. Confidential interviews reported that there are no staff romantically involved with one another. Confidential interviews revealed that no staff within the home engage in touch or display affection towards another. Confidential interview revealed that staff do not allow clients to engage in inappropriate behavior with other clients. Confidential interviews revealed that staff transport minors safely. Confidential interview stated that there was a minor accident some time last year, and it was reported to licensing and there were no injuries. Confidential interview stated that they feel safe when driven by staff. Confidential interviews reported that clients are given privacy, and on occasion staff may need to enter their room, after knocking, if there is no response. According to confidential interview, this would be warranted if there was a safety concern, but at no time would staff enter a room without notifying the client. Confidential interview revealed that staff knock first prior to entering. Confidential interview revealed that minor's information is shared among staff to inform of any behaviors, appointments, or concerns. It was reported that the sharing of information is not to gossip or talk about clients, but more so for their safety and for incoming staff to be aware of. Confidential interview indicated that staff speak about clients' personal information in the office with the door closed. Confidential interviews indicated that the walls are thin, so conversations may be overheard, but staff try to keep their voices to a minimum. Based on confidential interviews the allegations that staff speaks to minors in an inappropriate manner, staff engage in inappropriate interactions in the presence of minors, staff did not transport minors in a safe manner, staff do not accord minor's privacy, and staff do not keep minor's information confidential may have occurred, or are valid, however there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the allegations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of LIC9099 and appeal rights were given to Christina Martinez, Direct Care Counselor.

On September 26, 2024, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging, facility staff engaged in sexual interactions with minor in care, facility staff provided drugs to minor in care, facility staff used drugs with minor in care, and facility staff inappropriately handled minor in care. It was reported that S1 had been having sexual contact with male minors in the home and S1 had also been using drugs with the minors. It was reported that a client witnessed S1 use drugs with a client and S1 had taken the client out on dates alone. Regarding the allegation that facility staff engaged in sexual interactions with minor in care, a confidential interview revealed that S1 and C2 were sexually involved. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 was known to have taken C2 on a one-on-one outing for pizza, which took longer than usual. A confidential interview revealed that S1 was given permission to transport C2 to purchase pizza in a neighboring town which was not within proximity to the facility, causing the outing to take longer than usual. A confidential interview corroborated the explanation of why the outing took longer and confirmed S1 received permission to do so. Confidential interviews revealed S1 previously transported other youth in the facility on one-on-one outings and confidential interviews did not reveal any unprofessional or inappropriate interactions between S1 and C2 or any other clients in care. Regarding the allegation that facility staff provided drugs to minor in care, a confidential interview revealed that S1 provided cocaine to C2 and other minors in care. Confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegation and denied S1 was ever seen or known to have provided clients in care with any kind of illicit substances. Confidential interviews revealed that staff conduct self-checks and pocket checks for contraband after clients return from outings. Confidential interviews revealed that staff have found marijuana contraband on clients but have not found any paraphernalia or evidence of cocaine. Regarding the allegation that facility staff used drugs with minor in care, a confidential interview revealed that S1 took drugs with clients in care. Other confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegation, and confidential interviews revealed that S1 was not seen under the influence. Confidential interviews denied S1 was ever seen or known to have provided clients in care with illicit substances and additionally, confidential interviews also revealed S1 was not seen with drugs or paraphernalia. Continued... It was reported that while C1 was confronting S1 about the allegations stated above, S1 was standing in a doorway and proceeded to shut the door on C1's face hitting C1 on the face with the door. Regarding the allegation that staff inappropriately handled minor in care, a confidential interview revealed that S1 shut the door on C1's face while standing in the door frame of the garage door after S1 allowed for C3 to enter. Confidential interviews revealed an incident that was reported to CCL on September 16, 2024, in which C1 became upset after being told to wait for a client to exit the garage before entering. A record review indicated that S1 was exiting the garage when S1 saw C1 and another client in care roughhousing. C1 and another client requested a drink from inside of the garage, and S1 allowed one client to go in at a time and requested C1 wait to enter until the other came out. According to the record review, C1 became upset and barred staff from closing the door, however, shortly after S1 was able to close the door completely. Confidential interviews did not reveal any witnesses to the reported incident, however, confidential interview confirmed that facility staff limit the number of clients in the garage due to the garage housing client information and serving as a staff office. The investigation did not provide information on how S1 was able to get the door to fully close. Based on interviews and review of records, the allegations that facility staff engaged in sexual interactions with minor in care, facility staff provided drugs to minor in care, facility staff used drugs with minor in care and, facility staff inappropriately handled minor in care are all unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Taylor Baez, Supervisor. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Taylor Baez, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

During the investigation, LPA Saeteurn interviewed clients (C1-C3), staff (S1-S4), one witness (W2), and reviewed facility pertinent records. Confidential interviews confirmed the verbal exchange that took place on September 23, 2024, in which C1 was attempting to enter the facility garage and S1 informed C1 they were not allowed in the garage. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 was standing in the doorway entrance to the garage, preventing C1 from entering, due to C2 receiving medications from S2 in the garage and C1 having a history of attempting to retrieve restricted items from the garage. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was challenging S1 to do something about C1 attempting to get into the garage when S1 proceeded to walk towards C1. A review of a Special Incident Report (SIR) submitted by the facility to CCL detailed that C1 tried to run through S1 to get into the garage where a client had just entered to take their medication in privacy. The SIR included that S1 blocked C1 at the doorway and, with arms extended, redirected C1 out of the doorway, and secured the garage behind them. A confidential interview indicated that S1 pushed C1, however other confidential interviews revealed that S1 did not throw or push C1, but rather S1 proceeded to walk towards C1 with their arms out. Confidential interviews revealed that during the process in which S1 walked towards C1, C1 jumped back and fell onto the floor. A confidential interview indicated that C1 exclaimed, "S1 put hands on me" and proceeded to get up to walk to their room. The investigation did not yield witnesses to corroborate that S1 mishandled C1 during the exchange. Based on interviews conducted and record review, the allegation that facility staff mishandled a minor while in care is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Joshua Harris, Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Joshua Harris, Administrator, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.
